content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νέα_1"> last-born (not “young,” for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τέκνα</foreign> includes the old men, v. 17), added for contrast with <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦ πάλαι</foreign>. Oedipus, —who believes himself a Corinthian (774), —marks his respect for the ancient glories of the Theban house to whose throne he has been called: see esp. 258 f. So the Thebans are <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">στρατὸς Καδμογενής</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 303">Aesch. Seven 303</bibl> </cit> , <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">Καδμογενὴς γέννα</quote> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 808">Eur. Phoen. 808</bibl> </cit>, or <foreign xml:lang="grc">Καδμεῖο</foreign>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τροφή_1"> = <foreign xml:lang="grc">θρέμματα</foreign> (abstract for concrete); <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Cycl. 189">Eur. Cycl. 189</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρνῶν τροφαί</quote> </cit> = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄρνες ἐκτεθραμμέναι</foreign>. Cadmus, as guardian genius of Thebes, is still <foreign xml:lang="grc">τροφεύς</foreign> of all who are reared in the <foreign xml:lang="grc">δῶμα Καδμεῖον</foreign> (v. 29). Campbell understands, “my last-born care derived from ancient Cadmus,” —as though the <foreign xml:lang="grc">τροφεύς</foreign> were Oedipus. But could <foreign xml:lang="grc">Κάδμου τροφή</foreign> mean “[;<emph>my</emph>]; nurslings [;<emph>derived from</emph>]; Cadmus”? It is by the word <foreign xml:lang="grc">τέκνα</foreign> that Oedipus expresses his own fatherly care. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἕδρας_2"> The word <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἕδρα</foreign>= “posture,” here, as usu., <emph>sitting:</emph> when <emph>kneeling</emph>is meant, some qualification is added, as <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 293">Eur. Phoen. 293</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γονυπετεῖς ἕδρας προσπίτνω σ’,</quote> </cit> “I supplicate thee on my knees.” The suppliants are sitting on the steps (<foreign xml:lang="grc">βάθρα</foreign>) of the altars, on which they have laid the <foreign xml:lang="grc">κλάδοι</foreign>: see 142: cp. 15 <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσήμεθα,</foreign> 20 <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">θακεῖ</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 40">: Aesch. Eum. 40</bibl> </cit> (Orestes a suppliant in the Delphian temple) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπ’ ὀμφαλῷ</foreign> (on the omphalos) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἕδραν ἔχοντα προστρόπαιον … ἐλαίας θ’ ὑψιγέννητον κλάδον</foreign>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θοάζετε_2"> prob. = <foreign xml:lang="grc">θάσσετε,</foreign> “sit,” <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἕδρας</foreign> being cognate acc. In Eur. <foreign xml:lang="grc">θοάζω</foreign>( <foreign xml:lang="grc">θοός</foreign>) always =“to hasten” (transitive or intrans.). But Empedocles and Aesch. clearly use <foreign xml:lang="grc">θοάζω</foreign> as =<foreign xml:lang="grc">θάσσω</foreign>, the sound and form perh. suggesting the epic <foreign xml:lang="grc">θαάσσω, θόωκος</foreign>. See Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱκτηρίοις_κλάδοισιν_3"> The suppliant carried a branch of olive or laurel (<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱκετηρία</foreign>), round which were twined festoons of wool(<foreign xml:lang="grc">στέφη, στέμματα,</foreign> —which words can stand for the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱκετηρία</foreign> itself, below 913, <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.14">Hom. Il. 1.14</ref>): <cit> <bibl n="Plut. Thes. 18">Plut. Thes. 18</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦν δὲ [ἡ ἱκετηρία] κλάδος ἀπὸ τῆς ἱερᾶς ἐλαίας, ἐρίῳ λευκῷ κατεστεμμένος.</quote> </cit> He laid his branch on the altar (<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 124">Eur. Her. 124</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βωμὸν καταστέψαντες</quote> </cit>), and left it there, if unsuccessful in his petition (<ref n="Eur. Supp. 259">Eur. Supp. 259</ref>); if successful, he took it away (<ref n="Eur. Supp. 359">Eur. Supp. 359</ref>, below 143). </gloss>

data.quote:
ἦν δὲ [ἡ ἱκετηρία] κλάδος ἀπὸ τῆς ἱερᾶς
							ἐλαίας,
									ἐρίῳ λευκῷ κατεστεμμένος.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱκτηρίοις_ἐξεστεμμένοι_3"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱκτηρίους κλάδους ἐξεστεμμένους ἔχοντες</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 4.3.28">Xen. Anab. 4.3.28</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">διηγκυλωμένους τοὺς ἀκοντιστὰς καὶ ἐπιβεβλημένους τοὺς τοξότας,</quote> </cit> “the javelin-throwers <emph>with</emph> javelins <emph>grasped</emph> by the thong(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγκύλη</foreign>), and the archers <emph> with</emph> arrows <emph>fitted</emph> to the string.” So 18 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξεστεμμένον</foreign> absol., = provided with <foreign xml:lang="grc">στέφη</foreign> (i.e. with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱκετηρίαι</foreign>: see last note). Triclinius supposes that the suppliants, besides carrying boughs, wore garlands(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐστεφανωμένοἰ,</foreign> and the <emph>priests</emph> may have done so: but <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξεστεμμ</foreign>. does not refer to this. </gloss>

data.quote:
διηγκυλωμένους τοὺς ἀκοντιστὰς καὶ
							ἐπιβεβλημένους
									τοὺς τοξότας,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμοῦ_δὲ_4"> The verbal contrast is merely between the <emph>fumes</emph> of incense burnt on the altars as a propitiatory offering (<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 8.48">Hom. Il. 8.48</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τέμενος βωμός τε θυήεις),</quote> </cit> and the <emph>sounds</emph> — whether of invocations to the Healer, or of despair. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλων_7"> Redundant, but serving to contrast <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγγέλων</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτός,</foreign> as if one said, “from messengers,—at second hand.” Blaydes cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.2">Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.2</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως μὴ δῑ ἄλλων ἑρμηνέων τὰς τῶν θεῶν συμβουλίας συνείης, ἀλλ’ αὐτὸς … γιγνώσκοις.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὅπως μὴ δῑ ἄλλων ἑρμηνέων τὰς τῶν θεῶν
							συμβουλίας
									συνείης, ἀλλ’ αὐτὸς … γιγνώσκοις.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧδ_7"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">δεῦρο,</foreign> as in vv. 144, 298, and often in Soph.: even with <foreign xml:lang="grc">βλέπειν, ὁρᾶν,</foreign> as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 402">Soph. Trach. 402</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βλέφ’ ὧδε</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">βλέπε δεῦρο</foreign>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_καλούμενος_8"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">πᾶσι</foreign> with <foreign xml:lang="grc">κλεινός</foreign> (cp. 40 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πᾶσι κράτιστον</foreign>), not with <foreign xml:lang="grc">καλούμενος</foreign>: “called Oedipus famous in the sight of all,” not “called famous Oed. by all.” Cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">πασίγνωστος, πασίδηλος, πασιμέλουσα, πασίφιλος</foreign>. The tone is Homeric (<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 9.19">Hom. Od. 9.19</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴμ’ Ὀδυσεύς … καί μευ κλέος οὐρανὸν ἵκει,</quote> </cit> imitated by <cit> <bibl n="Verg. A. 1.378">Verg. Aen. 1.378</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">sum pius Aeneas … fama super aethera notus</quote> </cit>): Oedipus is a type, for the frank heroic age, of Arist.'s <foreign xml:lang="grc">μεγαλόψυχος—ὁ μεγάλων αὑτὸν ἀξιῶν, ἄξιος ὤν</foreign> (<ref n="Aristot. Nic. Eth. 1123a">Aristot. Nic. Eth. 4.3</ref>). </gloss>

data.quote:
εἴμ’ Ὀδυσεύς … καί μευ κλέος οὐρανὸν
									ἵκει,

sum
							pius Aeneas … fama super aethera
								notus

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔφυς_9"> which is more than <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἶ,</foreign> refers, not to appearance(<foreign xml:lang="grc">φυή</foreign>), but to the natural claim (<foreign xml:lang="grc">φύσις</foreign>) of age and office combined. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸ_τῶνδε_10"> “in front of,” and so “on behalf of,” “<emph>for</emph>” these. Ellendt: “<foreign xml:lang="lat">Non est <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀντὶ τῶνδε,</foreign> nec <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπὲρ τῶνδε,</foreign> sed <foreign xml:lang="grc">μᾶλλον</foreign> s. <foreign xml:lang="grc">μάλιστα τῶνδε,</foreign> <emph>prae ceteris dignus</emph> propter auctoritatem et aetatem</foreign>.” Rather <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀντὶ τῶνδε</foreign> = “as their deputy”: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπὲρ τῶνδε</foreign> = “as their champion”: <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸ τῶνδε</foreign> = “as their spokesman.” So <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 811">Soph. OC 811</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρῶ γὰρ καὶ πρὸ τῶνδε.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίνι_τρόπῳ_10"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καθέστατε_10"> only: <foreign xml:lang="grc">δείσαντες ἢ στέρξαντες</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴτε ἐδείσατέ τι, εἴτε ἐστέρξατε</foreign> (not <foreign xml:lang="grc">πότερον δείσαντες; ἢ στέρξαντες;</foreign>), “in what mood are ye set here, whether it be one of fear or of desire?” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στέρξαντες_11"> “having formed a desire”: the aor. part., as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 212">Soph. Aj. 212</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεί σε … | στέρξας ἀνέχει</quote> </cit> “is constant to the love which he hath formed for thee.” <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1100">Soph. El. 1100</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τί βουληθεὶς πάρει</quote> </cit> ;<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1052">Soph. Aj. 1052</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αυτὸν ἐλπίσαντες … ἄγειν.</quote> </cit> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1093">Soph. OC 1093</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τὸν ἀγρευτὰν Ἀπόλλω | καὶ κασιγνήταν … | στέργω διπλᾶς ἀρωγὰς | μολεῖν,</quote> </cit> “I <emph>desire</emph>”: where, in such an invocation(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰὼ … Ζεῦ, … πόροις, κ.τ.λ.), στέργω</foreign> surely cannot mean, “I <emph>am content</emph>.” Oed. asks: “Does this supplication mean that <emph>some new dread has seized you</emph> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">δείσαντες</foreign>)? Or that <emph>ye have set your hearts</emph> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">στέρξαντες</foreign>)<emph>on some particular boon</emph> which I can grant?”—Others render <foreign xml:lang="grc">στέρξαντες</foreign> “<emph>having acquiesced</emph>.” This admits of two views. (i) “Are ye <emph>afraid</emph> of suffering? Or have ye already <emph>learned to bear</emph> suffering?” To this point the glosses <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπομείναντες, παθόντες</foreign>. But this seems unmeaning. He <emph>knows</emph> that the suffering has come, and he does not suppose that they are <emph>resigned</emph> to it (cp. v. 58). (ii) Prof. Kennedy connects <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἢ στέρξαντες ὡς θέλοντος ἂν | ἐμοῦ προσαρκεῖν πᾶν;</foreign> i.e. are ye come in vague terror, or <emph>in contentment, as believing</emph> that I would be willing to help you? This is ingenious and attractive. But (a) it appears hardly consonant with the kingly courtesy of this opening speech for Oedipus to assume that their belief in his good-will would reconcile them to their present miseries. (b) We seem to require some direct and express intimation of the king's willingness to help, such as the words <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς θέλοντος … πᾶν</foreign> give only when referred to <foreign xml:lang="grc">φράζε</foreign>. (c) The rhythm seems to favour the question at <foreign xml:lang="grc">στέρξαντες. —στέξαντες,</foreign> explained as “<emph>having endured</emph>,” may be rejected, because (1) the sense is against it—see on (i) above: (2) <foreign xml:lang="grc"> στέγειν</foreign> in classical Greek = “to be proof against,” not “to suffer”: (3) <foreign xml:lang="grc">στέξω, ἔστεξα</foreign> are unknown to Attic, which has only the pres. and the imperf. </gloss>

data.quote:
καὶ τὸν ἀγρευτὰν Ἀπόλλω | καὶ κασιγνήταν … |
							στέργω διπλᾶς ἀρωγὰς | μολεῖν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἂν_11"> (to be connected with <foreign xml:lang="grc">φράζε</foreign>) implies the apodosis of a conditional sentence. Grammatically, this might be either (a) <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ δυναίμην, θέλοιμι ἄν,</foreign> or (b) <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ ἠδυνάμην, ἤθελον ἄν</foreign>: here, the sense fixes it to (a). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_11">, thus added to the gen. absol., expresses the <emph>supposition</emph> on which the agent acts. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 2.6.32">Xen. Mem. 2.6.32</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς οὐ προσοίσοντος (ἐμοὖ τὰς χεῖρας, … δίδασκε·</quote> </cit> “as (you may be sure) I will not lay hands on you, teach me.” </gloss>

data.quote:
ὡς οὐ προσοίσοντος (ἐμοὖ τὰς χεῖρας, …
									δίδασκε·

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατοικτίρων_13"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἰκτίρω,</foreign> not <foreign xml:lang="grc"> οἰκτείρω,</foreign> is the spelling attested by Attic inscriptions of circ. 550-350 B.C.: see Meisterhans, <title>Grammatik der Attischen Inschriften</title>, p. 89. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_κατοικτίρων_13">. An infinitive or participle, which for any reason would regularly take <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή,</foreign> usually takes <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ οὐ</foreign> if the principal verb of the sentence is negative. Here, <foreign xml:lang="grc">δυσάλγητος</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ εὐάλγητος</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Dem. 19.123">Dem. 19.123</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(πόλεις) χαλεπαὶ λαβεῖν … μὴ οὐ χρόνῳ καὶ πολιορκίᾳ</quote> </cit>(sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">λαμβάνοντι,</foreign>) where <foreign xml:lang="grc">χαλεπαί</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ ῥᾴδιαι·</foreign> “cities <emph>not easy</emph> to take, <emph> unless</emph> by a protracted siege.” The participial clause, <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ οὐ κατοικτίρων,</foreign> is equivalent to a protasis, <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ κατοικτίροιμι</foreign>. Prof. Kennedy holds that the protasis is <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ θέλοιμι</foreign> understood, and that <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ οὐ κατοικτίρων</foreign> is epexegetic of it: —“Yes(<foreign xml:lang="grc"> γάρ</foreign>) I should be unfeeling, <emph>if I did not wish</emph> (to help you): that is, if I refused to pity such a supplication as this.” But the double negative <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ οὐ</foreign> could not be explained by a negative in the protasis <foreign xml:lang="grc">(εἰ μὴ θέλοιμἰ·</foreign> it implies a negative in the apodosis <foreign xml:lang="grc">(δυσάλγητος ἂν εἴην)</foreign>. Since, then, the resolution into <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ εὐάλγητος ἂν εἴην</foreign> is necessary, nothing seems to be gained by supposing a suppressed protasis, <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ θέλοιμι</foreign>. </gloss>

data.quote:
(πόλεις) χαλεπαὶ λαβεῖν … μὴ οὐ χρόνῳ καὶ
							πολιορκίᾳ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βωμοῖσι_σοῖς_16"> The altars of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">προστατήριοι θεοί</foreign> in front of the palace, including that of Apollo <foreign xml:lang="grc"> Λύκειος</foreign> (919). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μακρὰν_πτέσθαι_16">. So Andromache to her child —<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">νεοσσὸς ὡσεὶ πτέρυγας ἐσπίτνων ἐμάς</quote> <bibl n="Eur. Tro. 746">Eur. Tro. 746</bibl> </cit>. The proper Attic form for the aor. of <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέτομαι</foreign> was <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπτόμην,</foreign> which alone was used in prose and Comedy. Though forms from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπτάμην</foreign> sometimes occur in Tragedy, as in the Homeric poems, Elms. had no cause to wish for <foreign xml:lang="grc">πτάσθαι</foreign> here. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὺν_βαρεῖς_17"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">βαρεῖς ὡς γήρᾳ συνόντες.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1663">Soph. OC 1663</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν νόσοις | ἀλγεινός</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1017">Soph. Aj. 1017</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν γήρᾳ βαρύς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγὼ_μὲν_18"> The answering clause, <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἱ δὲ ἄλλων θεῶν,</foreign> must be supplied mentally: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 5.893">Hom. Il. 5.893</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν μὲν ἐγὼ σπουδῇ δάμνησ’ ἐπέεσσι</quote> </cit> (sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰς δὲ ἄλλας ῥᾳδίως</foreign>). It is slightly different when <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέν,</foreign> used alone, emphasizes the personal pronoun, as in <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ μὲν οὐκ οἶδα</quote> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 1.4.12">Xen. Cyrop. 1.4.12</bibl> </cit> .</gloss>

data.quote: τὴν μὲν ἐγὼ σπουδῇ δάμνησ’ ἐπέεσσι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἵδε_τ_18">. The conjecture <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἱ δ’ ἐπ’</foreign>(“chosen to represent the youth”) involves a questionable use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπί·</foreign> cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 787">Soph. Ant. 787</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾐθέων_18">, unmarried youths: <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 18.593">Hom. Il. 18.593</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠΐθεοι καὶ παρθένοι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 944">Eur. Phoen. 944</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Αἵμονος … γάμοι | σφαγὰς ἀπείργουσ’· οὐ γάρ ἐστιν ᾔθεος</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Plut. Thes. 15">Plut. Thes. 15</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾐθέους ἑπτὰ καὶ παρθένους.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
Αἵμονος … γάμοι | σφαγὰς ἀπείργουσ’· οὐ γάρ
							ἐστιν ᾔθεος

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξεστεμμένον_19"> see on 3. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγοραῖσι_20"> local dative, like <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰκεῖν οὐρανῷ</quote> <bibl n="Pind. N. 10">Pind. N. 10.58</bibl> </cit>. Thebes was divided from N. to S. into two parts by the torrent called Strophia. The W. part, between the Strophia and the Dirce, was the upper town or Cadmeia: the E. part, between the Strophia and the Ismenus, was <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ κάτω πόλις.</foreign> The name <foreign xml:lang="grc">Καδμεία</foreign> was given especially to the S. eminence of the upper town, the acropolis. (1) One of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγοραί</foreign> meant here was on a hill to the north of the acropolis, and was the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγορὰ Καδμείας.</foreign> See <ref n="Paus. 9.12.3">Paus. 9.12.3</ref>. (2) The other was in the lower town. <ref n="Xen. Hell. 5.2.29">Xen. Hell. 5.2.29</ref> refers to this <foreign xml:lang="grc">—ἡ βουλὴ ἐκάθητο ἐν τῇ ἐν ἀγορᾷ στοᾷ, διὰ τὸ τὰς γυναῖκας ἐν τῇ Καδμείᾳ θεσμοφοριάζειν</foreign>: unless <foreign xml:lang="grc">Καδμεία</foreign> has the narrower sense of “acropolis.” Cp. <ref n="Aristot. Pol. 7.1331a">Aristot. Pol. 4.12.2</ref> on the Thessalian custom of having two <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγοραί</foreign>— one, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐλευθέρα,</foreign> from which everything <foreign xml:lang="grc">βάναυσον</foreign> was excluded. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρός_ναοῖς_20">. Not “<emph>both</emph> at the two temples,” etc. as if this explained <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγοραῖσι,</foreign> but “<emph>and</emph>,” etc.: for the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγοραί</foreign> would have their own altars of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγοραῖοι θεοί,</foreign> as of Artemis (161). One of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">διπλοῖ ναοί</foreign> may be that of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Παλλὰς Ὄγκα,</foreign> near the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ὀγκαία πύλη</foreign> on the W. side of Thebes(<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">πύλας | Ὄγκας Ἀθάνας</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 487">Aesch. Seven 487</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ὄγκα Παλλάς</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 501">Aesch. Seven 501</bibl> </cit>), whose statue and altar <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν ὑπαίθρῳ</foreign> Paus. mentions (9. 12. 2). The other temple may be that of Athene <foreign xml:lang="grc">Καδμεία</foreign> or of Athena <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἰσμηνία</foreign>— both mentioned by the schol., but not by Paus. Athena <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ζωστηρία,</foreign> too, had <emph> statues</emph> at Thebes (<ref n="Paus. 9.17.3">Paus. 9.17.3</ref>). The schol. mentions also <foreign xml:lang="grc"> Ἀλαλκομενία,</foreign> but her shrine was at the village of Alalcomenae near Haliartus (<ref n="Paus. 9.23.5">Paus. 9.23.5</ref>). It was enough for Soph. that his Athenian hearers would think of the Erechtheum and the Parthenon—the shrines of the Polias and the Parthenos—above them on the acropolis. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπ_σποδῷ_21"> “The oracular ashes of Ismenus” = the altar in the temple of Apollo <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἰσμήνιος,</foreign> where divination by burnt offerings(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ δῑ ἐμπύρων μαντεία</foreign>) was practised. So the schol., quoting Philochorus (in his <foreign xml:lang="grc">περὶ μαντικῆς,</foreign> circ. 290 B.C.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σποδῷ_21">: the embers dying down when the <foreign xml:lang="grc">μαντεῖον</foreign> has now been taken from the burnt offering: cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1007">Soph. Ant. 1007</ref>. Soph. may have thought of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἀπόλλων Σπόδιος,</foreign> whose altar(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκ τέφρας τῶν ἱερείων</foreign>) Paus. saw to the left of the Electrae gates at Thebes: 9. 11. 7. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἰσμηνοῦ_21">, because the temple was by the river Ismenus: <cit> <ref n="Paus. 9.10.2">Paus. 9.10.2</ref> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔστι δὲ λόφος ἐν δεξιᾷ τῶν πυλῶν</quote> </cit> (on the right of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἠλέκτραι πύλαι</foreign> on the S. of Thebes, within the walls) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱερὸς Ἀπόλλωνος· καλεῖται δὲ ὅ τε λόφος καὶ ὁ θεὸς Ἰσμήνιος, παραρρέοντος τοῦ ποταμοῦ ταύτῃ τοῦ Ἰσμηνοῦ.</foreign> Ismenus (which name <ref>Curt. Etym. 617</ref>, connects with rt <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰς,</foreign> to wish, as = “desired”) was described in the Theban myths as the son of Asopus and Metope, or of Amphion and Niobe. The son of Apollo by Melia (the fountain of the Ismenus) was called Ismenius. Cp. <ref n="Hdt. 8.134">Hdt. 8.134</ref> (the envoy of Mardonius in the winter of 480-79) <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷ Ἰσμηνίῳ Ἀπόλλωνι ἐχρήσατο· ἔστι δὲ κατάπερ ἐν Ὀλυμπίῃ ἱροῖσι χρηστηριάζεσθαι·</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Pind. O. 8">Pind. O. 8.1 ff.</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Οὐλυμπία | … ἵνα μάντιες ἄνδρες | ἐμπύροις τεκμαιρόμενοι παραπειρῶνται Διός.</quote> </cit> In <ref n="Pind. P. 11">Pind. P. 11.4</ref> the Theban heroines are asked to come <foreign xml:lang="grc">πὰρ Μελίαν</foreign> (because she shared Apollo's temple) “to the holy treasure-house of golden tripods, which Loxias hath honoured exceedingly, and hath named it <emph> Ismenian,</emph> a truthful seat of oracles” (MSS. <foreign xml:lang="grc">μαντείων,</foreign> not <foreign xml:lang="grc"> μαντίων,</foreign> Fennell): for the tripod dedicated by the <foreign xml:lang="grc">δαφναφόρος,</foreign> or priest of Ismenian Apollo, see <ref n="Paus. 9.10.4">Paus. 9.10.4</ref>. Her. saw offerings dedicated by Croesus to Amphiaraus <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν τῷ νηῷ τοῦ Ἰσμηνίου Ἀπόλλωνος</foreign> (1. 52), and notices inscriptions there (5. 59). The <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἰσμήνιον,</foreign> the temple at Abae in Phocis, and that on the hill <foreign xml:lang="grc">Πτῶον</foreign> to the E. of Lake Copais, were, after Delphi, the chief shrines of Apollo in N. Greece. </gloss>

data.quote: ἔστι δὲ λόφος ἐν δεξιᾷ τῶν πυλῶν

Οὐλυμπία | … ἵνα μάντιες ἄνδρες | ἐμπύροις
							τεκμαιρόμενοι παραπειρῶνται Διός.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βυθῶν_24"> “from the depths,” i.e. out of the trough of the waves which rise around. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 337">Soph. Ant. 337</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">περιβρυχίοισιν | περῶν ὑπ’ οἴδμασιν,</quote> </cit> <emph> under</emph> swelling waves which threaten to engulf him. Arat. 426 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπόβρυχα ναυτίλλονται.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φοινίου_24"> here merely poet. for <foreign xml:lang="grc">θανασίμου,</foreign> as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 770">Soph. Trach. 770</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φοινίας | ἐχθρᾶς ἐχίδνης ἰός</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1689">Soph. OC 1689</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φόνιος Ἀΐδας.</quote> </cit> But in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 351">Soph. Aj. 351</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φοινία ζάλη</quote> </cit>= the madness which drove Ajax to <emph>bloodshed.</emph> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔτ_τε_24">: for position of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔτ_24">, cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 161">Soph. Trach. 161</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἔτ’ οὐκ ὤν</quote> </cit> ,<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1217">Soph. Phil. 1217</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔτ’ οὐδέν εἰμι.</quote> </cit> With <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἷός τε</foreign> the verb is often omitted, as 1415, <ref n="Soph. OC 1136">Soph. OC 1136</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Trach. 742">Soph. Trach. 742</ref>,<ref n="Aristoph. Kn. 343">Aristoph. Kn. 343</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φθίνουσα_δέ_25"> rhetorical iteration(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπαναφορά</foreign>); cp. 259, 370, <ref n="Soph. OC 5, 610">Soph. OC 5, 610</ref>, etc. The anger of heaven is shown (1) by a <emph>blight</emph> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(φθίνουσἀ</foreign> on the fruits of the ground, on flocks and on child-birth: (2) by a <emph>pestilence</emph> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(λοιμός)</foreign> which ravages the town. Cp. 171 ff. For the threefold blight, <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 6.139">Hdt. 6.139</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποκτείνασι δὲ τοῖσι Πελασγοῖσι τοὺς σφετέρους παῖδάς τε καὶ γυναῖκας οὔτε γῆ καρπὸν ἔφερε οὔτε γυναῖκές τε καὶ ποῖμναι ὁμοίως ἔτικτον καὶ πρὸ τοῦ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aeschin. 3.111">Aeschin. 3.111</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μήτε γῆν καρποὺς φέρειν μήτε γυναῖκας τέκνα τίκτειν γονεῦσιν ἐοικότα, ἀλλὰ τέρατα, μήτε βοσκήματα κατὰ φύσιν γονὰς ποιεῖσθαι.</quote> </cit> Schneid. and Blaydes cp. <ref>Philostr. Apoll. 3.20</ref>, p. 51. 21 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ γῆ οὐ ξυνεχώρει αὐτοῖς ἵστασθαι· τήν τε γὰρ σπορὰν ἣν ἐς αὐτὴν ἐποιοῦντο, πρὶν ἐς κάλυκα ἥκειν, ἔφθειρε, τούς τε τῶν γυναικῶν τόκους ἀτελεῖς ἐποίει, καὶ τὰς ἀγέλας πονηρῶς ἔβοσκεν.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀποκτείνασι δὲ τοῖσι Πελασγοῖσι τοὺς σφετέρους
							παῖδάς τε καὶ γυναῖκας οὔτε γῆ καρπὸν ἔφερε οὔτε γυναῖκές τε καὶ
									ποῖμναι ὁμοίως ἔτικτον καὶ πρὸ τοῦ

μήτε γῆν καρποὺς φέρειν μήτε γυναῖκας τέκνα
							τίκτειν γονεῦσιν ἐοικότα, ἀλλὰ τέρατα, μήτε βοσκήματα κατὰ φύσιν
									γονὰς ποιεῖσθαι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κάλυξιν_ἐγκάρποις_25"> The datives mark the points or parts in which the land <foreign xml:lang="grc">φθίνει.</foreign> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κάλυξιν ἔγκαρπος</foreign> is the shell or case which encloses immature fruit, —whether the blossom of fruit-trees, or the era of wheat or barley: <ref>Theophr. Hist. Plant. 8.2.4</ref> (of <foreign xml:lang="grc">κριθή</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">πυρός) πρὶν ἂν προαύξηθεὶς (ὁ στάχυς) ἐν τῇ κάλυκι γένηται.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγέλαις_βουνόμοις_26"> (paroxyt.) =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγέλαι βοῶν νεμομένων</foreign>: but <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀκτὴ βούνομος,</foreign> proparoxyt., a shore on which oxen are pastured, <ref n="Soph. El. 181">Soph. El. 181</ref>. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 861">Soph. El. 861</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χαλαργοῖς ἐν ἁμίλλαις</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἁμίλλαις ἀργῶν χηλῶν</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 5">Pind. P. 5.28</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρισθάρματον … γέρας</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">γέρας ἀρίστου ἅρματος.</foreign> The epithet marks that the blight on the flocks is closely connected with that on the pastures: cp. Dionys. Hal. 1. 23 (describing a similar blight) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔτε πόα κτήνεσιν ἐφύετο διαρκής.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόκοισι_26">, the labours of child-bed: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 1031">Eur. Med. 1031</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">στερρὰς ἐνεγκοῦσ’ ἐν τόκοις ἀλγηδόνας</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. IT 1466">Eur. IT 1466</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γυναῖκες ἐν τόκοις ψυχορραγεῖς.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl>Dion. Hal. 1.23</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀδελφὰ δὲ τούτοις</quote> </cit>(i.e. to the blight on fruits and crops) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγίνετο περί τε προβάτων καὶ γυναικῶν γονάς· ἢ γὰρ ἐξημβλοῦτο τὰ ἔμβρυα, ἢ κατὰ τοὺς τόκους διεφθείρετο ἔστιν ἂ καὶ τὰς φερούσας συνδιαλυμηνάμενα.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγόνοις_27"> abortive, or resulting in a still birth. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_δ_27">, adv., “and among our other woes,” “and withal”: so 183, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 206">Soph. Trach. 206</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Aj. 675">Soph. Aj. 675</ref>. Not in “tmesis” with <foreign xml:lang="grc">σκήψας,</foreign> though Soph. has such tmesis elsewhere, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 420">Soph. Ant. 420</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν δ’ ἐμεστώθη,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1274">Soph. Ant. 1274</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν δ’ ἔσεισεν.</quote> </cit> For the simple <foreign xml:lang="grc">σκήψας</foreign>, cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 308">Aesch. Ag. 308</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἶτ’ ἔσκηψεν,</quote> </cit> “then it swooped.” So <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Pers. 715">Aesch. Pers. 715</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λοιμοῦ τις ἦλθε σκηπτός.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_θεὸς_27">, the bringer of the plague which spreads and rages <emph>like</emph> fire (176 <foreign xml:lang="grc">κρεῖσσον ἀμαιμακέτου πυρός,</foreign> 191 <foreign xml:lang="grc">φλέγει μἐ·</foreign> but also with reference to <emph> fever,</emph> <foreign xml:lang="grc">πυρετός.</foreign> <cit> <bibl>Hippoc. 4.140</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁκόσοισι δὲ τῶν ἀνθρώπων πῦρ (</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc"> πυρετὸς) ἐμπίπτῃ</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 22.31">Hom. Il. 22.31</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καί τε φέρει</quote> </cit> (Seirius) <foreign xml:lang="grc">πολλὸν πυρετὸν δειλοῖσι βροτοῖσι</foreign> (the only place where <foreign xml:lang="grc"> πυρετός</foreign> occurs in <title>Il.</title> or <title>Od.</title>). In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 55">Soph. OC 55</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν δ’ ὁ πυρφόρος θεὸς | Τιτὰν Προμηθεύς</quote> </cit> refers to the representation of Prometheus with the narthex, or a torch, in his right hand (<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 1121">Eur. Phoen. 1121</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεξιᾷ δὲ λαμπάδα | Τιτὰν Προμηθεὺς ἔφερεν ὥς</quote> </cit>). Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 432">Aesch. Seven 432</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρα πυρφόρον, | φλέγει δὲ λαμπάς, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> Here also the Destroyer is imagined as <emph>armed with a deadly brand</emph>, —against which the Chorus presently invoke the holy fires of Artemis (206) and the “blithe torch” of Dionysus (214). For </gloss>

data.quote: ἐν δ’ ὁ πυρφόρος θεὸς | Τιτὰν Προμηθεύς

δεξιᾷ δὲ λαμπάδα | Τιτὰν Προμηθεὺς ἔφερεν
									ὥς
ἄνδρα πυρφόρον, | φλέγει δὲ λαμπάς, κ.τ.λ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεὸς_27"> said of <foreign xml:lang="grc">λοιμός,</foreign> cp. Simonid. Amorg. fr. 7. 101 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ αἶψα λιμὸν οἰκίης ἀπώσεται, | ἐχθρὸν συνοικητῆρα, δυσμενέα θεόν.</foreign> Soph. fr. 837 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἡ φρόνησις ἁγαθὴ θεὸς μέγας.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέλας_δ_29"> elision at end of v. is peculiar in Trag. to Soph., who is said to have adopted it from a poet Callias (Athen. 10 p. 453 E): hence it was called <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἶδος Σοφόκλειον.</foreign> Examples: <foreign xml:lang="grc">δ’</foreign> 785, 791, 1224; <ref n="Soph. OC 17">Soph. OC 17</ref>;<ref n="Soph. Ant. 1031">Soph. Ant. 1031</ref>;<ref n="Soph. El. 1017">Soph. El. 1017</ref>:<foreign xml:lang="grc">τ’</foreign> below, 1184: <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ταῦτ’</foreign> 332. [;In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1164">Soph. OC 1164</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μολόντ’</quote> </cit> should prob. be <foreign xml:lang="grc">μόνον.</foreign>]; In Comedy: <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">δ’</quote> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 1716">Eur. Hipp. 1716</bibl> </cit> ,<ref n="Aristoph. Eccl. 351">Aristoph. Eccl. 351</ref>:<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">μ’</quote> <bibl n="Aristoph. Frogs 298">Aristoph. Frogs 298</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλουτίζεται_30"> with allusion to <foreign xml:lang="grc">Πλόύτων,</foreign> as Hades was called by an euphemism(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑποκοριστικῶς,</foreign> schol. <ref n="Aristoph. Pl. 727">Aristoph. Pl. 727</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅτι ἐκ τῆς κάτωθεν ἀνίεται ὁ πλοῦτος</foreign> (crops and metals), as Plato says, <ref n="Plat. Crat. 403a">Plat. Crat. 403a</ref>. Cp. Soph. fr. 251 (Nauck(2)) (from the satyric drama <title>Inachus</title> )<foreign xml:lang="grc">Πλούτωνος (</foreign>=<foreign xml:lang="grc"> Ἅιδοὐ ἥδ’ ἐπείσοδος</foreign>: Lucian <title>Timon</title> 21(<foreign xml:lang="grc">Πλοῦτος</foreign> speaks), <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ Πλούτων</foreign> (Hades) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀποστέλλει με παρ’ αὐτοὺς ἅτε πλουτοδότης καὶ μεγαλόδωρος καὶ αὐτὸς ὤν· δηλοῖ γοῦν καὶ τῷ ὀνόματι.</foreign> Schneid. cp. <ref>Statius Theb. 2.48</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">pallentes devius umbras Trames agit nigrique Iovis vacua atria ditat Mortibus</foreign>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέν_νυν_31"> as in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 441">Soph. Trach. 441</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_σ_31">, governed by <foreign xml:lang="grc">κρίνοντες</foreign> in 34. But he begins as if instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἑζόμεσθ’ ἐφέστιοι, ἱκετεύομεν</foreign> were to follow: hence <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἰσούμενον</foreign> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἴσον.</foreign> It is needless to take <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰσούμενον</foreign> (1) as accus. absol., or (2) as governed by <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἑζόμεσθ’ ἐφέστιοι</foreign> in the sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱκετεύομεν,</foreign> —like <foreign xml:lang="grc">φθορὰς … ψήφους ἔθεντο</foreign> <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 814">Aesch. Ag. 814</ref>, or <foreign xml:lang="grc">γένος … νέωσον αἶνον</foreign> <ref n="Aesch. Supp. 533">Aesch. Supp. 533</ref>. Musgrave conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰσούμενοι</foreign> as = “deeming equal,” but the midd. would mean “making <emph>ourselves</emph> equal,” like <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντισουμένου</quote> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.11">Thuc. 3.11</bibl> </cit>. Plato has <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰσούμενον</foreign> as passive in <ref n="Plat. Phaedrus 238e">Plat. Phaedrus 238e</ref>, and <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰσοῦσθαι</foreign> as passive in <ref n="Plat. Parm. 156b">Plat. Parm. 156b</ref>: cp. 581 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰσοῦμαι.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δαιμόνων_συναλλαγαῖς_34"> = “conjunctures” caused by gods (subjective gen.), special visitations, as opposed to the <emph>ordinary</emph> chances of life(<foreign xml:lang="grc">συμφοραῖς βίου</foreign>). Such <foreign xml:lang="grc">συναλλαγαί</foreign> were the visit of the Sphinx (130) and of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">πυρφόρος θεός</foreign> (27). Cp. 960 <foreign xml:lang="grc">νόσου συναλλαγῇ,</foreign> a visitation in the form of disease (defining gen.). Here, the sense might indeed be, “dealings (of men) with gods,” = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅταν ἄνθρωποι συναλλάσσωνται δαίμοσιν</foreign>: but the absolute use of <foreign xml:lang="grc"> συναλλαγή</foreign> for “a conjuncture of events” in <ref n="Soph. OC 410">Soph. OC 410</ref> (n.) favours the other view. In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 845">Soph. Trach. 845</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀλεθρἱαισι συναλλαγαῖς</quote> </cit>= “at the fatal meeting” of Deianeira with Nessus. But in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 157">Soph. Ant. 157</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεῶν συντυχίαι</quote> </cit> = fortunes sent <emph>by</emph> gods. The common prose sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">συναλλαγή</foreign> is “reconciliation,” which Soph. has in <ref n="Soph. Aj. 732">Soph. Aj. 732</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅς_γ_35"> The </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γ_35"> of the MSS. suits the immediately preceding verses better than the conjectural <foreign xml:lang="grc">τε</foreign>, since the judgment(<foreign xml:lang="grc">κρίνοντες)</foreign> rests solely on what Oed. has done, not partly on what he is expected to do. Owing to the length of the first clause (35-39) <foreign xml:lang="grc">τ’</foreign> could easily be added to <foreign xml:lang="grc">νῦν</foreign> in 40 as if another <foreign xml:lang="grc">τε</foreign> had preceded. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξέλυσας_δασμὸν_35">. The notion is not, “paid it in full,” but “loosed it,” —the thought of the tribute suggesting that of the riddle which Oed. solved. Till he came, the <foreign xml:lang="grc">δασμός</foreign> was as a knotted cord in which Thebes was bound. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 653">Soph. Trach. 653</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἄρης … ἐξέλυσ’ | ἐπίπονον ἁμέραν,</quote> </cit> “has burst the bondage of the troublous day.” <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 695">Eur. Phoen. 695</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποδῶν σῶν μόχθον ἐκλύει παρών,</quote> </cit> “his presence dispenses with (solves the need for) the toil of thy feet.” This is better than (1) “freed the city from the songstress, in respect of the tribute,” or (2) “freed the city from the tribute(<foreign xml:lang="grc">δασμόν</foreign> by attraction for <foreign xml:lang="grc">δασμοῦ</foreign>) to the songstress.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκληρᾶς_36"> “hard,” stubborn, relentless. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Andr. 261">Eur. Andr. 261</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκληρὸν θράσος.</quote> </cit> In 391 <foreign xml:lang="grc">κύων</foreign> expresses a similar idea. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_ταῦθ_37"> “and that too”: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 322">Soph. Ant. 322</ref>(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐποίησας τὸ ἔργον) καὶ ταῦτ’ ἐπ’ ἀργυρῷ γε τὴν ψυχὴν προδούς</foreign>:<ref n="Soph. El. 614">Soph. El. 614</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδὲν_πλέον_37">, nothing more than anyone else knew; nothing that could help thee. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Crat. 387a">Plat. Crat. 387a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλέον τι ἡμῖν ἔσται,</quote> </cit> we shall gain something. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Sym. 217c">Plat. Sym. 217c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν γάρ μοι πλέον ἦν,</quote> </cit> it did not help me. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξειδὼς_ἐκδιδαχθείς_37">: not having heard (incidentally)—much less having been <emph>thoroughly schooled</emph>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσθήκῃ_θεοῦ_38"> “by the aid of a god.” <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 25.24">Dem. 25.24</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ εὐταξία τῇ τῶν νόμων προσθήκῃ τῶν αἰσχρῶν περίεστι,</quote> </cit> “discipline, with <emph>the support</emph> of the laws, prevails against villainy.” <cit> <bibl>Dion. Hal. 5.67</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προσθήκης μοῖραν ἐπεῖχον οὗτοι τοῖς ἐν φάλαγγι τεταγμένοις,</quote> </cit> “these served as <emph> supports</emph> to the main body of the troops.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">προστίθεσθαί τινι,</foreign> to take his side: <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 6.80">Thuc. 6.80</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς ἀδικουμένοις … προσθεμένους</quote> </cit>: so <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1332">Soph. OC 1332</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷς ἂν σὺ προσθῇ.</quote> </cit> (The noun <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσθήκη</foreign> does not occur as = “<emph>mandate</emph>,” though <ref n="Hdt. 3.62">Hdt. 3.62</ref> has <foreign xml:lang="grc">τό τοι προσέθηκα πρῆγμα.</foreign>) The word is appropriate, since the achievement of Oed. is viewed as essentially a triumph of human wit: a divine agency prompted him, but remained in the background. </gloss>

data.quote:
ἡ εὐταξία τῇ τῶν νόμων προσθήκῃ τῶν αἰσχρῶν
							περίεστι,

προσθήκης μοῖραν ἐπεῖχον οὗτοι τοῖς ἐν φάλαγγι
							τεταγμένοις,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νῦν_τ_40"> it is unnecessary to read <foreign xml:lang="grc">νῦν δ’</foreign>: see on 35. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶσιν_40">, ethical dat. masc. (cp. 8), “in the eyes of all men.” <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 1071">Soph. Trach. 1071</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλοῖσιν οἰκτρόν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴτε_42"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶσθα ἀλκήν, ἀκούσας φήμην θεῶν του</foreign> (<emph> by</emph> having heard a voice from some god), </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴτε_42_2"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶσθα ἀλκὴν ἀπ’ ἀνδρός που.</foreign> We might take <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπ’ ἀνδρὸς</foreign> with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλκήν,</foreign> but it is perh. simpler to take it with <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶσθα</foreign>: cp. 398 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπ’ οἰωνῶν μαθών,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.125">Thuc. 1.125</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπειδὴ ἀφ’ ἁπάντων ἤκουσαν τὴν γνώμην</quote> </cit>: though <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρά</foreign> (or <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρός) τινος</foreign> is more frequent. </gloss>

data.quote: ἐπειδὴ ἀφ’ ἁπάντων ἤκουσαν τὴν γνώμην

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φήμην_43"> any message (as in a dream, <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">φήμη ὀνείρου,</quote> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.43">Hdt. 1.43</bibl> </cit>), any rumour, or speech casually heard, which might be taken as a hint from the god. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 20.98">Hom. Od. 20.98</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ζεῦ πάτερ … | φήμην τίς μοι φάσθω … </quote> </cit> (Odysseus prays), “Let some one, I pray, show me <emph>a word of omen</emph>.” Then a woman, grinding corn within, is heard speaking of the suitors, “may they now sup their last”: <foreign xml:lang="grc">χαῖρεν δὲ κλεηδόνι δῖος Ὀδυσσεύς,</foreign> “rejoiced in the sign of the voice.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀμφή</foreign> was esp. the voice of an oracle; <foreign xml:lang="grc">κληδών</foreign> comprised <emph> inarticulate</emph> sounds(<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλ. δυσκρίτους,</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 486">Aesch. PB 486</bibl> </cit> ). </gloss>

data.quote: Ζεῦ πάτερ … | φήμην τίς μοι φάσθω …

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_βουλευμάτων_44"> I take these two verses with the whole context from v. 35, and not merely as a comment on the immediately preceding words <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴτ’ ἀπ’ ἀνδρὸς οἶσθά που.</foreign> Oedipus has had practical experience(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμπειρία</foreign>) of great troubles; when the Sphinx came, his wisdom stood the trial. Men who have become thus <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔμπειροι</foreign> are apt to be <emph>also</emph> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(καἴ</foreign> prudent in regard to the future. Past <emph>facts</emph> enlighten the <emph> counsels</emph> which they offer on things still uncertain; and we observe that the issues of their counsels are not usually futile or dead, but effectual. Well may we believe, then, that he who saved us from the Sphinx can tell us how to escape from the plague. Note these points. (1) The words <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμπείροισι</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">βουλευμάτων</foreign> serve to suggest the antithesis between past and future. (2) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰς_τῶνβουλευμάτων_44">= literally, <emph>the occurrences</emph> connected with (resulting from) <emph>the counsels</emph>. The phrase, “issues of counsels,” concisely expresses this. The objection which has been made to this version, that <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξυμφορά</foreign> is not <foreign xml:lang="grc"> τελευτή,</foreign> rests on a grammatical fallacy, viz., that, in <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξυμφορὰ βουλεύματος,</foreign> the genitive must be of the same kind as in <foreign xml:lang="grc">τελευτὴ βουλεύματος. τύχη</foreign> is not <foreign xml:lang="grc">τελευτή,</foreign> yet in <ref n="Soph. OC 1506">Soph. OC 1506</ref> it stands with a gen. of connection, just as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξυμφορά</foreign> does here:<foreign xml:lang="grc">(θεῶν) τύχην τις ἐσθλὴν τῆσδ’ ἔθηκε τῆς ὁδοῦ</foreign> (a good fortune connected with this coming). Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.140">Thuc. 1.140</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνδέχεται γὰρ τὰς ξυμφορὰς τῶν πραγμάτων οὐχ ἦσσον ἀμαθῶς χωρῆσαι ἢ καὶ τὰς διανοίας τοῦ ἀνθρώπου</quote> </cit> :<emph>the issues of human affairs</emph> can be as incomprehensible in their course as the thoughts of man (where, again, the “occurrences connected with human affairs” would be more literal): ib. <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς τὰς ξυμφορὰς καὶ τὰς γνώμας τρεπομένους,</foreign> altering their views according to the <emph>events</emph>.<cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.87">Thuc. 3.87</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς ξυμφορᾶς τῷ ἀποβάντι,</quote> </cit> by the <emph>issue</emph> which has resulted. (3) </gloss>

data.quote:
ἐνδέχεται γὰρ τὰς ξυμφορὰς τῶν πραγμάτων οὐχ
							ἦσσον
									ἀμαθῶς χωρῆσαι ἢ καὶ τὰς διανοίας τοῦ ἀνθρώπου

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζώσας_45"> is not “successful,” but “operative,” —effectual for the purpose of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">βουλεύματα</foreign>: as v. 482 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ζῶντα</foreign> is said of the oracles which remain operative against the guilty, and <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 457">Soph. Ant. 457</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ζῇ ταῦτα</quote> </cit> of laws which are ever in force. Conversely <foreign xml:lang="grc">λόγοι θνῄσκοντες μάτην</foreign> (<ref n="Aesch. Lib. 845">Aesch. Lib. 845</ref>) are threats which come to nothing. The scholium in L gives the sense correctly:— <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν τοῖς συνετοῖς τὰς συντυχίας καὶ τὰς ἀποβάσεις τῶν βουλευμάτων ὁρῶ ζώσας καὶ οὐκ ἀπολλυμένας.</foreign> See Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐλαβήθηθ_47"> have a care <emph>for thy repute</emph>— as the next clause explains. Oed. is supposed to be above personal risk; it is only the degree of his future glory (55) which is in question; a fine touch, in view of the destined sequel. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_προθυμίας_48"> causal genit.: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Crito 43b">Plat. Crito 43b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλάκις μὲν δή σε … εὐδαιμόνισα τοῦ τρόπου.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
πολλάκις μὲν δή σε … εὐδαιμόνισα τοῦ
									τρόπου.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μεμνώμεθα_49"> This subjunctive occurs also in <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 14.168">Hom. Od. 14.168</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῖνε καὶ ἄλλα παρὲξ μεμνώμεθα,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Stat. 285c">Plat. Stat. 285c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φυλάττωμεν … καὶ … μεμνώμεθα,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phileb. 31a">Plat. Phileb. 31a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μεμνώμεθα δὴ καὶ ταῦτα περὶ ἀμφοῖν.</quote> </cit> Eustathius (1303. 46, 1332. 18) cites the word here as </gloss>

data.quote: μεμνώμεθα δὴ καὶ ταῦτα περὶ ἀμφοῖν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μεμνῴμεθα_49"> (optative). We find, indeed, <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">μεμνῷο</quote> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 1.7.5">Xen. Anab. 1.7.5</bibl> </cit> (v. l. <foreign xml:lang="grc">μεμνῇο</foreign>),<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">μεμνεῷτο</quote> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 23.361">Hom. Il. 23.361</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">μεμνῷτο</quote> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.3">Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.3</bibl> </cit>, but these are rare exceptions. On the other hand, <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">μεμνῄμην</quote> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 24.745">Hom. Il. 24.745</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">μεμνῇτο</quote> <bibl n="Aristoph. Pl. 991">Aristoph. Pl. 991</bibl> </cit> ,<ref n="Plat. Rep. 518a">Plat. Rep. 518a</ref>. If Soph. had meant the optative he would have written <foreign xml:lang="grc">μεμνῄμεθα</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 119">Soph. Phil. 119</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἂν … κεκλῇο.</quote> </cit> See Curtius <title>Greek Verb</title> 2.226 (Eng. tr. p. 423). The personal appeal, too, here requires the subjunct., not optat.: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 174">Soph. OC 174</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ δῆτ’ ἀδικηθῶ,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 802">Soph. Trach. 802</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδ’ αὐτοῦ θάνω.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στάντες_τ_50"> For partic. with <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέμνημαι</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 3.1.31">Xen. Cyrop. 3.1.31</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμέμνητο γὰρ εἰπών</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Pind. N. 2">Pind. N. 2.15</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θνατὰ μεμνάσθω περιστέλλων μέλη</quote> </cit>: for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τε … καί,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1112">Soph. Ant. 1112</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτός τ’ ἔδησα καὶ παρὼν ἐκλύσομαι,</quote> </cit> <emph> as</emph> I bound, <emph>so</emph> will I loose. </gloss>

data.quote: αὐτός τ’ ἔδησα καὶ παρὼν ἐκλύσομαι,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀσφαλείᾳ_51"> “in steadfastness”: a dative of manner, equivalent to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀσφαλῶς</foreign> in the proleptic sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὥστε ἀσφαλῆ εἶναι.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1318">Soph. OC 1318</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κατασκαφῇ |. . δῃώσειν,</quote> </cit> n. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.56">Thuc. 3.56</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ μὴ τὰ ξύμφορα πρὸς τὴν ἔφοδον αὑτοῖς ἀσφαλείᾳ πράσσοντες,</quote> </cit> those who <emph> securely</emph> made terms on their own account which were not for the common good in view of the invasion. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 2.82">Thuc. 2.82</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀσφαλείᾳ δὲ τὸ ἐπιβουλεύσασθαι</quote> </cit> (where <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀσφάλεια</foreign> is a false reading), to form designs <emph>in security</emph>, opp. to <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ ἐμπλήκτως ὀξύ,</foreign> fickle impetuosity. The primary notion of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀσφαλής</foreign> (“not slipping”) is brought out by <foreign xml:lang="grc">πεσόντες</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνόρθωσον.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
οἱ μὴ τὰ ξύμφορα πρὸς τὴν ἔφοδον αὑτοῖς
							ἀσφαλείᾳ
									πράσσοντες,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄρνιθι_αἰσίῳ_52"> like <foreign xml:lang="lat">secunda alite</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="lat">fausta avi</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="lat">bono omine</foreign>. A bird of omen was properly <foreign xml:lang="grc"> οἰωνός</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 15.531">Hom. Od. 15.531</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔ τοι ἄνευ θεοῦ ἔπτατο δεξιὸς ὄρνις· | ἔγνων γάρ μιν ἐσάντα ἰδὼν οἰωνὸν ἐόντα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 3.3.22">Xen. Cyrop. 3.3.22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰωνοῖς χρησάμενος αἰσίοις.</quote> </cit> But cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IA 607">Eur. IA 607</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄρνιθα μὲν τόνδ’ αἴσιον ποιούμεθα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 730">Eur. Her. 730</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄρνιθος οὕνεκα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Birds 720">Aristoph. Birds 720</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φήμη γ’ ὑμῖν ὄρνις ἐστί, πταρμόν τ’ ὄρνιθα καλεῖτε, | ξύμβολον ὄρνιν, φωνὴν ὄρνιν, θεράποντ’ ὄρνιν, ὄνον ὄρνιν.</quote> </cit> For dat., Schneid. cp. Hipponax fr. 63 (Bergk) <foreign xml:lang="grc">δεξιῷ … ἐλθὼν ῥωδιῷ</foreign>(heron). In Bergk <title>Poet. Lyr.</title> p. 1049 fr. incerti 27 <foreign xml:lang="grc">δεξιῇ σίττῃ</foreign> (woodpecker) is a conject. for <foreign xml:lang="grc">δεξιὴ σίττη.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
οὔ τοι ἄνευ θεοῦ ἔπτατο δεξιὸς ὄρνις· | ἔγνων
							γάρ
									μιν ἐσάντα ἰδὼν οἰωνὸν ἐόντα

φήμη γ’ ὑμῖν ὄρνις ἐστί, πταρμόν τ’ ὄρνιθα
							καλεῖτε, | ξύμβολον ὄρνιν, φωνὴν ὄρνιν, θεράποντ’ ὄρνιν, ὄνον
									ὄρνιν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_52"> is better taken as = “also” than as “both” (answering to <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ τανῦν</foreign> in 53). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρξεις_κρατεῖν_54"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κρατεῖν τινός,</foreign> merely to hold in one's power; <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄρχειν</foreign> implies a constitutional rule. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 338d">Plat. Rep. 338d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκοῦν τοῦτο κρατεῖ ἐν ἑκάστῃ πόλει, τὸ ἄρχον;</quote> </cit> Her. 2. i <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄλλους τε παραλαβὼν τῶν ἦρχε καὶ δὴ καὶ Ἑλλήνων τῶν ἐπεκράτεε,</foreign> i.e. the Asiatics who were his lawful subjects, and the Greeks over whom he could exert force. But here the poet intends no stress on a verbal contrast: it is as if he had written, <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴπερ ἄρξεις, ὥσπερ ἄρχεις.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 457">Soph. Trach. 457</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κεἰ μὲν δέδοικας, οὐ καλῶς ταρβεῖς</quote> </cit>: below 973 <foreign xml:lang="grc">προὔλεγον … | ηὔδας.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐκοῦν τοῦτο κρατεῖ ἐν ἑκάστῃ πόλει, τὸ
									ἄρχον;
κεἰ μὲν δέδοικας, οὐ καλῶς ταρβεῖς

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξὺν_ἀνδράσιν_55"> not “with the help of men,” but “with men in the land,” = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρας ἐχούσης γῆς.</foreign> Cp. 207 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξὺν αἷς</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἃς ἔχουσα.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 191">Soph. El. 191</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀεικεῖ σὺν στολᾷ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 30">Soph. Aj. 30</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺν νεορράντῳ ξίφει.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 116">Soph. Ant. 116</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξύν θ’ ἱπποκόμοις κορύθεσσι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἐστιν_56"> <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 7.77">Thuc. 7.77</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρες γὰρ πόλις, καὶ οὐ τείχη οὐδὲ νῆες ἀνδρῶν κεναί.</quote> </cit> Dio Cass. 56. 6 <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνθρωποι γάρ που πόλις ἐστίν, οὐκ οἰκίαι, κ.τ.λ.</quote> <bibl n="Hdt. 8.61">Hdt. 8.61</bibl> </cit> (Themistocles, taunted by Adeimantus after the Persian occupation of Athens in 480 B.C. with being <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄπολις,</foreign> retorted) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἑωυτοῖσι … ως εἴη καὶ πόλις καὶ γῆ μέζων ἤπερ κείνοισι, ἔστ’ ἂν διηκόσιαι νῆές σφι ἔωσι πεπληρωμέναι.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἄνδρες γὰρ πόλις, καὶ οὐ τείχη οὐδὲ νῆες
							ἀνδρῶν
									κεναί.

ἄνθρωποι γάρ που πόλις ἐστίν, οὐκ οἰκίαι,
							κ.τ.λ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πύργος_56"> = the city wall with its towers: the sing. as below, 1378: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 953">Soph. Ant. 953</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ πύργος, οὐχ ἁλίκτυποι | … νᾶες</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hec. 1209">Eur. Hec. 1209</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πέριξ δὲ πύργος εἶχ’ ἔτι πτόλιν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: πέριξ δὲ πύργος εἶχ’ ἔτι πτόλιν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνδρῶν_57"> depends on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔρημος_57">, of which </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_ἔσω_57"> is epexegetic. Rhythm and Sophoclean usage make this better than to take <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρῶν μὴ ξυνοικ. ἔ.</foreign> as a gen. absol. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 464">Soph. Aj. 464</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γυμνὸν φανέντα τῶν ἀριστείων ἄτερ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 31">Soph. Phil. 31</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κενὴν οἴκησιν ἀνθρώπων δίχα</quote> </cit> :<ref>Lucret. 5.841</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">muta sine ore etiam, sine voltu caeca.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γνωτὰ_ἀγνῶτα_58"> The emphasis of this formula sometimes appears to deprecate an opposite impression in the mind of the hearer: “known, and not (<emph>as you perhaps think</emph>) unknown.” <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 3.59">Hom. Il. 3.59</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεί με κατ’ αἶσαν ἐνείκεσας οὐδ’ ὑπὲρ αἶσαν,</quote> </cit> duly, and not, —as you perhaps expect me to say, —unduly. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 3.25">Hdt. 3.25</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμμανής τε ἐὼν καὶ οὐ φρενήρης</quote> </cit>— being mad, —for it must be granted that no man in his right mind would have acted thus. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 397">Soph. OC 397</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βαιοῦ κοὐχὶ μυρίου χρόνου,</quote> </cit> soon, and not after such delay as thy impatience might fear. </gloss>

data.quote:
ἐπεί με κατ’ αἶσαν ἐνείκεσας οὐδ’ ὑπὲρ
									αἶσαν,
ἐμμανής τε ἐὼν καὶ οὐ φρενήρης

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νοσοῦντες_νοσεῖ_60"> We expected <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ νοσοῦντες οὐ νοσεῖτε, ὡς ἐγώ.</foreign> But at the words <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐγώ</foreign> the speaker's consciousness of his own exceeding pain turns him abruptly to the strongest form of expression that he can find <foreign xml:lang="grc">—οὐκ ἔστιν ὑμῶν ὅστις νοσεῖ,</foreign> <emph>there is not one of you</emph> whose pain is as mine. In <ref n="Plat. Phileb. 19b">Plat. Phileb. 19b</ref> (quoted by Schneid.) the source of the anacolouthon is the same: <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ γὰρ δυνάμενοι τοῦτο κατὰ παντὸς ἑνὸς καὶ ὁμοίου καὶ ταὐτοῦ δρᾶν καὶ τοῦ ἐναντίου, ὡς ὁ παρελθὰν λόγος ἐμήνυσεν, οὐδεὶς εἰς οὐδὲν οὐδενὸς ἂν ἡμῶν οὐδέποτε γένοιτο ἄξιος,</foreign> — instead of the tamer <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν γενοίμεθα.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_αὑτόν_62"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">καθ’ αὑτόν,</foreign> “by himself” (<ref n="Soph. OC 966">Soph. OC 966</ref>), is strictly only an emphatic repetition of <foreign xml:lang="grc">μόνον</foreign>: but the whole phrase <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰς ἕνα μόνον καθ’ αὑτόν</foreign> is virtually equivalent to <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰς ἕνα ἕκαστον καθ’ αὑτόν,</foreign> each several one apart from the rest. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πόλιν_σ_64"> The king's soul grieves for the whole State, —for himself, charged with the care of it, —and for each several man(<foreign xml:lang="grc">σἔ.</foreign> As the first contrast is between public and private care, <foreign xml:lang="grc">κἀμέ</foreign> stands between <foreign xml:lang="grc">πόλιν</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">σέ.</foreign> For the elision of <foreign xml:lang="grc">σέ,</foreign> though accented, cp. 329 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τἄμ’, ὡς ἂν εἴπω μὴ τὰ σ’</foreign>: 404 <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ τὰ σ’</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1499">Soph. El. 1499</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ γοῦν σ’</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 339">Soph. Phil. 339</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴμοι μὲν ἀρκεῖν σοί γε καὶ τὰ σ’</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 323">Eur. Hipp. 323</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔα μ’ ἁμαρτεῖν· οὐ γὰρ ἐς σ’ ἁμαρτάνω.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: οἴμοι μὲν ἀρκεῖν σοί γε καὶ τὰ σ’
ἔα μ’ ἁμαρτεῖν· οὐ γὰρ ἐς σ’ ἁμαρτάνω.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὕπνῳ_65">, more forcible than a cogn. acc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὕπνον,</foreign> nearly = “soundly.” Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 427">Soph. Ant. 427</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γόοισιν ἐξῴμωξεν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 176">Soph. Trach. 176</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φόβῳ, φίλαι, ταρβοῦσαν</quote> </cit>: [;Eur.]; fr. 1132 (Nauck(2)) 40 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀργῇ χολωθείς</foreign> (where Nauck, rashly, I think, conjectures <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔργεἰ.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Verg. A. 1.680">Verg. Aen. 1.680</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">sopitum somno</quote> </cit> .<foreign xml:lang="grc">εὕδειν, καθεύδειν</foreign> (<ref n="Xen. Anab. 1.3.11">Xen. Anab. 1.3.11</ref>) oft. = “to be at ease” (cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔνθ’ οὐκ ἂν βρίζοντα ἴδοις,</foreign> of Agam., <ref n="Hom. Il. 4.223">Hom. Il. 4.223</ref>): the addition of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὕπνῳ</foreign> raises and invigorates a trite metaphor. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλάνοις_67"> has excellent manuscript authority here; and Soph. uses <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλάνου</quote> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1114">Soph. OC 1114</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλάνοις</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 758">Soph. Phil. 758</bibl> </cit>, but <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάνη</foreign> nowhere. Aesch. has <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάνη</foreign> only: Eur. <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάνος</foreign> only, unless the fragment of the <title> Rhadamanthus</title> be genuine (659 Nauck(2), v. 8, <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὕτω βίοτος ἀνθρώπων πλάνἠ.</foreign> Aristoph. has <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάνος</foreign> once (<ref n="Aristoph. Wasps 872">Aristoph. Wasps 872</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάνη</foreign> never. Plato uses both <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάνη</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάνος,</foreign> the former oftenest: Isocrates has <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάνος,</foreign> not <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάνη.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ηὕρισκον_68"> “could find” (impf.). Attic inscriptions of the t=h or early t/h cent. B.C. support the temporal augment in the historical tenses of <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὑρίσκω</foreign> (Meisterhans, <title>Gram. Att. Inschr.</title>, p. 78). Our best MS. of Soph. (L), however, preserves no trace of it, except in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 406">Soph. Ant. 406</ref> (see cr. n. there). Curtius (<ref>Curt. Verb. 1.139</ref>, Eng. tr. 93) thinks that, while the omission of the syllabic augment was an archaic and poetical license, that of the temporal was “a sacrifice to convenience of articulation, and was more or less common to all periods”: so that <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴκαζον</foreign> could exist in Attic by the side of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ᾔκαζον, εὕρισκον</foreign> by the side of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ηὕρισκον.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταύτην_ἔπραξα_69"> a terse equivalent for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταύτῃ ἔργῳ ἐχρησάμην.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Φοίβου_τίφωνῶν_71"> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 414d">Plat. Rep. 414d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ οἶδα ὁποίᾳ τόλμῃ ἢ ποίοις λόγοις χρώμενος ἐρῶ.</quote> </cit> These are exceptions to the rule that, where an interrogative pronoun (as <foreign xml:lang="grc">τίς</foreign>) and a relative (as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄστις</foreign>) are both used in an indirect question, the former stands first: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Crito 48a">Plat. Crito 48a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἄρα … φροντιστέον, τί ἐροῦσιν οἱ πολλοὶ ἡμᾶς, ἀλλ’ ὅ τι ὁ ἐπαΐων, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 448e">Plat. Gorg. 448e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδεὶς ἐρωτᾷ ποία τις εἴη ἡ Γοργίου τέχνη, ἀλλὰ τίς, καὶ ὅντινα δέοι καλεῖν τὸν Γοργίαν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 500a">Plat. Gorg. 500a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκλέξασθαι ποῖα ἀγαθὰ καὶ ὁποῖα κακά</quote> </cit> :<ref n="Plat. Phileb. 17b">Plat. Phileb. 17b</ref>(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἴσμεν) πόσα τέ ἐστι καὶ ὁποῖα.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐκ οἶδα ὁποίᾳ τόλμῃ ἢ ποίοις λόγοις χρώμενος
							ἐρῶ.

οὐκ ἄρα … φροντιστέον, τί ἐροῦσιν οἱ πολλοὶ
							ἡμᾶς, ἀλλ’ ὅ τι ὁ ἐπαΐων, κ.τ.λ.

οὐδεὶς ἐρωτᾷ ποία τις εἴη ἡ Γοργίου τέχνη,
							ἀλλὰ
									τίς, καὶ ὅντινα δέοι καλεῖν τὸν Γοργίαν
ἐκλέξασθαι ποῖα ἀγαθὰ καὶ ὁποῖα κακά

lemma:
Φοίβου … ὅ τι  δρῶν … τί
							φωνῶν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δρῶν_φωνῶν_72">: there is no definite contrast between <emph>doing</emph> and <emph>bidding others to do:</emph> rather “deed” and “word” represent the two chief forms of agency, the phrase being equivalent to “in what possible way.” Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 659">Aesch. PB 659</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεοπρόπους ἴαλλεν, ὡς μάθοι τί χρὴ | δρῶντ’ ἢ λέγοντα δαίμοσιν πράσσειν φίλα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
θεοπρόπους ἴαλλεν, ὡς μάθοι τί χρὴ | δρῶντ’ ἢ
							λέγοντα δαίμοσιν πράσσειν φίλα.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ῥυσαίμην_72"> (L's reading) is right: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥυσοίμην</foreign> is grammatically possible, but less fitting. The direct deliberative form is <foreign xml:lang="grc">τί δρῶν ῥύσωμαι;</foreign> the indirect, <foreign xml:lang="grc">πυνθάνομαι ὅ τι</foreign> (or <foreign xml:lang="grc">τἴ δρῶν ῥύσωμαι, ἐπυθόμην ὅ τι</foreign> (or <foreign xml:lang="grc">τἴ δρῶν ῥυσαίμην.</foreign> This indirect deliberative occurs, not only with verbs of “doubting” (<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Hell. 7.4.39">Xen. Hell. 7.4.39</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠπόρει ὅ τι χρήσαιτο τῷ πράγματἰ,</quote> </cit> but also with verbs of “asking”: <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.25">Thuc. 1.25</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν θεὸν ἐπήροντο, εἰ παραδοῖεν … τὴν πόλιν</quote> </cit> (oblique of <foreign xml:lang="grc">παραδῶμεν τὴν πόλιν).</foreign> Kennedy wrongly says that <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥυσαίμην</foreign> here could be only the oblique of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐρρυσάμην</foreign> (as if, in <ref n="Thuc. 1.25">Thuc. 1.25</ref>,<foreign xml:lang="grc">παραδοῖεν</foreign> could be only the oblique of <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρέδοσαν)</foreign>; and that, for the sense, it would require <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄν.</foreign> This would also be right, but in a different constr., viz., as oblique of <foreign xml:lang="grc">τί δρῶν ῥυσαίμην ἄν</foreign>; Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 991">Soph. Trach. 991</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ ἔχω πῶς ἂν | στέρξαιμι,</quote> </cit> and <ref n="Soph. Ant. 270">Soph. Ant. 270 ff.</ref> n. In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 33">Soph. El. 33</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς μάθοιμ’, ὅτῳ τρόπῳ πατρὶ | δίκας ἀροίμην,</quote> </cit> the opt. is that of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἠρόμην,</foreign> being oblique for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄρωμαι,</foreign> rather than of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀροῦμαι.</foreign> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥυσοίμην</foreign> would be oblique of <foreign xml:lang="grc">τί δρῶν ῥύσομαι; ῥυσοίμην</foreign> (oblique for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥύσομαι</foreign>) would imply that he was confident of a successful <emph>result,</emph> and doubtful only concerning the <emph> means;</emph> it is therefore less suitable. </gloss>

data.quote: ἠπόρει ὅ τι χρήσαιτο τῷ πράγματἰ,

τὸν θεὸν ἐπήροντο, εἰ παραδοῖεν … τὴν
									πόλιν
οὐ γὰρ ἔχω πῶς ἂν | στέρξαιμι,

ὡς μάθοιμ’, ὅτῳ τρόπῳ πατρὶ | δίκας
									ἀροίμην,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καί_χρόνῳ_73"> Lit., “and already the day, compared with the lapse of time [;since his departure];, makes me anxious what he doth”: i.e. when I think what day this is, and how many days ago he started, I feel anxious. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤδη_73">, showing that <emph>to-day</emph> is meant, sufficiently defines <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦμαρ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρόνῳ_73"> is not for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷ χρόνῳ,</foreign> <emph>the</emph> time since he left, —though this is implied, —but is abstract, —time in its course. The absence of the art. is against our taking <foreign xml:lang="grc">χρόνῳ</foreign> as “the time which I had allowed for his journey.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυμμετρούμενον_73">: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 4.158">Hdt. 4.158</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">συμμετρησάμενοι τὴν ὥρην τῆς ἡμέρης, νυκτὸς παρῆγον,</quote> </cit> “having <emph> calculated</emph> the time, they led them past the place by night”: lit., “having compared the season of the day (with the distance to be traversed).” <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 1214">Eur. Orest. 1214</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ δὴ πέλας νιν δωμάτων εἶναι δοκῶ· | τοῦ γὰρ χρόνου τὸ μῆκος αὐτὸ συντρέχει</quote> </cit> “for the length of time (since her departure) just tallies (with the time required for the journey).” </gloss>

data.quote:
συμμετρησάμενοι τὴν ὥρην τῆς ἡμέρης, νυκτὸς
							παρῆγον,

καὶ δὴ πέλας νιν δωμάτων εἶναι δοκῶ· | τοῦ γὰρ
							χρόνου τὸ μῆκος αὐτὸ συντρέχει

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λυπεῖ_πράσσει_74"> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 794">Soph. Aj. 794</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥστε μ’ ὠδίνειν τί φῄς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_πέρα_74"> .<foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ εἰκός</foreign> is <emph>a reasonable estimate</emph> of the time required for the journey. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 2.73">Thuc. 2.73</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡμέρας … ἐν αἶς εἰκὸς ἦν κομισθῆναι (αὐτούς),</quote> </cit> the number of days which might reasonably be allowed for their journey (from Plataea to Athens and back). Porson conjectured <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦ γὰρ εἰκότος περᾷ,</foreign> as = “for he overstays the due limit”—thinking v. 75, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄπεστι … χρόυνου,</foreign> to be a spurious interpolation. The same idea had occurred to Bentley. But (1) <foreign xml:lang="grc">περᾶν</foreign> with the genitive in this sense is strange (in 674 <foreign xml:lang="grc">θυμοῦ περᾶν</foreign> is different), and would not be readily understood as referring to <emph>time;</emph> (2) it is Sophoclean to explain and define <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦ εἰκότος πέρα</foreign> by <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλείω τοῦ καθήκοντος χρόνου.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἡμέρας … ἐν αἶς εἰκὸς ἦν κομισθῆναι
									(αὐτούς),

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_καλὸν_78"> to fit purpose, “opportunely”: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Sym. 174e">Plat. Sym. 174e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς καλὸν ἥκεις.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1168">Soph. Aj. 1168</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μὴν ἐς αὐτὸν καιρὸν … | πάρεισιν.</quote> </cit> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Ach. 686">Aristoph. Ach. 686</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς τάχος</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ταχέως,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Birds 805">Aristoph. Birds 805</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς εὐτέλειαν</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">εὐτελῶς.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: καὶ μὴν ἐς αὐτὸν καιρὸν … | πάρεισιν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἵδε_78">: some of those suppliants who are nearer to the stage entrance on the spectators' left—the conventional one for an arrival <emph>from the country</emph>— have made signs to the Priest. Creon enters, wearing a wreath of bay leaves bright with berries, in token of a favourable answer. See Appendix, Note 1, sect. 2. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_ὄμματι_80"> may his radiant look prove the herald of good news. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_τύχῃ_80">, nearly = <foreign xml:lang="grc">μετὰ τύχης,</foreign> “invested with,” “attended by”: cp. 1112 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔν τε γὰρ μακρῷ | γήρᾳ ξυνᾴδει</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 488">Soph. Aj. 488</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σθένοντος ἐν πλούτῳ.</quote> </cit> <foreign xml:lang="grc">τύχη σωτὴρ</foreign> (<ref n="Aesch. Ag. 664">Aesch. Ag. 664</ref>), like <foreign xml:lang="grc">χεὶρ πράκτωρ</foreign>(<ref n="Aesch. Ag. 111">Aesch. Ag. 111</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">θέλκτωρ πειθώ</foreign> (<ref n="Aesch. Supp. 1040">Aesch. Supp. 1040</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">καρανιστῆρες δίκαι</foreign>(<ref n="Aesch. Eum. 186">Aesch. Eum. 186</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λαμπρὸς_81"> with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν τύχῃ κ.τ.λ.,</foreign> —being applicable at once to <emph>brilliant</emph> fortune and (in the sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">φαιδρός</foreign>) to a <emph>beaming</emph> countenance. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰκάσαι_ἡδύς_82"> (sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">βαίνει</foreign>). Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 410">Soph. El. 410</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ δείματός του νυκτέρου, δοκεῖν ἐμοί.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 151">Soph. OC 151</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσαίων | μακραίων τ’, ἐπεικάσαι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἐκ δείματός του νυκτέρου, δοκεῖν ἐμοί.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡδύς_82">, not “joyous,” but “pleasant to us,” “bringing good news”: as 510 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡδύπολις,</foreign> pleasant to the city: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 929">Soph. El. 929</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡδὺς αὐδὲ μητρὶ δυσχερής,</quote> </cit> a guest welcome, not grievous, to her. In <ref n="Soph. Trach. 869">Soph. Trach. 869</ref> where <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀηδὴς καὶ συνωφρυωμένη</foreign> is said of one who approaches with bad news, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνηδής</foreign> is not “unwelcome,” but rather “sullen,” “gloomy.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολυστεφὴς_δάφνης_83"> The use of the gen. after words denoting fulness is extended to the notions of encompassing or overshadowing: e.g. <foreign xml:lang="grc">περιστεφῇ … ἀνθέων θήκην</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. El. 895">Soph. El. 895</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">στέγην … ἦς</foreign> [;v. l. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ᾗ]; κατηρεφεῖς δόμοι</foreign> (<ref n="Eur. Hipp. 468">Eur. Hipp. 468</ref>). But the dat. would also stand: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 9.183">Hom. Od. 9.183</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σπέος … δάφνῃσι κατηρεφές</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Hes. WD 513">Hes. WD 513</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λάχνῃ δέρμα κατάσκιον.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παγκάρπου_83">, covered with berries: cp.<ref n="Soph. OC 676">Soph. OC 676</ref>.<ref>Plin. NH 15.30</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">maximis baccis atque e viridi rubentibus</foreign> (of the Delphic laurel). The wreath announces good news, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 179">Soph. Trach. 179</ref>: so in <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 806">Eur. Hipp. 806</ref> Theseus, returning from the oracle at Delphi to find Phaedra dead, cries <foreign xml:lang="grc">τί δῆτα τοῖσδ’ ἀνέστεμμαι κάρα | πλεκτοῖσι φύλλοις, δυστυχὴς θεωρὸς ὤν;</foreign> So Fabius Pictor returned from Delphi to Rome <foreign xml:lang="lat">coronatus laurea corona</foreign> (<ref>Liv. 23.11</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξύμμετρος_κλύειν_84"> He is at a just distance for hearing: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξύμμετρος</foreign> =<emph>commensurate</emph> (in respect of his distance) <emph>with</emph> the range of our voices (implied in <foreign xml:lang="grc">κλύειν</foreign>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κήδευμα_85"> “kinsman” (by marriage). = <foreign xml:lang="grc">κηδεστής,</foreign> here = <foreign xml:lang="grc">γαμβρός</foreign> (70). <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 756">Soph. Ant. 756</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γυναικὸς ὢν δούλευμα μὴ κώτιλλέ με.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 928">Eur. Orest. 928</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τἄνδον οἰκουρήματα</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰς ἔνδον οἰκουρούσας.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: γυναικὸς ὢν δούλευμα μὴ κώτιλλέ με.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγω_εὐτυχεῖν_87"> Creon, unwilling to speak plainly before the Chorus, hints to Oedipus that he brings a clue to the means by which the anger of heaven may be appeased. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξελθόντα_88">, of the <emph>event,</emph> “having issued”; cp. 1011 <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή μοι Φοῖβος ἐξέλθῃ σαφής;</foreign> so 1182 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξήκοι.</foreign> The word is chosen by Creon with veiled reference to the duty of <emph>banishing</emph> the defiling presence (98 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐλαύνειν</foreign>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάντ_88"> predicative with <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὐτυχεῖν,</foreign> “will all of them (= altogether) be well.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">λέγω</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἂν_εὐτυχεῖν_88"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">λέγω ὅτι εὐτυχοίη ἄν.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὔπος_89"> the actual oracle(<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὔπος τὸ θεοπρόπον,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 822">Soph. Trach. 822</bibl> </cit> ):</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγῳ_89"> (90), Creon's own saying(<foreign xml:lang="grc">λέγω,</foreign> 87). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προδείσας_90">, alarmed beforehand. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 7.50">Hdt. 7.50</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρέσσον δὲ πάντα θαρσέοντα ἥμισυ τῶν δεινῶν πάσχειν μᾶλλον ἢ πᾶν χρῆμα προδειμαίνοντα μηδαμὰ μηδὲν παθεῖν.</quote> </cit> No other part of <foreign xml:lang="grc">προδείδω</foreign> occurs: <foreign xml:lang="grc">προταρβεῖν, προφοβεῖσθαι</foreign> = “to fear beforehand,” but <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπερ δέδοικά σου,</foreign> I fear <emph>for</emph> thee, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 82">Soph. Ant. 82</ref>. In compos. with a verb of <emph>caring for</emph>, however, <foreign xml:lang="grc">προό</foreign> sometimes = <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὑπέρ,</foreign> e.g. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">προκήδομαι</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 741">Soph. Ant. 741</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

data.quote:
κρέσσον δὲ πάντα θαρσέοντα ἥμισυ τῶν δεινῶν
							πάσχειν μᾶλλον ἢ πᾶν χρῆμα προδειμαίνοντα μηδαμὰ μηδὲν
									παθεῖν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλησιαζόντων_91"> here = <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλησίον ὄντων</foreign>: usu. the verb = either (i) to approach, or (2) to <emph>consort with</emph> (dat.), as below, 1136. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_εἴτε_91">, as <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 468">Aesch. Eum. 468</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ δ’, εἰ δικαίως εἴτε μή, κρῖνον δίκην.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: σὺ δ’, εἰ δικαίως εἴτε μή, κρῖνον δίκην.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴτε_ἔσω_92"> <foreign xml:lang="grc"> (χρῄζεις), (ἕτοιμός εἰμι τοῦτο δρᾶν).</foreign> So <ref n="Eur. Ion 1120">Eur. Ion 1120</ref> (quoted by Elms., etc.) <foreign xml:lang="grc">πεπυσμέναι γάρ, εἰ θανεῖν ἡμᾶς χρεών, | ἥδιον ἂν θάνοιμεν, εἴθ’ ὁρᾶν φάος</foreign>: i. e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴτε ὁρᾶν φάος (χρἤ, (ἥδιον ἂν ὁρῷμεν αὐτὄ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐς_πάντας_93"> <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 8.26">Hdt. 8.26</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε ἠνέσχετο σιγῶν εἶπέ τε ἐς πάντας τάδε</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.72">Thuc. 1.72</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς τὸ πλῆθος εἰπεῖν</quote> </cit> (before the assembly). </gloss>

data.quote: οὔτε ἠνέσχετο σιγῶν εἶπέ τε ἐς πάντας τάδε

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλέον_93"> adverbial, as in <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1101">Soph. Aj. 1101</ref>, etc.: schol. <foreign xml:lang="grc">περὶ τούτων πλέον ἀγωνίζομαι ἢ περὶ τῆς ἐμαυτοῦ ψυχῆς.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῶνδε_93"> object. gen. with <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ πένθος</foreign> (not with <foreign xml:lang="grc">περἴ·</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1097">Soph. El. 1097</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τᾷ Ζηνὸς εὐσεβείᾳ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
