<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_καὶ_94"> “than <emph>even.</emph>” This must not be confounded with the occasional use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἢ καί</foreign> in <emph> negative</emph> sentences containing a comparison: e.g. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1103">Soph. Aj. 1103</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἔσθ’ ὅπου σοὶ τόνδε κοσμῆσαι πλέον | ἀρχῆς ἔκειτο θεσμὸς ἢ καὶ τῷδε σέ</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1145">Soph. El. 1145</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε γάρ ποτε | μητρὸς σύ γ’ ἦσθα μᾶλλον ἢ κἀμοῦ φίλος</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 5.23">Antiph. 5.23</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐζητεῖτο οὐδέν τι μᾶλλον ὑπὸ τῶν ἄλλων ἢ καὶ ὑπ’ ἐμοῦ</quote> </cit> (where <foreign xml:lang="grc">καί</foreign> is redundant, = “on my part”). </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐκ ἔσθ’ ὅπου σοὶ τόνδε κοσμῆσαι πλέον | ἀρχῆς
							ἔκειτο θεσμὸς ἢ καὶ τῷδε σέ

οὔτε γάρ ποτε | μητρὸς σύ γ’ ἦσθα μᾶλλον ἢ
							κἀμοῦ
									φίλος

ἐζητεῖτο οὐδέν τι μᾶλλον ὑπὸ τῶν ἄλλων ἢ καὶ
							ὑπ’
									ἐμοῦ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγοιμ_ἂν_95"> a deferential form, having regard to the permission just given. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 674">Soph. Phil. 674</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χωροῖς ἂν εἴσω</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 637">Soph. El. 637</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλύοις ἂν ἤδη.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_97"> marks that the partic. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τεθραμμένον_97"> expresses the view held by the subject of the leading verb (<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄνωγεν</foreign>): i.e., “<emph>as</emph> having been harboured” = “which (<emph>he says</emph>) has been harboured.” Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 1.2.1">Xen. Anab. 1.2.1</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔλεγε θαρρεῖν ὡς καταστησομένων τούτων εἰς τὸ δέον</quote> </cit>: he said, “Take courage, <emph>in the assurance that</emph>” etc. </gloss>

data.quote:
ἔλεγε θαρρεῖν ὡς καταστησομένων τούτων εἰς τὸ
							δέον

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλαύνειν_98"> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξελαύνειν</foreign> was regular in this context: <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.126">Thuc. 1.126</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ ἄγος ἐλαύνειν τῆς θεοῦ</quote> </cit>(i.e. to banish the Alcmaeonidae): and so 1. 127, 128, 135, 2. 13. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδ_τρέφειν_98"> The <foreign xml:lang="grc">μίασμα</foreign> is <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνήκεστον</foreign> in the sense that it cannot be healed <emph>by anything else than</emph> the death or banishment of the bloodguilty. But it can still be healed if that expiation is made. Thus <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνήκεστον</foreign> is a proleptic predicate: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 565c">Plat. Rep. 565c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτον τρέφειν τε καὶ αὔξειν μέγαν</quote> </cit> :<ref n="Soph. OC 527">Soph. OC 527</ref> n. See <cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 4.3.7">Antiph. 4.3.7</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντὶ τοῦ παθόντος</quote> </cit>/GREEK> (in the cause of the dead) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπισκήπτομεν ὑμῖν τῷ τούτου φόνῳ τὸ μήνιμα τῶν ἀλιτηρίων ἀκεσαμένους πᾶσαν τὴν πόλιν καθαρὰν τοῦ μιάσματος καταστῆσαι,</foreign> “to heal with this man's blood the deed which angers the avenging spirits, and so to purge the whole city of the defilement.” </gloss>

data.quote: τοῦτον τρέφειν τε καὶ αὔξειν μέγαν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποίῳ_ξυμφορᾶς_99"> By what purifying rite (does he command us <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐλαύνειν τὸ μίασμα</foreign>)? What is the manner of our misfortune (i.e. our defilement)? <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 390">Eur. Phoen. 390</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς ὁ τρόπος αὐτοῦ; τί φυγάσιν τὸ δυσχερές;</quote> </cit> “what is the manner thereof?) sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦ κακοῦ,</foreign> exile). </gloss>

data.quote:
τίς ὁ τρόπος αὐτοῦ; τί φυγάσιν τὸ
									δυσχερές;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυμφορᾶς_99">, euphemistic for guilt, as <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 934b">Plat. Laws 934b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λωφῆσαι πολλὰ μέρη τῆς τοιαύτης ξυμφορᾶς,</quote> </cit> to be healed in great measure of such a malady (viz., of evil-doing): <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 854d">Plat. Laws 854d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τῷ προσώπῳ καὶ ταῖς χερσὶ γραφεὶς τὴν ξυμφοράν,</quote> </cit> “with his <emph> misfortune</emph> [;the crime of sacrilege]; branded on his face and hands.” <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.35">Hdt. 1.35</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">συμφορῇ ἐχόμενος</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐναγής,</foreign> under a ban. Prof. Kennedy understands: “what is the mode of <emph>compliance</emph> (with the oracle)?” He compares <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 641">Soph. OC 641</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῇδε γὰρ ξυνοίσομαι</quote> </cit> (“for with that choice I will comply”). But elsewhere, at least, <foreign xml:lang="grc">συμφορά</foreign> does not occur in a sense parallel with <foreign xml:lang="grc">συμφέρεσθαι,</foreign> “to agree with.” </gloss>

data.quote: λωφῆσαι πολλὰ μέρη τῆς τοιαύτης ξυμφορᾶς,

ἐν τῷ προσώπῳ καὶ ταῖς χερσὶ γραφεὶς τὴν
							ξυμφοράν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνδρηλατοῦντας_100"> As if, instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποίῳ καθαρμῷ,</foreign> the question had been <foreign xml:lang="grc">τί ποιοῦντας;</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_πόλιν_101"> since it is this blood <foreign xml:lang="grc">[;τόδε,</foreign> viz. that implied in <foreign xml:lang="grc">φόνον];</foreign> which brings the storm on Thebes. <foreign xml:lang="grc">χειμάζον,</foreign> acc. absol. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_101"> presents the fact as the ground of belief on which the Thebans are commanded to act: “Do thus, <emph>assured that</emph> it is this blood,” etc. Cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 380">Soph. OC 380</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Hell. 2.4.1">Xen. Hell. 2.4.1</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ δὲ τριάκοντα, ὡς ἐξὸν ἤδη αὐτοῖς τυραννεῖν ἀδεῶς, προεῖπον, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Supp. 268">Eur. Supp. 268</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πόλις δὲ πρὸς πόλιν | ἔπτηξε χειμασθεῖσα,</quote> </cit> “city with city seeks shelter, when vexed by storms.” </gloss>

data.quote:
οἱ δὲ τριάκοντα, ὡς ἐξὸν ἤδη αὐτοῖς τυραννεῖν
							ἀδεῶς, προεῖπον, κ.τ.λ.
πόλις δὲ πρὸς πόλιν | ἔπτηξε χειμασθεῖσα,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπευθύνειν_104"> to steer in a right course. The infin. is of the imperf., = <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρότερον ἢ ἀπηύθυνες,</foreign> before you were steering (began to steer). Oedipus took the State out of angry waters into smooth: cp. 696 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμὰν γᾶν φίλαν | ἐν πόνοις ἀλύουσαν κατ’ ὀρθὸν οὔρισας</foreign>: fr. 151 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλήκτροις ἀπευθύνουσιν οὐρίαν τρόπιν,</foreign> “with the helm(<foreign xml:lang="grc">πλῆκτρα,</foreign> the blades of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">πηδάλιἀ</foreign> they steer their bark before the breeze.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_πω_105"> As Oed. knows that Laius is dead, the tone of unconcern given by this colloquial use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔπω</foreign> (instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔποτἐ</foreign> is a skilful touch. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 402">Soph. El. 402</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΧΡ. σὺ δ’ οὐχὶ πείσει … ; ΕΛ. οὐ δῆτα· μήπω νοῦ τοσόνδ’ εἴην κενή</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hec. 1278">Eur. Hec. 1278</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μήπω μανείη Τυνδαρὶς τοσόνδε παῖς</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 12.270">Hom. Il. 12.270</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ οὔπω πάντες ὁμοῖοι | ἀνέρες ἐν πολέμῳ</quote> </cit>: cp. our (ironical) “I have <emph>yet</emph> to learn.” </gloss>

data.quote:
ΧΡ. σὺ δ’ οὐχὶ πείσει … ; ΕΛ. οὐ δῆτα· μήπω
									νοῦ τοσόνδ’ εἴην κενή
ἀλλ’ οὔπω πάντες ὁμοῖοι | ἀνέρες ἐν πολέμῳ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὺς_τινας_107"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">τούς</foreign> implies that the death <emph>had</emph> human authors; <foreign xml:lang="grc">τινας,</foreign> that they are <emph> unknown.</emph> So in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. The practice of the Laurentian MS. fluctuates. It gives the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ι</foreign> subscript here, in 623, 1457; <ref n="Soph. OC 611">Soph. OC 611</ref>;<ref n="Soph. Ant. 547">Soph. M.</title> 482, 29, <foreign xml:lang="grc">θνῄσκω, μιμνῃσκω. Δίδυμος</foreign> [;circ. 30 B.C.]; <foreign xml:lang="grc">χωρὶς τοῦ ι— … ἡ μέντοι παράδοσις ἔχει τὸ ι. —</foreign> </gloss>

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμποδών_128"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄν,</foreign> with <foreign xml:lang="grc">κακὸν</foreign>, not with <foreign xml:lang="grc"> εἶργε</foreign>, “what trouble (being) in your path?” Cp. 445 <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρὼν … ἐμποδὼν | ὀχλεῖς.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τυραννίδος_128">. Soph. conceives the Theban throne as having been vacant from the death of Laius—who left no heir—till the election of Oed. The abstract <foreign xml:lang="grc">τυραννίδος</foreign> suits the train of thought on which Oed. has already entered, —viz. that the crime was the work of a Theban faction )124( who wished to destroy, not the king merely, but the kingship. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Lib. 973">Aesch. Lib. 973</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵδεσθε χώρας τὴν διπλῆν τυραννίδα</quote> </cit> )Clytaemnestra and Aegisthus(. </gloss>

Sym. 182a">Plat. Sym. 182a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ περὶ τὸν ἔρωτα νόμος ἐν μὲν ταῖς ἄλλαις πόλεσι νοῆσαι ῥᾴδιος· ἁπλῶς γὰρ ὤρισται· ὁ δὲ ἐνθάδε καὶ ἐν Λακεδαίμονι ποικίλος.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 7.3">Hdt. 7.3</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόμαντις δὲ ἡ χρέουσα, κατάπερ ἐν Δελφοῖσι, καὶ οὐδὲν ποικιλώτερον,</quote> </cit> “the chief prophetess is she who gives the oracles, as at Delphi, and in no wise of darker speech.” </gloss>

Rh. 1.1.14</bibl> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Dem. 40.16">Dem. 40.16</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάλιν ἐξ ὑπαρχῆς λαγχάνουσί μοι δίκας.</quote> </cit> The phrase <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν τῇ τῆς ἐπιστήμης ὑπαρχῇ</foreign> occurs in the paraphrase by Themistius of Arist. <foreign xml:lang="grc">περὶ φυσικῆς ἀκροάσεως</foreign> 8. 3 )Berlin ed. vol. 1. 247 b 29(: elsewhere the word occurs only in <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ὑπαρχῆς.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 725">Soph. El. 725</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποστροφῆς</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑποστραφέντες</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 5.116">Hdt. 5.116</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ νέης</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.92">Thuc. 3.92</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ καινῆς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: πάλιν δ’ ὥσπερ ἐξ ὑπαρχῆς ἐπανίωμεν
πάλιν ἐξ ὑπαρχῆς λαγχάνουσί μοι δίκας.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὖθις_132">, as he had done in the case of the Sphinx's riddle: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὔτ_132"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ ἀφνῆ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπαξίως_133"> )which would usually have a genitive( implies the standard—worthily of his <emph>own godhead</emph>, or <emph>of the occasion</emph>— and is slightly stronger than </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀξίως_133">. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hec. 168">Eur. Hec. 168</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπωλέσατ’, ὠλέσατ’</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 181">Eur. Orest. 181</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">διοιχόμεθ’, οἰχόμεθ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 400">Eur. Alc. 400</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπάκουσον, ἄκουσον.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸ_134"> <emph>on behalf of</emph>, cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸ τῶνδε</foreign> 10, <ref n="Soph. OC 811">Soph. OC 811</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 8.8.4">Xen. Cyrop. 8.8.4</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴ τις … διακινδυνεύσειε πρὸ βασιλέως</quote> </cit>: 1. 6. 42 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀξιώσουσι σὲ πρὸ ἑαυτῶν βουλεύεσθαι.</foreign> Campb. reads <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς τοῦ θανόντος,</foreign> which here could mean only “<emph>at the instance of</emph> the dead.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρός</foreign> never = “on behalf of,” “for the sake of,” but sometimes “<emph>on the side of</emph>”: e.g. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.124">Hdt. 1.124</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποστάντες ἀπ’ ἐκείνου καὶ γενόμενοι πρὸς σέο,</quote> </cit> “ranged themselves on your side”: <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.75">Hdt. 1.75</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλπίσας πρὸς ἑωυτοῦ τὸν χρησμὸν εἶναι,</quote> </cit> that the oracle was on his side: below, 1434, <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς σοῦ … φράσω,</foreign> I will speak on your side, —in your interest: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 479">Soph. Trach. 479</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τὸ πρὸς κείνου λέγειν,</quote> </cit> to state his side of the case also. </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀποστάντες ἀπ’ ἐκείνου καὶ γενόμενοι πρὸς
									σέο,
ἐλπίσας πρὸς ἑωυτοῦ τὸν χρησμὸν εἶναι,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπιστροφήν_134"> a turning round (<ref n="Soph. OC 1045">Soph. OC 1045</ref>), hence, attention, regard: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιστροφὴν τίθεσθαι</foreign> )like <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">σπουδήν, πρόνοιαν τίθ.,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 13">Soph. Aj. 13</bibl> </cit>, 536( = <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιστρέφεσθαί )τινος(,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 599">Soph. Phil. 599</bibl> </cit> .<cit> <bibl n="Dem. 23.136">Dem. 23.136</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐπεστράφη</quote> </cit> “heeded not” = <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν ἐφρόντισε</quote> <bibl n="Dem. 23.135">Dem. 23.135</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπὲρ_οὐχὶ_137"> i.e. not merely in the cause of Laius, whose widow he has married. The arrangement of the words is designed to help a second meaning of which the speaker is unconscious: “in the cause of a friend who is <emph>not</emph> far off” )his own father(. The reference to Laius is confirmed by <foreign xml:lang="grc">κείνῳ προσαρκῶν</foreign> in 141. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὑτοῦ_138"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμαυτοῦ.</foreign> The reflexive <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὑτοῦ,</foreign> etc., is a pron. of the 1st pers. in <ref n="Soph. OC 966">Soph. OC 966</ref>,<ref n="Soph. El. 285">Soph. El. 285</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1132">Soph. Aj. 1132</ref>: of the n)d pers., in <ref n="Soph. OC 853">Soph. OC 853</ref>, 930, 1356, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 451">Soph. Trach. 451</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποσκεδῶ_138">, dispel, as a taint in the air: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 8.149">Hom. Od. 8.149</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκέδασον δ’ ἄπο κήδεα θυμοῦ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedo 77d">Plat. Phaedo 77d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ … ὁ ἄνεμος αὐτὴν )τὴν ψυχὴν( ἐκβαίνουσαν ἐκ τοῦ σώματος διαφυσᾷ καὶ διασκεδάννυσιν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
μὴ … ὁ ἄνεμος αὐτὴν )τὴν ψυχὴν( ἐκβαίνουσαν ἐκ
							τοῦ σώματος διαφυσᾷ καὶ διασκεδάννυσιν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκεῖνον_κτανών_139"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκεῖνον</foreign> has emphasis: cp. 820. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιαύτη_140"> referring to <foreign xml:lang="grc">κτανὼν,</foreign> implies <foreign xml:lang="grc">φονίᾳ</foreign>: on <foreign xml:lang="grc">τιμωρεῖν</foreign> see 107. The spectator thinks of the time when Oed. shall be blinded by his own hand. —For the double </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἂν_140"> cp. 339, 862, 1438. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παῖδες_142"> The king here, as the priest in 147, addresses <emph>all</emph> the suppliants. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄλλος</foreign> )144( is one of the king's attendants. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βάθρων_ἵστασθε_142"> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 417">Soph. Ant. 417</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χθονὸς … ἀείρας</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 630">Soph. Phil. 630</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νεὼς ἄγοντα.</quote> </cit> Prose would require a compound verb: <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Sym. 4.31">Xen. Sym. 4.31</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπανίστανται … θάκων.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄραντες_143"> .<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Supp. 481">Aesch. Supp. 481</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλάδους γε τούτους αἶψ’ ἐν ἀγκάλαις λαβὼν | βωμοὺς ἐπ’ ἄλλους δαιμόνων ἐγχωρίων | θές.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
κλάδους γε τούτους αἶψ’ ἐν ἀγκάλαις λαβὼν |
							βωμοὺς
									ἐπ’ ἄλλους δαιμόνων ἐγχωρίων | θές.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶν_δράσοντος_145"> to do everything = to leave nothing untried: for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς</foreign> cp. 97. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Apol. 39a">Plat. Apol. 39a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐάν τις τολμᾷ πᾶν ποιεῖν καὶ λέγειν.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Hell. 7.4.21">Xen. Hell. 7.4.21</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάντα ἐποίει ὅπως, εἰ δύναιτο, ἀπαγάγοι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἐάν τις τολμᾷ πᾶν ποιεῖν καὶ λέγειν.
πάντα ἐποίει ὅπως, εἰ δύναιτο, ἀπαγάγοι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐτυχεῖς_πεπτωκότες_145">: “fortunate,” if they succeed in their search for the murderer, who, as they now know, is in their land )110(: “ruined,” if they fail, since they will then rest under the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνήκεστον μίασμα</foreign> )98(. The unconscious speaker, in his last word, strikes the key-note of the destined <foreign xml:lang="grc">περιπέτεια.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦ_παῖδες_147"> see on 142. <foreign xml:lang="grc">—καὶ δεῦρ’ ἔβημεν,</foreign> we <emph> e'en</emph> came here: i.e. this was the motive of our coming in the first instance. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 380">Soph. Phil. 380</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπειδὴ καὶ λέγεις θρασυστομῶν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Lys. 12.29">Lys. 12.29</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παρὰ τοῦ ποτε καὶ λήψεσθε δίκην;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: παρὰ τοῦ ποτε καὶ λήψεσθε δίκην;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξαγγέλλεται_148">, proclaims on his own part )midd.(, of himself: i.e. promises unasked, <foreign xml:lang="lat">ultro pollicetur</foreign>. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1376">Soph. Aj. 1376</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγγέλλομαι … εἶναι φίλος,</quote> </cit> “I offer friendship.” Eur. has thus used <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξαγγ.</foreign> even where metre permitted the more usual <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπαγγέλλομαι</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Heraclid. 531">Eur. Heraclid. 531</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀξαγγέλλομαι | θνῄσκειν,</quote> </cit> I offer to die. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἅμα_149"> i.e. may the god, who has summoned us to put away our pollution, <emph>at the same time</emph> come among us as a healing presence. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φάτι_151"> of a god's utterance or oracle )1440(, a poet. equivalent for <foreign xml:lang="grc">φήμη</foreign>: cp. 310 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπ’ οἰωνῶν φάτιν.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Διὸς_151">, because Zeus speaks by the mouth of his son; <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 19">Aesch. Eum. 19</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Διὸς προφήτης δ’ ἐστὶ Λοξίας πατρός.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: Διὸς προφήτης δ’ ἐστὶ Λοξίας πατρός.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁδυεπὲς_151">, merely a general propitiatory epitnet: the Chorus have not yet heard whether the response is comforting or not. It is presently told to them by Oed. )242(. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 480">Soph. El. 480</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁδυπνόων … ὀνειράτων,</quote> </cit> dreams breathing comfort )from the gods(. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίς_ἔβας_151"> What art thou that hast come? i.e. in what spirit hast thou come? bringing us health or despair? </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τᾶς_πολυχρύσου_151">, “rich in gold,” with allusion to the costly <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἀναθήματα</foreign> dedicated at Delphi, and esp. to the treasury of the temple, in which gold and silver could be deposited, as in a bank, until required for use. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 9.404">Hom. Il. 9.404</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ὅσα … λαϊνος οὐδὸς ἀφήτορος ἐντὸς ἐέργει | Φοίβου Ἀπόλλωνος, Πυθοῖ ἐνὶ πετρηέσσῃ.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.121">Thuc. 1.121</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ναυτικόν τε ἀπὸ τῆς ὑπαρχούσης τε οὐσίας ἐξαρτυσόμεθα, καὶ ἀπὸ τῶν ἐν Δελφοῖς καὶ Ὀλυμπίᾳ χρημάτων.</quote> </cit> Athen. 233 F <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷ μὲν οὖν ἐν Δελφοῖς Ἀπόλλωνι τὸν πρότερον ἐν τῇ Λακεδαίμονι χρυσὸν καὶ ἀργυνον [;πρότερον</foreign> = before the time of Lysander]; <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱστοροῦσιν ἀνατεθῆναι.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Andr. 1093">Eur. Andr. 1093</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεοῦ | χρυσοῦ γέμοντα γύαλα</quote> </cit> )recesses(, <foreign xml:lang="grc">θησαυροὺς βροτῶν.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ion 54">Eur. Ion 54</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Δελφοί σφ’ ἔθεντο</quote> </cit> )the young Ion( <foreign xml:lang="grc">χρυσοφύλακα τοῦ θεοῦ, | ταμίαν τε πάντων.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 6">Pind. P. 6.8</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν πολυχρύσῳ Ἀπολλωνίᾳ … νάπᾳ</quote> </cit>) i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν Πυθοἷ.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐδ’ ὅσα … λαϊνος οὐδὸς ἀφήτορος ἐντὸς ἐέργει
									| Φοίβου Ἀπόλλωνος, Πυθοῖ ἐνὶ πετρηέσσῃ.

ναυτικόν τε ἀπὸ τῆς ὑπαρχούσης τε οὐσίας
							ἐξαρτυσόμεθα, καὶ ἀπὸ τῶν ἐν Δελφοῖς καὶ Ὀλυμπίᾳ χρημάτων.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Πυθῶνος_152"> <emph> from</emph> Pytho (Delphi): for the gen. see on 142 <foreign xml:lang="grc">βάθρων | ἵστασθε.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτέταμαι_153"> is interpreted by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φοβερὰν_πάλλων_153">, which is to be taken in close connection with it. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκτείνεσθαι</foreign> is not found elsewhere of <emph>mental tension</emph> )though <ref>Dion. Hal. Comp. Verb. 15</ref> ad fin. has <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ τῆς διανοίας ἔκτασις καὶ τὸ τοῦ δείματος ἀπροσδόκητον.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 1.3.11">Xen. Cyrop. 1.3.11</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕως παρατείναιμι τοῦτον, ὥσπερ οὗτος ἐμὲ παρατείνει ἀπὸ σοῦ κωλύων,</quote> </cit> —<emph>‘rack,’ ‘torture’</emph> him. But <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρατείνεσθαι,</foreign> when used <emph>figuratively,</emph> usually meant “to be worn out,” “fatigued to death”: e.g. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Lysis 204c">Plat. Lysis 204c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παραταθήσεται ὑπὸ σοῦ ἀκούων θαμὰ λέγοντος,</quote> </cit> <foreign xml:lang="lat">enecabitur,</foreign> he will be tired to death of hearing it. So <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 3.13.6">Xen. Mem. 3.13.6</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παρατέταμαι μακρὰν ὁδὸν πορευθείς.</quote> </cit> Triclinius explains here, “I am <emph>prostrated</emph> by dread”(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκπέπληγμαι, παρ’ ὅσον οἱ ἐκπλαγέντες ἔκτασιν σώματος καὶ ἀκινησίαν πάσχουσιν</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 585">Eur. Med. 585</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἓν γὰρ ἐκτενεῖ σ’ ἔπος)</quote> </cit>: so <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 858">Soph. Phil. 858</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκτέταται νύχιος</quote> </cit> (of a sleeper). But the context favours the other view. </gloss>

data.quote:
ἕως παρατείναιμι τοῦτον, ὥσπερ οὗτος ἐμὲ
							παρατείνει ἀπὸ σοῦ κωλύων,

παραταθήσεται ὑπὸ σοῦ ἀκούων θαμὰ
									λέγοντος,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάλλων_153"> transitive, governing <foreign xml:lang="grc">φρένα,</foreign> <emph>making my heart to shake</emph>; not intransitive, for <foreign xml:lang="grc">παλλόμενος,</foreign> with <foreign xml:lang="grc"> φρένα</foreign> as accus. of the part affected. An intransitive use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάλλω</foreign> in this figurative sense is not warranted by such instances as <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Lys. 1304">Aristoph. Lys. 1304</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κοῦφα πάλλων,</quote> </cit> “lightly leaping in the dance”: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. El. 435">Eur. El. 435</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπαλλε δελφίς (</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἐσκίρτἀ,</foreign> “the dolphin leaped”: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. El. 477">Eur. El. 477</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵπποι ἔπαλλον</quote> </cit> “quivered” (in death). Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 881">Aesch. PB 881</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κραδία φόβῳ φρένα λακτίζει</quote> </cit>: so, when the speaker is identified with the troubled spirit within him, we can say <foreign xml:lang="grc">φρένα πάλλω,</foreign> —where <foreign xml:lang="grc">φρένα</foreign> has a less distinctly physical sense than in <ref n="Aesch. PB 881">Aesch. PB 881</ref>, yet has physical associations which help to make the phrase less harsh. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Δάλιε_154"> The Delphian Apollo is also Delian—having passed, according to the Ionic legend, from his native Delos, through Attica, to Delphi (<ref n="Aesch. Eum. 9">Aesch. Eum. 9</ref>). A Boeotian legend claimed Tegyra as the birthplace of Apollo: Plut. <title>Pelop.</title> 16 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐνταῦθα μυθολογοῦσι τὸν θεὸν γενέσθαι, καὶ τὸ μὲν πλησίον ὄρος Δῆλος καλεῖται.</foreign> We can scarcely say, however, with Schneidewin that <foreign xml:lang="grc">Δάλιε</foreign> here “bewrays the Athenian,” when we remember that the Theban Pindar hails the Delphian Apollo as <foreign xml:lang="grc">Λύκιε καὶ Δάλου ἀνάσσων Φοῖβε</foreign> (<ref n="Pind. P. 1">Pind. P. 1.39</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰήιε_154"> (again in 1096), invoked with the cry <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰή</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 221">Soph. Trach. 221</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰὼ ἰὼ Παιάν.</quote> </cit> Soph. has the form <foreign xml:lang="grc">παιών, παιήων</foreign> as = “a healer” (not with ref. to Apollo), <ref n="Soph. Phil. 168">Soph. Phil. 168</ref>, 832. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁζόμενος_155"> (rt. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἁγ,</foreign> whence <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄγιος)</foreign> implies a <emph>religious</emph> fear: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 9.478">Hom. Od. 9.478</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σχέτλῑ, ἐπεὶ ξείνους οὐχ ἅζεο σῷ ἐνὶ οἴκῳ | ἐσθέμεναι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
σχέτλῑ, ἐπεὶ ξείνους οὐχ ἅζεο σῷ ἐνὶ οἴκῳ |
							ἐσθέμεναι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_χρέος_155">: “what thing thou wilt accomplish for me”: i.e., what expiation thou wilt prescribe, as the price of deliverance from the plague. Will the expiation be of a new kind(<foreign xml:lang="grc">νέον</foreign>)? Or will some ancient mode of atonement be called into use once more(<foreign xml:lang="grc">πάλιν</foreign>)?<foreign xml:lang="grc">πάλιν</foreign> recalls <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 154">Aesch. Ag. 154</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μίμνει γὰρ φοβερὰ παλίνορτος | οἰκονόμος δολία μνάμων μῆνις τεκνόποινος.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
μίμνει γὰρ φοβερὰ παλίνορτος | οἰκονόμος δολία
							μνάμων μῆνις τεκνόποινος.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νέον_155">, adjective with <foreign xml:lang="grc">χρέος</foreign>: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάλιν_156">, adverb with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξανύσεις. τί μοι νέον χρέος ἐξανύσεις; ἢ τί χρέος πάλιν ἐξανύσεις;</foreign> The <emph>doubling</emph> of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἤ</foreign> harshly co-ordinates <foreign xml:lang="grc">νέον</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάλιν,</foreign> as if one said <foreign xml:lang="grc">τίνας ἢ μαχομένους ἢ ἀμαχεὶ ἐνίκησαν;</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρέος_156"> here = <foreign xml:lang="grc">χρῆμα,</foreign> “matter” (implying importance): cp. <ref n="Aesch. Supp. 374">Aesch. Supp. 374</ref> (of a king) <foreign xml:lang="grc">χρέος | πᾶν ἐπικραίνεις</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 530">Eur. Her. 530</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί καινὸν ἦλθε τοῖσδε δώμασιν χρέος;</quote> </cit> Others take it as = “obligation” (cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 235">Soph. OC 235</ref>), but against this is </gloss>

data.quote: τί καινὸν ἦλθε τοῖσδε δώμασιν χρέος;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξανύσεις_156">, which could not mean either to “impose” or to “exact” it. Whitelaw renders, “what requirement thou wilt enact (by oracular voice),” finding this use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνύω</foreign> in <ref n="Soph. OC 454">Soph. OC 454</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 1178">Soph. Ant. 1178</ref>; but there (as below, 720) it has its normal sense, “fulfil.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περιτελλομέναις_ὥραις_156"> an epic phrase which <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 697">Aristoph. Birds 697</ref> also has. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 14.293">Hom. Od. 14.293</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὅτε δὴ μῆνές τε καὶ ἡμέραι ἐξετελεῦντο | ἂψ περιτελλομένου ἔτεος, καὶ ἐπήλυθον ὧραι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀλλ’ ὅτε δὴ μῆνές τε καὶ ἡμέραι ἐξετελεῦντο |
							ἂψ
									περιτελλομένου ἔτεος, καὶ ἐπήλυθον ὧραι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρυσέας_157"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> The answer (not yet known to them) sent by Apollo is personified as </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Φάμα_157">, a divine Voice, —“the daughter of golden hope,” because—whether favourable or not—it is the <emph>issue</emph> of that hope with which they had awaited the god's response. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεκλόμενος_159"> is followed in 164 by <foreign xml:lang="grc">προφάνητέ μοι</foreign> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὔχομαι προφανῆναι.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 686d">Plat. Laws 686d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποβλέψας γὰρ πρὸς τοῦτον τὸν στόλον οὗ πέρι διαλεγόμεθα ἔδοξέ μοι πάγκαλος … εἶναι.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 3.2.10">Antiph. 3.2.10</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπολυόμενος δὲ ὑπό τε τῆς ἀληθείας τῶν πραχθέντων ὑπό τε τοῦ νόμου καθ’ ὃν διώκεται, οὐδὲ τῶν ἐπιτηδευμάτων εἵνεκα δίκαιοι τοιούτων κακῶν ἀξιοῦσθαί ἐσμεν.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 8.8.10">Xen. Cyrop. 8.8.10</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦν δὲ αὐτοῖς νόμιμον … νομίζοντες.</quote> </cit> The repetition of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄμβροτ’</foreign> has provoked some weak and needless conjectures: see on 517. </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀποβλέψας γὰρ πρὸς τοῦτον τὸν στόλον οὗ πέρι
							διαλεγόμεθα ἔδοξέ μοι πάγκαλος … εἶναι.

ἀπολυόμενος δὲ ὑπό τε τῆς ἀληθείας τῶν
							πραχθέντων
									ὑπό τε τοῦ νόμου καθ’ ὃν διώκεται, οὐδὲ τῶν ἐπιτηδευμάτων εἵνεκα
							δίκαιοι τοιούτων κακῶν ἀξιοῦσθαί ἐσμεν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γαιάοχόν_160"> holding or guarding our land; so <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Supp. 816">Aesch. Supp. 816</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γαιάοχε παγκρατὲς Ζεῦ.</quote> </cit> In <ref n="Soph. OC 1072">Soph. OC 1072</ref> it is the Homeric epithet of Poseidon, “girdling the earth,” <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸν πόντιον γαιάοχον.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">Παλλὰς πολιοῦχος</quote> <bibl n="Aristoph. Kn. 581">Aristoph. Kn. 581</bibl> </cit> (<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολιάοχος</quote> <bibl n="Pind. O. 5">Pind. O. 5.10</bibl> </cit> ),<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολισσοῦχοι θεοί</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 69">Aesch. Seven 69</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κυκλόεντ_θρόνον_161"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">κυκλοέσσης ἀγορᾶς θρόνον</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 793">Soph. Ant. 793</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νεῖκος ἀνδρῶν ξύναιμον,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 993">Soph. Trach. 993</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ Κηναία κρηπὶς βωμῶν.</quote> </cit> “Round throne of the marketplace” means simply (I now think) “throne consisting of the round marketplace.” The sitting statue of Artemis is in the middle of the agora; hence the agora itself is poetically called her throne. The word <foreign xml:lang="grc">κύκλος</foreign> in connection with the Athenian agora, of which it perhaps denoted a special part; schol. <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Kn. 137">Aristoph. Kn. 137</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ δὲ κύκλος Ἀθήνησίν ἐστι καθάπερ μάκελλος, ἐκ τῆς κατασκευῆς</quote> </cit> (form) <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν προσηγορίαν λαβών. ἔνθα δὴ πιπράσκεται χωρὶς κρεῶν τὰ ἄλλα ὤνια, καὶ ἐξαιρέτως δὲ οἱ ἰχθύες.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 919">Eur. Orest. 919</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀλιγάκις ἄστυ κἀγορᾶς χραίνων κύκλον,</quote> </cit> “the circle of the agora,” i.e. “its bounds”: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.74">Thuc. 3.74</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰς οἰκίας τὰς ἐν κύκλῳ τῆς ἀγορᾶς,</quote> </cit> “all round” the agora. In <ref n="Hom. Il. 18.504">Hom. Il. 18.504</ref>, cited by Casaubon on <ref n="Thphr. Char. 2.4">Theophr. Char. 2.4</ref>,<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱερῷ ἐνὶ κύκλῳ</foreign> refers merely to the <foreign xml:lang="grc">γέροντες</foreign> in council. This is better than (1) “her round seat in the agora”— <foreign xml:lang="grc">κυκλόεντα</foreign> meaning that the pedestal of the statue was circular; (2) “her throne in the agora, round which <foreign xml:lang="grc">κύκλιοι χοροί</foreign> range themselves.” This last is impossible. </gloss>

data.quote:
ὁ δὲ κύκλος Ἀθήνησίν ἐστι καθάπερ μάκελλος, ἐκ
							τῆς
									κατασκευῆς
τὰς οἰκίας τὰς ἐν κύκλῳ τῆς ἀγορᾶς,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐκλέα_161">, alluding to Artemis <foreign xml:lang="grc">Εὔκλεια,</foreign> the vipgin goddess of Faip Fame, wopshirred esr. by Locpians and Boeotians: <cit> <bibl n="Plut. Arist. 20">Plut. Arist. 20</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βωμὸς γὰρ αὐτῇ καὶ ἄγαλμα παρὰ πᾶσαν ἀγορὰν ἵδρυται, καὶ προθύουσιν αἵ τε γαμούμεναι καὶ οἱ γαμοῦντες</quote> </cit>: also at Corinth, <ref n="Xen. Hell. 4.4.2">Xen. Hell. 4.4.2</ref>. Pausanias saw a temple of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἄρτεμις Εὔκλεια,</foreign> with a statue by Scopas, near the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Προιτίδες πύλαι</foreign> on the N.E. side of Thebes. Near it were statues of Apollo Boedromios and Hermes Agoraios. The latter suggests that the Agora of the Lower Town (which was deserted when Pausanias visited Thebes) may have been near. In mentioning the <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἀγορά,</foreign> Soph. may have been further influenced by the fact that Artemis was worshipped as <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἀγοραία</foreign>: thus in the altis at Olympia there was an <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἀρτεμίδος Ἀγοραίας βωμός</foreign> near that of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ζεὺς Ἀγοραῖος</foreign> (<ref n="Paus. 5.15.4">Paus. 5.15.4</ref>). </gloss>

data.quote:
βωμὸς γὰρ αὐτῇ καὶ ἄγαλμα παρὰ πᾶσαν ἀγορὰν
							ἵδρυται, καὶ προθύουσιν αἵ τε γαμούμεναι καὶ οἱ γαμοῦντες

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄτας_ὕπερ_165"> “<emph>on account of</emph> ruin” (i.e. “to avert it”): cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 932">Soph. Ant. 932</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλαύμαθ’ ὑπάρξει βραδυτῆτος ὕπερ.</quote> </cit> So <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 111">Aesch. Seven 111</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴδετε παρθένων ἱκέσιον λόχον δουλοσύνας ὕπερ,</quote> </cit> “to avert slavery.” Cp. 187. </gloss>

data.quote:
ἴδετε παρθένων ἱκέσιον λόχον δουλοσύνας
									ὕπερ,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀρνυμένας_πόλει_165">: the dat. (poet.) as after verbs of <emph>attacking</emph>, e.g. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιέναι, ἐπιτίθεσθαι.</foreign> Musgrave's conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπερορνυμένας πόλει</foreign> (the compound nowhere occurs) has been adopted by some editors. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἠνύσατ_ἐκτοπίαν_166"> <emph> made</emph> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκτοπίαν,</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξωρίσατε,</foreign> a rare use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνύω</foreign> like <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποιεῖν, καθιστάναι, ἀποδεικνύναι</foreign>: for the ordinary use, cp. 720 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκεῖνον ἤνυσεν | φονέα γενέσθαι,</foreign> <emph>effected that</emph> he should become. In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1178">Soph. Ant. 1178</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὔπος ὡς ἄρ’ ὀρθὸν ἤνυσας,</quote> </cit> the sense is not ‘made right,’ but ‘<emph>brought</emph> duly <emph>to pass</emph>.’</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔλθετε_νῦν_166">, an echo of <foreign xml:lang="grc">προφάνητέ μοι, προτέρας</foreign> having suggested <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ νῦν</foreign>: as in 338 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἐμὲ ψέγεις</foreign> repeats <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀργὴν ἐμέμψω τὴν ἐμήν.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧ_πόποι_167"> is merely a cry like <foreign xml:lang="grc">παπαῖ</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 853">Soph. Trach. 853</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κέχυται νόσος, ὦ πόποι, οἷον, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: κέχυται νόσος, ὦ πόποι, οἷον, κ.τ.λ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στόλος_170"> like <foreign xml:lang="grc">στρατός</foreign> (<ref n="Pind. P. 2">Pind. P. 2.46</ref>, etc.), = <foreign xml:lang="grc">λαός.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔνι_170"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔνεστι,</foreign> is available. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φροντίδος_ἔγχος_170"> not, a weapon <emph>consisting in</emph> a device, but a weapon <emph>discovered by</emph> human wit, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔγχος ᾧ τις ἀλέξεται</foreign> being a bold equivalent for <foreign xml:lang="grc">μηχανὴ ἀλεξητηρία.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόκοισιν_172"> <emph> by</emph> births. Women are released from travail, not by the birth of living children, but either by death before delivery, or by still births. See on 26, and cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hes. WD 244">Hes. WD 244</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲ γυναῖκες τίκτουσιν.</quote> </cit> If <foreign xml:lang="grc">τόκοισιν</foreign>= “<emph>in</emph> child-bed” (and so the schol., <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν τοῖς τόκοις</foreign>), the meaning would be simply, “women die in child-bed,” —not necessarily “before child-birth”; but the point here is the blight on the fruits of earth and womb, —not merely the mortality among women. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλον_ἄλλῳ_175"> “one <emph>after</emph> another.” The dative here seems to depend mainly on the notion of adding implied by the iteration itself; though it is probable that the neighbourhood of <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρός</foreign> in <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσίδοις</foreign> may have been felt as softening the boldness. That <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσορᾶν</foreign> could be used as = “to see <emph>in addition</emph>”is inconceivable; nor could such use be justified by that of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐνορᾶν τινι</foreign> as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁρᾶν ἔν τινι.</foreign> And no one, I think, would be disposed to plead lyric license for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄλλῳ πρὸς ἴδοις</foreign> on the strength of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀκτὰν πρὸς ἑσπέρου θεοῦ</foreign> in 177. Clearly there was a tendency (at least in poetry) to use the dative thus, though the <emph>verb</emph> of the context generally either (a) helps the sense of “adding,” or (b) leaves an alternative. Under (a) I should put <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 235">Soph. El. 235</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίκτειν ἄταν ἄταις</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hel. 195">Eur. Hel. 195</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δάκρυα δάκρυσί μοι φέρων.</quote> </cit> Under (b), <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 1257">Eur. Orest. 1257</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πήματα πήμασιν ἐξεύρῃ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 1496">Eur. Phoen. 1496</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φόνῳ φόνος | Οἰδιπόδα δόμον ὤλεσε</quote> </cit>: where the datives <emph>might</emph> be instrumental. On the whole, I forbear to recommend <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄλλον δ’ ἂν ἄλλᾳ προσίδοις,</foreign> though easy and tempting; cp. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 2.4">Thuc. 2.4</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλλοι δὲ ἄλλῃ τῆς πόλεως σποράδην ἀπώλλυντο.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἄλλοι δὲ ἄλλῃ τῆς πόλεως σποράδην
									ἀπώλλυντο.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄρμενον_176"> aor. part. (<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 2.571">Hom. Il. 2.571</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοῦρα … ὄρμενα πρόσσω</quote> </cit>), “sped,” “hurried,” since the life is quickly gone. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρεῖσσον_πυρὸς_176">, because the <foreign xml:lang="grc">πυρφόρος λοιμός</foreign> drives all before it. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀκτὰν_πρὸς_177"> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ἀκτάν,</foreign> since the attributive gen. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἑσπέρου θεοῦ</foreign> is equiv. to an adj. agreeing with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀκτάν</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 84">Soph. OC 84</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕδρας | πρώτων ἐφ’ ὑμῶν,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 126">Soph. OC 126</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλσος ἐς … κορᾶν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 14">Soph. El. 14</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοσόνδ’ ἐς ἥβης</quote> </cit>: so <ref n="Aesch. PB 653">Aesch. PB 653</ref>,<ref n="Aesch. Seven 185">Aesch. Seven 185</ref>:<ref n="Eur. Orest. 94">Eur. Orest. 94</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑσπέρου_θεοῦ_177">: as the Homeric Erebos is in the region of sunset and gloom (<ref n="Hom. Od. 12.81">Hom. Od. 12.81</ref>), and Hades is <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐννυχίων ἄναξ</quote> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1559">Soph. OC 1559</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧν_ἀνάριθμος_179"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὧν,</foreign> masc., referring to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄλλον … ἄλλῳ,</foreign> — “to such (deaths) knowing no limit”: cp. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάριθμος θρήνων</quote> <bibl n="Soph. El. 232">Soph. El. 232</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηνῶν | ἀνήριθμος</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 602">Soph. Aj. 602</bibl> </cit>. An adj. formed with <foreign xml:lang="grc">α</foreign> privative, whether from noun or from verb, constantly takes a gen. in poetry: see on 190(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄχαλκος</foreign>),885(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀφόβητος</foreign>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γένεθλα_180"> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">πόλεως</foreign>), “her sons”: cp. 1424 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ θνητῶν γένεθλα,</foreign> the sons of men. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νηλέα_180">, unpitied; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνοίκτως_180">, without <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶκτος,</foreign> lament, made for them: they receive neither <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταφή</foreign> nor <foreign xml:lang="grc">θρῆνος.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 2.50">Thuc. 2.50</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλῶν ἀτάφων γιγνομένων</quote> </cit> (in the plague, 430 B.C.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_δ_181"> cp. on 27. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔπι_181">, adv.: <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 7.65">Hdt. 7.65</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τόξα δὲ καλάμινα εἶχον, … ἐπὶ δέ, σίδηρον</quote> </cit>(v. l. <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐ος) ἦν.</foreign> But <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔπι</foreign> =<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπεστι,</quote> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 1.515">Hom. Il. 1.515</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

data.quote:
τόξα δὲ καλάμινα εἶχον, … ἐπὶ δέ,
									σίδηρον

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀκτὰν_βώμιον_182"> “at the steps of the altars”: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Lib. 722">Aesch. Lib. 722</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκτὴ χώματος,</quote> </cit> the edge of the mound: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 984">Eur. Her. 984</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφὶ βωμίαν | ἔπτηξε κρηπῖδ’,</quote> </cit> at the base of the altar. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλοθεν_ἄλλαν_182"> (with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιστενάχουσι</foreign>), because the sounds are heard from various quarters. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱκτῆρες_185"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λυγρῶν_πόνων_185">, entreating on account of (for release from) their woes, causal gen.: cp. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλγεῖν τύχης,</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 571">Aesch. Ag. 571</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λάμπει_186"> 473 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔλαμψε … φάμα</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 104">Aesch. Seven 104</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κτύπον δέδορκα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅμαυλος_186">, i.e. heard at the same time, though not <foreign xml:lang="grc">σύμφωνος</foreign> with it. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧν_ὕπερ_188"> see on 165. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐῶπα_ἀλκάν_188"> cp. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγανὴ σαίνουσ’ | ἐλπίς,</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 101">Aesch. Ag. 101</bibl> </cit> (where Weil <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">προφανεῖσ’), ἱλαρὸν φέγγος</quote> <bibl n="Aristoph. Frogs 455">Aristoph. Frogs 455</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἄρεά_τε_190"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> The acc. and infin. <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἄρεα … νωτίσαι</foreign> depend on <foreign xml:lang="grc">δός</foreign> or the like, suggested by the preceding words. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 7.179">Hom. Il. 7.179</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ζεῦ πάπερ, ἢ Αἴαντα λαχεῖν ἢ Τυδέος υἱόν</quote> </cit> (grant that). <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 253">Aesch. Seven 253</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεοὶ πολῖται, μή με δουλείας τυχεῖν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: Ζεῦ πάπερ, ἢ Αἴαντα λαχεῖν ἢ Τυδέος υἱόν
θεοὶ πολῖται, μή με δουλείας τυχεῖν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαλερόν_190">, raging: cp. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">μαλεροῦ πυρός</quote> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 9.242">Hom. Il. 9.242</bibl> </cit> :<foreign xml:lang="grc">μαλερῶν … λεόντων</foreign> <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 141">Aesch. Ag. 141</ref>. Ares is for Soph. not merely the <emph>war-god</emph>, but generally <foreign xml:lang="grc"> βροτολοιγός,</foreign> <emph>the Destroyer</emph>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 706">Soph. Aj. 706</ref>. Here he is identified with the fiery plague. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄχαλκος_ἀσπίδων_190"> (cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 36">Soph. El. 36</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄσκευον ἀσπίδων</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 324">Eur. Phoen. 324</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄπεπλος φαρέων</quote> </cit>): Ares comes not, indeed, as the god of <emph>war</emph> (<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ χαλκοβόας Ἄρης,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1046">Soph. OC 1046</bibl> </cit>), yet shrieks of the dying surround him with a cry(<foreign xml:lang="grc">βοή</foreign>) as of battle. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περιβόατον_191"> could not mean “crying loudly”: the prose use (“famous” or “notorious” <ref n="Thuc. 6.31">Thuc. 6.31</ref>) confirms the pass. sense here. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀντιάζω_191">, attacking: <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 4.80">Hdt. 4.80</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠντίασάν μιν</quote> </cit> (acc.) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἱ Θρήϊκες.</foreign> Aesch. has the word once only, as = “to meet” (not in a hostile sense), <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 1557">Aesch. Ag. 1557</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πατέρ’ ἀντιάσασα</quote> </cit>: Eur. always as = “to entreat”; and so <ref n="Soph. El. 1009">Soph. El. 1009</ref>. Dindorf reads <foreign xml:lang="grc">φλέγει με περιβόατον</foreign> (the accus. on his own conject.), <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀντιάζω</foreign> (suggested by Herm.), “I <emph>pray</emph> that” etc. But the received text gives a more vivid picture. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νωτίσαι_192"> to turn the back in flight (<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Andr. 1141">Eur. Andr. 1141</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς φυγὴν ἐνώτισαν),</quote> </cit> a poet. word used by Aesch. with acc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">πόντον,</foreign> to <emph>skim</emph> (<ref n="Aesch. Ag. 286">Aesch. Ag. 286</ref>), by <ref n="Eur. Phoen. 651">Eur. Phoen. 651</ref> (Dionysus) <foreign xml:lang="grc">κισσὸς ὃν … ἐνώτισεν</foreign> as = “to cover the back of.” </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δράμημα_192">, cognate acc.: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάτρας_192">, gen. after verb of parting from: see on <foreign xml:lang="grc">βάθρων,</foreign> 142. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔπουρον_194"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπουριζόμενον</foreign> (ironical). Lidd. and Scott s. v. refer to Clemens Alexandr. <title>Paed.</title> 130 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷ τῆς ἀληθείας πνεύματι ἔπουρος ἀρθείς,</foreign> “lifted <emph>on a prospering gale</emph> by the spirit of Truth.” So <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 815">Soph. Trach. 815</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὖρος ὀφθαλμῶν ἐμῶν | αὐτῇ γένοιτ’ ἄπωθεν ἑρπούσῃ καλῶς</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 467">Soph. Trach. 467</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλὰ ταῦτα μὲν | ῥείτω κατ’ οὖρον.</quote> </cit> <emph> Active</emph> in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 954">Soph. Trach. 954</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπουρος ἑστιῶτις αὔρα</quote> </cit> (schol. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄνεμος οὔριος ἐπὶ τῆς οἰκίας),</foreign> “wafting,” The v.l. <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἄπουρον</foreign> would go with <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάτρας,</foreign> “<emph>away from</emph> the <emph>borders</emph> of my country” —from Ionic <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὖρος</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅρος,</foreign> like <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅμουρος</foreign> (<ref n="Hdt. 1.57">Hdt. 1.57</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">πρόσουρος</foreign>(<ref n="Soph. Phil. 691">Soph. Phil. 691</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">ξύνουρος</foreign> (<ref n="Aesch. Ag. 495">Aesch. Ag. 495</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc"> τηλουρός.</foreign> Pollux 6. 198 gives <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔξορος, ἐξόριος,</foreign> but we nowhere find an Ionic <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἄπουρος</foreign>: while for Attic writers <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄφορος</foreign> (from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅρος</foreign>) would have been awkward, since <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄφορος</foreign> “sterile” was in use. </gloss>

data.quote:
οὖρος ὀφθαλμῶν ἐμῶν | αὐτῇ γένοιτ’ ἄπωθεν
							ἑρπούσῃ
									καλῶς
ἀλλὰ ταῦτα μὲν | ῥείτω κατ’ οὖρον.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέγαν_Ἀμφιτρίτας_194">, the Atlantic. <foreign xml:lang="grc">θάλαμος Ἀμφιτρίτης</foreign> <emph> alone</emph> would be merely “the sea” (<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 3.91">Hom. Od. 3.91</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν πελάγει μετὰ κύμασιν Ἀμφιτρίτης),</quote> </cit> but </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέγαν_194"> helps to localise it, since the Atlantic(<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ ἔξω στηλέων θάλασσα ἡ Ἀτλαντὶς καλεομένη,</quote> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.202">Hdt. 1.202</bibl> </cit>) was esp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ μεγάλη θάλασσα.</foreign> Thus <ref>Polyb. 3.37</ref> calls the Mediterranean <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν καθ’ ἡμᾶς,</foreign>— the Atlantic, <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν ἔξω καὶ μεγάλην προσαγορευομένην.</foreign> In <ref n="Plat. Phaedo 109b">Plat. Phaedo 109b</ref> the limits of the known habitable world are described by the phrase, <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοὺς μέχρι τῶν Ἡρακλείων στηλῶν ἀπὸ Φάσιδος</foreign> (which flows into the Euxine on the E.), <ref n="Eur. Hipp. 3">Eur. Hipp. 3</ref>,<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅσοι τε πόντου</foreign> (the Euxine) <foreign xml:lang="grc">τερμόνων τ’ Ἀτλαντικῶν | ναίουσιν εἴσω</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 234">Eur. Her. 234</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥστ’ Ἀτλαντικῶν πέρα | φεύγειν ὅρων ἄν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἡ ἔξω στηλέων θάλασσα ἡ Ἀτλαντὶς
									καλεομένη,
ὥστ’ Ἀτλαντικῶν πέρα | φεύγειν ὅρων ἄν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπόξενον_196"> Aesch. has the word as = “estranged from”(<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">γῆς,</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 1282">Aesch. Ag. 1282</bibl> </cit>), cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀποξενοῦσθαι.</foreign> Here it means “<emph>away from</emph> strangers” in the sense of “keeping them at a distance.” Such compounds are usu. <emph>passive</emph> in sense: cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπόδειπνος</foreign> (Hesych., = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄδειπνος), ἀπόθεος, ἀπόμισθος, ἀπόσιτος, ἀπότιμος</foreign> (215), <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀποχρήματος.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπόξενος_ὅρμος_196">, the Euxine: an oxymoron, = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅρμος ἄνορμος,</foreign> as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 217">Soph. Phil. 217</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ναὸς ἄξενον ὄρμον.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Strab. 7.298">Strabo 7.298</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄπλουν γὰρ εἶναι τότε τὴν θάλατταν ταύτην καὶ καλεῖσθαι Ἄξενον διὰ τὸ δυσχείμερον καὶ τὴν ἀγριότητα τῶν περιοικούντων ἐθνῶν καὶ μάλιστα τῶν Σκυθικῶν, ξενοθυτούντων, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> The epithet <foreign xml:lang="grc">Θρῄκιον</foreign> here suggests the savage folk to whom Ares is <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγχίπτολις</foreign> on the W. coast of the Euxine (<ref n="Soph. Ant. 969">Soph. Ant. 969</ref>).<ref>Ovid Trist. 4.4.55</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">Frigida me cohibent Euxini litora Ponti: Dictus ab antiquis Axenus ille fuit.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἄπλουν γὰρ εἶναι τότε τὴν θάλατταν ταύτην καὶ
							καλεῖσθαι Ἄξενον διὰ τὸ δυσχείμερον καὶ τὴν ἀγριότητα τῶν
									περιοικούντων ἐθνῶν καὶ μάλιστα τῶν Σκυθικῶν, ξενοθυτούντων,
							κ.τ.λ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τελεῖν_ἔρχεται_198"> Reading <foreign xml:lang="grc">τελεῖν,</foreign> as Herm. suggested, instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">τέλει,</foreign> I construe thus: <foreign xml:lang="grc">—εἴ τι νύξ ἀφῇ, ἦμαρ ἐπέρχεται τελεῖν τοῦτο,</foreign> “If night omit anything (in the work of destruction), day comes after it to accomplish this.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τελεῖν_198"> is the infin. expressing purpose, as often after a verb of going or sending, where the fut. participle might have been used: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 7.208">Hdt. 7.208</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔπεμπε … κατάσκοπον ἱππέα, ἰδέσθαι</quote> </cit>[; =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀψόμενον</foreign>];<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁκόσοι τέ εἰσι, κ.τ.λ.·</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 6.50">Thuc. 6.50</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δέκα δὲ τῶν νεῶν προὔπεμψαν ἐς τὸν μέγαν λιμένα πλεῦσαί τε καὶ κατασκέψασθαι … καὶ κηρῦξαι.</quote> </cit> Here the <emph>pres.</emph> inf. is right, because the act is not single but repeated. Observe how strongly </gloss>

data.quote:
δέκα δὲ τῶν νεῶν προὔπεμψαν ἐς τὸν μέγαν
							λιμένα
									πλεῦσαί τε καὶ κατασκέψασθαι … καὶ κηρῦξαι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τελεῖν_198_2"> is supported by the position of the word (“To accomplish, —if night omit aught, —day follows”). No version of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τέλει_198"> explains this. The most tolerable is: —“<emph>In fulness</emph>— if night omit aught—day attacks(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπέρχεται</foreign>) this”: but I do not think that such a rendering can stand. See Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_ἀφῇ_198"> Cp. 874 <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ ὑπερπλησθῇ</foreign> (lyric): <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1443">Soph. OC 1443</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ στερηθῶ</quote> </cit> (dialogue): <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 710">Soph. Ant. 710</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κεἴ τις ᾖ</quote> </cit> (do.). In using <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ</foreign> with subjunct., the Attic poets were influenced by the epic usage, on which see Monro, <title>Homeric Grammar</title> sect. 292. The instances in classical prose are usu. doubtful, but in <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 6.21">Thuc. 6.21</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ ξυστῶσιν</quote> </cit> has good authority. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπ_ἔρχεται_199"> for the adverbial <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπί</foreign> separated from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔρχεται,</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1777">Soph. OC 1777</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδ’ ἐπὶ πλείω | θρῆνον ἐγείρετε.</quote> </cit> This is “tmesis” in the larger sense: tmesis proper is when the prep. is essential to the sense of the verb: <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 8.108">Hom. Il. 8.108</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔς ποτ’ ἀπ’ Αἰνείαν ἑλόμην</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὓς ἀφειλόμην Αἰνείαν</foreign>: cp. Monro <title>H. G.</title> sect. 176. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόν_200"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅν,</foreign> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἄρεα</foreign> (190). Cp. 1379 n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Λύκειε_203"> Apollo, properly the god of light(<foreign xml:lang="grc">λυκ</foreign>), whose image, like that of Artemis, was sometimes placed before houses (<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 637">Soph. El. 637</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Φοῖβε προστατήριε,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 449">Aesch. Seven 449</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προστατηρίας | Ἀρτέμιδος</quote> </cit>), so that the face should catch the first rays of the morning sun(<foreign xml:lang="grc">δαίμονες … ἀντήλιοι</foreign> <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 519">Aesch. Ag. 519</ref>): then, through <foreign xml:lang="grc">Λύκειος</foreign> being explained as <foreign xml:lang="grc">λυκοκτόνος</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. El. 7">Soph. El. 7</ref>), Apollo the <emph>Destroyer</emph> of foes: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 145">Aesch. Seven 145</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Λύκεῑ ἄναξ, Λύκειος γενοῦ | στρατῷ δαΐῳ.</quote> </cit> Cp. below, 919. </gloss>

data.quote: Λύκεῑ ἄναξ, Λύκειος γενοῦ | στρατῷ δαΐῳ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγκυλᾶν_204"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγκύλη,</foreign> a cord brought round on itself, a noose or loop, here = the <foreign xml:lang="grc">νευρά</foreign> of the <emph> bent</emph> bow. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγκύλων,</foreign> the reading of L and A, was taken by Eustath. 33.3 of the <emph>bow</emph> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἄγκυλα τόξἀ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνδατεῖσθαι_205"> pass., to be distributed, i.e. <emph>showered abroad</emph> on the hostile forces. The order of words, and the omission of <foreign xml:lang="grc">σέ,</foreign> are against making <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐνδατ.</foreign> midd., though elsewhere the pass. occurs only in <foreign xml:lang="grc">δέδασμαι</foreign>: Appian, however, has <foreign xml:lang="grc">γῆς διαδατουμένης</foreign> 1.1. It is possible that Soph. may have had in mind <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 18.263">Hom. Il. 18.263</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν πεδίῳ, ὅθι περ Τρῶες καὶ Ἀχαιοὶ | ἐν μέσῳ ἀμφότεροι μένος Ἄρηος δατέονται,</quote> </cit> “share the rage of war,” give and take blows. Others understand, “I would fain <emph>celebrate,</emph>”a sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἐνδατεῖσθαι</foreign> derived from that of <emph>distributing words</emph> <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">(λόγους ὀνειδιστῆρας ἐνδατούμενος,</quote> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 218">Eur. Her. 218</bibl> </cit>). The bad sense occurs in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 791">Soph. Trach. 791</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ δυσπάρευνον λέκτρον ἐνδατούμενος</quote> </cit>: the good, only in Aesch. fr. 340 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ δ’ ἐνδατεῖται τὰς ἑὰς εὐπαιδίας,</foreign> “celebrates his happy race of children.” </gloss>

data.quote:
ἐν πεδίῳ, ὅθι περ Τρῶες καὶ Ἀχαιοὶ | ἐν μέσῳ
							ἀμφότεροι μένος Ἄρηος δατέονται,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσταθέντα_206"> from <foreign xml:lang="grc">προΐστημι,</foreign> not <foreign xml:lang="grc">προστείνω.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 803">Soph. Aj. 803</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόστητ’ ἀναγκαίας τύχης.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 637">Soph. El. 637</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Φοῖβε προστατήριε.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OT 881">Soph. OT 881</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεὸν οὐ λήξω προστάταν ἴσχων.</quote> </cit> For 1st aor. pass. part., cp. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">κατασταθείς</quote> <bibl n="Lys. 24.9">Lys. 24.9</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">συσταθείς</quote> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 685c">Plat. Laws 685c</bibl> </cit>. The conject. <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσταλέντα</foreign> (as = “launched”) is improbable (1) because it would mean rather “having set out on a journey”; cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 20">Soph. OC 20</ref>: (2) on account of the metaphor in <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρωγά. προσταθέντα</foreign> from <foreign xml:lang="grc">προστείνω</foreign> (a verb which does not occur) would scarcely mean “directed against the enemy,” but rather “strained against the bowstring.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσταχθέντα,</foreign> found in one MS., would make <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρωγά</foreign> prosaic, while <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσταθέντα</foreign>— if not strictly suitable—is at least poetical: the difference is like that between speaking of “auxiliary forces” and of “champions.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἀρτέμιδος_αἴγλας_207"> the torches with which Artemis was represented, —holding one in each hand (<cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Frogs 1362">Aristoph. Frogs 1362</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">διπύρους ἀνέχουσα λαμπάδας</quote> </cit> ,<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 214">Soph. Trach. 214</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἄρτεμιν ἀμφίπυρον</quote> </cit>), —in her character of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Διϊλύκη, σελασφόρος, φωσφόρος, ἀνθήλιος,</foreign> —names marking her connection with Selene; cp. Aesch. fr. 164 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀστερωπὸν ὄμμα Λητῴας κόρης.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Λύκῑ_διᾴσσει_208"> as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐλαφηβόλος, ἀγροτέρα,</foreign> huntress: <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 6.102">Hom. Od. 6.102</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἵη δ’ Ἄρτεμις εἶσι κατ’ οὔρεος ἰοχέαιρα, | … τερπομένη κάπροισι καὶ ὠκείῃς ἐλάφοισιν· | τῇδέ θ’ ἅμα νύμφαι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
οἵη δ’ Ἄρτεμις εἶσι κατ’ οὔρεος ἰοχέαιρα, | …
							τερπομένη κάπροισι καὶ ὠκείῃς ἐλάφοισιν· | τῇδέ θ’ ἅμα
									νύμφαι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Λύκια_208">: the <emph>Lycian</emph> hills are named here in order to associate Artemis more closely with her brother under his like-sounding name of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Λύκειος.</foreign> At Troezen there was even a temple of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἄρτεμις Λυκεία</foreign>: Paus. says (2. 31. 4) that he could not learn why she was so called(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐς δὲ τὴν ἐπίκλησιν οὐδὲν εἶχον πυθέσθαι παρὰ τῶν ἐξηγητῶν</foreign>), and suggests that this may have been her title among the Amazons—a guess which touches the true point, viz. that the <foreign xml:lang="grc"> Λυκεία</foreign> was a feminine counterpart of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Λύκειος</foreign>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_χρυσομίτραν_209"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">μίτρα,</foreign> a snood: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ba. 831">Eur. Ba. 831</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΔΙ. κόμην μὲν ἐπὶ σῷ κρατὶ ταναὸν ἐκτενῶ. ΠΕΝΘΕΥΣ. τὸ δεύτερον δὲ σχῆμα τοῦ κόσμου τί μοι; ΔΙ. πέπλοι ποδήρεις· ἐπὶ κάρᾳ δ’ ἔσται μίτρα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ΔΙ. κόμην μὲν ἐπὶ σῷ κρατὶ ταναὸν ἐκτενῶ.
							ΠΕΝΘΕΥΣ.
									τὸ δεύτερον δὲ σχῆμα τοῦ κόσμου τί μοι; ΔΙ. πέπλοι ποδήρεις· ἐπὶ
							κάρᾳ δ’ ἔσται μίτρα.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τᾶσδ_γᾶς_210"> As he is <foreign xml:lang="grc">Βάκχος,</foreign> so is Thebes called <foreign xml:lang="grc">Βακχεία</foreign>(<ref n="Soph. Trach. 510">Soph. Trach. 510</ref>), while he, on the other hand, was <foreign xml:lang="grc">Καδμεΐας νύμφας ἄγαλμα</foreign> (1115). The <emph> mutual</emph> relation of the names is intended here by <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπώνυμον.</foreign> The word usually means <emph>called after</emph> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(τινός).</foreign> But <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄρχων ἐπώνυμος, ἥρωες ἐπώνυμοι</foreign> were those who <emph>gave</emph> names to the year, the tribes: and so <ref n="Soph. Aj. 574">Soph. Aj. 574</ref>(<foreign xml:lang="grc">σάκος) ἐπώνυμον,</foreign> the shield which <emph>gave</emph> its name to Eurysaces. Cp. <ref n="Eur. Ion 1555">Eur. Ion 1555</ref> where Athena says, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπώνυμος δὲ σῆς ἀφικόμην χθονός,</foreign> <emph>giving</emph> my name to thy land. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἰνῶπα_εὔιον_211"> “ruddy”—“to whom Bacchants cry <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὐοῖ.</foreign>” Note how in this passionate ode all bright colours(<foreign xml:lang="grc">χρυσέας, εὐῶπα, χρυσοστρόφων, αἴγλας, χρυσομίτραν, οἰνῶπα, ἀγλαῶπι</foreign>), and glad sounds(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰήιε Παιάν, εὔιον</foreign>), are contrasted with the baleful fires of pestilence and the shrieks of the dying. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Μαινάδων_ὁμόστολον_212"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">στελλόμενον ἅμα ταῖς Μαινάσιν,</foreign> setting forth, roaming with the Maenads: <ref n="Apollon. 2.802">Apoll. Rhod. 2. 802</ref> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁμόστολος ὑμὶν ἕπεσθαι.</foreign> The nymphs attendant on Dionysus, who nursed the infant god in Nysa, and afterwards escorted him in his wanderings, are called <foreign xml:lang="grc">Μαινάδες, θυιάδες, Βάκχαι.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 6.132">Hom. Il. 6.132</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μαινομένοιο Διωνύσοιο τιθήνας | σεῦε κατ’ ἠγάθεον Νυσήιον· αἱ δ’ ἅμα πᾶσαι | θύσθλα</quote> </cit>(i.e. thyrsi and torches) <foreign xml:lang="grc">χαμαὶ κατέχευαν.</foreign> Aesch. fr. 397 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάτερ θέοινε, Μαινάδων ζευκτήριε,</foreign> who bringest the Maenads under thy spell. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 22.460">Hom. Il. 22.460</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μεγάροιο διέσσυτο, μαινάδι ἴση, | παλλομένη κραδίην.</quote> </cit> <ref n="Catul. 63">Catull. 63.23</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">capita Maenades vi iaciunt hederigerae</foreign>: as Pind. fr. 224 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥιψαύχενι σὺν κλόνῳ.</foreign> Lucian may have had our passage in mind, when he mentions the <foreign xml:lang="grc">μίτρα</foreign> and the Maenads together: <cit> <bibl>Lucian Dial. D. 18</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θῆλυς οὕτω, … μίτρᾳ μὲν ἀναδεδεμένος τὴν κόμην, τὰ πολλὰ δὲ μαινομέναις ταῖς γυναιξὶ συνών.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
μαινομένοιο Διωνύσοιο τιθήνας | σεῦε κατ’
							ἠγάθεον
									Νυσήιον· αἱ δ’ ἅμα πᾶσαι | θύσθλα

μεγάροιο διέσσυτο, μαινάδι ἴση, | παλλομένη
							κραδίην.

θῆλυς οὕτω, … μίτρᾳ μὲν ἀναδεδεμένος τὴν
									κόμην, τὰ πολλὰ δὲ μαινομέναις ταῖς γυναιξὶ συνών.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγλαῶπι_214"> A cretic has been lost. G. Wolff's </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σύμμαχον_214"> is simple and appropriate. Arndt's conjecture, <foreign xml:lang="grc">δαΐᾳ</foreign> (“destroying, consuming,” prob. from rt. <foreign xml:lang="grc">δαv,</foreign> to kindle, Curt. <title>Etym.</title> sect. 258), is supported by the possibility of a corruption <foreign xml:lang="grc">ΔΑΙΔΙ</foreign> having been rejected as a gloss on <foreign xml:lang="grc">πεύκᾳ.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 9.347">Hom. Il. 9.347</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δήϊον πῦρ,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 222">Aesch. Seven 222</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πυρὶ δαΐῳ.</quote> </cit> But in connection with the “blithe torch” of Dionysus such an epithet is unsuitable. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ἀπότιμον_215"> See on <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπόξενον</foreign>196. Ares is “without honour” among the gentler gods: cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 5.31">Hom. Il. 5.31</ref> (Apollo speaks), <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἆρες, Ἄρες βροτολοιγέ, μιαιφόνε, τειχεσιπλῆτα</foreign>: and <ref n="Hom. Il. 5.890">Hom. Il. 5.890</ref> where Zeus says to Ares, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔχθιστός τέ μοι ἔσσι θεῶν, κ.τ.λ.</foreign> So the Erinyes are <foreign xml:lang="grc">στύγη θεῶν</foreign>(<ref n="Aesch. Eum. 644">Aesch. Eum. 644</ref>); and the house of Hades is hateful even to the gods (<ref n="Hom. Il. 20.65">Hom. Il. 20.65</ref> ). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεόν_215"> one syll., by synizesis: cp. 1519. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰτεῖς_216"> Oedipus had entered in time to hear the closing strains of that prayer for aid against the pestilence which the Chorus had been addressing to the gods. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἃ_αἰτεῖς_216">. The place of <foreign xml:lang="grc">λάβοις</foreign> is against taking <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλκὴν κἀνακούφισιν κακῶν</foreign> as in apposition with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἂ</foreign>: rather the construction changes, and <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἃ</foreign> is left as an accus. of general reference. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τἄμ_216"> emphatic by place: “you pray (to the gods): hear <emph>me</emph> and (with their help) you shall have your wish.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλύων_217"> not strictly = <foreign xml:lang="grc">πειθαρχῶν,</foreign> “obediently” (in which sense <foreign xml:lang="grc">κλύειν</foreign> takes <emph> gen.,</emph> <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἐν τέλει,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1352">Soph. Aj. 1352</bibl> </cit>), but simply, “on hearing them”: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δέχεσθαι_217">, as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1321">Soph. Phil. 1321</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κοὔτε σύμβουλον δέχει.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῇ_ὑπηρετεῖν_217">, =<foreign xml:lang="grc">θεραπεύειν τὴν νόσον,</foreign> to do that which the disease requires (for its cure), like <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑπηρετοίην τῷ παρόντι δαίμονι</quote> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1306">Soph. El. 1306</bibl> </cit>. In Eur. fr. 84, 7 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ αὖ πένεσθαι κἀξυπηρετεῖν τύχαις | οἷοί τε,</foreign> Nauck now gives with Athenaeus 413 C <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ ξυνηρετμεῖν.</foreign> Acc. to the commoner use of the word, the phrase would mean <emph>to humour</emph> the disease, i.e. obey morbid impulses: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 12.23">Lys. 12.23</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῇ ἑαυτοῦ παρανομίᾳ προθύμως ἐξυπηρετῶν,</quote> </cit> eagerly <emph>indulging the excess of</emph> his own lawlessness. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλκὴν_218"> as well as </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνακούφισιν_218">, with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακῶν_218"> :<cit> <bibl n="Hes. WD 199">Hes. WD 199</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κακοῦ δ’ οὐκ ἔσσεται ἀλκή</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 1322">Eur. Med. 1322</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρυμα πολεμίας χερός</quote> </cit>: below 1200 <foreign xml:lang="grc">θανάτων .. πύργος.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁγὼ_μὲν_219a">. Oedipus has just learned from Creon that Laius was believed to have been murdered by robbers on his way to Delphi, but that, owing to the troubles caused by the Sphinx, no effective search had been made at the time (114-131). He has at once resolved to take up the matter—both because Apollo enjoins it, and as a duty to the Theban throne (255). But the murder occurred before he had come to Thebes. He must therefore appeal for some clue — su/mbolon — to those who were at Thebes when the rumour was fresh. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξένος_219"> “a stranger” to the affair, is tinged with the notion, “unconnected with Thebes”: and this is brought out by <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀστὸς</foreign> in 222. For other explanations of the passage, see Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_πραχθέντος_220"> the murder. Not, “what was <emph>done</emph> at the time by way of search”: for (a) <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ πραχθέν,</foreign> as opp. to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ λόγος,</foreign> must mean the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔργον</foreign> to which the <foreign xml:lang="grc"> λόγος</foreign> is related: (b) Oed. has lately expressed his surprise that <emph>nothing</emph> effective was done (128), and could not, therefore, refer with such emphasis to <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ πραχθέν</foreign> in this sense. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_ἴχνευον_221"> In his <title>Syntax of the Moods and Tenses of the Greek Verb</title> (1889), sect. 511, Prof. Goodwin deals with this passage. His view agrees with that given in my second ed., so far as concerns two points, viz.: (1) that the chief protasis is not contained in <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ οὐκ ἔχων</foreign>: and (2) that <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ οὐκ ἔχων</foreign> is still necessarily conditional. But his analysis of the whole is simpler; it is as follows. The chief protasis is contained in the word <foreign xml:lang="grc"> αὐτός</foreign>, “unaided,” which is equivalent to, <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μόνος ἴχνευον,</foreign> <emph>if I were attempting to trace it alone</emph>. [;I had said that <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτός</foreign> “implies the protasis”; but had taken the protasis itself to be, <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ ἐξεῖπον,</foreign> supplied from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξερῶ</foreign> :<emph>if I had not thus spoken</emph>, —appealing to you for help.]; Then, <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ οὐκ ἔχων</foreign> is equivalent to <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ εἶχον.</foreign> Now, the difficulty here seemed to be that <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ εἶχον</foreign> would imply, “but I <emph>have</emph> a clue”: whereas, in fact, he has none. [;I met this by suggesting that <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ οὐκ ἔχων</foreign> expresses the fact (of his having no clue), not simply as a fact, but as a condition, —“<emph>in a case where</emph> I had no clue”; being equivalent, not to <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ εἶχον,</foreign> but rather to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅτε μὴ εἶχον.</foreign>]; Goodwin's answer is that the conditional sentence, written in full, would stand thus, —(1) and (2) denoting respectively the <emph>chief</emph> protasis, and the <emph> subordinate</emph> protasis: (1) <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μόνος ἴχνευον, οὐκ ἂν μακρὰν ἴχνευον,</foreign> (2) <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ εἶχόν τι σύμβολον.</foreign> Now (1) is an unreal supposition (he is <emph> not</emph> tracking alone); and that makes the whole supposition unreal. <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ εἶχον</foreign> is here a part of that unreal supposition; and therefore it can have that form, although, as a fact, he has no clue. (Suppose it to be said of a man too old for work: “If he were young, he would not be doing well, if he did not work”: <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ νέος ἦν, οὐκ ἂν εὖ ἐποίει, εἰ μὴ ἐπόνει.</foreign> The chief protasis, <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ νέος ἦν,</foreign> being unreal, makes all the rest unreal. The fact is, <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ πονεῖ</foreign>: and <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ ἐπόνει</foreign> does not imply, <foreign xml:lang="grc">πονεῖ.</foreign> Compressed, this would be, <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν εὖ ἐποίει νέος ὤν, μὴ οὐ πονῶν.</foreign> )</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτός_221">, unaided: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 13.729">Hom. Il. 13.729</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ οὔπως ἅμα πάντα δυνήσεαι αὐτὸς ἑλέσθαι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀλλ’ οὔπως ἅμα πάντα δυνήσεαι αὐτὸς
									ἑλέσθαι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νῦν_δ_222"> “but as it is”: i.e., “since it would be vain to attempt the search <emph> alone</emph>— since I came to Thebes only after the event.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὕστερος_222">, sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦ πραχθέντος</foreign>: for the adj. instead of an adv., cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 217">Soph. Aj. 217</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νύκτερος … ἀπελωβήθη</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 1.424">Hom. Il. 1.424</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χθιζὸς ἔβη</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 1.4.12">Xen. Anab. 1.4.12</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς προτέροις προτέροις<note>προτέροις=πρότερον</note> μετὰ Κύρου ἀναβᾶσι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: τοῖς προτέροις προτέροις  μετὰ Κύρου ἀναβᾶσι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_τελῶ_222"> ,<foreign xml:lang="lat">inter cives censeor:</foreign> a metaphor from being rated (for taxation) in a certain class: <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 6.108">Hdt. 6.108</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς Βοιωτοὺς τελέειν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ba. 822">Eur. Ba. 822</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς γυναῖκας ἐξ ἀνδρὸς τελῶ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀστὸς_ἀστοὺς_222">, like <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 267">Soph. Aj. 267</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κοινὸς ἐν κοινοῖσι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ba. 467">Eur. Ba. 467</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυμπεσὼν μόνος μόνοις</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 135">Soph. Phil. 135</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ξένᾳ ξένον</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ba. 633">Eur. Ba. 633</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴσος ὢν ἴσοις ἀνήρ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεἰ_ὑπεξελεῖν_227"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> is the reading of all the MSS.: for the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπεξελθὼν</foreign> of the first hand in one Milan MS. of the early 1t/h cent. (Ambros. L 39 sup., Campbell's M(2)) is a mere slip. I read </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπεξελεῖν_αὑτοῦ_227">, the change of <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸν</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸς</foreign> having necessarily followed that of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπεξελεῖν</foreign> into <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὑπεξελὼν</foreign> due to an interpretation which took the latter with <foreign xml:lang="grc">φοβεῖται</foreign>.
