Cp. <ref n="Thuc. 4.83">Thuc. 4.83</ref> (Arrhibaeus, the enemy of Perdiccas, makes overtures to Brasidas, and the Chalcidians exhort Brasidas to listen): <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐδίδασκον αὐτὸν μὴ ὑπεξελεῖν τῷ Περδίκκᾳ τὰ δεινά,</foreign> “they impressed upon him that he must not <emph>remove the dangers from the path of Perdiccas</emph>”— by repulsing the rival power of Arrhibaeus. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπεξελεῖν τὰ δεινά</foreign>= to take them <emph>away</emph> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκ</foreign>)<emph>from under</emph> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ὑπὄ</foreign> the feet, —from the path immediately before him: <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷ Περδίκκᾳ</foreign> being a dat. commodi. Similarly <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 7.8">Hdt. 7.8</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τούτων … ὑπεξαραιρημένων,</quote> </cit> “when these have been taken out of the way.” So here: <foreign xml:lang="grc">κεἰ μὲν φοβεῖται</foreign>,<emph>and if he is afraid</emph> (as knowing <emph>himself</emph> to be the culprit), <emph>then I bid him</emph> (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κελεύω_227"> continued from 226) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπεξελεῖν_ἐπίκλημα_227"> <emph>to take the peril of the charge out of his path</emph>,<foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸν καθ’ αὑτοῦ</foreign> <foreign xml:lang="grc"> (σημαίνοντἀ</foreign> <emph>by speaking against himself</emph>. If the culprit is denounced by another person, he will be liable to the extreme penalty. If he denounces himself, he will merely be banished. By denouncing himself, he forestalls the danger of being denounced by another. For other explanations, see Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀβλαβής_229"> the reading of A and most MSS., “without damage,” <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀζήμιος,</foreign> is far more suitable than <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀσφαλής</foreign> to this context: and Soph. has the word as a cretic in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 650">Soph. El. 650</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ζῶσαν ἀβλαβεῖ βίῳ.</quote> </cit> Although in L <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀσφαλής</foreign> appears as the older reading, so common a word was very likely to be intruded; while it would be difficult to explain how the comparatively rare <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀβλαβής</foreign> could have supplanted it. A metrical doubt may have first brought <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀσφαλής</foreign> in. Dindorf, reading <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀσφαλής,</foreign> recognises the superior fitness of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀβλαβής</foreign> here, and thinks that it may be the true reading, even though its appearance in the margin of L was due to conjecture. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλον_χθονὸς_230"> “another [;i.e. other than one of yourselves, the Thebans]; from a strange land”: an alien, whether resident at Thebes, or not: cp. 451 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὗτός ἐστιν ἐνθάδε, | ξένος λόγῳ μέτοικος.</foreign> The cases contemplated in the proclamation (223-235) are (1) a Theban denouncing another Theban, (2) a Theban denouncing himself, (3) a Theban denouncing an alien. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_κέρδος_231"> the (expected) gain, <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ μήνυτρα.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 191">Soph. Trach. 191</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως | πρὸς σοῦ τι κερδάναιμι καὶ κτῴμην χάριν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὅπως | πρὸς σοῦ τι κερδάναιμι καὶ κτῴμην
									χάριν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσκείσεται_232"> will be stored up <emph>besides</emph> (cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 1039">Eur. Alc. 1039</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλγος ἄλγει … προσκείμενον,</quote> </cit> <emph> added</emph>).<foreign xml:lang="grc">χάρις κεῖται</foreign> is perf. pass. of <foreign xml:lang="grc">χάριν τίθεμαι</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατατίθεμαι (τινί</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρὰ τινἴ,</foreign> —a metaphor from deposits of money: <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ χρήματα … κείσθω παρ’ οἷς τισιν ἃν ὑμῖν δοκῇ</foreign> <ref n="Plat. L. 7.346c">Plat. Letter 346c</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φίλου_αὑτοῦ_233"> with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπώσει</foreign> only (<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 15.503">Hom. Il. 15.503</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπώσασθαι κακὰ νηῶν</quote> </cit> ). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φίλου_δείσας_233"> as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">δείσας ὑπὲρ φίλου</foreign> (like <foreign xml:lang="grc">κήδομαι, φροντίζειν</foreign>) would be too harsh, and rhythm is against it. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὔπος_τόδε_233">, this command to give up the guilty. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπαυδῶ_236"> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπ‐,</foreign> because the first clauses are negative), I command,(<foreign xml:lang="grc">μή</foreign>)</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τινα_τῆσδε_236"> that no one belonging to this land, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μήτ_προσφωνεῖν_236"> shall either entertain or accost, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ἐστί_236">. For the gen. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γῆς_236">, cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Prot. 316b">Plat. Prot. 316b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἱπποκράτης ὅδε ἐστὶ μὲν τῶν ἐπιχωρίων, Ἀπολλοδώρου υἱός, οἰκίας μεγάλης καὶ εὐδαίμονος.</quote> </cit> Since </gloss>

data.quote:
Ἱπποκράτης ὅδε ἐστὶ μὲν τῶν ἐπιχωρίων,
							Ἀπολλοδώρου υἱός, οἰκίας μεγάλης καὶ εὐδαίμονος.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μήτε_μήτε_236"> in 238 connect </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐσδέχεσθαι_236"> and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσφωνεῖν_236">, we require either (a) separate verbs for </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐχαῖσι_236"> and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θύμασιν_236">, or (b) as Elms. proposed, <foreign xml:lang="grc">μηδὲ</foreign> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">μήτε</foreign> before </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θύμασιν_236_2">. Cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1297">Soph. OC 1297</ref>, where in a similar, though simpler, sentence I receive Hermann's <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔτ’.</foreign> Here, however, I hesitate to alter, because the very fact that <foreign xml:lang="grc">μήτε</foreign> has already been thrice used might so easily have prompted its use (instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">μηδέ</foreign>) before <foreign xml:lang="grc"> θύμασιν.</foreign> As the MS. text stands, we must suppose a <foreign xml:lang="grc">μήτε</foreign> suppressed before </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐχαῖσι_236_2">, the constr. being </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μήτε_ποιεῖσθαι_236"> [;<foreign xml:lang="grc">μήτε</foreign>];</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_θύμασιν_236">. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 532">Aesch. Ag. 532</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Πάρις γὰρ οὔτε συντελὴς πόλις</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Lib. 294">Aesch. Lib. 294</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δέχεσθαι δ’ οὔτε συλλύειν τινά.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοινὸν_240"> here = <foreign xml:lang="grc">κοινωνόν,</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 267">Soph. Aj. 267</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ κοινὸς ἐν κοινοῖσι λυπεῖσθαι ξυνών.</quote> </cit> <ref n="Plat. Laws 868e">Plat. Laws 868e</ref> (the slayer) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξυνέστιος αὐτοῖς μηδέποτε γιγνέσθω μηδὲ κοινωνὸς ἱερῶν.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: ἦ κοινὸς ἐν κοινοῖσι λυπεῖσθαι ξυνών.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χέρνιβος_240"> (partitive gen.) is more suitable than <foreign xml:lang="grc">χέρνιβας</foreign> to the idea of exclusion from all fellowship in ordinary worship: <foreign xml:lang="grc">χέρνιβας νέμειν</foreign> would rather suggest a special <foreign xml:lang="grc">κάθαρσις</foreign> of the homicide. When sacrifice was offered by the members of a household(<foreign xml:lang="grc">κοινωνὸν εἷναι χερνίβων … κτησίου βωμοῦ πέλας</foreign> <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1037">Aesch. Ag. 1037</ref>) or of a clan(<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">χέρνιψ φρατέρων</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 656">Aesch. Eum. 656</bibl> </cit>), a brand taken from the altar was dipped in water, and with the water thus consecrated(<foreign xml:lang="grc">χέρνιψ</foreign>) the company and the altar were sprinkled: then holy silence was enjoined(<foreign xml:lang="grc">εὐφημία ἔστω</foreign>): and the rite began by the strewing of barley meal(<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐλοχύται</foreign>) on altar and victim. (<ref>Athen. 409</ref>:<ref n="Eur. Her. 922">Eur. Her. 922 ff.</ref>) Acc. to <ref n="Dem. 20.158">Dem. 20.158</ref> a law of Draco prescribed <foreign xml:lang="grc">χέρνιβος</foreign> [;so the best MSS.: v. l. <foreign xml:lang="grc">χερνίβων]; εἴργεσθαι τὸν ἀνδροφόνον, σπονδῶν, κρατήρων, ἱερῶν, ἀγορᾶς.</foreign> This was a sentence of excommunication (1) from the life of the family and the clan, (2) from the worship common to all Hellenes, who, as opposed to <foreign xml:lang="grc">βάρβαροι,</foreign> are (<ref n="Aristoph. Lys. 1129">Aristoph. Lys. 1129</ref>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">οἳ μιᾶς ἐκ χέρνιβος | βωμοὺς περιρραίνοντες, ὥσπερ ξυγγενεῖς, | Ὀλυμπίασιν, ἐν Πύλαις, Πυθοῖ.</foreign> The mere presence of the guilty could render sacrifice inauspicious: <cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 5.82">Antiph. 5.82</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἱεροῖς παραστάντες πολλοὶ δὴ καταφανεῖς ἐγένοντο οὐχ ὅσιοι ὄντες καὶ διακωλύοντες τὰ ἱερὰ μὴ γίγνεσθαι</quote> </cit> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">bene succedere</foreign>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ νομιζόμενα.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἱεροῖς παραστάντες πολλοὶ δὴ καταφανεῖς
							ἐγένοντο
									οὐχ ὅσιοι ὄντες καὶ διακωλύοντες τὰ ἱερὰ μὴ γίγνεσθαι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὠθεῖν_δὲ_241"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐδῶ,</foreign> understood from the negative <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπαυδῶ</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 7.104">Hdt. 7.104</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐῶν φεύγειν … ἀλλὰ ἐπικρατέειν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατεύχομαι_246"> Suidas <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατεύχεσθαι· τὸ καταρᾶσθαι. οὕτω Πλάτων. καὶ Σοφοκλῆς, κατεύχομαι δὲ τὸν δεδρακότα τάδε.</foreign> Phot. <title>Lex.</title> p. 148. 7 <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατεύχεσθαι τῶν Ἀχαιῶν· ἀντὶ τοῦ κατὰ τῶν Ἀχαιῶν εὔχεσθαι. οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς.</foreign> Here the ref. is to Plato <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 393e">Plat. Rep. 393e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν δὲ</quote> </cit> (the Homeric Chryses, priest of Apollo) <foreign xml:lang="grc"> … κατεύχεσθαι τῶν Ἀχαιῶν πρὸς θεόν.</foreign> But Photius prefixes the words, <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατεύχεσθαι· τὸ καταρᾶσθαι. οὕτως Πλάτων.</foreign> It is clear, then, that in Photius <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὕτως Πλάτων</foreign> have changed places. The “Soph. fr. 894,” quoted by Lidd. and Scott under <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατεύχομαι</foreign> as= imprecari, thus vanishes (Nauck <title>Fragm. Trag. (2)</title> p. 357). Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 632">Aesch. Seven 632</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πόλει | οἵας ἀρᾶται καὶ κατεύχεται τύχας.</quote> </cit> But where, as here </gloss>

data.quote: πόλει | οἵας ἀρᾶται καὶ κατεύχεται τύχας.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατεύχομαι_246_2"> is used without gen. (or dat.), it is rather <emph>to pray solemnly</emph>: often, however, in a context which <emph>implies</emph> imprecation: e.g. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 935a">Plat. Laws 935a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κατεύχεσθαι ἀλλήλοις ἐπαρωμένους</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 394a">Plat. Rep. 394a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κατεύχετο τῖσαι τοὺς Ἀχαιοὺς τὰ ἂ δάκρυα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: κατεύχετο τῖσαι τοὺς Ἀχαιοὺς τὰ ἂ δάκρυα.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴτε_τις_246">: whether the unknown man (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τις_246">) who has escaped discovery is </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἷς_246">, alone in the crime, or one of several. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τις_246_2">, because the person is indefinite: cp. 107. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νιν_ἄμορον_248"> Porson (<title>praef. Hec.</title> p. ix.) defends the redundant </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νιν_248"> by <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 287">Soph. Trach. 287</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸν δ’ ἐκεῖνον, εὖτ’ ἂν ἁγνὰ θύματα | ῥέξῃ πατρῴῳ Ζηνὶ τῆς ἁλώσεως, | φρόνει νιν ὡς ἥξοντα.</quote> </cit> The form <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄμορος</foreign> occurs in <ref n="Eur. Med. 1395">Eur. Med. 1395</ref> (where <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄμοιρος</foreign> is a v. l.); <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἄμμορος</foreign> in <ref n="Eur. Hec. 421">Eur. Hec. 421</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Phil. 182">Soph. Phil. 182</ref>.</gloss>

data.quote:
αὐτὸν δ’ ἐκεῖνον, εὖτ’ ἂν ἁγνὰ θύματα | ῥέξῃ
							πατρῴῳ Ζηνὶ τῆς ἁλώσεως, | φρόνει νιν ὡς ἥξοντα.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακὸν_κακῶς_248"> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1369">Soph. Phil. 1369</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔα κακῶς αὐτοὺς ἀπόλλυσθαι κακούς.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Pl. 65">Aristoph. Pl. 65</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπό σ’ ὀλῶ κακὸν κακῶς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπεύχομαι_249"> imprecate on <emph>myself:</emph> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Criti. 120b">Plat. Criti. 120b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα ἐπευξάμενος ἕκαστος αὐτῶν αὑτῷ καὶ τῷ ἀφ’ αὑτοῦ γένει.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ταῦτα ἐπευξάμενος ἕκαστος αὐτῶν αὑτῷ καὶ τῷ
							ἀφ’
									αὑτοῦ γένει.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴκοισιν_ξυνέστιος_249">: not tautological, since <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξυνέστιος</foreign> is more than <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔνοικος,</foreign> implying admission to the family worship at the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἑστία</foreign> and to the <foreign xml:lang="grc">σπονδαί</foreign> at meals. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 868e">Plat. Laws 868e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἱερῶν μὴ κοινωνείτω μηδὲ … ξυνέστιος αὐτοῖς μηδέποτε γιγνέσθω μηδὲ κοινωνὸς ἱερῶν.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Euthyph. 4b">Plat. Euthyph. 4b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ εἰ μὲν ἐν δίκῃ [;ἔκτεινεν];, ἐᾶν,</quote> </cit> if he slew the man justly, forbear; <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ δὲ μή, ἐπεξιέναι</foreign> (prosecute the slayer), <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐάνπερ ὁ κτείνας συνέστιός σοι καὶ ὁμοτράπεζος ᾖ. ἴσον γὰρ τὸ μίασμα γίγνεται, ἐὰν ξυνῇς τῷ τοιούτῳ ξυνειδὼς καὶ μὴ ἀφοσιοῖς σεαυτόν τε καὶ ἐκεῖνον τῇ δίκῃ ἐπεξιών.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἱερῶν μὴ κοινωνείτω μηδὲ … ξυνέστιος αὐτοῖς
							μηδέποτε γιγνέσθω μηδὲ κοινωνὸς ἱερῶν.
καὶ εἰ μὲν ἐν δίκῃ [;ἔκτεινεν];, ἐᾶν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖσδ_251"> the slayer or slayers (247): see on 246. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀκάρπως_κἀθέως_254"> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1181">Soph. El. 1181</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ σῶμ’ ἀτίμως κἀθέως ἐφθαρμένον</quote> </cit>: below 661 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄθεος, ἄφιλος,</foreign> forsaken by gods and men. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰκὸς_ἦν_256"> The imperfect indic. of a verb denoting obligation(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔδει, χρῆν, προσῆκεν, εἰκὸς ἦν),</foreign> when joined <emph>without</emph> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄν</foreign> to an infinitive, often implies a conditional sentence with imperfect indic. in protasis and apodosis: e.g. <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ εἰκὸς ἦν ἐᾶν</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν εἰᾶτε (εἰ τὰ δέοντα ἐποιεῖτἐ,</foreign> you would not (now) be neglecting it (if you did your duty): <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 2.7.10">Xen. Mem. 2.7.10</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὲν τοίνυν αἰσχρόν τι ἔμελλον ἐργάσεσθαι</quote> </cit> [;if I were now intending—as I am not];, <foreign xml:lang="grc">θάνατον ἀντ’ αὐτοῦ προαιρετέον ἦν,</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">προῃρούμην ἂν (εἰ τὰ δέοντα ἐποίουν).</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 6.78">Thuc. 6.78</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ μάλιστα εἰκὸς ἦν ὑμᾶς … προορᾶσθαι,</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">προεωρᾶτε ἂν εἰ τὰ εἰκότα ἐποιεῖτε.</foreign> So <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐβουλόμην, ἠξίουν,</foreign> without <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄν,</foreign> of that which one wishes were true, but which is not so. </gloss>

data.quote:
εἰ μὲν τοίνυν αἰσχρόν τι ἔμελλον
									ἐργάσεσθαι

καὶ μάλιστα εἰκὸς ἦν ὑμᾶς …
									προορᾶσθαι,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὕτως_256"> in this (careless) manner: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1278">Soph. OC 1278</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς μή μ’ ἄτιμον … | οὕτως ἀφῇ με</quote> </cit> :<ref n="Soph. Ant. 315">Soph. Ant. 315</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Phil. 1067">Soph. Phil. 1067</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote: ὡς μή μ’ ἄτιμον … | οὕτως ἀφῇ με

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βασιλέως_τ_257"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">τε</foreign> is to be retained after <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασιλέως,</foreign> because (1) there is a climax, which is destroyed if <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασιλέως</foreign> stands merely in apposition with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρὸς ἀρίστου</foreign>: (2) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρὸς ἀρίστου</foreign> represents the claim of birth and personal merit, as <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασιλέως</foreign> represents the special claim of a king on his people. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1302">Soph. Phil. 1302</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρα πολέμιον | ἐχθρόν τε.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κυρῶ_ἐγὼ_258"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγώ τε κυρῶ,</foreign> answered by <foreign xml:lang="grc">κοινῶν τε, κ.τ.λ.</foreign> For <foreign xml:lang="grc">τε</foreign> so placed cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 249">Soph. El. 249</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρροι τ’ ἂν αἰδὼς | ἁπάντων τ’ εὐσέβεια θνατῶν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἔρροι τ’ ἂν αἰδὼς | ἁπάντων τ’ εὐσέβεια
									θνατῶν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμόσπορον_260"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁμοίως σπειρομένην,</foreign> i. e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἣν καὶ ἐκεῖνος ἔσπειρε</foreign>: but in 460 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πατρὸς | ὁμόσπορος</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀμοίως (τὴν αὐτὴν) σπείρων. ὁμογενής</foreign> in 1361 is not similar. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοινῶν_ἐκπεφυκότα_261"> common things <emph>of</emph> ( =<emph>ties</emph> consisting <emph>in</emph>) kindred children would have been generated: = <foreign xml:lang="grc">κοινῶν παίδων κοινὴ φύσις ἐγένετο ἄν,</foreign> a brood, common to Laius and Oedipus, of children akin to each other (as having the same mother, Iocasta) would have issued: “children born of one mother would have made ties between him and me.” For <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄν</foreign> doubled cp. 139, 339. </gloss>
lemma: κοινῶν παίδων κοινὰ ἦν ἂν ἐκπεφυκότα

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοινῶν_261"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀδελφῶν, ὁμαίμων</foreign>(<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1">Soph. Ant. 1</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ κοινὸν αὐτάδελφον Ἰσμήνης κάρα</quote> </cit>). The language of this passage is carefully framed so as to bear a second meaning, of which the speaker is unconscious, but which the spectators can feel: Iocasta has actually borne children to her own son Oedipus: thus in <foreign xml:lang="grc">κοινῶν παίδων κοινὰ … ἐκπεφυκότα,</foreign> the obvious sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc"> κοινά,</foreign> “<emph>common to Laius and Oedipus</emph>,” has behind it a second sense, in which it hints at a brood who are <emph>brothers and sisters of their own sire</emph>: see below 1403 f. This subtle emphasis—so ghastly, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξυνετοῖσιν</foreign>— of the iteration in <foreign xml:lang="grc">κοινῶν κοινά</foreign> must not be obliterated by amending <foreign xml:lang="grc">κοίν’ ἄν</foreign> into <foreign xml:lang="grc">κύματ’</foreign> (Nauck) or <foreign xml:lang="grc">σπέρματ’</foreign> (Blaydes). Similarly, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_δυστύχησεν_261">, is susceptible of the sense—“if his son (Oed. himself) had not been ill-fated.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">κείνῳ γένος ἐδυστύχησε</foreign> (his hope of issue was disappointed) is here a bold phrase for <foreign xml:lang="grc">κεῖνος ἐδυστύχησε τὰ περὶ γένος</foreign>: for Oed. is not <emph>now</emph> supposed to know the story of the exposed babe (see 717 f.). Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Andr. 418">Eur. Andr. 418</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾶσι δ’ ἀνθρώποις ἄρ’ ἦν | ψυχὴ τέκν’· ὅστις δ’ αὔτ’ ἄπειρος ὢν ψέγει, | ἦσσον μὲν ἀλγεῖ, δυστυχῶν δ’ εὐδαιμονεῖ</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Andr. 711">Eur. Andr. 711</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἣ στεῖρος οὖσα μόσχος οὐκ ἀνέξεται | τίκτοντας ἄλλους, οὐκ ἔχουσ’ αὐτὴ τέκνα· | ἀλλ’ εἰ τὸ κείνης δυστυχεῖ παίδων πέρι, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Supp. 66">Eur. Supp. 66</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐτεκνία</quote> </cit> opp. to <foreign xml:lang="grc">δυστυχία.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
πᾶσι δ’ ἀνθρώποις ἄρ’ ἦν | ψυχὴ τέκν’· ὅστις
							δ’
									αὔτ’ ἄπειρος ὢν ψέγει, | ἦσσον μὲν ἀλγεῖ, δυστυχῶν δ’
									εὐδαιμονεῖ

ἣ στεῖρος οὖσα μόσχος οὐκ ἀνέξεται | τίκτοντας
							ἄλλους, οὐκ ἔχουσ’ αὐτὴ τέκνα· | ἀλλ’ εἰ τὸ κείνης δυστυχεῖ παίδων
									πέρι, κ.τ.λ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νῦν_δ_263"> “but as it is,” with aor. equivalent to a <emph>perf.,</emph> as <ref n="Soph. OC 84">Soph. OC 84</ref>, 371. Cp. below 948 <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ νῦν ὅδε | πρὸς τῆς τύχης ὄλωλε.</foreign> So with <emph> historic</emph> pres., <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 12.36">Lys. 12.36</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὲν οὖν ἐν τῷ δικαστηρίῳ ἐκρίνοντο, ῥᾳδίως ἂν ἐσώζοντο· … νῦν δ’ εἰς τὴν βουλὴν εἰσάγουσιν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
εἰ μὲν οὖν ἐν τῷ δικαστηρίῳ ἐκρίνοντο, ῥᾳδίως
							ἂν
									ἐσώζοντο· … νῦν δ’ εἰς τὴν βουλὴν εἰσάγουσιν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνήλατο_263"> i.e. he was cut off by a timeless fate, leaving no issue, cp. 1300: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1345">Soph. Ant. 1345</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ κρατί μοι | πότμος … εἰσήλατο</quote> </cit>: so the Erinyes say, <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">μάλα γὰρ οὖν ἁλομένα | ἀνέκαθεν βαπυρεσῆ | καταφέπω ροδὸς ἀκμάν</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 369">Aesch. Eum. 369</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 1175">Aesch. Ag. 1175</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δαίμων ὑπερβαρὴς ἐμπίτνων</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Pers. 515">Aesch. Pers. 515</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ δυσπόνητε δαῖμον, ὡς ἄγαν βαρὺς | ποδοῖν ἐνήλλου παντὶ Περσικῷ γένει.</quote> </cit> The classical constr. with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐνάλλομαι,</foreign> as with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐνθρώσκω</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμπηδάω,</foreign> is usually the dat., though <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰς</foreign> with accus. occurs in later Greek; a point urged by Deventer in his objections to this verse, which is, however, clearly sound. </gloss>

data.quote:
μάλα γὰρ οὖν ἁλομένα | ἀνέκαθεν βαπυρεσῆ |
							καταφέπω ροδὸς ἀκμάν

ὦ δυσπόνητε δαῖμον, ὡς ἄγαν βαρὺς | ποδοῖν
							ἐνήλλου
									παντὶ Περσικῷ γένει.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνθ_ὧν_264"> properly <emph>wherefore</emph> (<ref n="Soph. OC 1295">Soph. OC 1295</ref>): here, <emph>therefore.</emph> The protasis <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπεὶ κυρῶ</foreign> (258) required an apodosis introduced by <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀντὶ τούτων</foreign>: but the parenthesis <foreign xml:lang="grc">νῦν δ’ ἐς τὸ κείνου κ.τ.λ.</foreign> (263) has led to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦν_264"> being irregularly substituted for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοὐτων.</foreign> Cp. 1466: <cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 5.11">Antiphon 5.11</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δέον σε διομόσασθαι κ.τ.λ. … ἃ σὺ παρελθών,</quote> </cit> where the length of the protasis has similarly caused <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἅ</foreign> to be substituted for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα.</foreign> Distinguish from this the use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνθ’ ὧν,</foreign> by ordinary attraction, for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀντὶ τούτων ἅ</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὅτι,</foreign>=<emph>because</emph>,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 1068">Soph. Ant. 1068</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote:
δέον σε διομόσασθαι κ.τ.λ. … ἃ σὺ
									παρελθών,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάδ_264"> cogn. acc. to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπερμαχοῦμαι_264"> as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1346">Soph. Aj. 1346</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ ταῦτ’ Ὀδυσσεῦ τοῦδ’ ὑπερμαχεῖς ἐμοί;</quote> </cit> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 5.185">Hom. Il. 5.185</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχ ὅ γ’ ἄνευθε θεοῦ τάδε μαίνεται.</quote> </cit> Brunck, Nauck and Blaydes adopt Mudge's conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc"> τοῦδ’.</foreign> But the MSS. agree in the harder and more elegant reading. </gloss>

data.quote: σὺ ταῦτ’ Ὀδυσσεῦ τοῦδ’ ὑπερμαχεῖς ἐμοί;
οὐχ ὅ γ’ ἄνευθε θεοῦ τάδε μαίνεται.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπερμαχοῦμαι_265"> only here: in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 194">Soph. Ant. 194</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1346">Soph. Aj. 1346</ref> Soph. uses <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπερμαχεῖν.</foreign> But we need not therefore, with Elms. and Blaydes, read <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπὲρ μαχοῦμαι.</foreign> The derivative form <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπερμαχέω,</foreign> to be a champion, implies <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπέρμαχος,</foreign> as <foreign xml:lang="grc">συμμαχέω</foreign> is from <foreign xml:lang="grc">σύμμαχος, προμαχέω</foreign> from <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρόμαχος· ὑπερμάχομαι</foreign> is a simple compound, like <foreign xml:lang="grc">συμμάχομαι</foreign> (Plat., Xen.), <foreign xml:lang="grc">προμάχομαι</foreign> (<title>Iliad</title>, Dio. Sic., Plut.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀπὶ_ἀφίξομαι_265"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζητῶν_265">, will leave nothing untried in seeking: a poetical variation of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ πᾶν ἐλθεῖν</foreign> (<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 3.1.18">Xen. Anab. 3.1.18</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἆρ’ οὐκ ἂν ἐπὶ πᾶν ἔλθοι … ὡς φόβον παράσχοι</quote> </cit>), as in <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 284">Eur. Hipp. 284</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς πάντ’ ἀφῖγμαι,</quote> </cit> “I have tried all means.” In prose <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀφικνεῖσθαι εἴς τι</foreign> usu. = to be <emph>brought</emph> to a situation, as <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 8.110">Hdt. 8.110</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς πᾶσαν βάσανον ἀπικνεομένοισι,</quote> </cit> though put to any torment; <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Euthyd. 292e">Plat. Euthyd. 292e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς πολλήν γε ἀπορίαν ἀφίκεσθε.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἆρ’ οὐκ ἂν ἐπὶ πᾶν ἔλθοι … ὡς φόβον
									παράσχοι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῷ_παιδὶ_267"> a dat. following <foreign xml:lang="grc">ζητῶν κ.τ.λ.</foreign> as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">τιμωρούμενος.</foreign> For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ΛαβδακείῳΠολυδώρου_267"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">τε</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 404">Eur. Med. 404</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς Σισυφείοις τοῖς τ’ Ἰάσονος γάμοις</quote> </cit>: for the adj., <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 3.190">Hom. Od. 3.190</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Φιλοκτήτην Ποιάντιον [;</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc"> Ποίαντος]; ἀγλαὸν υἱόν</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 7.105">Hdt. 7.105</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖς Μασκαμείοισι ἐκγόνοισι</quote> </cit> :<ref n="Soph. Phil. 1131">Soph. Phil. 1131</ref>:<ref n="Soph. Trach. 1219">Soph. Trach. 1219</ref>. Herodotus (<ref n="Hdt. 5.59">Hdt. 5.59</ref>) saw in the temple of the Ismenian Apollo at Thebes an inscription which he assigns to the age of Laius: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα ἡλικίην ἂν εἴη κατὰ Λάϊον τὸν Λαβδάκου τοῦ Πολυδώρου τοῦ Κάδμου.</foreign> Cadmus, in the myth, is the son of Agenor king of Phoenicia, whence Carthage is “Agenor's city” (<ref n="Verg. A. 1.338">Verg. Aen. 1.338</ref>): Polydorus, son of Cadmus and Harmonia, was king of Thebes. </gloss>

data.quote: τοῖς Σισυφείοις τοῖς τ’ Ἰάσονος γάμοις

Thes. 350</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῖς δ’ ἄλλαισιν ὑμῖν τοὺς θεοὺς | εὔχεσθε πάσαις πολλὰ δοῦναι κἀγαθά.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

Ag. 474</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μήτ’ εἴην πτολιπόρθης, | μήτ’ οὖν αὐτὸς ἁλούς, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 345">Soph. Phil. 345</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴτ’ ἀληθὲς εἴτ’ ἄρ’ οὖν μάτην</quote> </cit>: cp. above v. 90. But <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὖν</foreign> with the <emph> first</emph> clause, below, 1049: <ref n="Soph. El. 199">Soph. El. 199</ref>, 560: see on 25. </gloss>

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φθερεῖσθαι_272"> a fut. found also in <ref n="Eur. Andr. 708">Eur. Andr. 708</ref>(<foreign xml:lang="grc">φθερεῖ</foreign> 2 sing.): <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 7.48">Thuc. 7.48</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φθερεῖσθαι</quote> </cit>: Ionic <foreign xml:lang="grc">φθαρέομαι</foreign>:<ref n="Hdt. 9.42">Hdt. 9.42</ref>, 8. 108(<foreign xml:lang="grc"> φθαρήσομαι</foreign> in Hippocr., Arist., Plut.). The schol. says, <foreign xml:lang="grc">φθαρῆναι δεῖ γράφειν, οὐ φθερεῖσθαι,</foreign> distinguishing <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὔχομαι</foreign> with fut. infin., “I vow” (to do), from <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὔχομαι</foreign> with pres. or aor. infin., “I pray.” But verbs of wishing or praying sometimes take a fut. infin. instead of pres. or aor.: <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 6.57">Thuc. 6.57</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐβούλοντο … προτιμωρήσεσθαι</quote> </cit>: 6. 6 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐφιέμενοι μὲν … τῆς πάσης ἄρξειν</foreign>: 1. 27 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐδεήθησαν … ξυμπροπέμψειν</foreign>: 7. 56 <foreign xml:lang="grc">διενοοῦντο κλῄσειν.</foreign> See Goodwin, <title>Moods and Tenses</title> sect. 113 (new ed.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖς_ἄλλοισι_273"> The loyal, as opp. to <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἱ μὴ ταῦτα δρῶντες</foreign> (269). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔστ_ἀρέσκοντ_273"> cp. 126. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥ_Δίκη_273">, Justice who <emph>ever</emph> helps the righteous cause; Blaydes needlessly writes <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ Δίκη τε σύμμαχος.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1012">Soph. OC 1012</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλθεῖν ἀρωγοὺς συμμάχους τε (τὰς θεάς).</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὖ_275"> cf. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 229">Soph. Trach. 229</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ εὖ μὲν ἵγμεθ’, εὖ δὲ προσφωνούμεθα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἀλλ’ εὖ μὲν ἵγμεθ’, εὖ δὲ προσφωνούμεθα.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥσπερ_ἀραῖον_275"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> As you have brought me into your power under a curse [;if I speak not the truth];, <emph>so</emph> (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧδε_275">, i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔνορκος)</foreign> I will speak. <cit> <bibl n="Aeschin. 3.90">Aeschin. 3.90</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μίαν ἐλπίδα λοιπὴν κατεῖδε σωτηρίας, ἔνορκον λαβεῖν τὸν Ἀθηναίων δῆμον … βοηθήσειν,</quote> </cit> to <emph>bind them by an oath</emph> that they would help. <foreign xml:lang="grc">λαβεῖν</foreign> here has nearly the same force as in <foreign xml:lang="grc">λαβεῖν αἰχμάλωτον</foreign> etc.: <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 4.5">Lys. 4.5</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποχείριον λαβὼν τὸ σῶμα,</quote> </cit> having got his person into my power. </gloss>

data.quote:
μίαν ἐλπίδα λοιπὴν κατεῖδε σωτηρίας, ἔνορκον
							λαβεῖν τὸν Ἀθηναίων δῆμον … βοηθήσειν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀραῖον_275"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τῇ ἀρᾷ ἔνοχον,</foreign> cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅρκιος … λέγω</foreign> <ref n="Soph. Ant. 305">Soph. Ant. 305</ref>. The paraphrase of Eustath. 1809. 14 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὥσπερ με εἶλες διὰ τῆς ἀρᾶς</foreign> is substantially right. The use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">καταλαβεῖν</foreign> is not really similar (<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 9.106">Hdt. 9.106</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πίστι τε καταλαβόντες καὶ ὁρκίοισι,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 4.85">Thuc. 4.85</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅρκοις … καταλαβὼν τὰ τέλη</quote> </cit>), since the <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατά</foreign> in comp. gives the sense of <emph>overtaking,</emph> and so of <emph>binding.</emph> Nor can we compare <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 284">Soph. OC 284</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥσπερ ἔλαβες τὸν ἱκέτην ἐχέγγυον,</quote> </cit> where the sense is, “As thou hast <emph>received</emph> the (self-surrendered) suppliant under thy pledge.” </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γὰρ_277"> after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔκτανον_277"> merely prefaces the statement: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Prot. 320c">Plat. Prot. 320c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοκεῖ τοίνυν … μῦθον ὑμῖν λέγειν. ἦν γάρ ποτε κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
δοκεῖ τοίνυν … μῦθον ὑμῖν λέγειν. ἦν γάρ ποτε
							κ.τ.λ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεῖξαι_278"> “point to.” Note the emphatic place of the word: the speaker knows not that he is face to face with the slayer. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_ζήτημα_278">, acc. of general reference. The simpler form would have been, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦν τοῦ πέμψαντος τὸ ζήτημα καὶ λῦσαι</foreign>: but, instead of a verb which could govern <foreign xml:lang="grc">ζήτημα,</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόδ_εἰπεῖν_278"> is substituted, because it conveniently introduces the clause </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅστις_εἴργασται_278">, explaining what the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ζήτημα</foreign> itself was. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_ζήτημα_278_2"> is then left much as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἃ αἰτεῖς</foreign> is left in 216 when the insertion of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλκὴν κ.τ.λ.</foreign> has modified the construction. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἃν_θέλωσιν_281"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1368">Soph. Phil. 1368</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἄμ’ ἀναγκάζεις τόδε.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἃν_281"> as 580, 749: <ref n="Soph. OC 13">Soph. OC 13</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 1057">Soph. Ant. 1057</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Phil. 1276">Soph. Phil. 1276</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1085">Soph. Aj. 1085</ref>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδ_εἷς_281"> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 884">Soph. Ant. 884</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ἂν εἷς παύσαιτ’ ἄν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1656">Soph. OC 1656</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ἂν εἷς | θνητῶν φράσειε.</quote> </cit> In this emphatic form even a prep. could be inserted (<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Hell. 5.4.1">Xen. Hell. 5.4.1</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ὑφ’ ἑνός,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 4.1.14">Xen. Cyrop. 4.1.14</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲ πρὸς μίαν</quote> </cit>), and in prose <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲ εἷς</foreign> stood without elision: in <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 927">Aristoph. Frogs 927</ref> etc., where the MSS. have <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲ ἕν</foreign> (Dind. writes <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν), οὐδ’ ἂν ἕν</foreign> is a possible v. l. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_τῶνδε_282"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">μετὰ τάδε</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Dem. 18.313">Dem. 18.313</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγον ἐκ λόγου λέγων.</quote> </cit> —For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεύτερα_282">, second-<emph>best,</emph> cp. the proverb <foreign xml:lang="grc">δεύτερος πλοῦς</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 943c">Plat. Laws 943c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν τῶν ἀριστείων κρίσιν … καὶ τὴν τῶν δευτέρων καὶ τρίτων.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τὴν τῶν ἀριστείων κρίσιν … καὶ τὴν τῶν
									δευτέρων καὶ τρίτων.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἂν_λέγοιμι_282"> see on 95. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_οὐ_283"> not <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ μή,</foreign> because the sentence is negative: below, 1232: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 544">Soph. Ant. 544</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή μ’ ἀτιμάσῃς τὸ μὴ οὐ | θανεῖν.</quote> </cit> But even in such a negative sentence the simple <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ μή</foreign> occurs: below, 1388: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 443">Soph. Ant. 443</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote: μή μ’ ἀτιμάσῃς τὸ μὴ οὐ | θανεῖν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνακτ_284"> <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 11.151">Hom. Od. 11.151</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Τειρεσίαο ἄνακτος.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταὐτὰ_ὁρῶντα_284"> not = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταὐτὰ φρονοῦντα</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">γιγνώσκοντα,</foreign> “taking the same views,” but <emph>seeing in the same manner</emph>, i.e. with equal clearness: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁρῶντα_284"> absol., as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 74">Soph. OC 74</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅσ’ ἂν λέγοιμι, πάνθ’ ὁρῶντα λέξομαι</quote> </cit> :</gloss>

data.quote: ὅσ’ ἂν λέγοιμι, πάνθ’ ὁρῶντα λέξομαι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταὐτὰ_284"> adverbial = <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατὰ ταὐτά</foreign>: the dat. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνακτ_284_2"> as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1358">Soph. OC 1358</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν πόνῳ | ταὐτῷ βεβηκὼς … ἐμοί.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 4.119">Hdt. 4.119</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τωὐτὸ ἂν ὑμῖν ἐπρήσσομεν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_τοῦτο_287"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατέλιπον</foreign> would have meant, “I did not leave this among things neglected.” Soph. fuses the negative form with the positive, and instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατέλιπον</foreign> writes </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπραξάμην_287">: “I saw to this (midd.) in such a manner that it also should not be among things neglected.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">πράσσεσθαι</foreign> (midd.) elsewhere usu. = “to exact” (<ref n="Thuc. 4.65">Thuc. 4.65</ref> etc.): here = <foreign xml:lang="grc">διαπράσσεσθαι,</foreign> effect for oneself. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 45">Soph. Aj. 45</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξεπράξατο</quote> </cit> (effected his purpose). G. Wolff, sharing Kviecpala's objections to the phrase <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν ἀργοῖς πράσσεσθαι,</foreign> places a point after <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦτ’</foreign> (“but neither is this among things neglected: —I did it”). The extreme harshness of the asyndeton condemns this; and the suggested <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔπραξα μήν</foreign> is no remedy. For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_287"> cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐν ἐλαφρῷ ἐποιεύμην</foreign> (<ref n="Hdt. 1.118">Hdt. 1.118</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν εὐχερεῖ | ἔθου (ταῦτα</foreign>)<ref n="Soph. Phil. 875">Soph. Phil. 875</ref> ,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτ’ οὖν ἐν αἰσχρῷ θέμενος</quote> <bibl n="Eur. Hec. 806">Eur. Hec. 806</bibl> </cit> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀργοῖς_287">, not things <emph>undone,</emph> but things at which the work is sluggish or tardy; <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1605">Soph. OC 1605</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κοὐκ ἦν ἔτ’ οὐδὲν ἀργὸν ὧν ἐφίετο</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 776">Eur. Phoen. 776</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἓν δ’ ἐστὶν ἡμῖν ἀργόν, εἴ τι θέσφατον | οἰωνόμαντις Τειρεσίας ἔχει φράσαι,</quote> </cit> i.e. “in one thing our zeal has lagged, —the quest whether” etc.: Theognis however (583 Bergk 3rd ed.) has <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ μὲν προβέβηκεν ἀμήχανόν ἐστι γενέσθαι | ἀργά,</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀποίητα,</foreign> infecta. </gloss>

data.quote: κοὐκ ἦν ἔτ’ οὐδὲν ἀργὸν ὧν ἐφίετο

ἓν δ’ ἐστὶν ἡμῖν ἀργόν, εἴ τι θέσφατον |
							οἰωνόμαντις Τειρεσίας ἔχει φράσαι,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διπλοῦς_πομπούς_288"> he had sent two successive messages—one messenger with each. <foreign xml:lang="grc">πομπός</foreign> = one who is sent to escort(<foreign xml:lang="grc">πέμπειν</foreign>) or fetch a person (<ref n="Soph. OC 70">Soph. OC 70</ref>). The words could mean (as Ellendt takes them) “two sets of messengers”: but the other view is simpler, and consists equally well with <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἵδε</foreign> in 297. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_θαυμάζεται_289"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">θαυμάζω εἰ μὴ πάρεστι;</foreign> but with <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ,</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">θαυμάζω ὅτι οὐ πάρεστι</foreign>: differing nearly as “I wonder <emph>why</emph>”and “I wonder <emph>that.</emph>”<ref n="Xen. Anab. 4.4.15">Xen. Anab. 4.4.15</ref> (he spoke of) <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ μὴ ὄντα ὡς οὐκ ὄντα</foreign>: i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴ τι μὴ ἦν, ἔλεγεν ὅτι οὐκ ἦν.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τά_ἔπη_290"> the rumours which were current —<emph>apart from</emph> the knowledge which the seer may have to give us. Not “<emph>the other</emph> rumours.” Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedo 110e">Plat. Phaedo 110e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ λίθοις καὶ γῇ καὶ τοῖς ἄλλοις ζῴοις τε καὶ φυτοῖς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
καὶ λίθοις καὶ γῇ καὶ τοῖς ἄλλοις ζῴοις τε καὶ
							φυτοῖς.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κωφὰ_290">: the rumour has died down; it no longer gives a clear sound. Cp. fr. 604 <foreign xml:lang="grc">λήθην τε τὴν ἅπαντ’ ἀπεστερημένην, | κωφήν, ἄναυδον.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 911">Soph. Aj. 911</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ πάντα κωφός, ὁ πάντ’ ἄϊδρις,</quote> </cit> reft of all sense and wit. </gloss>

data.quote: ὁ πάντα κωφός, ὁ πάντ’ ἄϊδρις,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_ποῖα_291"> cp. 120. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁδοιπόρων_292"> the survivor had spoken of <foreign xml:lang="grc">λῃσταί,</foreign> 122. The word now used comes nearer to the truth (cp. 801 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁδοιπορῶν</foreign>); but, as the next v. shows, Oed. does not regard this rumour as a different one from that which Creon had mentioned. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ἰδόντ_293"> the surviving eyewitness: cp. 119 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὦν εἶδε, πλὴν ἕν κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Oed. has not yet learned that this witness could be produced: cp. vv. 754 ff. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰδόντα_293"> is better than the conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">δρῶντα</foreign> (1) as expressing, not merely that the culprit is unknown, but that no eyewitness of the deed is now at hand: (2) because, with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁρᾷ,</foreign> it has a certain ironical point, —expressing the king's incredulity as to anything being made of this clue. Cp. 105, 108. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔχει_294"> is the murderer, who is foremost in the thoughts of the Chorus, —not the eye-witness(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ ἰδών,</foreign> 293). The reversion from plural(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁδοιπόρων,</foreign> 292) to singular is unconscious, just as in 124 we have <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ λῃστής,</foreign> after <foreign xml:lang="grc">λῃστάς</foreign> in 122. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δείματός_γ_294"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">δεῖμα,</foreign> prop. “an object of fear,” is used by Herodotus and the poets as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">δέος</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 6.74">Hdt. 6.74</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Κλεομένεα … δεῖμα ἔλαβε Σπαρτιητέων</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Supp. 566">Aesch. Supp. 566</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χλωρῷ δείματι θυμὸν | πάλλοντ’</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Supp. 599">Eur. Supp. 599</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥς μοι ὑφ’ ἥπατι δεῖμα χλοερὸν ταράσσει</quote> </cit>: id. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 767">Soph. El. 767</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ δείματος,</quote> </cit> from fear. Cp. above, 153. The <foreign xml:lang="grc">γε</foreign> gives emphasis: the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀραί</foreign> of Oed. were enough to scare the boldest. Hartung conjectures <foreign xml:lang="grc">δειμάτων ἔχει μέρος.</foreign> The plur. <foreign xml:lang="grc">δείματα</foreign> means either (a) objects of fear, or (b) much more rarely, <emph>fears,</emph> with reference to <emph>some particular objects</emph> already specified: as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 636">Soph. El. 636</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δειμάτων ἃ νῦν ἔχω,</quote> </cit> “the terrors which I now suffer,” alluding to the <emph>dreams.</emph> Here we seem to need the sing., “fear.” </gloss>

data.quote: ὥς μοι ὑφ’ ἥπατι δεῖμα χλοερὸν ταράσσει

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰς_ἀράς_295"> thy curses: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιάσδε_295">, being such as they are. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὑξελέγξων_295"> The present <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὑξελέγχων</foreign> would mean, “there is one who convicts him”: i.e. the supposed criminal, whom threats scare not, is already detected; for the prophet has come. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 8.139">Isoc. 8.139</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥστ’ οὐκ ἀπορήσομεν μεθ’ ὧν κωλύσομεν τοὺς ἐξαμαρτάνοντας, ἀλλὰ πολλοὺς ἕξομεν τοὺς ἑτοίμως καὶ προθύμως συναγωνιζομένους ἡμῖν</quote> </cit>: where, however, the present part. <foreign xml:lang="grc">συναγωνιζομένους</foreign> is relative to the future <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἕξομεν.</foreign> To this it may be objected: (1) the <emph> present</emph> participle with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔστιν</foreign> would not be suitable unless the conviction were in act of taking place: (2) the fut. partic. not only suits the context better—“one <emph>to convict</emph> him” [;supposing he is here];—but also agrees with the regular idiom: e.g. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1242">Soph. Phil. 1242</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς ἕσται μ’ οὑπικωλύσων τάδε;</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1197">Soph. El. 1197</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ οὑπαρήξων οὐδ’ ὁ κωλύσων πάρα;</quote> </cit> (cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 261">Soph. Ant. 261</ref>:)<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 27">Aesch. PB 27</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ λωφήσων γὰρ οὐ πέφυκέ πω</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 2.4.5">Xen. Anab. 2.4.5</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ ἡγησόμενος οὐδεὶς ἔσται.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὥστ’ οὐκ ἀπορήσομεν μεθ’ ὧν κωλύσομεν τοὺς
							ἐξαμαρτάνοντας, ἀλλὰ πολλοὺς ἕξομεν τοὺς ἑτοίμως καὶ προθύμως
							συναγωνιζομένους ἡμῖν
οὐδ’ οὑπαρήξων οὐδ’ ὁ κωλύσων πάρα;
ὁ λωφήσων γὰρ οὐ πέφυκέ πω

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾧ_298"> this pron. ends a v. <ref n="Soph. OC 14">Soph. OC 14</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Trach. 819">Soph. Trach. 819</ref>,<ref n="Soph. El. 873">Soph. El. 873</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμπέφυκεν_299"> a divine gift of prophecy: <ref n="Hdt. 9.94">Hdt. 9.94</ref> (of the seer Evenius) <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ μετὰ ταῦτα αὐτίκα ἔμφυτον μαντικὴν εἶχε.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνθρώπων_μόνῳ_299"> above all other men: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 261">Soph. OC 261</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μόνας … | σώζειν οἵας τε κ.τ.λ.,</quote> </cit> Athens, above all other cities, can save: <cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 14.57">Isoc. 14.57</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀφείλετε δὲ μόνοι τῶν Ἑλλήνων τοῦτον τὸν ἔρανον,</quote> </cit> <foreign xml:lang="lat"> unice</foreign> (though others owe it also). </gloss>

data.quote:
ὀφείλετε δὲ μόνοι τῶν Ἑλλήνων τοῦτον τὸν
							ἔρανον,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦ_νωμῶν_300"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">νωμάω (νεμ)</foreign> means (1) to distribute, (2) to dispose, and so to wield, ply, (3) figuratively, to ponder, <foreign xml:lang="lat">animo versare</foreign>:<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνὶ φρεσὶ κέρδε’ ἐνώμας</quote> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 18.216">Hom. Od. 18.216</bibl> </cit> :<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ὠσὶ νωμῶν καὶ φρεσὶν πυρὸς δίχα | χρηστηρίους ὄρνιθας ἀψευδεῖ τέχνῃ</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 25">Aesch. Seven 25</bibl> </cit> (of Teiresias): (4) then, absolutely, to <emph>observe:</emph> <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 4.128">Hdt. 4.128</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νωμῶντες … σῖτα ἀναιρεομένους,</quote> </cit> observing the moment when they were cutting forage. Similarly here, —with the idea of mental grasp unaided by eyesight. Plato (<ref n="Plat. Crat. 411d">Plat. Crat. 411d</ref>) fancifully connects <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνώμη</foreign> with <foreign xml:lang="grc">νώμησις, —τὸ γὰρ νωμᾶν καὶ τὸ σκοπεῖν ταὐτόν.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἐν ὠσὶ νωμῶν καὶ φρεσὶν πυρὸς δίχα |
							χρηστηρίους
									ὄρνιθας ἀψευδεῖ τέχνῃ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διδακτά_τε_300"> cp. the colloquial <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥητὸν ἄρρητόν τ’ ἔπος</foreign>(<ref n="Soph. OC 1001">Soph. OC 1001</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">dicenda tacenda</foreign>):<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἄρρητα</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπόρρητα</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 6.135">Hdt. 6.135</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄρρητα ἱρὰ ἐκφήνασαν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐράνιά_χθονοστιβῆ_301"> not in apposition with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄρρητα</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">διδακτά</foreign> respectively, but both referring to each, lore that may or that may not be told, whether of the sky or of the earth. Dindorf cp. Nicephorus Gregoras <title>Hist. Byz.</title> 695d <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄκτιστα γενέσθαι πάντα τά τ’ οὐράνια τά τε χθονοστιβῆ καὶ ὑδραῖα γένη</foreign>: where, however, <foreign xml:lang="grc">χθονοστιβῆ</foreign> has its literal sense, —“walking the earth”: here it is poet. for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπίγεια,</foreign> “the lowly things of earth.” Cp. <cit> <bibl n="HH 29">HH 29.2</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀθανάτων τε θεῶν χαμαὶ ἐρχομένων τ’ ἀνθρώπων.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀθανάτων τε θεῶν χαμαὶ ἐρχομένων τ’
									ἀνθρώπων.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέν_302"> is not balanced by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρονεῖς_δ_302"> (as if we had <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ βλέπεις μέν</foreign>), but by the thought of the expected healer (310). The </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δὲ_302"> after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρονεῖς_302"> introduces the apodosis after a concessive protasis, as <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 8.22">Hdt. 8.22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δὲ ὑμῖν ἐστι τοῦτο μὴ δυνατὸν ποιῆσαι, ὑμέες δὲ</quote> </cit>(<emph>then</emph>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔτι καὶ νῦν ἐκ τοῦ μέσου ἡμῖν ἕζεσθε.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 5.5.21">Xen. Cyrop. 5.5.21</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ εἰ μηδὲ τοῦτο … βούλει ἀποκρίνασθαι, σὺ δὲ τοὐτεῦνθεν λέγε.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
εἰ δὲ ὑμῖν ἐστι τοῦτο μὴ δυνατὸν ποιῆσαι,
							ὑμέες
									δὲ

ἀλλ’ εἰ μηδὲ τοῦτο … βούλει ἀποκρίνασθαι, σὺ
									δὲ τοὐτεῦνθεν λέγε.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἧς_303"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">νόσου.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προστάτην_303"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">νόσου,</foreign> a protector from a plague: strictly, one who stands in front of, <emph>shields,</emph> the city's distempered state. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 803">Soph. Aj. 803</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόστητ’ ἀναγκαίας τύχης,</quote> </cit> <emph> shelter</emph> my hard fate. In <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Andr. 220">Eur. Andr. 220</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χείρον’ ἀρσένων νόσον | ταύτην νοσοῦμεν, ἀλλὰ προὔστημεν καλῶς,</quote> </cit> “we suffer this distemper more cruelly than men, but ever rule it well,” the idea is that of <emph>administering</emph> (not protecting), as in <foreign xml:lang="grc">προΐστασθαι τῆς ἡλικίας,</foreign> to regulate one's own early years, <ref n="Isoc. 15.290">Isoc. 15.290</ref>. Cp. 882. </gloss>

data.quote:
χείρον’ ἀρσένων νόσον | ταύτην νοσοῦμεν, ἀλλὰ
							προὔστημεν καλῶς,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μοῦνον_304"> this Ionic form (like <foreign xml:lang="grc">κοῦρος, δουρί, ξεῖνος, γούνατα</foreign>) is used in dialogue by Soph.: Aesch. has not <foreign xml:lang="grc">μοῦνος,</foreign> though in <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 804">Aesch. PB 804</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τόν τε μουνῶπα στρατόν.</quote> </cit> In <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Rh. 31">Eur. Rh. 31</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μόναρχοι</quote> </cit> is now restored for <foreign xml:lang="grc">μούναρχοι.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_κλύεις_305"> “if <emph>indeed … ,</emph>”implying that he probably <emph>has</emph> heard it. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1127">Soph. Aj. 1127</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεινόν γ’ εἶπας, εἰ καὶ ζῇς θανών.</quote> </cit> On <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ καί</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ εἰ</foreign> see Appendix. Others would render, “if you have not heard from the messengers <emph>also,</emph>”supposing it to be a hyperbaton for <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ κλύεις καὶ τῶν ἀγγέλων.</foreign> This is impossible. Prof. Campbell compares <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 5.45">Thuc. 5.45</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ἢν ἐς τὸν δῆμον ταῦτα λέγωσιν,</quote> </cit> as if put for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἢν καὶ ἐς τὸν δῆμον</foreign>: but there the passage runs thus; (Spartan envoys had been pleading with effect before the Athenian <foreign xml:lang="grc">Βουλή·) —τὸν Ἀλκιβιάδην ἐφόβουν μὴ καί, ἢν ἐς τὸν δῆμον ταὐτὰ λέγωσιν, ἐπαγάγωνται τὸ πλῆθος καὶ ἀπωσθῇ ἡ Ἀργείων συμμαχία</foreign>: where the <foreign xml:lang="grc">καί</foreign> before <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἤν</foreign> goes with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπαγάγωνται.</foreign> Some adopt the conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴ τι μή,</foreign> “unless <emph> perchance</emph>”: for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τι</foreign> so used, see below 969, <ref n="Soph. OC 1450">Soph. OC 1450</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Trach. 586, 712">Soph. Trach. 586, 712</ref>: but no change is required. —For the pres. <foreign xml:lang="grc">κλύεις,</foreign> cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 261">Soph. Phil. 261</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote: δεινόν γ’ εἶπας, εἰ καὶ ζῇς θανών.
καὶ ἢν ἐς τὸν δῆμον ταῦτα λέγωσιν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαθόντες_εὖ_308"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὖ</foreign> = “with care,” “aright”: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 18">Soph. Aj. 18</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπέγνως εὖ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 528">Soph. Aj. 528</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐὰν τὸ ταχθὲν εὖ τολμᾷ τελεῖν.</quote> </cit> Meineke's conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἢ,</foreign> adopted by Nauck, is weak, and against the rhythm. </gloss>

data.quote: ἐὰν τὸ ταχθὲν εὖ τολμᾷ τελεῖν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπ_φάτιν_310"> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπό,</foreign> see 43: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φάτιν_310">, 151. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλην_ὁδόν_310"> as divination by fire (see on 21), to which Teiresias resorts (<ref n="Soph. Ant. 1005">Soph. Ant. 1005</ref>) when the voice of birds fails him. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ῥῦσαι_σεαυτὸν_312"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ. ῥύεσθαί τι</foreign> is <emph>to draw a thing to oneself</emph>, and so <emph>to protect it</emph>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ῥῦσαι_μίασμα_312"> here = literally, “<emph>take the defilement under thy care</emph>”; i.e. “make it thy care to remove the defilement.” Cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρόστητ’ ἀναγκαίας τύχης</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 803">Soph. Aj. 803</ref>), shelter my hard fate, (instead of, “shelter me from it.”) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶν_μίασμα_312"> the <emph>whole</emph> defilement, as affecting not only human life but also the herds and flocks and the fruits of the earth: cp. 253. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_τεθνηκότος_312"> gen. of the source from which the <foreign xml:lang="grc">μίασμα</foreign> springs, —more pathetic than <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦ φόνου,</foreign> as reminding the hearer that vengeance is due for innocent blood. Both </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶν_312"> and the usual sense of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μίασμα_312"> forbid us to understand, “avenge the uncleanness [;i.e. the unpunished murder]; of the dead man.” For <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥῦσαι δὲ</foreign> Blaydes conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">λῦσον δὲ,</foreign> comparing <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 598">Eur. Orest. 598</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μίασμα λῦσαι.</quote> </cit> But the triple </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ῥῦσαι_312"> is essential to the force. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_σοὶ_314"> =<foreign xml:lang="lat">penes te</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 248">Soph. OC 248</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ὑμῖν ὡς θεῷ | κείμεθα τλάμονες</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 278">Eur. Alc. 278</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν σοὶ δ’ ἐσμὲν καὶ ζῆν καὶ μή.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἐν ὑμῖν ὡς θεῷ | κείμεθα τλάμονες
ἐν σοὶ δ’ ἐσμὲν καὶ ζῆν καὶ μή.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνδρα_314"> accus. before, not after, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὠφελεῖν_314">, as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 710">Soph. Ant. 710</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἄνδρα, κεἴ τις ᾖ σοφός, τὸ μανθάνειν | πόλλ’ αἰσχρὸν οὐδέν.</quote> </cit> In both places <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρα</foreign> has a certain stress—“for mortal man.” But in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1344">Soph. Aj. 1344</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνδρα δ’ οὐ δίκαιον, εἰ θάνοι, | βλάπτειν τὸν ἐσθλόν, ἄνδρα</quote> </cit> is the object, agreeing with <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἐσθλόν.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀλλ’ ἄνδρα, κεἴ τις ᾖ σοφός, τὸ μανθάνειν |
							πόλλ’
									αἰσχρὸν οὐδέν.

ἄνδρα δ’ οὐ δίκαιον, εἰ θάνοι, | βλάπτειν τὸν
							ἐσθλόν, ἄνδρα

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀφ_δύναιτο_314">, by means of all his <emph>resources</emph> and <emph>faculties.</emph> The optat. is thus used in universal statements, and therefore especially in <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνῶμαι</foreign>: cp. 979: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 666">Soph. Ant. 666</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὃν πόλις στήσειε, τοῦδε χρὴ κλύειν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.19">Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.19</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλὰ τοῦ μὲν αὐτὸν λέγειν, ἃ μὴ σαφῶς εἰδείη, φείδεσθαι δεῖ.</quote> </cit> So here we supply <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐστί</foreign> (not <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἂν εἴη</foreign>) with <foreign xml:lang="grc"> κάλλιστος.</foreign> The difference between <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀφ’ ὧν ἂν ἔχῃ</foreign> (“may have”), and <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔχοι</foreign> (“might have”), is that the latter form treats the “having” as an abstract hypothesis(<foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴ τι ἔχοι</foreign>). </gloss>

data.quote: ἀλλ’ ὃν πόλις στήσειε, τοῦδε χρὴ κλύειν

ἀλλὰ τοῦ μὲν αὐτὸν λέγειν, ἃ μὴ σαφῶς εἰδείη,
							φείδεσθαι δεῖ.

lemma: ἀφ’ ὦν ἔχοι τε καὶ δύναιτο

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λύῃ_317"> for subjunct. without <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄν,</foreign> cf. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 395">Soph. OC 395</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃς νέος πέσῃ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1074">Soph. Aj. 1074</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνθα μὴ καθεστήκῃ δέος</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 1008">Soph. Trach. 1008</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅ τι καὶ μύσῃ.</quote> </cit> The subjunct., <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔνθα μὴ λύῃ,</foreign>= “in a case where it may not profit”: the indic., <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔνθα μὴ λύει,</foreign> = “in a case where it does not profit.” The use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή,</foreign> whether with subjunct. or with indic., generalises the statement. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 839">Soph. OC 839</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ πίτασσ’ ἃ μὴ κρατεῖς</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1442">Soph. OC 1442</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ πεῖθ’ ἃ μὴ δεῖ.</quote> </cit> But L has <foreign xml:lang="grc">λύηι,</foreign> and some other MSS. have <foreign xml:lang="grc">λύη</foreign>: and it is much more likely that this should have become <foreign xml:lang="grc">λύει</foreign> than vice versa. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τέλη_λύῃ_317"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">λυσιτελῇ,</foreign> only here: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 627">Eur. Alc. 627</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φημὶ τοιούτους γάμους | λύειν βροτοῖς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταῦτα_γὰρ_317"> (I have to bewail this now), <emph>for,</emph> though I once knew it, I had forgotten it. Teiresias, twice summoned (288), had come reluctantly. Only now, in the presence of Oedipus, does he realise the full horror of the secret which he holds. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διώλεσ_318"> = let slip out of my memory; cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">σῴζεσθαι</foreign> to <emph>remember</emph>,<ref n="Soph. El. 993, 1257">Soph. El. 993, 1257</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Trach. 682">Soph. Trach. 682</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Theaet. 153b">Plat. Theaet. 153b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κτᾶταί τε μαθήματα καὶ σῴζεται</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 455b">Plat. Rep. 455b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἃ ἔμαθε, σῴζεται.</quote> </cit> So <ref>Teren. Phorm. 2.3.39</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">perii hercle: nomen perdidi,</foreign> “have forgotten.” —Some explain, “<emph> suppressed</emph> the thought.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_ἔστιν_319"> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 920">Soph. El. 920</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φεῦ τῆς ἀνοίας … ΧΡΥΣ. τί δ’ ἔστιν;</quote> </cit> and so often in Soph. (as 1144, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 339">Soph. Trach. 339</ref>,<ref n="Soph. El. 921">Soph. El. 921</ref>):<foreign xml:lang="grc">δέ</foreign> marking that the attention is turned to a new point, as in <foreign xml:lang="grc">τί δ’;</foreign> <foreign xml:lang="lat">quid vero?</foreign> (941), or to a new person: <cit> <bibl n="Isaeus 8.24">Isaeus 8.24</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ δὲ τίς εἶ;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: φεῦ τῆς ἀνοίας … ΧΡΥΣ. τί δ’ ἔστιν;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διοίσω_321"> bear to the end: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 1143">Eur. Hipp. 1143</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δάκρυσι διοίσω | πότμον ἄποτμον,</quote> </cit> <emph>live out</emph> joyless days: <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.11">Thuc. 1.11</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ ξυνεχῶς τὸν πόλεμον διέφερον. διαφέρειν</quote> </cit> could not mean “to bear <emph>apart</emph>”(from each other), though that is implied. </gloss>

data.quote: εἰ ξυνεχῶς τὸν πόλεμον διέφερον. διαφέρειν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πίθῃ_321">, i.e. obey me by letting me go home. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔτ_ἔννομ_322"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.·</foreign> not in conformity with usage, which entitled the State to benefit by the wisdom of its <foreign xml:lang="grc">μάντις.</foreign> The king's first remonstrances are gentle. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποστερῶν_323"> “withholding”: <cit> <bibl n="Aristot. Rh. 2.6.3">Aristot. Rh. 2.6.3</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποστερῆσαι παρακαταθήκην,</quote> </cit> depositum non reddere. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φάτιν_323"> of a divine message, 151. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁρῶ_γὰρ_324"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: (<emph>I</emph> do <emph>not</emph> speak), for I see that <emph>neither</emph> dost <emph>thou</emph> speak opportunely: (I am silent) therefore, lest I too should speak unseasonably. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_καιρόν_325"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">καιρίως,</foreign> as <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1279">Soph. Phil. 1279</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Trach. 59">Soph. Trach. 59</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_οὖν_325"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: “(I do not speak), then, in order that <emph>neither</emph> (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδέ_325">) may I share your mishap (of speaking amiss).” If he speaks not, <emph> neither</emph> will he speak wrongly. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 2.63">Thuc. 2.63</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰκὸς … μὴ φεύγειν τοὺς πόνους, ἢ μηδὲ τὰς τιμὰς διώκειν.</quote> </cit> I now prefer this view to taking </gloss>

data.quote:
εἰκὸς … μὴ φεύγειν τοὺς πόνους, ἢ μηδὲ τὰς
							τιμὰς διώκειν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδ_ἐγώ_325"> as irregular for <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ καὶ ἐγώ</foreign> (“lest I too … ”), —revolving <foreign xml:lang="grc">μηδέ</foreign> into <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή</foreign> <emph>not</emph>,<foreign xml:lang="grc"> δέ</foreign> <emph>on the other hand</emph>; though the place of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγώ</foreign> suggests this. Kviecpala's </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_λέγων_325"> is ingenious and attractive; it may, indeed, be right; but seems hardly necessary. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_θεῶν_326"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> The attribution of these two verses to the Chorus in some MSS. is probably due to the plur. in 327 having misled those who did not see that the king speaks for all Thebes. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρονῶν_γ_326"> if thou hast understanding (of this matter): cp. 569 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐφ’ οἷς γὰρ μὴ φρονῶ σιγᾶν φιλῶ</foreign>: not, “if thou art sane.” But in 328 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ φρονεῖτε</foreign>= “are without understanding,” “are senseless.” </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγὼ_κακά_328"> I will never reveal my (not to call them <emph>thy</emph>) griefs. </gloss>
lemma:
ἐγὼ δ’ οὐ μή ποτε ἐκφήνω τὰ ἐμὰ (ὡς ἂν μὴ
							εἴπω
									τὰ σἂ κακά

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_κακά_328">,= those secrets touching Oedipus which lie heavy on the prophet's soul: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_κακά_328_2">, those same secrets in their import for Oedipus. We might render <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἂν εἴπω μὴ τὰ σ’</foreign> either (i) as above, or (ii) “in order that I may not utter thy griefs.” But (i) is preferable for these reasons: —(1) The subjunct. <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴπω</foreign> with <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή</foreign> was familiar in such phrases. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 487d">Plat. Rep. 487d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς μὲν πλείστους καὶ πάνυ ἀλλοκότους γιγνομένους, ἵνα μὴ παμπονήρως εἴπωμεν,</quote> </cit> “becoming very strange persons, —not to use a more unqualified epithet”: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 507d">Plat. Rep. 507d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ἄλλαις πολλαῖς, ἵνα μὴ εἴπω ὅτι οὐδεμιᾷ, τοιούτου προσδεῖ οὐδενός,</quote> </cit> i.e. few, —not to say none: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Hipp. Min. 372d">Plat. Hippias Min. 372d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιοῦτός εἰμι οἷός πέρ εἰμι, ἵνα μηδὲν ἐμαυτὸν μεῖζον εἵπω,</quote> </cit>—to say nothing more of myself. The substitution of </gloss>

data.quote:
τοὺς μὲν πλείστους καὶ πάνυ ἀλλοκότους
							γιγνομένους, ἵνα μὴ παμπονήρως εἴπωμεν,

οὐδ’ ἄλλαις πολλαῖς, ἵνα μὴ εἴπω ὅτι οὐδεμιᾷ,
							τοιούτου προσδεῖ οὐδενός,

τοιοῦτός εἰμι οἷός πέρ εἰμι, ἵνα μηδὲν ἐμαυτὸν
							μεῖζον εἵπω,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἂν_328"> for the commoner <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἵνα</foreign> in no way alters the meaning. For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_μή_328">, cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Birds 1508">Aristoph. Birds 1508</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τουτὶ … τὸ σκιάδειον ὑπέρεχε | ἄνωθεν, ὡς ἂν μή μ’ ἴδωσιν οἱ θεοί.</quote> </cit> For </gloss>

data.quote:
τουτὶ … τὸ σκιάδειον ὑπέρεχε | ἄνωθεν, ὡς ἂν
									μή μ’ ἴδωσιν οἱ θεοί.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_μὴ_328"> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἂν μὴ εἴπω,</foreign> cp. 255, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 66">Soph. Phil. 66</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δ’ ἐργάσει | μὴ ταῦτα.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1365">Soph. OC 1365</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δ’ ἐξέφυσα τάσδε μὴ ’μαυτῷ τροφούς.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 7.214">Hdt. 7.214</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰδείη γὰρ ἂν καὶ ἐὼν μὴ Μηλιεὺς … τὴν ἀτραπόν.</quote> </cit> (2) The emphatic position of </gloss>

data.quote: εἰ δ’ ἐξέφυσα τάσδε μὴ ’μαυτῷ τροφούς.

εἰδείη γὰρ ἂν καὶ ἐὼν μὴ Μηλιεὺς … τὴν
									ἀτραπόν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τἄμ_328"> suits this version. (3) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκφήνω_328"> is more forcible than </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴπω_328">. If the meaning were, “I will not <emph>reveal</emph> my griefs, in order that I may not <emph>mention</emph> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴπω</foreign>) thy griefs,” the clauses would be ill-balanced. See Appendix, n. on vv. 328 f. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνειδὼς_330"> because <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκφήνω</foreign> implied that he knew. Cp. 704 <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸς ξυνειδώς, ἢ μαθὼν ἄλλου πάρα;</foreign> i.e. of his own knowledge, or on hearsay? Not, “being an accomplice” (as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 266">Soph. Ant. 266</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνειδέναι | τὸ πρᾶγμα βουλεύσαντι</quote> </cit>): Oed. can still control his rising anger. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγὼ_οὔτ_332"> synizesis. The rugged verse is perh. designed to express agitation. Cp. 1002 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ οὐχί</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 939">Soph. OC 939</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ οὔτ’ ἄνανδρον,</quote> </cit> 998 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ οὐδέ,</foreign> 1436 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τελεῖτ’, ἐπεὶ οὔ μοι</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 458">Soph. Ant. 458</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ οὐκ ἔμελλον</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1390">Soph. Phil. 1390</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ οὐκ Ἀτρείδας</quote> </cit> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταῦτ_332">, 29 n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέτρου_φύσιν_334"> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 1279">Eur. Med. 1279</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ τάλαιν’, ὡς ἄρ’ ἦσθα πέτρος ἢ σίδᾳρος.</quote> </cit> For the periphrasis cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedrus 251b">Plat. Phaedrus 251b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ τοῦ πτεροῦ φύσις,</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ πτερόν, πεφυκὸς ὥσπερ πέφυκε,</foreign> being constituted as it is: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Tim. 45b">Plat. Tim. 45b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν τῶν βλεφάρων φύσιν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Tim. 74d">Plat. Tim. 74d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν τῶν νεύρων φύσιν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Tim. 84c">Plat. Tim. 84c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ τοῦ μυελοῦ φύσις</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 145d">Plat. Laws 145d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν ὕδατος φύσιν.</quote> </cit> And so often in Arist., e.g. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ τοῦ πνεύματος φύσις</quote> <bibl n="Aristot. Meteo. 2.8">Aristot. Meteor. 2.8</bibl> </cit> :<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ τῶν νεύρων φύσις</quote> <bibl n="Aristot. HA 3.5">Aristot. Hist. An. 3.5</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

data.quote: ὦ τάλαιν’, ὡς ἄρ’ ἦσθα πέτρος ἢ σίδᾳρος.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποτέ_335"> tandem aliquando: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 816">Soph. Phil. 816</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μέθες ποτέ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1041">Soph. Phil. 1041</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίσασθ’ ἀλλὰ τῷ χρόνῳ ποτέ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀτελεύτητος_336"> not brought to an end: <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 4.175">Hom. Il. 4.175</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτελευτήτῳ ἐπὶ ἔργῳ.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl>Plut. Mor. 114f</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ γὰρ δὴ ἀτελεύτητον νομίζειν τὸ πένθος ἀνοίας ἐστὶν ἐσχάτης.</quote> </cit> Here, a man “with whom one cannot make an end,” —who cannot be brought to the desired issue. In freely rendering, “Wilt thou never make an end?” we remember, of course, that the adj. could not literally mean “not finishing.” Possibly it is borrowed from the colloquial vocabulary of the day: the tone is like that of the Latin <foreign xml:lang="lat"> odiosus</foreign>. </gloss>

data.quote:
τὸ γὰρ δὴ ἀτελεύτητον νομίζειν τὸ πένθος
							ἀνοίας
									ἐστὶν ἐσχάτης.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμέμψω_337"> aor. referring to the moment just past: so oft. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπῄνεσα, ξυνῆκα, ησθην· ἒπτηξα</foreign>(<ref n="Soph. OC 1466">Soph. OC 1466</ref>):<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἔφριξα</foreign>(<ref n="Soph. Aj. 693">Soph. Aj. 693</ref>):<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐδεξάμην</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. El. 668">Soph. El. 668</ref>):<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπέπτυσα</foreign> (<ref n="Eur. Hec. 1276">Eur. Hec. 1276</ref>).</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμοῦ_ναίουσαν_337">, while (or though) it dwells close to thee, —possesses and sways thee. So <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1134">Soph. OC 1134</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κηλὶς κακῶν ξύνοικος</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 784">Soph. El. 784</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βλάβη | ξύνοικος</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 639">Soph. Aj. 639</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">συντρόφοις | ὀργαῖς.</quote> </cit> But (as Eustathius saw, 755. 14) the words have a second meaning: “thou seest not that thine own <foreign xml:lang="grc">[;τὴν σήν,</foreign> thy kinswoman, thy mother]; is dwelling with thee [;as thy wife];.” The ambiguity of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὴν_σὴν_337">, the choice of the phrase </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμοῦ_ναίουσαν_337_2">, and the choice of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατεῖδες_337">, leave no doubt of this. Cp. 261. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_ψέγεις_338"> the thought of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀργὴν ἐμέμψω τὴν ἐμήν</foreign> returns upon itself, as if from a sense that the contrast between <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμέμψω</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατεῖδες</foreign> would be imperfectly felt without such an iteration. This is peculiarly Sophoclean; cp. above 166(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔλθετε καὶ νῦν</foreign>): Schneidewin cp. also <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1111">Soph. Aj. 1111</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ … τῆς σῆς οὕνεκ’ … | ἀλλ’ οὕνεχ’ ὅρκων … | σοῦ δ’ οὐδέν</quote> </cit>: and similarly <ref n="Soph. Ant. 465">Soph. Ant. 465 ff.</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Trach. 431">Soph. Trach. 431 ff.</ref>,<ref n="Soph. El. 361">Soph. El. 361 ff.</ref> </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐ … τῆς σῆς οὕνεκ’ … | ἀλλ’ οὕνεχ’
									ὅρκων … | σοῦ δ’ οὐδέν

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_339"> warrants the repeated </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἂν_339">: cp. 139: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 69">Soph. Ant. 69 ff.</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Andr. 934">Eur. Andr. 934</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν ἔν γ’ ἐμοῖς δόμοις | βλέπουσ’ ἂν αὐγὰς τἄμ’ ἐκαρποῦτ’ ἂν λέχη.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
