Aj. 1107</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ σέμν’ ἔπη | κόλαζ’ ἐκείνους</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 550">Soph. Ant. 550</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί ταῦτ’ ἀνιᾶς μ’;</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀτιμάζεις_340">, by rejecting the request that he would speak: <ref n="Soph. Ant. 544">Soph. Ant. 544</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥξει_αὐτά_341"> The subject to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥξει_341"> is designedly left indeterminate: “(the things of which I wot) will come of themselves.” The seer is communing with his own thought, which dwells darkly on the <foreign xml:lang="grc">κακά</foreign> of v. 329. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτά_341"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτόματα</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 17.252">Hom. Il. 17.252</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀργαλέον δέ μοί ἐστι διασκοπιᾶσθαι ἕκαστον … | ἀλλά τις αὐτὸς ἴτω.</quote> </cit> Cp. the phrase <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸ δείξει,</foreign> <foreign xml:lang="lat">res ipsa arguet,</foreign> the result will show: Soph. fr. 355 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταχὺ δ’ αὐτὸ δείξει τοὔργον.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀργαλέον δέ μοί ἐστι διασκοπιᾶσθαι ἕκαστον … |
							ἀλλά τις αὐτὸς ἴτω.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκοῦν_ἥξει_342"> Elmsley, Nauck and Hartung read <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ οὖν … ἐμοί;</foreign> but the positive </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρὴ_342"> is stronger without the query. “Then, seeing that they will <emph>come,</emph> thou on thy part (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_σὲ_342">) shouldest <emph>tell</emph> them to me.” The stress of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_342"> falls primarily on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὲ_342">, but serves at the same time to contrast </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγειν_342"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥξει_342">. In </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἅ_ἥξει_342"> the causal force of the relative is brought out by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_342"> :<foreign xml:lang="lat">quippe quae ventura sint.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_φράσαιμι_343"> The courteous formula (95, 282), just because it is such, here expresses fixed resolve. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἥτις_ἀγριωτάτη_343"> :<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 17.61">Hom. Il. 17.61</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτε τίς τε λέων … βοῦν ἁρπάσῃ ἥτις ἀρίστη</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Apol. 23a">Plat. Apol. 23a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλαὶ ἀπέχθειαι … καὶ οἶαι χαλεπώταται</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Dem. 2.18">Dem. 2.18</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὲν γάρ τις ἀνήρ ἐστιν ἐν αὐτοῖς οἷος ἔμπειρος πολέμου καὶ ἀγώνων</quote> </cit> [;sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐστί];, τούτους, κ.τ.λ.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὅτε τίς τε λέων … βοῦν ἁρπάσῃ ἥτις
									ἀρίστη

εἰ μὲν γάρ τις ἀνήρ ἐστιν ἐν αὐτοῖς οἷος
							ἔμπειρος
									πολέμου καὶ ἀγώνων

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_μὴν_345"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_345">, “aye verily”: cp. <ref n="Soph. El. 554">Soph. El. 554</ref>, where <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἢν ἐφῇς μοι</foreign> is answered (556) by <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ μὴν ἐφίημ’.</foreign> (For a slightly different <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ μήν … γε,</foreign> see <ref n="Soph. OC 396">Soph. OC 396</ref>.) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἔχω_345"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔχων ὀργῆς ὡς ἔχω,</foreign> being so wroth as I am. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.22">Thuc. 1.22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἑκατέρων τις εὐνοίας ἢ μνήμης ἔχοι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hel. 313">Eur. Hel. 313</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς δ’ εὐμενείας τοισίδ’ ἐν δόμοις ἔχεις;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ὡς ἑκατέρων τις εὐνοίας ἢ μνήμης ἔχοι
πῶς δ’ εὐμενείας τοισίδ’ ἐν δόμοις ἔχεις;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρήσω_οὐδὲν_345"> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">τούτων</foreign>)</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἅπερ_ξυνίημ_345">, I will leave unsaid nothing (of those things) which I comprehend, i.e. I will reveal my whole insight into the plot. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνίημι_345"> suits the intellectual pride of Oedipus: he does not say “think” or “suspect”: cp. 628. For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γὰρ_345"> after </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴσθι_345"> cp. 277. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_τε_347"> could no more stand for ‘and’ … ‘both’ than <foreign xml:lang="lat">et … que</foreign> could. </gloss>

καὶ ξυμφυτεῦσαι … εἰργάσθαι θ’. καί …
									τε

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καί_347"> here (adeo) implies, “no mere <emph>sympathiser,</emph> but <emph> actually</emph> the <emph>plotter.</emph>”Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1394">Soph. OC 1394</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ</quote> </cit> (<emph>e'en</emph>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">πᾶσι Καδμείοισι τοῖς σαυτοῦ θ’ ἅμα.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυμφυτεῦσαι_347"> :<cit> <bibl n="Pind. I. 5">Pind. I. 5.12</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σύν τέ οἱ δαίμων φυτεύει δόξαν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 953">Soph. Aj. 953</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Παλλὰς φυτεύει πῆμα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 198">Soph. El. 198</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεινὰν δεινῶς προφυτεύσαντες | μορφάν</quote> </cit> (of crime). Hermann preferred <foreign xml:lang="grc">δ’</foreign> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">τ’</foreign> after <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰργάσθαι,</foreign> as meaning, “<emph>but</emph> hast done it (only) by another's hands” (i.e. “<emph>though</emph> thou hast not executed it thyself”): this, however, besides being forced, destroys the climax. </gloss>

data.quote: σύν τέ οἱ δαίμων φυτεύει δόξαν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅσον_347"> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">εἶχες εἰργάσθαι</foreign>)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_καίνων_347">, so far as you could be the author of the deed without slaying: <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 4.16">Thuc. 4.16</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φυλάσσειν δὲ καὶ τὴν νῆσον Ἀθηναίους μηδὲν ἧσσον, ὄσα μὴ ἀποβαίνοντας</quote> </cit>: 1. 111 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῆς γῆς ἐκράτουν ὄσα μὴ προϊόντες πολὺ ἐκ τῶν ὅπλων</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 1214">Soph. Trach. 1214</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">| ὅσον γ’ ἂν</quote> </cit> (sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">δρῴην τοῦτὀ αὐτὸς μὴ ποτιψαύων χεροῖν.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
φυλάσσειν δὲ καὶ τὴν νῆσον Ἀθηναίους μηδὲν
							ἧσσον,
									ὄσα μὴ ἀποβαίνοντας

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_τοῦτο_349"> the <emph>doing</emph> of this thing also, <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτὴν τὴν πρᾶξιν,</foreign> as dist. from the plotting and the direction of the act. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄληθες_350"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> The same word marks the climax of Creon's anger in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 758">Soph. Ant. 758</ref>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Birds 393">Aristoph. Birds 393</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐτεόν;</quote> </cit> etc. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐννέπω_ἐμμένειν_350">, I command that thou abide: so <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 101">Soph. Phil. 101</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λέγω σε … λαβεῖν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾦπερ_προεῖπας_351"> (sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμμένειν</foreign>), by which thou didst proclaim that (all) should abide: this is better than taking </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾦπερ_351"> as by attraction for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅπερ,</foreign> since <foreign xml:lang="grc">προεῖπον</foreign> could take an acc. of <emph>the thing proclaimed</emph> (e.g. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξενίαν, πόλεμον, θάνατον</foreign>), but not of the edict itself (as <foreign xml:lang="grc">κήρυγμα</foreign>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_μιάστορι_353"> an anacolouthon for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ὄντα … μιάστορα,</foreign> as if <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐννέπω σοί</foreign> had preceded. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμέ_353"> just before made this necessary. In <ref n="Eur. Med. 57">Eur. Med. 57</ref> most MSS. give <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὥσθ’ ἵμερός μ’ ὑπῆλθε γῇ τε κοὐρανῷ | λέξαι μολούσῃ δεῦρο δεσποίνης τύχας,</foreign> where Porson, reading <foreign xml:lang="grc">μολοῦσαν,</foreign> admits that the dat. stands in Philemon's parody (Athenaeus 288 D), <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἵμερός μ’ ὑπῆλθε γῇ τε κοὐρανῷ | λέξαι μολόντι τοὖψον ὡς ἐσκεύασα.</foreign> Elms. cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IA 491">Eur. IA 491</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλλως τέ μ’ ἔλεος τῆς ταλαιπώρου κόρης | εἰσῆλθε συγγένειαν ἐννοουμένῳ.</quote> </cit> Conversely <ref n="Thuc. 6.85">Thuc. 6.85</ref> sect. 2(<foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῖς ἐκεῖ ξυμμάχοις</foreign> followed by <foreign xml:lang="grc">Χίους,</foreign> etc., in appos.). </gloss>

data.quote:
ἄλλως τέ μ’ ἔλεος τῆς ταλαιπώρου κόρης |
							εἰσῆλθε
									συγγένειαν ἐννοουμένῳ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξεκίνησας_354"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκκινεῖν</foreign> is used of starting game, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 567">Soph. El. 567</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξεκίνησεν ποδοῖν | … ἔλαφον</quote> </cit>: of rousing one from rest, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1242">Soph. Trach. 1242</ref>, and fig. of exciting pain which had been lulled, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 979">Soph. Trach. 979</ref>. Here the notion is that of a startling utterance. Cp. the use of <foreign xml:lang="grc"> κινεῖν</foreign> in the sense of mooting subjects which should not have been touched: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. El. 302">Eur. El. 302</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεὶ δὲ κινεῖς μῦθον,</quote> </cit> i.e. since thou <emph>hast</emph> broached this theme: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1526">Soph. OC 1526</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἃ δ’ ἐξάγιστα μηδὲ κινεῖται λόγῳ.</quote> </cit> In <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 1317">Eur. Med. 1317</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί τάσδε κινεῖς κἀναμοχλεύεις πύλας;</quote> </cit> Porson, with the author of the <title>Christus Patiens</title>, reads <foreign xml:lang="grc">λόγους,</foreign> thinking that <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Cl. 1399">Aristoph. Cl. 1399</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ καινῶν ἐπῶν | κινητὰ καὶ μοχλευτά</quote> </cit> alluded to that place. So <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀκίνητα (ἔπἠ</foreign> =<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπόρρητα</quote> <bibl n="Soph. OC 624">Soph. OC 624</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1060">Soph. Ant. 1060</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄρσεις με τἀκίνητα διὰ φρενῶν φράσαι. | κίνει, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἃ δ’ ἐξάγιστα μηδὲ κινεῖται λόγῳ.
ὦ καινῶν ἐπῶν | κινητὰ καὶ μοχλευτά

ὄρσεις με τἀκίνητα διὰ φρενῶν φράσαι. | κίνει,
							κ.τ.λ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_ποῦ_355"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> And on what ground dost thou think to escape (punishment for) this thing? For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποῦ_355"> cp. 390: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1100">Soph. Aj. 1100</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ σὺ στρατηγεῖς τοῦδε;</quote> </cit> Distinguish </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καί_355"> (1) <emph>prefixed</emph> to interrogative particles, when it expresses an objection: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 280">Aesch. Ag. 280</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τίς τόδ’ ἐξίκοιτ’ ἂν ἀγγέλων τάχος;</quote> </cit> <ref n="Dem. 19.257">Dem. 19.257</ref> (with Shilleto's note), and <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ πῶς;</foreign> passim: (2) <emph>suffixed,</emph> where, granting a fact, it asks for further information: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 278">Aesch. Ag. 278</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποίου χρόνου δὲ καὶ πεπόρθηται πόλις;</quote> </cit> (assuming it to be taken, <emph>when was</emph> it taken?) <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 834">Eur. Alc. 834</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ καί σφε θάπτει;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: καὶ τίς τόδ’ ἐξίκοιτ’ ἂν ἀγγέλων τάχος;
ποίου χρόνου δὲ καὶ πεπόρθηται πόλις;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτο_φεύγειν_355"> here = <foreign xml:lang="grc">τούτου τὴν δίκην ἐκφεύγειν</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 795">Eur. Med. 795</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παίδων φόνον | φεύγουσα,</quote> </cit> fleeing from (the penalties of) the murder: <ref n="Cic. Clu. 59.163">Cic. Pro Cluent. 59.163</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">calumniam ( = crimen calumniae) non effugiet.</foreign> But in <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 12.34">Lys. 12.34</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτο … οὐ φεύγω</quote> </cit> = “I do not avoid this point.” </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰσχῦον_356"> expresses the living strength of the divine instinct within him: cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ζῶντα</foreign> 482. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τρέφω_356"> see on <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμπέφυκεν</foreign> 299. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τέχνης_356"> slightly contemptuous; cp. 388, 562, 709. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προὐτρέψω_358"> the midd., as 1446: but the act., <ref n="Soph. Ant. 270">Soph. Ant. 270</ref>,<ref n="Soph. El. 1193">Soph. El. 1193</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_λέγων_360"> or (while you <emph>do</emph> understand my meaning already) are you merely trying by your talk (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγων_360">) to provoke a still fuller statement of it? <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 3.135">Hdt. 3.135</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δείσας μή εὑ ἐκπειρῷτο Δαρεῖος,</quote> </cit> was making trial of him: <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Kn. 1234">Aristoph. Kn. 1234</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καί σου τοσοῦτο πρῶτον ἐκπειράσομαι,</quote> </cit> “thus far make trial of thee” (test thee by one question). The notion of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκ</foreign> in the compound is that of drawing forth something from the person tested. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγων_360_2"> here implies <emph>idle</emph> talk, cp. 1151 <foreign xml:lang="grc">λέγει γὰρ εἰδὼς οὐδέν</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 55">Soph. Phil. 55</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν Φιλοκτήτου σε δεῖ | ψυχὴν ὅπως λόγοισιν ἐκκλέψεις λέγων</quote> </cit>: where, as here, the partic. denotes the process. If we read <foreign xml:lang="grc">λέγειν,</foreign> we must supply <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὥστε</foreign>: “tempting me so that I should speak”: a weak sense. <foreign xml:lang="grc">λόγῳ</foreign> could only mean, “by thy talk”: whereas it would naturally mean “in word” (only, and not <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔργῳ</foreign>). Musgrave conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">λοχῶν</foreign> (laying a snare for me); Arndt <foreign xml:lang="grc">μ’ ἑλεῖν;</foreign> (to catch me): Madvig <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκ πείρας λέγεις;</foreign> But, with </gloss>

data.quote:
τὴν Φιλοκτήτου σε δεῖ | ψυχὴν ὅπως λόγοισιν
							ἐκκλέψεις λέγων

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγων_360_3">, all is, I think, sound. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐχ_γ_361"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ. οὐ (ξυνῆκἀ οὕτω γ’ ἀκριβῶς ὥστε εἰπεῖν</foreign>: cp. 1131. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γνωστόν_361">: “known.” So the MSS.: but <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνωτὰ</foreign> 58, <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνωτὸν</foreign> 396. In fr. 262 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκ κάρτα βαιῶν γνωτὸς ἂν γένοιτ’ ἀνήρ, γνωτός</foreign>= “well-known,” <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνώριμος</foreign>: but Soph. used <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνωστός</foreign> in the same sense in the <title> Hermione</title> (Antiatticista 87.25). It has been held that, where a sigmatic form of the verbal (as <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνωστός</foreign>) existed along with the non-sigmatic (as <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνωτός</foreign>), Attic usage distinguished <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνωστός</foreign> as = “what <emph>can</emph> be known” from <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνωτός</foreign> as = “what <emph>is</emph> known.” But there is no ground for assuming that such a distinction was observed. See Appendix, n. on v. 361. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὖ_ζητεῖς_362"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ. φημί σε φονέα κυρεῖν (ὄντἀ τοῦ ἀνδρὸς οὖ (τὸν φονέἀ ζητεῖς.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_χαίρων_363"> cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1299">Soph. Phil. 1299</ref> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πημονὰς_363">: i.e. such charges are downright calamities, infamies. There is something of a colloquial tone in the phrase: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 68">Soph. Aj. 68</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲ συμφορὰν δέχου | τὸν ἄνδρα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 301">Soph. El. 301</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ πάντ’ ἄναλκις οὗτος, ἡ πᾶσα βλάβη.</quote> </cit> Cp. 336 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀτελεύτητος.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: ὁ πάντ’ ἄναλκις οὗτος, ἡ πᾶσα βλάβη.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴπω_364"> delib. subjunct.: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ion 758">Eur. Ion 758</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴπωμεν, ἢ σιγῶμεν, ἢ τί δράσομεν;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: εἴπωμεν, ἢ σιγῶμεν, ἢ τί δράσομεν;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὺν_φιλτάτοις_366"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">σὺν τῇ φιλτάτῃ</foreign> (Iocasta): since <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁμιλοῦντ’</foreign> implies wedlock, and not merely the companionship denoted by <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξυνών</foreign> in 457: for the allusive plural, cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 335">Soph. Trach. 335</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὕστινας</quote> </cit> (meaning Iole): <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 652">Soph. El. 652</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φίλοισι</quote> </cit> (Aegisthus). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵν_κακοῦ_367"> cp. 413, 1442. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 375">Soph. Trach. 375</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ ποτ’ εἰμὶ πράγματος;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_καὶ_368"> “dost thou <emph>indeed?</emph>”<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 402">Aesch. Eum. 402</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ καὶ τοιαύτας τῷδ’ ἐπιρροιζεῖς φυγάς;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἦ καὶ τοιαύτας τῷδ’ ἐπιρροιζεῖς φυγάς;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλὴν_δὲ_370"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Note in these two vv. (1) the rhetorical iteration(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπαναφορά</foreign>) of the pers. pron., as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 250">Soph. OC 250</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρός σ’ ὅ τι σοι φίλον ἐκ σέθεν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 787">Soph. OC 787</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἔστι σοι ταῦτ’, ἀλλά σοι ταῦτ’ ἔστ’</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1054">Soph. Phil. 1054</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλὴν εἰς σέ· σοὶ δέ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 15.41">Isoc. 15.41</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κινδυνεύων τὰ μὲν ὑφ’ ὑμῶν τὰ δὲ μεθ’ ὑμῶν τὰ δὲ δῑ ὑμᾶς τὰ δ’ ὑπὲρ ὑμῶν.</quote> </cit> (2) the ninefold <foreign xml:lang="grc">τ (παρήχησις)</foreign> in 371; cp. 425: <ref n="Soph. OC 1547">Soph. OC 1547</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 528">Soph. Aj. 528</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐὰν τὸ ταχθὲν εὖ τολμᾷ τελεῖν.</quote> </cit> Similarly <foreign xml:lang="grc">π</foreign>,<ref n="Soph. El. 210">Soph. El. 210</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1112">Soph. Aj. 1112</ref>:<foreign xml:lang="grc">ς</foreign>,<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 476">Eur. Med. 476</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔσωσά σ’· ὡς ἴσασιν Ἑλλήνων ὄσοι, κ.τ.λ.·</quote> </cit> <ref>Ennius Ann. 1.151</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">O Tite tute Tati tibi tanta tyranne tulisti</foreign>:<ref n="Cic. Clu. 35.96">Cic. Pro Cluent. 35.96</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">non fuit igitur illud iudicium iudicii simile, iudices.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: πρός σ’ ὅ τι σοι φίλον ἐκ σέθεν
οὐκ ἔστι σοι ταῦτ’, ἀλλά σοι ταῦτ’ ἔστ’

κινδυνεύων τὰ μὲν ὑφ’ ὑμῶν τὰ δὲ μεθ’ ὑμῶν τὰ
							δὲ
									δῑ ὑμᾶς τὰ δ’ ὑπὲρ ὑμῶν.
ἐὰν τὸ ταχθὲν εὖ τολμᾷ τελεῖν.
ἔσωσά σ’· ὡς ἴσασιν Ἑλλήνων ὄσοι, κ.τ.λ.·

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄθλιος_372"> of wretched <emph>folly.</emph> Cp. the use of <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνολβος,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1156">Soph. Aj. 1156</bibl> </cit> ,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 1025">Soph. Ant. 1025</ref> (joined with <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄβουλος), μέλεος (</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 621">Soph. Aj. 621</bibl> </cit> ),<foreign xml:lang="grc">κακοδαίμων, κ.τ.λ.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδεὶς_373"> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔστιν</foreign>)</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὃς_οὐχὶ_373"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">πᾶς τις</foreign>: [;Plat.]; <ref n="Eur. Alc. 1">Eur. Alc. 1</ref>. 103 B <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδεὶς ὃς οὐχ ὑπερβληθεὶς … πέφευγε.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 725">Soph. Aj. 725</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤρασσον … οὔτις ἔσθ’ ὃς οὐ.</quote> </cit> More properly <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδεὶς ὅστις οὐ,</foreign> declined (by attraction) in both parts, as <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedo 117d">Plat. Phaedo 117d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδένα ὅντινα οὐ κατέκλασε τῶν παρόντων.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: οὐδένα ὅντινα οὐ κατέκλασε τῶν παρόντων.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μιᾶς_νυκτός_374"> thou art cherished by (thy life is passed in) one unbroken night: the pass. form of <foreign xml:lang="grc">μία νύξ σε τρέφει.</foreign> Cp. fr. 524 (N.(2)), <foreign xml:lang="grc">τερπνῶς γὰρ ἀεὶ πάντας ἁνοία τρέφει,</foreign> folly ever <emph>gives</emph> a joyous <emph>life:</emph> fr. 532. 4 <foreign xml:lang="grc">βόσκει δὲ τοὺς μὲν μοῖρα δυσαμερίας, | τοὺς δ’ ὄλβος ἡμῶν</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 367">Eur. Hipp. 367</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ πόνοι τρέφοντες βροτούς,</quote> </cit> cares that <emph>make up the life</emph> of men. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μιᾶς_374"> might be simply <foreign xml:lang="grc">μόνης,</foreign> but, in its emphatic place here, rather = “unbroken,” unvaried by day: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aristot. Rh. 3.9.1">Aristot. Rh. 3.9.1</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(λέξιν) εἰρομένην καὶ τῷ συνδεσμῷ μίαν,</quote> </cit> forming one continuous chain. The ingenious conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">μαίας</foreign> (nurse) seems to me far less forcible. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_μοῖρα_376"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">σε πεσεῖν κ.τ.λ.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκπρᾶξαι_377"> “to accomplish” (not to “exact”); </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάδε_377"> has a mysterious vagueness (cp. 341), but includes <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ πεσεῖν σε,</foreign> as in 1158 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τόδ’</foreign> refers to <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὀλέσθαι.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Κρέων_δὲ_379"> = “<emph>Nay</emph>, Creon,” —introducing an objection, as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 729">Soph. Trach. 729</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιαῦτα δ’ ἂν λέξειεν κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 395">Soph. OC 395</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γέροντα δ’ ὀρθοῦν φλαῦρον</quote> </cit>: and <ref n="Soph. OC 1443">Soph. OC 1443</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῷ_βίῳ_381"> locative dative, defining the sphere of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑπερφέρουσα_381">, like <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔτι μέγας οὐρανῷ | Ζεύς</quote> <bibl n="Soph. El. 174">Soph. El. 174</bibl> </cit> .</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πολυζήλῳ_381">= full of emulation(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ζῆλος</foreign>). Others understand, “in the <emph>much admired</emph> life” (of princes). This is the sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">πολύζηλον (πόσιν)</foreign> in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 185">Soph. Trach. 185</ref>. But (1) <foreign xml:lang="grc">βίῳ</foreign> seems to denote life generally, rather than a particular station: (2) the phrase, following <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλοῦτε καὶ τυραννί,</foreign> would be a weak addition. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τέχνη_ὑπερφέρουσα_381"> refers to the view that the art of ruling is the highest of arts: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 138">Soph. Phil. 138</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τέχνα γὰρ τέχνας ἑτέρας προὔχει | καὶ γνώμα, παρ’ ὅτῳ τὸ θεῖον | Διὸς σκῆπτρον ἀνάσσεται</quote> </cit>: for skill and wit(<foreign xml:lang="grc">γνώμη</foreign>), surpassing those of other men, belong to him by whom is swayed the godlike sceptre which Zeus gives. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 4.2.11">Xen. Mem. 4.2.11</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μεγίστης ἐφίεσαι τέχνης· ἔστι γὰρ τῶν βασιλέων αὕτη, καὶ καλεῖται βασιλική.</quote> </cit> But there is also an allusion to the skill shown in solving the riddle, by which Oed. surpassed the <foreign xml:lang="grc">μαντικὴ τέχνη</foreign> of Teiresias (cp. 357). </gloss>

data.quote:
τέχνα γὰρ τέχνας ἑτέρας προὔχει | καὶ γνώμα,
							παρ’
									ὅτῳ τὸ θεῖον | Διὸς σκῆπτρον ἀνάσσεται

μεγίστης ἐφίεσαι τέχνης· ἔστι γὰρ τῶν βασιλέων
							αὕτη, καὶ καλεῖται βασιλική.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρ_φυλάσσεται_382"> is guarded, stored, in your keeping: i.e. how much envy do ye tend to excite against those who receive your gifts. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φυλάσσεται_382">, stronger than <foreign xml:lang="grc">τρέφεται,</foreign> represents envy as the <emph>inseparable</emph> attendant on success: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1213">Soph. OC 1213</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκαιοσύναν φυλάσσων,</quote> </cit> stubborn in folly: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ion 735">Eur. Ion 735</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄξῑ ἀξίων γεννητόρων | ἤθη φυλάσσεις.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δωρητόν_αἰτητόν_384"> feminine. The adjectives might be neuter: “a thing given, not asked.” But this use of the neuter adj., when the subject is regarded in its most general aspect, is far most common in <emph>simple</emph> predications, as <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 2.204">Hom. Il. 2.204</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἀγαθὸν πολυκοιρανίη</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 109">Eur. Hipp. 109</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τερπνὸν ἐκ κυναγίας | τράπεζα πλήρης.</quote> </cit> And <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνωτόν</foreign> in 396—which must agree with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἥν</foreign>— favours the view that here also the adjectives are fem. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 2.742">Hom. Il. 2.742</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλυτὸς Ἱπποδάμεια</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 2.41">Thuc. 2.41</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γῆν ἐσβατόν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 7.87">Thuc. 7.87</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀσμαὶ οὐκ ἀνεκτοί</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 9.573b">Plat. Rep. 573b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μανίας … ἐπακτοῦ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Erx. 398d">Plat. Eryx. 398d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρετὴ διδακτός</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1460">Soph. OC 1460</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πτερωτὸς βροντή</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 446">Soph. Trach. 446</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ … μεμπτός εἰμι</quote> </cit> (Deianeira). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταύτης_385"> redundant, for emphasis: <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 8.7.9">Xen. Cyrop. 8.7.9</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ δὲ προβουλεύειν καὶ τὸ ἡγεῖσθαι, ἐφ’ ὅτι ἂν καιρὸς δοκῇ εἷναι, τοῦτο προστάττω.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τὸ δὲ προβουλεύειν καὶ τὸ ἡγεῖσθαι, ἐφ’ ὅτι ἂν
							καιρὸς δοκῇ εἷναι, τοῦτο προστάττω.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑφεὶς_387"> having secretly sent as his agent, “having suborned.” <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Ax. 368e">Plat. Axioch. 368e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προέδρους ἐγκαθέτους ὑφέντες,</quote> </cit> “having privily brought in suborned presidents.” The word </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μάγος_387"> expresses contempt for the rights of divination practised by Teiresias: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγύρτης_387"> taunts him as a mercenary impostor. So <ref>Plut. Mor. 165f</ref> joins <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγύρτας καὶ γόητας,</foreign> Zosimus 1.11 <foreign xml:lang="grc">μάγοις τε καὶ ἀγύρταις.</foreign> The passage shows how Asiatic superstitions had already spread among the vulgar, and were scorned by the educated, in Greece. The Persian <foreign xml:lang="grc"> μάγος</foreign> (as conceived by the Greeks) was one who claimed to command the aid of beneficent deities(<foreign xml:lang="grc">δαίμονες ἀγαθοεργοἴ,</foreign> while the <foreign xml:lang="grc">γόης</foreign> was properly one who could call up the dead (Suid. 1. 490: cp. <ref>Plut. De Defect. Orac. 10</ref>). So <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1496">Eur. Orest. 1496</ref> (Helen has been spirited away), <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἢ φαρμάκοισιν</foreign> (by charms), <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἢ μάγων | τέχναισιν, ἢ θεῶν κλοπαῖς.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγύρτην_388"> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγείρω</foreign>), a priest, esp. of Cybele(<foreign xml:lang="grc">μητραγύρτης,</foreign> or, when she had the lunar attributes, <foreign xml:lang="grc">μηναγύρτης</foreign>), who sought money from house to house(<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ τὰς τῶν πλουσίων θύρας ἰόντες,</quote> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 364b">Plat. Rep. 364b</bibl> </cit>), or in public places, for predictions or expiatory rites: Maximus Tyrius 19. 3 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἐν τοῖς κύκλοις ἀγειρόντων … , οἳ δυοῖν ὀβολοῖν τῷ προστυχόντι ἀποθεσπίζουσιν.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: ἐπὶ τὰς τῶν πλουσίων θύρας ἰόντες,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_κέρδεσιν_388"> in the case of gains: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1315">Soph. Aj. 1315</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ἐμοὶ θρασύς;</quote> </cit> rather than, “on opportunities for gain”(= <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅταν ᾖ κερδαίνειν</foreign>) as Ellendt takes it. Cicero's <foreign xml:lang="lat">videbat in litteris</foreign> (<ref>Cic. Tusc. 5.38.112</ref>, quoted by Schneid.) seems not strictly similar, meaning rather “in the region of letters” (like <foreign xml:lang="lat">in tenebris</foreign>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπεὶ_390"> = “for” (if this is <emph>not</emph> true): <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 351">Soph. El. 351</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ ταῦτα … δειλίαν ἔχει | ἐπεὶ δίδαξον, κ.τ.λ.;</quote> </cit> so <ref n="Soph. OC 969">Soph. OC 969</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐ ταῦτα … δειλίαν ἔχει | ἐπεὶ δίδαξον,
									κ.τ.λ.;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποῦ_390"> where? i.e. in what sense? <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ion 528">Eur. Ion 528</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποῦ δέ μοι πατὴρ σύ;</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἶ_σαφής_390"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">πέφηνας ὤν</foreign>: cp. 355. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κύων_391"> esp. because the Sphinx was the watchful agent of Hera's wrath: cp. 36. <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 1287">Aristoph. Frogs 1287</ref> has a line from the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Σφίγξ</foreign> of Aesch., <foreign xml:lang="grc">Σφίγγα δυσαμεριᾶν</foreign> [;vulg. <foreign xml:lang="grc">δυσαμεριαν]; πρύτανιν κύνα πέμπει,</foreign> “the watcher who presides over evil days” (for Thebes). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ῥαψῳδὸς_391"> chanting her riddle (in hexameter verse), as the public reciters chanted epic poems. The word is used with irony: the baneful lay of the Sphinx was not such as the servant of Apollo chants. Cp. 130. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τό_αἴνιγμ_393"> is nominative: the riddle did not belong to (was not for) the first comer, that he should solve it. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 751">Soph. OC 751</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γάμων | ἔμπειρος, ἀλλὰ τοὐπιόντος ἁρπάσαι.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 6.22">Thuc. 6.22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλὴ γὰρ οὖσα ἡ στρατιὰ οὐ πάσης ἔσται πόλεως ὑποδέξασθαι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐ γάμων | ἔμπειρος, ἀλλὰ τοὐπιόντος
									ἁρπάσαι.

πολλὴ γὰρ οὖσα ἡ στρατιὰ οὐ πάσης ἔσται πόλεως
							ὑποδέξασθαι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_ἐπιών_393">, any one who comes up; cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 372d">Plat. Rep. 372d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς νῦν ὁ τυχὼν καὶ οὐδὲν προσήκων ἔρχεται ἐπ’ αὐτό.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὡς νῦν ὁ τυχὼν καὶ οὐδὲν προσήκων ἔρχεται ἐπ’
							αὐτό.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διειπεῖν_393"> “to declare,” “to solve”: cp. 854. <foreign xml:lang="grc">διά</foreign> implies the drawing of clear distinctions; cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 295">Soph. OC 295</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">διειδέναι,</quote> </cit> <foreign xml:lang="lat">diiudicare,</foreign> n. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἣν_τουγνωτὸν_395"> (<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἔχων)</foreign> </gloss>
lemma:
ἣν οἴτ’ ἀπ’ οἰωνῶν ἔχων οὔτ’ ἐκ θεῶν του
							γνωτὸν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προὐφάνης_395">: and thou wast not publicly seen to have this art, either from (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπ_395">) birds, or as known through the agency of (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_395">) any god. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προὐφάνης_395_2">. when brought to a public test. For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπό_395"> cp. 43: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_395_2"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεῶν_του_395">, of the primary or remoter agent (<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Hell. 3.1.6">Xen. Hell. 3.1.6</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ βασιλέως ἐδόθη</quote> </cit>), meaning by a <foreign xml:lang="grc">φήμη</foreign> (43) or other sign. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γνωτόν_395">: cp. on 384. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μολών_395"> he was a mere stranger who chanced to arrive then. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_εἰδὼς_397"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅστις μηδὲν ᾔδη,</foreign> “I, <emph>a man who</emph> knew nothing,” the generic <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή,</foreign> here with concessive force, —“though I knew nothing, I silenced her” (qui nihil <emph>scirem,</emph> vici tamen). So in <ref n="Dem. 19.31">Dem. 19.31</ref> the generic <foreign xml:lang="grc"> μή</foreign> has a causal force: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ βουλὴ δέ, ἡ μὴ κωλυθεῖσα ἀκοῦσαι τἀληθῆ παρ’ ἐμοῦ, οὔτ’ ἐπῄνεσε τούτους, κ.τ.λ.</foreign> (“the senate, <emph>a body which</emph> had not been prevented.” etc.). See Whitelaw in <title>Trans. Camb. Phil. Soc.</title>, 1886, p. 17. Cp. 638, 875, 1019. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέλας_400"> adv., so <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 669">Aesch. Seven 669</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παραστατεῖν πέλας.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλαίων_401"> cp. 368, 1152: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 754">Soph. Ant. 754</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κλαίων φρενώσεις.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_συνθεὶς_401"> Creon, as whose agent (387) Teir. is regarded: so in <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 8.68">Thuc. 8.68</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ τὴν γνώμην εἰπών</quote> </cit> is contrasted with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ τὸ πρᾶγμα ξυνθείς.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δόκεις_402"> is the scornful phrase of an angry man; I know little concerning thee, but from thine aspect I should judge thee to be old: cp. 562 where Oed. asks, <foreign xml:lang="grc">τότ’ οὖν ὁ μάντις οὗτος ἦν ἐν τῇ τέχνῃ;</foreign> Not (1) “seemed,” as opposed to really being; nor (2) “wast felt by me” to be old: a sense which the word surely could not yield. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παθὼν_403"> by bodily pain, and not merely <foreign xml:lang="grc">μαθών,</foreign> by reproof: cp. 641. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶά_403"> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περ_φρονεῖς_403">: see on 624 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶόν ἐστι τὸ φθονεῖν.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀργῇ_405"> modal dat., cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 659">Soph. OC 659</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θυμῷ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_σ_405"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.,</foreign> the elision as in 329: see on 64. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόδε_407"> emphatically resumes <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅπως</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λύσομεν_407"> ,<emph>this</emph> we must consider: cp. 385 <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ταύτης</foreign>: so <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 458">Soph. Trach. 458</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ μὴ πυθέσθαι, τοῦτό μ’ ἀλγύνειεν ἄν</quote> </cit> :<ref n="Soph. Phil. 913">Soph. Phil. 913</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote: τὸ μὴ πυθέσθαι, τοῦτό μ’ ἀλγύνειεν ἄν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_καὶ_408"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_καὶ_408_2"> see on 305. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξισωτέον_408"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">δεῖ ἐξισοῦν τὸ γοῦν ἴσα ἀντιλέξαι,</foreign> one must equalize the right at least of like reply; i.e. you must make me so far your equal as to grant me the right of replying at the same length. The phrase is a pleonastic fusion of (1) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξισωτέον τὸ ἀντιλέξαι</foreign> with (2) <foreign xml:lang="grc">συγχωρητέον τὸ ἴσα ἀντιλέξαι.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Λοξίᾳ_410"> see note to 853. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥστ_κρέοντος_410"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> “You charge me with being the tool of Creon's treason. I have a right to plead my own cause when I am thus accused. I am not like a resident alien, who can plead before a civic tribunal only by the mouth of that patron under whom he has been registered.” Every <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέτοικος</foreign> at Athens was required <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιγράφεσθαι προστάτην,</foreign> i.e. to have the name of a citizen, as patron, inscribed over his own. In default, he was liable to an <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπροστασίου γραφή.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Peace 684">Aristoph. Peace 684</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὑτῷ πονηρὸν προστάτην ἐπεγράψατο</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Ach. 1095">Aristoph. Ach. 1095</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεγράφου τὴν Γοργόνα,</quote> </cit> you took the Gorgon for your patron: <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 31.9">Lys. 31.9</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν Ὠρωπῷ μετοίκιον κατατιθεὶς</quote> </cit> (paying the alien's tax) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ προστάτου ᾤκει.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γεγράψομαι_410"> will <emph>stand</emph> enrolled: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Kn. 1370">Aristoph. Kn. 1370</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδεὶς κατὰ σπουδὰς μετεγγραφήσεται, | ἀλλ’ ὥσπερ ἦν τὸ πρῶτον ἐγγεγράψεται</quote> </cit>: Theocr. 18. 47 <foreign xml:lang="grc">γράμματα δ’ ἐν φλοιῷ γεγράψεται,</foreign> <emph>remain</emph> written. —For the gen. </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐδεὶς κατὰ σπουδὰς μετεγγραφήσεται, | ἀλλ’
							ὥσπερ
									ἦν τὸ πρῶτον ἐγγεγράψεται

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Κρέοντος_410"> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Kn. 714">Aristoph. Kn. 714</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν δῆμον σεαυτοῦ νενόμικας.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγω_δ_412"> a solemn exordium, bespeaking attention: cp. 449. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τυφλόν_ὠνείδισας_412"> As <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὠνείδισας</foreign> could not stand for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπεκάλεσας,</foreign> “called me reproachfully,” <foreign xml:lang="grc">τυφλόν</foreign> must stand for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς τυφλὸν ὄντα.</foreign> For the ellipse of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄντα,</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 899">Soph. El. 899</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς δ’ ἐν γαλήνῃ πάντ’ ἐδερκόμην τόπον</quote> </cit>: for that of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 142">Soph. OC 142</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή μ’, ἱκετεύω, προσίδητ’ ἄνομον.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ὡς δ’ ἐν γαλήνῃ πάντ’ ἐδερκόμην τόπον

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὺ_δέδορκας_413"> “Thou <emph>both</emph> has sight <emph>and</emph> dost not see,” i.e. thou hast sight, and at the same time dost not see. The conject. of Reiske and Brunck, <foreign xml:lang="grc">σύ, καὶ δεδορκώς</foreign>(<emph>though</emph> having sight), <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ βλέπεις,</foreign> spoils the direct contrast with <foreign xml:lang="grc">τυφλόν.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔνθα_ναίεις_414"> might mean, “in what a situation thou art”: but, as distinguished from the preceding and following clauses, is best taken literally: “where thou dwellest,”—viz., in thy murdered father's house. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἆρ_οἶσθα_415"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Thy parents are unknown to thee. <emph>Yea. and</emph> (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_415">) thou knowest not how thou hast sinned against them, —the dead and the living. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφιπλὴξ_417"> as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 930">Soph. Trach. 930</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφιπλῆγι φασγάνῳ</quote> </cit>= a sword which smites with both edges, so here <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀμφιπλὴξ ἀρά</foreign> is properly <emph>a curse which smites on both sides, </emph>— on the mother's and on the father's part. The pursuing <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἀρά</foreign> must be conceived as bearing a whip with double lash(<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">διπλῆ μάστιξ,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 242">Soph. Aj. 242</bibl> </cit>). Cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀμφίπυρος,</foreign> carrying two torches (<ref n="Soph. Trach. 214">Soph. Trach. 214</ref>). The genitives </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μητρός_πατρός_417"> might be causal, with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀμφιπλήξ,</foreign> “smiting twice— <emph>for</emph> mother and for sire,” but are better taken with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρά,</foreign> which here = <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἐρινύς</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 70">Aesch. Seven 70</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀρά τ’, Ἐρινὺς πατρὸς ἡ μεγασθενής.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: Ἀρά τ’, Ἐρινὺς πατρὸς ἡ μεγασθενής.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεινόπους_418"> with dread, untiring chase: so the Fury, who chases guilt “as a hound tracks a wounded fawn” (<ref n="Aesch. Eum. 246">Aesch. Eum. 246</ref>), is <foreign xml:lang="grc">χαλκόπους</foreign>(<ref n="Soph. El. 491">Soph. El. 491</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">τανύπους</foreign>(<ref n="Soph. Aj. 837">Soph. Aj. 837</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc"> καμψίπους</foreign> (“fleet,” <ref n="Aesch. Seven 791">Aesch. Seven 791</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Βλέποντα_419"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.,</foreign> i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τότε σκότον βλέποντα, εἰ καὶ νῦν ὀρθὰ βλέπεις.</foreign> The Greek love of direct anthithesis often coordinates clauses where we must subordinate one to the other: cp. below, 673: <cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 6.54">Isoc. 6.54</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς οὐκ αἰσχρόν, … τὴν μὲν Εὐρώπην καὶ τὴν Ἀσίαν μεστὴν πεποιηκέναι τροπαίων, … ὑπὲρ δὲ τῆς πατρίδος … μηδὲ μίαν μάχην φαίνεσθαι μεμαχημένους;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βλέπειν_σκότον_419">, like <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν σκότῳ … | ὀψοἰατο</foreign> (1273), <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ba. 510">Eur. Ba. 510</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκότιον εἰσορᾷ κνέφας.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βοῆς_δὲ_420"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Of thy cry what haven shall there not be (i.e. to what place shall it not be borne), —what part of Cithaeron shall not be resonant with it(<foreign xml:lang="grc">σύμφωνος ἔσται</foreign> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτῇ</foreign>), re-echo it? If we took <foreign xml:lang="grc">σύμφωνος ἔσται</foreign> (and not <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔσται</foreign> alone) with <foreign xml:lang="grc">λιμήν</foreign> as well as with <foreign xml:lang="grc">Κιθαιρών,</foreign> the figurative force of <foreign xml:lang="grc">λιμήν</foreign> would be weakened. We must not understand: What haven of the sea or what mountain (as if Cithaeron stood for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄρος</foreign>) shall not resound? </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λιμήν_420">, poet. in the sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑποδοχή,</foreign> for that in which anything is received: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Pers. 250">Aesch. Pers. 250</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ Περσὶς αἶα καὶ μέγας πλούτου λιμήν</quote> </cit> (imitated by <ref n="Eur. Orest. 1077">Eur. Orest. 1077</ref>): the augural seat of Teiresias is <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">παντὸς οἰωνοῦ λιμήν,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1000">Soph. Ant. 1000</bibl> </cit>: the place of the dead is <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἅιδου λιμήν</foreign>,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 1284">Soph. Ant. 1284</ref>: cp. below, 1208. </gloss>

data.quote: ὦ Περσὶς αἶα καὶ μέγας πλούτου λιμήν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποῖος_Κιθαιρὼν_421"> vigorous for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποῖον μέρος Κιθαιρῶνος.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_εἰσέπλευσας_421"> the marriage into which thou didst sail: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δόμοις_421">, in the house, local dat. (381): the marriage(<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὑμέναιος,</foreign> here = <foreign xml:lang="grc">γάμος</foreign>) was the haven into which he sailed, —a haven which seemed secure, but which, in reality, was for him a <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅρμος ἄνορμος.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐπλοίας_τυχών_421"> because Oed. <emph>seemed</emph> to have found <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄλβος,</foreign> and also because the gale of fortune had borne him <emph>swiftly</emph> on: cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔθ’ ὁρῶν οὔθ’ ἱστορῶν,</foreign> 1484. —The <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑμέναιος</foreign> was the song sung while the bride and bridegroom were escorted to their home, <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 18.492">Hom. Il. 18.492</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νύμφας δ’ ἐκ θαλάμων δαΐδων ὑπὸ λαμπομενάων | ἠγίνεον ἀνὰ ἄστυ, πολὺς δ’ ὑμέναιος ὀρώρει,</quote> </cit> as distinguished from the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιθαλάμιον</foreign> afterwards sung before the bridal chamber: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 813">Soph. Ant. 813</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔθ’ ὑμεναίων | ἔγκληρον, οὔτ’ ἐπινύμφειός | πώ μέ τις ὕμνος ὕμνησεν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
νύμφας δ’ ἐκ θαλάμων δαΐδων ὑπὸ λαμπομενάων |
							ἠγίνεον ἀνὰ ἄστυ, πολὺς δ’ ὑμέναιος ὀρώρει,

οὔθ’ ὑμεναίων | ἔγκληρον, οὔτ’ ἐπινύμφειός |
							πώ μέ
									τις ὕμνος ὕμνησεν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλων_δὲ_424"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Verses 422-425 correspond with the actual process of the drama. The words <foreign xml:lang="grc">καταίσθῃ τὸν ὑμέναιον</foreign> refer to the first discovery made by Oed., —that his wife was the widow of one whom he had himself slain: cp. 821. The </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλων_κακῶν_424"> denotes the further discovery that this wife was his mother, with all the horrors involved (1405). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἅ_ἐξισώσει_425"> which shall make thee level with <emph>thy</emph> (true) self, —by showing thee to be the son of Laius, not of Polybus; —and level with <emph>thine own children</emph>, i.e. like them, the child of Iocasta, and thus at once <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀδελφὸς καὶ πατήρ</foreign> (458). For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἅ_σ_425"> Markland conject. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅσ’,</foreign> which shall <emph>be made</emph> equal for thee and for thy children: and so Porson interpreted, conjecturing <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἅσσ’</foreign> from Agathon fr. 5 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγένητα ποιεῖν ἅσσ’ ἂν ᾖ πεπραγμένα.</foreign> Nauck ingeniously conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἅ σ’ ἐξισώσει σῷ τοκεῖ καὶ σοῖς τέκνοις.</foreign> But the vulgate is sound: for the <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρήχησις</foreign> cp. 371. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὐμὸν_στόμα_426"> i.e., it is Apollo who speaks by my mouth, which is not, as thou deemest, the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπόβλητον στόμα</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. OC 794">Soph. OC 794</ref>) of Creon. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προπηλάκιζε_426"> acc. to <cit> <bibl n="Aristot. Top. 6.6">Aristot. Top. 6.6</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προπηλακισμός</quote> </cit> was defined as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὕβρις μετὰ χλευασίας,</foreign> insult expressed by scoffing: so in <cit> <bibl n="Aristot. Nic. Eth. 1131a">Aristot. Nic. Eth. 5.2.13</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κακηγορία, προπηλακισμός</quote> </cit>= libellous language, <emph>gross</emph> abuse: and in <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Thes. 386">Aristoph. Thes. 386</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προπηλακιζομένας</quote> </cit> is explained by <foreign xml:lang="grc">πολλὰ καὶ παντοῖ’ ἀκουούσας κακά</foreign>.<ref n="Dem. 21.72">Dem. 21.72</ref> has <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀήθεις … τοῦ προπηλακίζεσθαι</foreign> as = “unused to gross contumely” (generally, but with immediate ref. to a blow). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτριβήσεται_426"> rooted out. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 683">Eur. Hipp. 683</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ζεύς σε γεννήτωρ ἐμὸς | πρόρριζον ἐκτρίψειεν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
Ζεύς σε γεννήτωρ ἐμὸς | πρόρριζον
									ἐκτρίψειεν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_ὄλεθρον_430"> cp. 1146: <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Pl. 394">Aristoph. Pl. 394</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐς κόρακας;</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 1183">Soph. Trach. 1183</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ θᾶσσον οἴσεις;</quote> </cit> Cratinus <foreign xml:lang="grc">Νόμοι</foreign> fr. 6 (Meineke p. 27) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἀπερρήσεις σὺ θᾶττον;</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 252">Aesch. Seven 252</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐς φθόρον σιγῶσ’ ἀνασχήσει τάδε</quote> </cit> ; </gloss>

data.quote: οὐκ ἐς φθόρον σιγῶσ’ ἀνασχήσει τάδε

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάλιν_ἄψορρος_430"> like <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 53">Soph. El. 53</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄψορρον ἤξομεν πάλιν</quote> </cit>: the gen. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴκων_τῶνδ_430"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποστραφείς_430"> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱκόμην_ἐκάλεις_482"> cp. 125, 402. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σχολῇ_ἄν_434"> The simple <foreign xml:lang="grc">σχολῇ</foreign> is stronger than <foreign xml:lang="grc">σχολῇ γε</foreign> would be: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 390">Soph. Ant. 390</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σχολῇ ποθ’ ἥξειν</quote> </cit> (where <foreign xml:lang="grc">σχολῇ γ’ ἄν</foreign> is an inferior v. l.), <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Soph. 233b">Plat. Soph. 233b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σχολῇ ποτ’ … ἤθελεν ἄν,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Prot. 330e">Plat. Prot. 330e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σχολῇ μέντ’ ἂν ἄλλο τι ὅσιον εἴη</quote> </cit> and often </gloss>

data.quote: σχολῇ μέντ’ ἂν ἄλλο τι ὅσιον εἴη

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴκους_434"> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 643">Soph. OC 643</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δόμους στείχειν ἐμούς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐστειλάμην_434"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">μετεστειλάμην, μετεπεμψάμην.</foreign> Distinguish <foreign xml:lang="grc">στέλλεσθαι,</foreign> to summon <emph>to oneself</emph>, from <foreign xml:lang="grc">στέλλειν</foreign> said (1) of the messenger, below 860 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέμψον τινὰ στελοῦντα</foreign>: (2) of him who sends word by a messenger, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 60">Soph. Phil. 60</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἵ σ’ ἐν λιταῖς στείλαντες ἐξ οἴκου μολεῖν</quote> </cit>: having <emph>urged</emph> thee with prayers to come: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 164">Soph. Ant. 164</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑμᾶς … πομποῖσιν … | ἔστειλ’ ἱκέσθαι,</quote> </cit> sent you word to come. </gloss>

data.quote: οἵ σ’ ἐν λιταῖς στείλαντες ἐξ οἴκου μολεῖν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιοίδ_435"> refers back to the taunt implied in <foreign xml:lang="grc">μῶρα φωνήσοντ’,</foreign> and is then made explicit by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μῶροι_ἔμφρονες_435">: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1271">Soph. Phil. 1271</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιοῦτος ἦσθα</quote> </cit> (referring to what precedes—thou wast such <emph>as thou now art</emph>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῖς λόγοισι χὥτε μου | τὰ τόξ’ ἔκλεπτες, πιστός, ἀτηρὸς λάθρα.</foreign> In fr. 700 (quoted by Nauck), <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ τὸν θεὸν τοιοῦτον ἐξεπίσταμαι, | σοφοῖς μὲν αἰνικτῆρα, … | σκαιοῖς δὲ φαῦλον,</foreign> we have not the preceding words, but doubtless <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοιοῦτον</foreign> referred to them. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_σοὶ_435"> must be accented; else the contrast would be, not partly between </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοὶ_435"> and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γονεῦσι_435">, but solely between </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοκεῖ_435"> and some other verbal notion. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοὶ_435_2"> does not, however, cohere so closely with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοκεῖ_435_2"> as to form a virtual cretic. It is need. less, then, to read (as Elms. proposed) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς μέν σοι</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς σοὶ μὲν.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1543">Soph. OC 1543</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥσπερ σφὼ πατρί</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Heraclid. 641">Eur. Heraclid. 641</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σωτὴρ νῷν βλάβης.</quote> </cit> As neither <foreign xml:lang="grc">σφὼ</foreign> nor <foreign xml:lang="grc">νῷν</foreign> adheres to the following rather than to the preceding word, it seems unnecessary to read with Porson <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς πρὶν σφὼ</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">νῷν σωτήρ.</foreign> Here we have </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_σοὶ_435_2"> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς σοὶ μὲν,</foreign> because, besides the contrast of persons, there is also a contrast between semblance (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_δοκεῖ_435">) and fact. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γονεῦσι_435_2"> “ for” them, i.e. in their judgment: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 904">Soph. Ant. 904</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καίτοι σ’ ἐγὼ τίμησα, τοῖς φρονοῦσιν, εὖ.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Birds 445">Aristoph. Birds 445</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾶσι νικᾶν τοῖς κριταῖς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: καίτοι σ’ ἐγὼ τίμησα, τοῖς φρονοῦσιν, εὖ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκφύει_437"> (<foreign xml:lang="grc">υ^</foreign>). The pres. is not historic (for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξέφυσε</foreign>), but denotes a permanent character: “is my sire.” <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ion 1560">Eur. Ion 1560</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥδε τίκτει σ’,</quote> </cit> is thy mother: so perh. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Heraclid. 208">Eur. Heraclid. 208</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πατὴρ δ’ ἐκ τῆσδε γεννᾶται σέθεν.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 8.2.27">Xen. Cyrop. 8.2.27</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ δὲ μὴ νικῶν</quote> </cit> (he who was not victorious) <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῖς μὲν νικῶσιν ἐφθόνει</foreign>: and so <foreign xml:lang="grc">φεύγειν</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">φυγὰς εἶναι</foreign> passim. Shilleto thus takes <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἱ ἐπαγόμενοι</foreign> in <ref n="Thuc. 2.2">Thuc. 2.2</ref>,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ προδιδόντες</quote> <bibl n="Thuc. 2.5">Thuc. 2.5</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ διαβάλλοντες</quote> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.4">Thuc. 3.4</bibl> </cit>; which, however, I should rather take simply as imperfect participles, = <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἳ ἐπήγοντο, προὐδίδοσαν, διέβαλλον.</foreign> He well compares <ref n="Verg. A. 9.266">Verg. Aen. 9.266</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">quem dat Sidonia Dido</foreign> (is the giver): in Persius 4.2 <foreign xml:lang="lat">sorbitio tollit quem dira cicutae,</foreign> I find rather a harsh historic pres. </gloss>

data.quote: πατὴρ δ’ ἐκ τῆσδε γεννᾶται σέθεν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔκουν_κτλ_440"> Well (<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὖν</foreign>— if I <emph>do</emph> speak riddles), art not thou most skilled to read them? </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιαῦτ_μοι_440"> ), make those things my reproach, in which [;<foreign xml:lang="grc">οἷς,</foreign> dat. of circumstance]; thou wilt find me great: i.e. mock my skill in reading riddles if thou wilt; but thou wilt find (on looking deeper) that it has brought me true honour. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιαῦτα_οἷς_440"> as <ref n="Soph. OC 1353">Soph. OC 1353</ref> (n.), <ref n="Soph. Ant. 691">Soph. Ant. 691</ref>, etc. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὕτη_μέντοι_442"> It was just (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_442">)that fortune, however (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέντοι_442">),that ruined thee. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_442_2"> emphasises the preceding word: so 778, 1292: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 93">Soph. Phil. 93</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πεμφθείς γε μέντοι</quote> </cit> (since I have been <emph>sent</emph>), 1052 <foreign xml:lang="grc">νικᾶν γε μέντοι</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 233">Soph. Ant. 233</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τέλος γε μέντοι,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 495">Soph. Ant. 495</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μισῶ γε μέντοι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τύχη_442"> implies some abatement of the king's boast, <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνώμῃ κυρήσας,</foreign> 398. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξέσωσ_442"> 1st pers., not 3rd. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κομιζέτω_δῆθ_445"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">δῆτα</foreign> in assent, as <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Supp. 206">Aesch. Supp. 206</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ζεὺς δὲ γεννήτωρ ἴδοι. ΔΑΝ. ἴδοιτο δῆτα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: Ζεὺς δὲ γεννήτωρ ἴδοι. ΔΑΝ. ἴδοιτο δῆτα.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμποδὼν_445"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρὼν_445">, —present where thy presence irks: cp. 128. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σύ_γε_445"> here gives a scornful force: the use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">σύ γε</foreign> in 1101 (n.) is different. The reading <foreign xml:lang="grc">τά γ’ ἐμποδὼν</foreign> (found in B) is explained by Brunck and Erfurdt (with Thomas Magister) “thou hinderest the business before us,” comparing <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 706">Eur. Phoen. 706</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἃ δ’ ἐμποδὼν μάλιστα</quote> </cit> (“most urgent”) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταῦθ’ ἥκω φράσων.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλγύνοις_446"> suits the continuing action better than <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλγύναις.</foreign> The aor. occurs <ref n="Soph. Trach. 458">Soph. Trach. 458</ref>(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλγύνειεν</foreign>) and <ref n="Eur. IA 326">Eur. IA 326</ref>(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλγῦναι</foreign>): but <foreign xml:lang="grc">αις</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc"> αι,</foreign> as optative endings, are not elsewhere found in Soph. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρόσωπον_448"> “thy face,”—thy angry presence: the blind man speaks as though he saw the “vultus instantis tyranni.” Not, “thy <emph>person</emph>” (i.e. thy royal quality): <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρόσωπον</foreign> is not classical in this sense, for which cp. the Hellenistic <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσωποληπτεῖν,</foreign>“ to be a respecter of persons,” and the spurious Phocylidea 10 (Bergk <title>Poet. Lyr.</title> p. 361) <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ ῥίψῃς πενίην ἀδίκως· μὴ κρῖνε πρόσωπον.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_ὅπου_448"> there is no case in which … : cp. 355, 390. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγω_σοι_449"> cp. 412. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ἐστιν_449"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> The antecedent, attracted into the case of the relative, is often thus prefixed to the relative clause, to mark with greater emphasis the subject of a coming statement: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 283">Soph. Trach. 283</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τάσδε δ’ ἅσπερ εἰσορᾷς | … χωροῦσι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 10.416">Hom. Il. 10.416</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φυλακὰς δ’ ἃς εἴρεαι, ἥρως, | οὔτις κεκριμένη ῥύεται στρατόν</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="HH 2.66">HH Dem. 66</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κούρην τὴν ἔτεκον … | τῆς ἀδινὴν ὄπ’ ἄκουσα</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Pl. 200">Aristoph. Pl. 200</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν δύναμιν ἣν ὑμεῖς φατὲ | ἔχειν με, ταύτης δεσπότης γενήσομαι.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Pl. Trin. 4.2">Plaut. Trinum. 985</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">Illum quem ementitu's, is ego sum ipse Charmides</quote> </cit>. </gloss>

data.quote:
φυλακὰς δ’ ἃς εἴρεαι, ἥρως, | οὔτις κεκριμένη
							ῥύεται στρατόν

κούρην τὴν ἔτεκον … | τῆς ἀδινὴν ὄπ’
									ἄκουσα

τὴν δύναμιν ἣν ὑμεῖς φατὲ | ἔχειν με, ταύτης
							δεσπότης γενήσομαι.

Illum quem ementitu's, is ego sum ipse
							Charmides

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνακηρύσσων_φόνον_450"> proclaiming (a search into) the murder: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 2.10.2">Xen. Mem. 2.10.2</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σῶστρα τούτου ἀνακηρύττων</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Andoc. 1.40">Andoc. 1.40</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ζητητάς τε ἤδη ᾑρημένους … καὶ μήνυτρα κεκηρυγμένα ἑκατὸν μνᾶς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ζητητάς τε ἤδη ᾑρημένους … καὶ μήνυτρα
							κεκηρυγμένα ἑκατὸν μνᾶς.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_Λαΐειον_451"> cp. 267. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξένος_μέτοικος_451"> a foreign sojourner: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξένος,</foreign> because Oed. was reputed a Corinthian. In poetry <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέτοικος</foreign> is simply <emph>one who comes to dwell with</emph> others: it has not the full technical sense which belonged to it at Athens, a resident <emph> alien:</emph> hence the addition of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξένος</foreign> was necessary. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 934">Soph. OC 934</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μέτοικος τῆσδε γῆς</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 868">Soph. Ant. 868</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς οὓς</quote> </cit> (to the dead) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἅδ’ ἐγὼ μέτοικος ἔρχομαι.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἶτα_δὲ_451"> opp. to <foreign xml:lang="grc">νῦν μέν,</foreign> implied in </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνθάδε_ἐγγενὴς_451">, “native,” as <foreign xml:lang="grc">γεννητός</foreign> is opp. to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποιητός</foreign> (adoptivus). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῇ_ξυμφορᾷ_454"> the (seemingly happy) event: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1230">Soph. El. 1230</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀπὶ συμφοραῖσί μοι | γεγηθὸς ἕρπει δάκρυον.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
κἀπὶ συμφοραῖσί μοι | γεγηθὸς ἕρπει
									δάκρυον.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_δεδορκότος_454"> <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 3.1.17">Xen. Cyrop. 3.1.17</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ἄφρονος σώφρων γεγένηται.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξένην_ἔπι_455"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">γῆν</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 184">Soph. OC 184</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξεῖνος ἐπὶ ξένης</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 135">Soph. Phil. 135</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν ξένᾳ ξένον.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γαῖαν_455"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προδεικνὺς_455"> only: <emph>pointing</emph> to, i.e. feeling, <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ψηλαφῶν,</foreign> the ground <emph>before</emph> him: so of a boxer, <foreign xml:lang="grc">χερσὶ προδεικνύς,</foreign> sparring, <ref>Theocr. 22.102</ref>. Cp. Lucian <title>Hercules</title> 1 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ τόξον ἐντεταμένον ἡ ἀριστερὰ προδείκνυσι,</foreign> i.e. holds in front of him: id. <title> Hermotimus</title> 68 <foreign xml:lang="grc">θαλλῷ προδειχθέντι ἀκολουθεῖν, ὥσπερ τὰ πρόβατα.</foreign> Seneca <title>Oed.</title> 656 <foreign xml:lang="lat">repet incertus viae, | Baculo senili triste praetentans iter.</foreign> The order of words is against taking </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξένην_455"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γαῖαν_455_2"> (when we should write <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ</foreign>), and supplying <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν ὁδόν</foreign> with <foreign xml:lang="grc">προδεικνύς.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνὼν_457"> the idea of daily converse under the same roof heightens the horror. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Andoc. 1.49">Andoc. 1.49</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἷς … ἐχρῶ κα62 οἷς συνῆσθα,</quote> </cit> your friends and associates. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀδελφὸς_αὑτὸς_457"> If </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀδελφὸς_457"> stood alone, then </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτὸς_457"> would be right: <emph>himself</emph> the brother of <emph>his own</emph> children: but with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀδελφὸς_πατὴρ_457"> we should read </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὑτός_457"> <emph>at once</emph> sire and brother of his own children. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 119">Soph. Phil. 119</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σοφός τ’ ἂν αὑτὸς κἀγαθὸς κεκλῇ’ ἅμα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 143">Eur. Alc. 143</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ πῶς ἂν αὑτὸς κατθάνοι τε καὶ βλέποι;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: σοφός τ’ ἂν αὑτὸς κἀγαθὸς κεκλῇ’ ἅμα
καὶ πῶς ἂν αὑτὸς κατθάνοι τε καὶ βλέποι;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμόσπορος_460"> here act., = <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν αὐτὴν σπείρων</foreign>: but passive above, 260. Acc. to the general rule, verbal derivatives with a short penult. are paroxytone when active in meaning (see on <foreign xml:lang="grc">βουνόμοις,</foreign> v. 26). But those compounded with a preposition (or with <foreign xml:lang="grc">α</foreign> privative) are excepted: hence <foreign xml:lang="grc">διάβολος,</foreign> not <foreign xml:lang="grc">διαβόλος.</foreign> So <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὁμόσπορος</foreign> here, no less than in 260. On the other hand <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρωτοσπόρος</foreign>= “sowing first,” <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρωτόσπορος</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">“φιπστ σοων.”</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λάβῃς_ἐψ_461"> without <foreign xml:lang="grc">με</foreign>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 768">Soph. Phil. 768</ref>(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἐᾶν</foreign> etc.), 801(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔμπρησον</foreign>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φάσκειν_462"> inf. for imperat., “say,” i.e.” deem,” as in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1411">Soph. Phil. 1411</ref>,<ref n="Soph. El. 9">Soph. El. 9</ref>. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 3.35">Hdt. 3.35</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢν δὲ ἁμάρτω, φάναι Πέρσας τε λέγειν ἀληθέα καί με μὴ σωφρονέειν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἢν δὲ ἁμάρτω, φάναι Πέρσας τε λέγειν ἀληθέα
							καί με
									μὴ σωφρονέειν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαντικῇ_462"> :<emph>in respect</emph> to seer-craft: for dat., cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IA 338">Eur. IA 338</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ δοκεῖν μὲν οὐχὶ χρῄζων, τῷ δὲ βούλεσθαι θέλων.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τῷ δοκεῖν μὲν οὐχὶ χρῄζων, τῷ δὲ βούλεσθαι
							θέλων.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεσπιέπεια_463"> giving divine oracles(<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔπη</foreign>), fem. as if from <foreign xml:lang="grc">θεσπιεπής</foreign> (not found): cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρτιέπεια, ἡδυέπεια.</foreign> Since <foreign xml:lang="grc">θέ‐σπ‐ι‐ς</foreign> already involves the stem <foreign xml:lang="grc">σεπ</foreign> (Curt. <title>E.</title> sect. 632), the termination, from <foreign xml:lang="grc">vεπ</foreign>(ib. 620), is pleonastic. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δελφὶς_πέτρα_463"> The town and temple of Delphi stood in a recess like an amphitheatre, on a high platform of rock which slopes out from the south face of the cliff: Strabo 9. 418 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἱ Δελφοί, πετρῶδες χωρίον, θεατροειδές, κατὰ κορυφὴν</foreign>(i.e. at the upper part of the rocky platform, nearest the cliff) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔχον τὸ μαντεῖον καὶ τὴν πόλιν, σταδίων ἑκκαίδεκα κύκλον πληροῦσαν</foreign>: i.e. the whole sweep of the curve extends nearly two miles. <cit> <bibl n="HH 3.283">HH Apoll. 283</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὕπερθεν | πέτρη ἐπικρέμαται</quote> </cit> (the rocky platform overhangs the Crisaean plain) <foreign xml:lang="grc">κοίλη δ’ ὑποδέδρομε βῆσσα</foreign> (the valley of the Pleistus). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἶπε_τελέσαντα_463"> (for <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἶπε τελέσαι</foreign>) is somewhat rare, but is not “a solecism” (as Kennedy calls it): cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1580">Soph. OC 1580</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λέξας Οἰδίπουν ὀλωλότα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Rh. 755">Eur. Rhes. 755</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐδᾷ ξυμμάχους ὀλωλότας</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 481c">Plat. Gorg. 481c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πότερόν σε φῶμεν νυνὶ σπουδάζοντα ἢ παίζοντα;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
πότερόν σε φῶμεν νυνὶ σπουδάζοντα ἢ
									παίζοντα;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρρητ_ἀρρήτων_465"> Blaydes cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1237">Soph. OC 1237</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόπαντα | κακὰ κακῶν,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 65">Soph. Phil. 65</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔσχατ’ ἐσχάτων,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Pers. 681">Aesch. Pers. 681</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ πιστὰ πιστῶν ἥλικές τ’ ἥβης ἐμῆς, | Πέρσαι γέροντες.</quote> </cit> Cp. also 1301 <foreign xml:lang="grc">μείζονα τῶν μακίστων.</foreign> (But <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 849">Soph. El. 849</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δειλαία δειλαίων [;κυρεῖς];,</quote> </cit> cited by Blaydes, and by Jelf sect. 139, is not in point.) </gloss>

data.quote:
ὦ πιστὰ πιστῶν ἥλικές τ’ ἥβης ἐμῆς, | Πέρσαι
							γέροντες.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀελλάδων_466"> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1081">Soph. OC 1081</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀελλαία ταχύρρωστος πελειάς</quote> </cit>: fr. 621 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀελλάδες φωναί.</foreign> Not, “<emph> daughters</emph> of the storm,” as if alluding to the mares impregnated by Boreas, <ref n="Hom. Il. 20.221">Hom. Il. 20.221</ref>. For the form, cp. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">θυστάδας λιτάς</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1019">Soph. Ant. 1019</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵππων_467"> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἵππων ποδός</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 2.134">Hdt. 2.134</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πυραμίδα δὲ καὶ οὗτος ἀπελίπετο πολλὸν ἐλάσσω τοῦ πατρός</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 3.3.41">Xen. Cyrop. 3.3.41</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χώραν ἔχετε οὐδὲν ἧττον ἔντιμον τῶν πρωτοστατῶν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

							τοῦ
