χώραν ἔχετε οὐδὲν ἧττον ἔντιμον τῶν
							πρωτοστατῶν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στεροπαῖς_470"> The oracular Apollo is <foreign xml:lang="grc">Διὸς προφήτης.</foreign> As punisher of the crime which the oracle denounced, he is here armed with his father's lightnings, not merely with his own arrow (205). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γενέτας_470">, one concerned with <foreign xml:lang="grc">γένος,</foreign> either passively, = “son,” as here (cp. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">γηγενέτᾳ</quote> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 128">Eur. Phoen. 128</bibl> </cit>), or actively, = “father.” Eur. has both senses. Cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">γαμβρός,</foreign> sonin-law, brother-in-law, or father-in-law: and so <foreign xml:lang="grc">κηδεστής</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">πενθερός</foreign> could have any one of these three senses. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Κῆρες_472"> avenging spirits, identified with the Furies in <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 1055">Aesch. Seven 1055</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Κῆρες Ἐρινύες, αἵ τ’ Οἰδιπόδα | γένος ὠλέσατε.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Hes. Th. 217">Hes. Th. 217</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(Νὺξ) καὶ Μοίρας καὶ Κῆρας ἐγείνατο νηλεοποίνους … | αἵ τ’ ἀνδρῶν τε θεῶν τε παραιβασίας ἐφέπουσαι | οὐδέποτε λήγουσι θεαὶ δεινοῖο χόλοιο, | πρίν γ’ ἀπὸ τῷ δώωσι κακὴν ὄπιν, ὅστις ἁμάρτῃ.</quote> </cit> The <foreign xml:lang="grc">Μοῖραι</foreign> decree, the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Κῆρες</foreign> execute. In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 133">Soph. Trach. 133</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κῆρες</quote> </cit> = calamities. </gloss>

data.quote:
Κῆρες Ἐρινύες, αἵ τ’ Οἰδιπόδα | γένος
									ὠλέσατε.

(Νὺξ) καὶ Μοίρας καὶ Κῆρας ἐγείνατο
							νηλεοποίνους … | αἵ τ’ ἀνδρῶν τε θεῶν τε παραιβασίας ἐφέπουσαι |
									οὐδέποτε λήγουσι θεαὶ δεινοῖο χόλοιο, | πρίν γ’ ἀπὸ τῷ δώωσι
							κακὴν
									ὄπιν, ὅστις ἁμάρτῃ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀναπλάκητοι_472"> not <emph>erring</emph> or <emph>failing</emph> in pursuit: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 120">Soph. Trach. 120</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλά τις θεῶν | αἰὲν ἀναμπλάκητον Ἅιδα σφε δόμων ἐρύκει,</quote> </cit> some god <emph>suffers not</emph> Heracles <emph>to fail</emph>, but keeps him from death. Metre requires here the form without <foreign xml:lang="grc">μ. ἀμπλακεῖν</foreign> is prob. a cognate of <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάζω</foreign> (from stem <foreign xml:lang="grc"> πλαγ</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλακ,</foreign> <ref>Curt. Etym. 367</ref>), strengthened with an inserted <foreign xml:lang="grc">μ</foreign>; cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄβροτος, ἄμβροτος.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀλλά τις θεῶν | αἰὲν ἀναμπλάκητον Ἅιδα σφε
							δόμων
									ἐρύκει,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔλαμψε_473"> see on 186. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_νιφόεντος_473"> the message flashed forth like a beacon from that snow-crowned range which the Thebans see to the west. I have elsewhere noted some features of the view from the Dryoscephalae pass over Mount Cithaeron:—“At a turn of the road the whole plain of Boeotia bursts upon the sight, stretched out far below us. There to the north-west soars up Helicon, and beyond it, Parnassus; and <emph>though this is the middle of May, their higher cliffs are still crowned with dazzling snow.</emph> Just opposite, nearly due north, is Thebes, on a low eminence with a range of hills behind it, and the waters of Lake Copais to the north-west, gleaming in the afternoon sun.” (<title>Modern Greece</title>, p. 75.) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ἄνδρα_475">, and take </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάντα_475"> as neut. plur., “by all means.” The adverbial <foreign xml:lang="grc"> πάντα</foreign> is very freq. in Soph., esp. with adj., as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 911">Soph. Aj. 911</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ πάντα κωφός, ὁ πάντ’ ἄϊδρις·</quote> </cit> but also occurs with verb, as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 338">Soph. Trach. 338</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τούτων ἔχω γὰρ πάντ’ ἐπιστήμην ἐγώ</quote> </cit>: Here, the emphasis on </gloss>

data.quote: ὁ πάντα κωφός, ὁ πάντ’ ἄϊδρις·
τούτων ἔχω γὰρ πάντ’ ἐπιστήμην ἐγώ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάντα_475_2"> would partly warrant us in taking it as acc. sing. masc., subject to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰχνεύειν.</foreign> But, though the masc. nominative <foreign xml:lang="grc">πᾶς</foreign> sometimes = <foreign xml:lang="grc">πᾶς τις,</foreign> it may be doubted whether Soph. would have thus used the ambiguous <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάντα</foreign> alone for the acc. sing. masc. Ellendt compares 226, but there <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάντα</foreign> is acc. plur. neut. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέτρας_ἰσόταυρος_478"> is J. F. Martin's and E. L. Lushington's brilliant emendation of <foreign xml:lang="grc">πετραῖος ὁ ταῦρος,</foreign> the reading of the first hand in L. It is at once closer to the letters, and more poetical, than <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέτρας ἅτε ταῦρος</foreign> (Dorville, —where the use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἅτε</foreign> is un-Attic), <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέτρας ἴσα ταύροις</foreign> (M. Schmidt), or <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέτρας ὡς ταῦρος,</foreign> which last looks like a prosaic correction. I suppose the corruption to have arisen thus. A transcriber who had before him <foreign xml:lang="grc">ΠΕΤΡΑΣΙΣΟΤΑΥΡΟΣ</foreign> took the first O for the art., and then amended <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ΠΕΤΡΑΣΙΣ</foreign> into the familiar word <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ΠΕΤΡΑΙΟΣ.</foreign> With a cursive MS. this would have been still easier, since in <foreign xml:lang="grc">πετρασισοταυρος</foreign> the first <foreign xml:lang="grc">ς</foreign> might have been taken for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ο</foreign> (not a rare mistake), and then a simple transposition of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ι</foreign> and the supposed <foreign xml:lang="grc">ο</foreign> would have given <foreign xml:lang="grc"> πετραιος.</foreign> It is true that such compounds with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰσο</foreign> usu. mean, not merely “like,” but “as good as” or “no better than”: e.g. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰσοδαίμων, ἰσόθεος, ἰσόνεκυς, ἰσόνειρος, ἰσόπαις, ἰσόπρεσβυς.</foreign> Here, however, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰσόταυρος_478"> can well mean “wild” or “fierce of heart” as a bull. And we know that in the lost <foreign xml:lang="grc">Κρέουσα</foreign> Soph. used <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰσοθάνατος</foreign> in a way which seemed too bold to Pollux (6. 174 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ πάνυ ἀνεκτόν</foreign>), —probably in the sense of “dread as death” (cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 215">Soph. Aj. 215</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θανάτῳ γὰρ ἴσον πάθος ἐκπεύσεἰ.</quote> </cit> The bull is the type of a savage wanderer who avoids his fellows. Soph. in a lost play spoke of a bull “that shuns the herd,” Bekk. <title> Anecd.</title> 459.31 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀτιμαγέλης· ὁ ἀποστάτης τῆς ἀγέλης ταῦρος· οὕτω Σοφοκλῆς</foreign>.<ref n="Verg. G. 3.225">Verg. Georg. 3.225</ref> (taurus) <foreign xml:lang="lat">Victus abit, longeque ignotis exulat oris.</foreign> <cit> <bibl>Theocr. 14.43</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἶνός θην λέγεταί τις, ἔβα καὶ ταῦρος ἀν’ ὕλαν</quote> </cit>: a proverb <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ τῶν μὴ ἀναστρεφόντων</foreign>(schol.). The image also suggests the fierce despair of the wretched outlaw: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Lib. 275">Aesch. Lib. 275</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποχρημάτοισι ζημίαις ταυρούμενον,</quote> </cit> “stung to fury by the wrongs that keep me from my heritage”: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 92">Eur. Med. 92</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄμμα ταυρουμένην</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Frogs 804">Aristoph. Frogs 804</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔβλεψε γοῦν ταυρηδὸν ἐγκύψας κάτω</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedo 117b">Plat. Phaedo 117b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταυρηδὸν ὑποβλέψας πρὸς τὸν ἄνθρωπον.</quote> </cit> With regard to the reading <foreign xml:lang="grc">πετραῖος ὁ ταῦρος,</foreign> see Appendix. </gloss>

data.quote:
αἶνός θην λέγεταί τις, ἔβα καὶ ταῦρος ἀν’
									ὕλαν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χηρεύων_479"> solitary, as one who is <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀφρήτωρ, ἀθέμιστος, ἀνέστιος</foreign>(<ref n="Hom. Il. 9.63">Hom. Il. 9.63</ref>): he knows the doom which cuts him off from all human fellowship (236 f.). <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 656">Aesch. Eum. 656</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποία δὲ χέρνιψ φρατέρων προσδέξεται;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_μαντεῖα_480"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ ἀπὸ μέσου ὀμφαλοῦ γᾶς</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1386">Soph. El. 1386</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δωμάτων ὑπόστεγοι</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπὸ στέγῃ δωμάτων</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 1351">Eur. Phoen. 1351</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λευκοπήχεις κτύπους χεροῖν.</quote> </cit> The <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀμφαλός</foreign> in the Delphian temple (<ref n="Aesch. Eum. 40">Aesch. Eum. 40</ref>), a large white stone in the form of a half globe, was held to mark the spot at which the eagles from east and west had met: hence Pindar calls Delphi itself <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέγαν ὀμφαλὸν εὐρυκόλπου | … χθονός</foreign>(<ref n="Pind. N. 7">Pind. N. 7.33</ref>):<ref>Liv. 38.48</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">Delphos, umbilicum orbis terrarum.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπονοσφίζων_480"> trying to put away (from himself): the midd. (cp. 691) would be more usual, but poetry admits the active: 894 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ψυχᾶς ἀμύνειν</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 294">Eur. Orest. 294</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνακάλυπτε … κάρα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 4">Pind. P. 4.106</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κομίζων</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">κομιζόμενος</foreign> (seeking to recover): <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 6">Soph. OC 6</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φέροντα</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">φερόμενον.</foreign> In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 979">Soph. Phil. 979</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπονοσφίζειν τινά τινος</quote> </cit>= to rob one of a thing: but here we cannot render “frustrating.” </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζῶντα_482"> “ living,” i.e. operative, effectual; see on 45 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ζώσας.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περιποτᾶται_482"> the doom pronounced by Apollo hovers around the murderer as the <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἷστρος</foreign> around some tormented animal: he cannot shake off its pursuit. The haunting thoughts of guilt are objectively imaged as terrible words ever sounding in the wanderer's ears. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεινὰ_οὖν_483"> .<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὖν</foreign> marks the turning to a new topic, with something of concessive force: “ <emph>it is true</emph> that the murderer is said to be here”: <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὲν</foreign> is answered by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δὲ_483"> after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέξω_483">. For <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὲν οὖν</foreign> with this distributed force, cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 664">Soph. OC 664</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 65">Soph. Ant. 65</ref>: for the composite <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὲν οὖν</foreign>( = “nay rather”), below, 705. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεινὰ_483"> is adverbial: for (1) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταράσσει_483"> could not mean <foreign xml:lang="grc">κινεῖ,</foreign> stirs up, raises, dread questions: (2) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοκοῦντα_ἀποφάσκοντα_483"> are acc. sing. masc., referring to <foreign xml:lang="grc">με</foreign> understood. The schol., <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔτε πιστὰ οὔτε ἄπιστα,</foreign> has favoured the attempt to take the participles as acc. neut. plur., </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποφάσκοντα_483"> being explained as “negative” in the sense of “admitting of negation,” <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπόφασιν καὶ ἀπιστίαν δεχόμενα</foreign> (Triclinius). This is fruitless torture of language. Nor will the conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπαρέσκοντ’</foreign> (Blaydes) serve: for, even if the Chorus found the charge credible, they would not find it <emph> pleasing.</emph> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοκοῦντα_483"> is not “believing,” but “<emph>approving</emph>.” Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1102">Soph. Ant. 1102</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ταῦτ’ ἐπαινεῖς καὶ δοκεῖς παρεικαθεῖν;</quote> </cit> “and you recommend this course, and approve of yielding?” The pregnant force of </gloss>

data.quote: καὶ ταῦτ’ ἐπαινεῖς καὶ δοκεῖς παρεικαθεῖν;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοκοῦντα_483_2"> is here brought out by the direct contrast with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποφάσκοντα_483_2">. In gauging the rarer uses of particular words by an artist in language so subtle and so bold as Soph. we must never neglect the context. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέξω_485"> probably deliberative aor. subj.: though it might be fut. indic. (cp. 1419, and n. on <ref n="Soph. OC 310">Soph. OC 310</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνθάδε_485"> the actual situation, implies the known facts of the past; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀπίσω_485"> refers to the seer's hint of the future (v. 453 <foreign xml:lang="grc">φανήσεται κ.τ.λ.)</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 2.482">Hom. Od. 2.482</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σεῖο δ’, Ἀχιλλεῦ, | οὔτις ἀνὴρ προπάροιθε μακάρτατος, οὔτ’ ἄρ’ ὀπίσσω</quote> </cit> (nor will be hereafter). </gloss>

data.quote:
σεῖο δ’, Ἀχιλλεῦ, | οὔτις ἀνὴρ προπάροιθε
							μακάρτατος, οὔτ’ ἄρ’ ὀπίσσω

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_Πολύβου_487"> A quarrel might have originated with either house. This is what the disjunctive statement marks: since </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔκειτο_487">, “had been made,” implies “had been provoked.” But we see the same Greek tendency as in the use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">τε καί</foreign> where <foreign xml:lang="grc">καί</foreign> alone would be more natural: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 927">Aesch. PB 927</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τό τ’ ἄρχειν καὶ τὸ δουλεύειν δίχα</quote> </cit> : cp. <ref>Hor. Ep. 1.2.12</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">Inter Hectora Priamiden animosum atque inter Achillen</foreign>. </gloss>

data.quote: τό τ’ ἄρχειν καὶ τὸ δουλεύειν δίχα

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_ὅτου_493"> In the antistr., 509, the words </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γὰρ_αὐτῷ_493"> are undoubtedly sound: here then we need to supply <foreign xml:lang="grc">¯¯ ˘˘</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">˘ ¯¯ ˘</foreign>. I incline to believe that the loss has been that of a participle going with <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασάνῳ.</foreign> Had this been </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βασανίζων_493">, the iteration would help to account for the loss. Reading </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_βασάνῳ_493">, I should take </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_493"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βασάνῳ_493">: “testing <emph>on</emph> the touchstone whereof” —“using which(<foreign xml:lang="grc">νεῖκος</foreign>) as a test.” [;Receiving my <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασανίζων,</foreign> Kennedy (ed. 1885) replaces the word <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασάνῳ</foreign> by <foreign xml:lang="grc"> πιθανῶς.</foreign>]; To Brunck's <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασάνῳ χρησάμενος</foreign> (<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 946c">Plat. Laws 946c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βασάνοις χρώμενοι</quote> </cit>) the objections are (1) the aorist part. where we need the pres., (2) the tame and prosaic phrase. Wolff writes, <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ὅτου δή, βασάνῳ <πίστιν ἔχων></foreign>: Wecklein and Mekler (in his recension of Dindorf's ed., Teubner, 1885) indicate a lacuna, <foreign xml:lang="grc">¯˘˘¯</foreign>, after <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασάνῳ.</foreign> Two other courses of emendation are possible: (i) To supply after <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔμαθον</foreign> something to express the informant, as <foreign xml:lang="grc">τινος ἀστῶν</foreign> or, <foreign xml:lang="grc">προφέροντος,</foreign> when <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ὅτου</foreign> would mean “at whose suggestion.” This remedy seems to me improbable. (ii) To supply <foreign xml:lang="grc">σύν</foreign> and an adj. for <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασάνῳ,</foreign> as <foreign xml:lang="grc">σὺν ἀληθεῖ β.,</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">β. σὺν φανερᾷ.</foreign> As the mutilated verse stands in the MSS., it cannot, I think, be translated without some violence to Greek idiom. The most tolerable version would be this: —“setting out from which(<foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ὅτου</foreign> neut., referring to <foreign xml:lang="grc">νεῖκος</foreign>), I can with good warrant(<foreign xml:lang="grc">βασάνῳ</foreign>) assail the public fame of Oed.” Then <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασάνῳ</foreign> would be an instrumental dative equivalent to <foreign xml:lang="grc">βάσανον ἔχων</foreign>: and <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ὅτου</foreign> would be like 1236 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς τίνος ποτ’ αἰτίας;</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 51">Soph. Ant. 51</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς αὐτοφώρων ἀμπλακημάτων· πρός</quote> </cit> denoting the source back to which the act can be traced. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπὶ_εἶμι_495"> a phrase from war: it is unnecessary to suppose tmesis: <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.157">Hdt. 1.157</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">στρατὸν ἐπ’ ἑωυτὸν ἰόντα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. IA 349">Eur. IA 349</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα μέν σε πρῶτ’ ἐπῆλθον, ἵνα σε πρῶθ’ ηὗρον κακόν,</quote> </cit> <emph>censured</emph> thee: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Andr. 688">Eur. Andr. 688</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτ’ εὖ φρονῶν σ’ ἐπῆλθον, οὐκ ὀργῆς χάριν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ταῦτα μέν σε πρῶτ’ ἐπῆλθον, ἵνα σε πρῶθ’ ηὗρον
							κακόν,

ταῦτ’ εὖ φρονῶν σ’ ἐπῆλθον, οὐκ ὀργῆς
									χάριν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θανάτων_497"> after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπίκουρος_497"> is not objective, “against” (as <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 4.3.7">Xen. Mem. 4.3.7</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῦρ … ἐπίκουρον … ψύχους</quote> </cit>), but causal, “on account of”; being softened by the approximation of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπίκουρος</foreign> to the sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">τιμωρός</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. El. 135">Eur. El. 135</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔλθοις τῶνδε πόνων ἐμοὶ τᾷ μελέᾳ λυτήρ, | … πατρί θ’ αἱμάτων | ἐχθίστων ἐπίκουρος</quote> </cit>(= “avenger”). The allusive plur. </gloss>

data.quote:
ἔλθοις τῶνδε πόνων ἐμοὶ τᾷ μελέᾳ λυτήρ, | …
							πατρί θ’ αἱμάτων | ἐχθίστων ἐπίκουρος

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Θανάτων_497"> is like <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἱμάτων</foreign> there, and <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεσποτῶν θανάτοισι</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Lib. 52">Aesch. Lib. 52</bibl> </cit>: cp. above 366, <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῖς φιλτάτοις.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὖν_498">, cp. 483) that <emph>gods</emph> indeed (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέν_498">) have perfect knowledge. But there is no way of deciding in a strict sense (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀληθής_498">) that any <emph>mortal</emph> who essays to read the future attains to more than I do— i.e. to more than <emph>conjecture:</emph> though I admit that one man may excel another in the art of interpreting omens according to the general rules of augural lore (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοφίᾳ_498">: cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">σοφὸς οἰωνοθέτας</foreign> 484). The disquieted speaker clings to the negative argument: “Teiresias is more likely to be right than a common man: still it is not <emph>certain</emph> that he is right.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλέον_φέρεται_500"> achieves a better result, —deserves to be ranked above me: <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.31">Hdt. 1.31</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοκέων πάγχυ δευτερεῖα γῶν οἴσεσθαι,</quote> </cit> “thinking that he was sure of the second place at least.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παραμείψειεν_504"> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IA 145">Eur. IA 145</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή τίς σε λάθῃ | τροχαλοῖσιν ὅχοις παραμειψαμένη | … ἀπήνη.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
μή τίς σε λάθῃ | τροχαλοῖσιν ὅχοις
									παραμειψαμένη
									| … ἀπήνη.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὶν_ἴδοιμ_506"> After an optative of wish or hypothesis in the principal clause, <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρίν</foreign> regularly takes optat.: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 961">Soph. Phil. 961</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄλοιο μήπω πρὶν μάθοιμ’ εἰ καὶ πάλιν | γνώμην μετοίσεις.</quote> </cit> So after <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅπως, ὅστις, ἵνα,</foreign> etc.: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 297">Aesch. Eum. 297</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕλθοι … | ὅπως γένοιτο</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hel. 435">Eur. Hel. 435</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς ἂν … μόλοι | ὄστις διαγγείλειε … ;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὄλοιο μήπω πρὶν μάθοιμ’ εἰ καὶ πάλιν | γνώμην
							μετοίσεις.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀρθὀν_506"> the notion is not “upright,” established, but “straight,” — <emph> justified</emph> by proof, as by the application of a rule: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Birds 1004">Aristoph. Birds 1004</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀρθῷ μετρήσω κανόνι προστιθείς</quote> </cit>: so below, 853, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1178">Soph. Ant. 1178</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὔπος ὡς ἄρ’ ὀρθὸν ἤνυσας.</quote> </cit> Hartung (whom Wolff follows) places the comma ofter </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀρθόν_506">, not after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔπος_506">: “ until I see (it) established, I will not approve the word of censurers”: but the acc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔπος</foreign> could not be governed by <foreign xml:lang="grc">καταφαίην</foreign> in this sense. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καταφαίην_507"> <cit> <bibl n="Aristot. Met. 3.1002b">Aristot. Met. 3.6</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀδύνατον ἅμα καταφάναι καὶ ἀποφάναι ἀληθῶς.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Def. 413c">Plat. Def. 413c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλήθεια ἕξις ἐν καταφάσει καὶ ἀποφάσει.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

ἀδύνατον ἅμα καταφάναι καὶ ἀποφάναι
									ἀληθῶς.
ἀλήθεια ἕξις ἐν καταφάσει καὶ ἀποφάσει.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπ_αὐτῷ_508"> against him: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1472">Soph. OC 1472</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πτερόεσσα_κόρα_508"> the Sphinx having the face of a maiden, and the winged body of a lion: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 1042">Eur. Phoen. 1042</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁ πτεροῦσσα παρθένος.</quote> </cit> See Appendix, n. on v. 508. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁδύπολις_510"> only, which, as a dat. of manner, it qualifies with nearly adverbial force: commending himself to the city under a practical test. — i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔργῳ καὶ οὐ λόγῳ.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 10">Pind. P. 10.67</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πειρῶντι δὲ καὶ χρυσὸς ἐν βασάνῳ πρέπει | καὶ νόος ὀρθός</quote> </cit>: “an upright mind, like gold, is shown by the touchstone, when one assays it”: as base metal <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">τρίβῳ τε καὶ προσβολαῖς | μελαμπαγὴς πέλει | δικαιωθείς</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 391">Aesch. Ag. 391</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>
