							νόος
									ὀρθός

τρίβῳ τε καὶ προσβολαῖς | μελαμπαγὴς πέλει |
							δικαιωθείς

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἁδύπολις_510_2"> in the sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἁνδάνων τῇ πόλει</foreign> (cp. <cit> <bibl n="Pind. N. 8">Pind. N. 8.38</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀστοῖς ἀδών</quote> </cit>): boldly formed on the analogy of compounds in which the adj. represents a verb governing the <emph>accus.,</emph> as <foreign xml:lang="grc">φιλόπολις</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">φιλῶν τὴν πόλιν, ὀρθόπολις</foreign> (epithet of a good dynasty) = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀρθῶν τὴν πόλιν</foreign> (<ref n="Pind. O. 2">Pind. O. 2.7</ref>). In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 370">Soph. Ant. 370</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑψίπολις</quote> </cit> is analogous, though not exactly similar, if it means <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑψηλὸς ἐν πόλει,</foreign> and not <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑψηλὴν πόλιν ἔχων</foreign> (like <foreign xml:lang="grc">δικαιόπολις</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">δικαίας πόλεις ἔχουσα,</foreign> of Aegina, <ref n="Pind. P. 8">Pind. P. 8.22</ref> ). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῷ_511"> “therefore,” as <ref n="Hom. Il. 1.418">Hom. Il. 1.418</ref> etc.; joined with <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">νύ,</quote> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 7.352">Hom. Il. 7.352</bibl> </cit> etc.: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Theaet. 179d">Plat. Theaet. 179d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ τοι, ὦ φλἜ Θεόδωρε, μᾶλλον σκεπτέον ἐξ ἀρχῆς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τῷ τοι, ὦ φλἜ Θεόδωρε, μᾶλλον σκεπτέον ἐξ
							ἀρχῆς.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπ_511"> on the part of: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 471">Soph. Trach. 471</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀπ’ ἐμοῦ κτήσει χάριν.</quote> </cit> The hiatus after <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷ</foreign> is an epic trait, occasionally allowed in tragic lyrics, as in the case of interjections (cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 832">Soph. Phil. 832</ref> n.). Here the stress on <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷ,</foreign> and the caesura, both excuse it. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 194">Soph. Aj. 194</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἄνα ἐξ ἑδράνων</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 148">Soph. El. 148</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἃ Ἴτυν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 157">Soph. El. 157</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἵα Χρυσόθεμις ζώει καὶ Ἰφιάνασσα</quote> </cit> (cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 9.145">Hom. Il. 9.145</ref>). Neither <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς</foreign> (Elmsley) nor <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρ’</foreign> (Wolff) is desirable. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀτλητῶν_515"> The verb <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀτλητέω,</foreign> found only here, implies an active sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄτλητος,</foreign> <foreign xml:lang="lat">impatiens:</foreign> as <foreign xml:lang="grc"> μεμπτός,</foreign> pass. in <ref n="Soph. OC 1036">Soph. OC 1036</ref>, is active in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 446">Soph. Trach. 446</ref>. So from the act. sense of the verbal adj. come <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλαστέω, ἀναισθητέω, ἀναισχυντέω, ἀνελπιστέω, ἀπρακτέω.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρός_ἐμοῦ_516"> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 738">Soph. Trach. 738</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί δ’ ἐστίν, ὦ παῖ, πρός γ’ ἑμοῦ στυγούμενον;</quote> </cit> The conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρός τί μου</foreign> was prompted by the absence of <foreign xml:lang="grc">τι</foreign> with </gloss>

data.quote:
τί δ’ ἐστίν, ὦ παῖ, πρός γ’ ἑμοῦ
									στυγούμενον;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέρον_516">: but cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 261">Aesch. Ag. 261</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ δ’ εἴτε</quote> </cit> (v. l. <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴ τἰ κεδνὸν εἴτε μὴ πεπυσμένη</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Soph. 237c">Plat. Soph. 237c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χαλεπὸν ἤρου</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Meno 97e">Plat. Meno 97e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἐκείνου ποιημάτων λελυμένον μὲν ἐκτῆσθαι οὐ πολλῆς τινος ἄξιόν ἐστι τιμῆς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τῶν ἐκείνου ποιημάτων λελυμένον μὲν ἐκτῆσθαι
							οὐ
									πολλῆς τινος ἄξιόν ἐστι τιμῆς.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴτε_517">, cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 236">Soph. Trach. 236</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 907d">Plat. Laws 907d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐάν τις ἀσεβῇ λόγοις εἴτ’ ἔργοις·</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 4">Pind. P. 4.78</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξεῖνος αἴτ’ ὢν ἀστός.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἐάν τις ἀσεβῇ λόγοις εἴτ’ ἔργοις·

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέρον_517"> 519 <foreign xml:lang="grc">φέροντι</foreign>: 520 <foreign xml:lang="grc">φέρει</foreign>: such repetitions are not rare in the best Greek and Latin writers. Cp. 158, 159 <foreign xml:lang="grc"> (ἄμβροτ’),</foreign> 1276, 1278 <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ὁμοῦ</foreign>),<ref>Lucr. 2.54-59</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat"> tenebris—tenebris—tenebris—tenebras.</foreign> See on <ref n="Soph. OC 554">Soph. OC 554</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 76">Soph. Ant. 76</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βίου_μακρ_518"> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 473">Soph. Aj. 473</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ μακροῦ χρῄζειν βίου</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1214">Soph. OC 1214</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἱ μακραὶ | ἁμέραι,</quote> </cit> where the art. refers to the normal span of human life. For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βίος_μακραίων_518"> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 791">Soph. Trach. 791</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσπάρευνον λέκτρον.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_ἁπλοῦν_519"> The charge does not hurt him in a <emph>single</emph> aspect only,—i.e. merely in his relation to his family and friends <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἰδίᾀ.</foreign> It touches him also in relation to the State <foreign xml:lang="grc">(κοινᾖ,</foreign> since treachery to his kinsman would be treason to his king. Hence it “tends to the largest result” (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέρει_μέγιστον_519">), bearing on the sum of his relations as man and citizen. The thought is, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ ζημία οὐχ ἁπλῆ ἐστιν ἀλλὰ πολυειδής</foreign> (cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedrus 270d">Plat. Phaedrus 270d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁπλοῦν ἢ πολυειδές ἐστιν</quote> </cit>): but the proper antithesis to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἁπλῆ</foreign> is merged in the comprehensive <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέγιστον.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλὰ_δὴ_523"> cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 627">Soph. Trach. 627</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦλθε_ἂν_523">, “might perhaps have come.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἧλθεν ἂν</foreign> is a potential indicative, denoting for past time what <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔλθοι ἂν</foreign> denotes for future time. That is, as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔλθοι ἂν</foreign> can mean, “it <emph>might</emph> come,” so <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦλθεν ἂν</foreign> can mean, “it <emph>might have</emph> come.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦλθεν ἂν</foreign> does not necessarily imply that the suggested possibility is contrary to fact; i.e., it does not necessarily imply, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἦλθεν.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 37.57">Dem. 37.57</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς ἂν ὁ μὴ παρὼν … ἐγώ τί σε ἠδίκησα;</quote> </cit> “how was I likely to do you any wrong?” [;This was the view taken in my first edition. Goodwin, in the new ed. of his <title>Moods and Tenses</title> (1889), has illustrated the “potential” indicative with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄν</foreign> (sect. 244), and has also shown at length that <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦλθεν ἂν</foreign> does not necessarily imply the unreality of the supposition (sect. 412). This answers the objection which led me, in a second edition, to suggest that <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταχ’ ἂν</foreign> was here no more than <foreign xml:lang="grc">τάχα,</foreign> and that the usage arose from an ellipse <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἦλθε, τάχα δ’ ἂν ἔλθοἰ.</foreign> In <ref n="Soph. OC 964">Soph. OC 964 ff.</ref> also I should now take <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦν … τάχ’ ἂν</foreign> as = “perchance it may have been.”]; </gloss>

data.quote: πῶς ἂν ὁ μὴ παρὼν … ἐγώ τί σε ἠδίκησα;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὔπος_δ_525">, because (1) Creon seems to ask the Chorus for a confirmation of the almost incredible report that <emph>Oed.</emph> had brought such a charge: he would naturally be less concerned to know whether any one had uttered it <emph>before</emph> Oed. (2) Verse 527 favours <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοὔπος.</foreign> —Cp. 848 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὡς φανέν γε τοὔπος.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ηὐδᾶτο_527"> these things were <emph>said</emph> (by Oedipus); but I do not know how much the words meant; i.e. whether he spoke at random, or from information which had convinced his judgment. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξ_τε_528"> gives a fuller emphasis than </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξ_δὲ_528">: when </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δ_528"> had been omitted, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τε_528"> was naturally changed to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δέ_528">. The place of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τε_528_2"> (as to which both verse and prose allowed some latitude) is warranted, since <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀμμάτων‐ὀρθῶν</foreign> opposed to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀπθῆς φρενός</foreign> forms a single notion. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξ_528">= “with”: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 455">Soph. El. 455</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ὑπερτέρας χερός</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 875">Soph. Trach. 875</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ἀκινήτου ποδός.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀμμάτων_ὀρθῶν_528">: cp. 1385: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 477">Soph. Aj. 477</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κεἰ μὴ τόδ’ ὄμμα καὶ φρένες διάστροφοι | γνώμης ἀπῇξαν τῆς ἐμῆς</quote> </cit>:<ref n="Eur. Her. 931">Eur. Her. 931</ref> (when the frenzy comes on Heracles) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ δ’ οὐκέθ’ αὑτὸς ἦν, | ἀλλ’ ἐν στροφαῖσιν ὀμμάτων ἐφθαρμένος, κ.τ.λ.</foreign> In <ref n="Hor. Carm. 1.3.18">Hor. Carm. 1.3.18</ref> Bentley gave <foreign xml:lang="lat">rectis oculis</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="lat"> siccis.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
κεἰ μὴ τόδ’ ὄμμα καὶ φρένες διάστροφοι |
							γνώμης
									ἀπῇξαν τῆς ἐμῆς

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_οἶδ_530"> Creon has asked: “Did any trace of madness show itself in the bearing or in the speech of Oedipus?” The Chorus reply: “Our part is only to hear, not to criticise.” These nobles of Thebes (1223) have no eyes for indiscretion in their sovereign master. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὗτος_σύ_532">: cp. 1121: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hec. 1280">Eur. Hec. 1280</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗτος σύ, μαίνει καὶ κακῶν ἐρᾷς τυχεῖν;</quote> </cit> where <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὗτος, σὺ μαίνει</foreign> is impossible. </gloss>

data.quote: οὗτος σύ, μαίνει καὶ κακῶν ἐρᾷς τυχεῖν;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόλμης_532"> gen. of quality (or material); cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 114">Soph. Ant. 114</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χιόνος πτέρυγι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 19">Soph. El. 19</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄστρων εὐφρόνη.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοσόνδε_τόλμηςπρόσωπον_532"> like <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοὐμὸν φρενῶν‐ὄνειρον</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. El. 1390">Soph. El. 1390</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">νεῖκος‐ἀνδρῶν ξύναιμον</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. Ant. 793">Soph. Ant. 793</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φονεὺς_κτλ_534"> ‘who art the proved assassin … and palpable robber …’ </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_ἐμῆς_535"> closely follows </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦδε_τἀνδρός_535">, as <ref n="Soph. OC 1329">Soph. OC 1329</ref>: so <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 865">Soph. Aj. 865</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μυθήσομαι</quote> </cit> immediately follows <foreign xml:lang="grc">Αἴας θροεῖ.</foreign> If a Greek speaker rhetorically refers to himself in the third person, he usu. reverts as soon as possible to the first. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔν_μοι_537"> The MSS. have </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_ἐμοί_537">, making a verse like <ref n="Soph. Trach. 4">Soph. Trach. 4</ref>,<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ | δὲ τὸν ἐμ|όν, καὶ πρὶν εἰς Ἅιδου μολεῖν.</foreign> But such a verse is rare, and unpleasing. When a tribrach holds the second place in a tragic senarius, we usually find that (a) the tribrach is a single word, as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1314">Soph. Phil. 1314</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥσθην | πατέρα | τὸν ἀμὸν εὐλογοῦντά σε</quote> </cit>: or (b) there is a caesura between the first and the second foot, as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 26">Soph. OC 26</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὅς|τις ὁ τόπ|ος</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1232">Soph. Phil. 1232</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παρ’ οὖπερ ἔλαβον</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Tro. 496">Eur. Tro. 496</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τρυχηρ|ὰ περὶ | τρυχηρὸν εἱμένην χρόα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 511">Eur. Phoen. 511</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλθόντ|α σὺν ὅπλ|οις τόνδε καὶ πορθοῦντα γῆν,</quote> </cit> —if there we should not read <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐλθόντ’ ἐν ὅπλοις.</foreign> On such a point as </gloss>

data.quote: ἥσθην | πατέρα | τὸν ἀμὸν εὐλογοῦντά σε

ἐλθόντ|α σὺν ὅπλ|οις τόνδε καὶ πορθοῦντα
									γῆν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμοὶ_537"> versus </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μοι_537"> the authority of our MSS. is not weighty. And the enclitic </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μοι_537_2"> suffices: for in this verse the stress is on the verbal notion (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰδών_537">), — Creon's supposed <emph>insight:</emph> the reference to Oedipus is drawn out in the next two verses by the verbs in the 1st person, <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνωριοῖμι—ἀλεξοίμην.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰδών_ἐν_537"> prose would say <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐνιδών,</foreign> either with or without <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν</foreign> (<ref n="Thuc. 1.95">Thuc. 1.95</ref>:<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅπερ καὶ ἐν τῷ Παυσανίᾳ ἐνεῖδον</foreign>: 3. 30 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὃ … τοῖς πολεμίοις ἐνορῶν</foreign>): cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.37">Hdt. 1.37</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε τινὰ δειλίην παριδών μοι</quote> </cit> (<emph>remarked</emph> in me) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔτε ἀθυμίην.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποεῖν_537"> Attic inscrr. of c. 450-300 B.C. omit the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ι</foreign> before <foreign xml:lang="grc">ε</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">η</foreign> (not before <foreign xml:lang="grc">ο</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">ω</foreign>), as L usu. does, when the 1st syll. is short: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 120">Soph. Phil. 120</ref> n. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_τοὔργον_538"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Supply <foreign xml:lang="grc"> νομίσας</foreign> or the like from </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰδών_538">: “thinking that <emph>either</emph> I would not see, … <emph>or</emph> would not ward it off”: an example of what Greek rhetoric called <foreign xml:lang="grc">χιασμός</foreign> (from the form of X), since the first clause corresponds with <foreign xml:lang="grc">μωρία,</foreign> and the second with <foreign xml:lang="grc">δειλία.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γνωριοῖμι_538"> “Futures in <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐ἰσω</foreign> are not common in the good Attic period: but we have no trustworthy collections on this point”: Curtius, <title>Verb</title> 11.312, Eng. tr. 481. On the other hand, as he says, more than 20 futures in <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐ιῶ</foreign> can be quoted from Attic literature. And though some ancient grammarians call the form “Attic,” it is not exclusively so: instances occur both in Homer (as <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 10.331">Hom. Il. 10.331</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγλαϊεῖσθαι,</quote> </cit> cp. Monro, <title>Hom. Gram.</title> §63) and in Herodotus (as <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 8.68">Hdt. 8.68</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτρεμιεῖν,</quote> </cit> besides about ten other examples in Hdt.). Thus the evidence for </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γνωριοῖμι_538_2"> outweighs the preference of our MSS. for <foreign xml:lang="grc"> γνωρίσοιμι.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_οὐκ_539"> The <foreign xml:lang="grc">κοὐκ</foreign> of the MSS. cannot be defended here—where stress is laid on the dilemma of <foreign xml:lang="grc">δειλία</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">μωρία</foreign>— by instances of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἤ … τε</foreign> carelessly put for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἤ—ἤ</foreign> in cases where there is no such sharp distinction of alternatives: as <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 2.289">Hom. Il. 2.289</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ παῖδες νεαροὶ χῆραί τε γυναῖκες</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 524">Aesch. Eum. 524</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ πόλις βροτός θ’ ὁμοίως.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἢ παῖδες νεαροὶ χῆραί τε γυναῖκες

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλεξοίμην_539"> see on 171. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλήθους_541"> refers to the rank and file of the aspirant's following, —his popular partisans or the troops in his pay; </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Φίλων_541">, to his powerful connections, —the men whose wealth and influence support him. Thus (542) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρήμασιν_541"> is substituted for <foreign xml:lang="grc">φίλων.</foreign> Soph. is thinking of the historical Greek <foreign xml:lang="grc">τύραννος,</foreign> who commonly began his career as a demagogue, or else “arose out of the bosom of the oligarchies” (Grote, vol. 3 p. 25). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὃ_542"> <emph>a thing</emph> which, marking the general category in which the <foreign xml:lang="grc">τυραννίς</foreign> is to be placed: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 3.9.8">Xen. Mem. 3.9.8</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φθόνον δὲ σκοπῶν ὅ τι εἴη.</quote> </cit> So the neut. adj. is used, <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 109">Eur. Hipp. 109</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τερπνὸν … | τράπεζα πλήρης</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hel. 1687">Eur. Hel. 1687</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γνώμης, ὃ πολλαῖς ἐν γυναιξὶν οὐκ ἔνι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: φθόνον δὲ σκοπῶν ὅ τι εἴη.
γνώμης, ὃ πολλαῖς ἐν γυναιξὶν οὐκ ἔνι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶσθ_πόησον_543"> In more than twelve places of the tragic or comic poets we have this or a like form where a person is eagerly bespeaking attention to a command or request. Instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶσθ’ ὡς δεῖ σε ποιῆσαι;</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶσθ’ ὥς σε κελεύω ποιῆσαι;</foreign> the anxious haste of the speaker substitutes an abrupt imperative: <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶσθ’ ὡς ποίησον;</foreign> That the imperative was here felt as equivalent to “<emph>you are to do</emph>,” appears clearly from the substitutes which sometimes replace it. Thus we find (1) fut. indic.; <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Cycl. 131">Eur. Cycl. 131</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶσθ’ οὖν ὃ δράσεις;</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 600">Eur. Med. 600</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶσθ’ ὡς μετεύξει καὶ σοφωτέρα φανεῖ;</quote> </cit> where the conjectures <foreign xml:lang="grc">δρᾶσον</foreign> (Canter) and <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέτευξαι</foreign> (Elmsley) are arbitrary: so with the 1st pers., <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IT 759">Eur. IT 759</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ οἶσθ’ ὃ δράσω;</quote> </cit> (2) a periphrasis: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Supp. 932">Eur. Supp. 932</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ οἶσθ’ ὃ δρᾶν σε βούλομαι τούτων πέρι;</quote> </cit> Only a sense that the imperat. had this force could explain the still bolder form of the phrase with 3rd pers.: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IT 1203">Eur. IT 1203</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶσθά νυν ἅ μοι γενέσθω</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἃ δεῖ γενέσθαι μοι</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Ach. 1064">Aristoph. Ach. 1064</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶσθ’ ὡς ποιείτω</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς δεῖ ποιεῖν αὐτήν,</foreign> where <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποιεῖτε</foreign> is a conjecture. There is no reason, in logic or in grammar, against this “subordinate imperative,” which the flexible Greek idiom allowed. Few would now be satisfied with the old theory that <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶσθ’ ὡς ποίησον</foreign> stood, by transposition, for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποίησον, οἶσθ’ ὡς;</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: οἶσθ’ ὡς μετεύξει καὶ σοφωτέρα φανεῖ;
ἀλλ’ οἶσθ’ ὃ δρᾶν σε βούλομαι τούτων πέρι;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακὸς_546"> with inf., cp. <ref n="Thuc. 6.38">Thuc. 6.38</ref> sect. 2 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡμεῖς δὲ κακοὶ … προφυλάξασθαι.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοῦ_546">, emphatic by place and pause: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1505">Soph. El. 1505</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χρῆν δ’ εὐθὺς εἶναι τήνδε τοῖς πᾶσιν δίκην | ὅστις πέρα πράσσειν γε τῶν νόμων θέλει, | κτείνειν· τὸ γὰρ πανοῦργον οὐκ ἂν ἦν πολύ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
χρῆν δ’ εὐθὺς εἶναι τήνδε τοῖς πᾶσιν δίκην |
							ὅστις
									πέρα πράσσειν γε τῶν νόμων θέλει, | κτείνειν· τὸ γὰρ πανοῦργον
							οὐκ
									ἂν ἦν πολύ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ηὕρηκ_546"> as to the augment, cp. 68 n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτ_αὐτὸ_547"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Oedipus flings back Creon's phrases, as the Antigone of Aeschylus bitterly echoes those of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">κῆρυξ</foreign> (<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐδῶ—αὐδῶ—τραχύς—τράχυν’,</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 1042">Aesch. Seven 1042 ff.</bibl> </cit>). An accent of rising passion is similarly given to the dialogue between Menelaus and Teucer (<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1142">Soph. Aj. 1142</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤδη ποτ’ εἶδον ἄνδρ’ ἐγώ</quote> </cit>— 1150 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ δέ γ’ ἄνδρ’ ὄπωπα</foreign>). Aristophanes parodies this style, <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Ach. 1097">Aristoph. Ach. 1097</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΛΑΜΑΧΟΣ. παῖ, παῖ, φέρ’ ἔξω δεῦρο τὸν γύλιον ἐμοί. ΔΙΚΑΙΟΠΟΛΙΣ. παῖ, παῖ, φέρ’ ἔξω δεῦρο τὴν κίστην ἐμοί.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ΛΑΜΑΧΟΣ. παῖ, παῖ, φέρ’ ἔξω δεῦρο τὸν γύλιον
							ἐμοί.
									ΔΙΚΑΙΟΠΟΛΙΣ. παῖ, παῖ, φέρ’ ἔξω δεῦρο τὴν κίστην ἐμοί.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἐρῶ_547"> how I will state this very matter (my supposed hostility to you): i.e. in what a light I will place it, by showing that I had no motive for it. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κτῆμα_549"> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1050">Soph. Ant. 1050</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅσῳ κράτιστον κτημάτων εὐβουλία.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐθαδίαν_549"> poet. for <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐθάδειαν</foreign> (<ref n="Aesch. PB 79">Aesch. PB 79</ref>, etc.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_χωρίς_549"> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐθάδεια</foreign> is not necessarily devoid of intelligence: as Heracles says (<ref n="Eur. Her. 1243">Eur. Her. 1243</ref>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">αὔθαδες ὁ θεός· πρὸς δὲ τοὺς θεοὺς ἐγώ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_οὐκ_555"> <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 100">Aesch. Seven 100</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀκούετ’ ἢ οὐκ ἀκούετ’ ἀσπίδων κτύπον;</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 4.682">Hom. Od. 4.682</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ εἰπέμεναι δμωῇσιν Ὀδυσσῆος θείοιο.</quote> </cit> Such “synizesis” points to the rapidity and ease of ancient Greek pronunciation: see J. H. H. Schmidt, <title>Rhythmik und Metrik</title> §3 (p. 9 of Eng. tr. by Prof. J. W. White). </gloss>

data.quote: ἀκούετ’ ἢ οὐκ ἀκούετ’ ἀσπίδων κτύπον;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σεμνόμαντις_556"> refers ironically to a solemn manner: cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">σεμνολογεῖν, σεμνοπροσωπεῖν, σεμνοπανοῦργος, σεμνοπαράσιτος,</foreign> etc. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὑτός_557"> “I am the same man in regard to my opinion” (dat. of respect): not, “am identical with my former opinion” (when the dat. would be like <foreign xml:lang="grc">Φοίβῳ</foreign> in 285). Thuc. can dispense with a dative, 2. 61 <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ ἐγὼ μὲν ὁ αὐτός εἰμι καὶ οὐκ ἐξίσταμαι</foreign>: though he adds it in 3. 38 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ μὲν οὖν ὁ αὐτός εἰμι τῇ γνώμῃ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δέδρακε_559"> Creon has heard only what Oedipus said of him: he does not yet know what Teiresias said of Oedipus (cp. 574). Hence he is startled at the mention of Laius. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_ἐννοῶ_559"> i.e. “I do not understand what Laius has to do with this matter.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χειρώματι_560"> deed of a (violent) hand: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 1022">Aesch. Seven 1022</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τυμβόχοα χειρώματα</quote> </cit>= service of the hands in raising a mound. In the one other place where Aesch. has the word, it means “prey” (<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 1326">Aesch. Ag. 1326</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δούλης θανσύσης εὐμαροῦς χειρώματος</quote> </cit>): Soph. uses it only here (though he has <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">δυσχείρωμα</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 126">Soph. Ant. 126</bibl> </cit>): Eur. never. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μακροὶ_561"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: long and ancient times would be measured; i.e. the reckoning of years from the present time would go far back into the past; </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μακροὶ_561_2"> denoting the course, and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παλαιοί_561"> the point to which it is retraced. Some sixteen years may be supposed to have elapsed since the death of Laius. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_τέχνῃ_562"> slightly contemptuous. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_562"> of a pursuit or calling: <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 2.82">Hdt. 2.82</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν Ἑλλήνων οἱ ἐν ποιήσει γενόμενοι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.28">Thuc. 3.28</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ ἐν τοῖς πράγμασι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 2.18">Isoc. 2.18</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ ἐν ταῖς ὀλιγαρχίαις καὶ ταῖς δημοκρατίαις</quote> </cit> (meaning, the <emph>administrators</emph> thereof): <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedo 59a">Plat. Phaedo 59a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐν φιλοσοφίᾳ ἡμῶν ὄντων</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 762a">Plat. Laws 762a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἐν ταῖς γεωργίαις</quote> </cit> :<ref n="Plat. Prot. 317c">Plat. Prot. 317c</ref> (Protagoras of himself as a <foreign xml:lang="grc">σοφιστής) πολλά γε ἔτη ἤδη εἰμὶ ἐν τῇ τέχνῃ.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: τῶν Ἑλλήνων οἱ ἐν ποιήσει γενόμενοι

οἱ ἐν ταῖς ὀλιγαρχίαις καὶ ταῖς
									δημοκρατίαις

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδαμοῦ_565"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑστῶτος_πέλας_565">, “when I was standing anywhere near”; but equivalent in force to, “on any occasion when I was standing near”: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1281">Soph. Aj. 1281</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃν οὐδαμοῦ φὴς οὐδὲ συμβῆναι ποδί.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ὃν οὐδαμοῦ φὴς οὐδὲ συμβῆναι ποδί.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρέσχομεν_567"> we held it, as in duty bound: <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρέχειν,</foreign> as distinct from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔχειν,</foreign> expressing that it was something to be expected <emph>on their part</emph>. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1498">Soph. OC 1498</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δικαίαν χάριν παρασχεῖν παθών.</quote> </cit> For <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρέσχομεν</foreign> after <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔσχομεν</foreign> cp. 133 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπαξίως … ἀξίως</foreign>: 575 <foreign xml:lang="grc">μαθεῖν … </foreign>: 576 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκμάνθαν.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοσόνδε_γ_570"> If we read </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_γ_570">, the coarse and blunt <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ σὸν</foreign> would destroy the edge of the sarcasm. Nor would <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ σὸν</foreign> consist so well with the calm tone of Creon's inquiry in 571. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοσόνδε_570"> does not need <foreign xml:lang="grc">δέ</foreign> after it, since </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶσθα_570"> is a mocking echo of <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶδα.</foreign> Cp. <ref n="Eur. IT 554">Eur. IT 554</ref> OP. <foreign xml:lang="grc">παῦσαί νυν ἤδη, μηδ’ ἐρωτήσῃς πέρα. ΙΦ. τοσόνδε γ’, εἰ ζῇ τοῦ ταλαιπώρου δάμαρ.</foreign> Against the conject. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τόσον δέ γ’</foreign> it is to be noted that Soph. has <foreign xml:lang="grc">τόσος</foreign> only in <ref n="Soph. Aj. 185">Soph. Aj. 185</ref> (lyric, <foreign xml:lang="grc">τόσσον</foreign>), 277 <foreign xml:lang="grc">(δὶς τόσ’),</foreign> and <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 53">Soph. Trach. 53</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φράσαι τὸ σόν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνῆλθε_572"> :<cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Kn. 1300">Aristoph. Kn. 1300</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φασὶν ἀλλήαις συνελθεῖν τὰς τριήρεις ἐς λόγον,</quote> </cit> “the triremes laid their heads together”: <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Kn. 467">Aristoph. Kn. 467</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰδίᾳ δ’ ἐκεῖ τοῖς Λακεδαιμονίοις ξυγγίγνεται</quote> </cit>. </gloss>

data.quote:
φασὶν ἀλλήαις συνελθεῖν τὰς τριήρεις ἐς
									λόγον,

ἰδίᾳ δ’ ἐκεῖ τοῖς Λακεδαιμονίοις
									ξυγγίγνεται

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰς_ἐμὰς_572"> the conject. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάσδ_ἐμὰς_572"> mars the passage: “he would never have described this slaying of L. as mine.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_διαφθοράς_572"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν εἶπεν ὄτι ἐγὼ Λάϊον διέφθειρα,</foreign> but with a certain bitter force added;—“we should never have heard a word of this slaying of Laius by me.” Soph. has purposely chosen a turn of phrase which the audience can recognise as suiting the fact that Oed. <emph>had</emph> slain Laius. For </gloss>
lemma: οὐκ ἂν εἶπε τὰς ἐμὰς Λαΐου διαφθοράς

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διαφθοράς_572"> instead of a clause with <foreign xml:lang="grc">διαφθείρειν,</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.137">Thuc. 1.137</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γράψας τὴν ἐκ Σαλαμῖνος προάγγελσιν τῆς ἀναχωρήσεως καὶ τὴν τῶν γεφυρῶν … οὐ διάλυσιν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
γράψας τὴν ἐκ Σαλαμῖνος προάγγελσιν τῆς
							ἀναχωρήσεως καὶ τὴν τῶν γεφυρῶν … οὐ διάλυσιν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοῦ_574"> instead of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σου_574"> is not indeed necessary; but we thus obtain a better balance to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀμοῦ_ταὔθ_574">, to question in like manner and measure. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταῦθ_574"> (MSS.) might refer to the events since the death of Laius, but has less point. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_δὴ_576"> rejects an alternative: here, without <foreign xml:lang="grc">γε,</foreign> as <ref n="Soph. Ant. 46">Soph. Ant. 46</ref>: more often with it, as <ref n="Soph. OC 110">Soph. OC 110</ref> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γήμας_ἔχεις_577"> simply, I think, =<foreign xml:lang="grc">γεγάμηκας,</foreign> though the special use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔχειν</foreign> (<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 4.569">Hom. Od. 4.569</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχεις Ἑλένην καί σφιν γαμβρὸς Διός ἐσσι</quote> </cit>) might warrant the version, “hast married, and hast to wife.” </gloss>

data.quote: ἔχεις Ἑλένην καί σφιν γαμβρὸς Διός ἐσσι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γῆς_579"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρχεις_νέμων_579"> explains </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταὐτά_579">,— “with equal sway” (cp. 201 <foreign xml:lang="grc">κράτη νέμων,</foreign> and 237): <foreign xml:lang="grc">γῆς ἴσον νέμων</foreign> would mean, “assigning an equal share of land.” The special sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">νέμων</foreign> is sufficiently indicated by the context; cp. <cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 3">Pind. P. 3.70</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃς Συρακόσσαισι νέμει βασιλεύς</quote> </cit> (rules at S.). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾖ_θέλουσα_580"> cp. 126, 274, 747. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τρίτος_580"> marking the completion of the lucky number, as <ref n="Soph. OC 8">Soph. OC 8</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1174">Soph. Aj. 1174</ref>,<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 759">Aesch. Eum. 759</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(τρίτου | Σωτῆρος)</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl>Menand. Sent. 231</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θάλασσα καὶ πῦρ καὶ γυνὴ τρίτον κακόν.</quote> </cit> For the gen. </gloss>

data.quote: θάλασσα καὶ πῦρ καὶ γυνὴ τρίτον κακόν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμοῦ_580">, cp. 1163 (<foreign xml:lang="grc">του</foreign>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνταῦθα_γὰρ_582"> (yes indeed:) <emph>for</emph> otherwise your guilt would be less glaring; it is just this fact that deprives it of excuse. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διδοίης_λόγον_583"> <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 3.25">Hdt. 3.25</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγον ἑωυτῷ δοὺς ὅτι … ἔμελλε κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> “on <emph>reflecting</emph> that,” etc.: <ref n="Dem. 45.7">Dem. 45.7</ref> (the speech prob. belongs to the time of Dem.) <foreign xml:lang="grc">λόγον δ’ ἐμαυτῷ διδοὺς εὑρίσκω κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Distinguish the plur. in Plato's <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποικίλῃ ποικίλους ψυχῇ … διδοὺς λόγους,</foreign> applying speeches (<ref n="Plat. Phaedrus 277c">Plat. Phaedrus 277c</ref>). </gloss>

data.quote: λόγον ἑωυτῷ δοὺς ὅτι … ἔμελλε κ.τ.λ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔτ_αὐτὸς_587"> would have been naturally followed by <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔτ’ ἄλλῳ παραινοῖμ’ ἄν,</foreign> but the form of the sentence changes to <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔτ’ ἄλλος (ἱμείρεἰ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_σοῦ_590"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκ</foreign> is here a correct substitute for <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρά,</foreign> since the king is the ultimate source of benefits: <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Hell. 3.1.6">Xen. Hell. 3.1.6</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκείνῳ δ’ αὕτη ἡ χώρα δῶρον ἐκ βασιλέως ἐδόθη.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἐκείνῳ δ’ αὕτη ἡ χώρα δῶρον ἐκ βασιλέως
									ἐδόθη.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέρω_590"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">φέρομαι,</foreign> as 1190, <ref n="Soph. OC 6">Soph. OC 6</ref> etc. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἂν_ἄκων_591"> he would do much of his own good pleasure, but much <emph>also</emph> (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_591">) against it, under pressure of public duty. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔπω_594"> ironical: see on 105. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_καλά_594">: honours which bring substantial advantage (real power and personal comfort), as opp. to honours in which outward splendour is joined to heavier care. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 61">Soph. El. 61</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοκῶ μέν, οὐδὲν ῥῆμα σὺν κέρδει κακόν</quote> </cit>: i.e. the sound matters not, if there is <foreign xml:lang="grc">κέρδος,</foreign> solid good. </gloss>

data.quote: δοκῶ μέν, οὐδὲν ῥῆμα σὺν κέρδει κακόν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶσι_χαίρω_596"> “all men wish me joy”: lit. “I rejoice with the consent of all men”: all are content that I should rejoice. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1446">Soph. OC 1446</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνάξιαι γὰρ πᾶσίν ἐστε δυστυχεῖν,</quote> </cit> all deem you undeserving of misfortune: <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Birds 445">Aristoph. Birds 445</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πᾶσι νικᾶν τοῖς κριταῖς | καὶ τοῖς θεαταῖς πᾶσι.</quote> </cit> The phrase has been suggested by <foreign xml:lang="grc">χαῖρέ μοι,</foreign> but refers to the meaning rather than to the form of the greeting: i.e. </gloss>

data.quote:
πᾶσι νικᾶν τοῖς κριταῖς | καὶ τοῖς θεαταῖς
							πᾶσι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶσι_χαίρω_596_2"> is not to be regarded as if it meant literally, “I have the word <foreign xml:lang="grc">χαῖρε</foreign> said to me by all.” This is one of the boldly subtle phrases in which the art of Soph. recalls that of Vergil. Others understand: (1) “I rejoice in all,” —instead of suspecting some, as the <foreign xml:lang="grc">τύραννος</foreign> does, who <foreign xml:lang="grc">φθονέει … τοῖσι ἀρίστοισι … χαίρει δὲ τοῖσι κακίστοισι τῶν ἀστῶν</foreign> <ref n="Hdt. 3.80">Hdt. 3.80</ref>: (2) “I rejoice in relation to all”— i.e. am on good terms with all: (3) “I rejoice in the sight of all”: i.e. enjoy a happiness which is the greater because men see it: (4) “I rejoice in all things.” This last is impossible. Of the others, (1) is best, but not in accord with the supposed position of Oedipus <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ πᾶσι κλεινός.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκκαλοῦσι_597"> Those who have a boon to ask of Oed. come to the palace (or to Creon's own house, see on 637) and send in a message, praying Creon to speak with them. Seneca's Creon says (<title>Oed.</title> 687) <foreign xml:lang="lat">Solutus onere regio, regni bonis Fruor, domusque civium coetu viget.</foreign> In Greek tragedy the king or some great person is often thus called forth. Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Lib. 663">Aesch. Lib. 663</ref>: Orestes summons an <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἰκέτης</foreign> by knocking at the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἑρκεία πύλη,</foreign> and, describing himself as a messenger, says <foreign xml:lang="grc">—ἐξελθέτω τις δωμάτων τελεσφόρος | γυνὴ τόπαρχος,</foreign> —when Clytaemnestra herself appears. So in <ref n="Eur. Ba. 170">Eur. Ba. 170</ref> Teiresias says <foreign xml:lang="grc">—τίς ἐν πύλαισι Κάδμον ἐκκαλεῖ δόμων;</foreign> “where is there a servant at the doors to call forth Cadmus from the house?” <foreign xml:lang="grc">—ἴτω τις, εἰσάγγελλε Τειρεσίας ὅτι | ζητεῖ νιν</foreign>: then Cadmus comes forth. The active <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκκαλεῖν</foreign> is properly said (as there) of him who takes in the message, the middle <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκκαλεῖσθαι</foreign> of him who sends it in (<ref n="Hdt. 8.19">Hdt. 8.19</ref>): but in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1264">Soph. Phil. 1264</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκκαλεῖσθε</quote> </cit> (n.) is an exception. Musgrave's <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἰκάλλουσι</foreign> is not a word which a man could complacently use to describe the treatment of himself by others. <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἴκαλος. κόλαξ</foreign> Hesych. (for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀκ‐ίαλος,</foreign> from the same rt., with the notion of <emph>soothing</emph> or <emph>stilling,</emph> as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀκεῖσθαι, ἦκα, ἀκέων, ἄκασκα, ἀκασκαῖος</foreign>):<cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Kn. 47">Aristoph. Kn. 47</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑποπεσὼν τὸν δεσπότην | ᾔκαλλ’, ἐθώπεῡ, ἐκολάκεῡ,</quote> </cit> “fawned, wheedled, flattered”: in tragedy only once, <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Andr. 630">Eur. Andr. 630</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φίλημ’ ἐδέξω, προδότιν αἰκάλλων κύνα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὑποπεσὼν τὸν δεσπότην | ᾔκαλλ’, ἐθώπεῡ,
							ἐκολάκεῡ,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_τυχεῖν_598"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὧν χρῄζουσιν.</foreign> The reading </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἅπαντ_598">, whether taken as accus. after </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τυχεῖν_598"> (“to gain all things”), or as accus. of respect (“to succeed in all”) not only mars the rhythm but enfeebles the sense. When </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτοῖσι_598"> was corrupted into </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὐτοῖς_πᾶν_598"> was changed into </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἅπαν_598">, as it is in L. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνταῦθα_598"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν τῷ ἐκκαλεῖν με,</foreign> in gaining my ear: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 585">Soph. OC 585</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνταῦθα γάρ μοι κεῖνα συγκομίζεται,</quote> </cit> in <emph>this</emph> boon I find <emph>those</emph> comprised. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πῶς_δῆτ_599"> Cp. <ref n="Hdt. 5.106">Hdt. 5.106</ref> (Histiaeus to Dareius) <foreign xml:lang="grc">βασιλεῦ, κοῖον ἐφθέγξαο ἔπος; ἐμὲ βουλεῦσαι πρῆγμα ἐκ τοῦ σοί τι ἢ μέγα ἢ σμικρὸν ἔμελλε λυπηρὸν ἀνασχήσειν; τί δ’ ἂν ἐπιδιζήμενος ποιέοιμι ταῦτα; τεῦ δὲ ἐνδεὴς ἐών, τῷ πάρα μὲν πάντα ὅσαπερ σοί, πάντων δὲ πρὸς σέο βουλευμάτων ἐπακούειν ἀξιεῦμαι</foreign>: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_γένοιτο_600"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> Creon has been arguing that <emph>he</emph> has no motive for treason. He now states a general maxim, “No mind would ever turn to treason, while it was sound.” As a logical inference, this holds good only of those who are in Creon's fortunate case. If, on the other hand, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καλῶς_φρονῶν_600"> means “alive to its own <emph>highest</emph> good,” and not merely to such self-interest as that of which Creon has spoken, then the statement has no strict connection with what precedes: it becomes a new argument of a different order, which might be illustrated from Plato's <foreign xml:lang="grc">κακὸς ἑκὼν οὐδείς.</foreign> It would be forcing the words to render: “A base mind could not approve itself wise,” i.e. “such treason as you ascribe to me would be silly.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔλεγχον_603"> accus. in apposition with the sentence: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 57">Eur. Her. 57</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ δυσπραξία | ἦς μήποθ’, ὅστις καὶ μέσως εὔνους ἐμοί, | τύχοι, φίλων ἔλεγχον ἀψευδέστετον.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἡ δυσπραξία | ἦς μήποθ’, ὅστις καὶ μέσως
							εὔνους
									ἐμοί, | τύχοι, φίλων ἔλεγχον ἀψευδέστετον.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτ_ἄλλο_605"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦτο δέ.</foreign> Soph. has <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦτο μέν</foreign> irregularly followed by <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦτ’ αὖθις</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. Ant. 165">Soph. Ant. 165</ref>), by <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἶτα</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. Phil. 1345">Soph. Phil. 1345</ref>), by <foreign xml:lang="grc">δέ</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 670">Soph. Aj. 670</ref>,<ref n="Soph. OC 440">Soph. OC 440</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῷ_τερασκόπῳ_605"> This title (given to Apollo, <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 62">Aesch. Eum. 62</ref>) has sometimes a shade of scorn, as when it is applied by the mocking Pentheus to Teiresias (<ref n="Eur. Ba. 248">Eur. Ba. 248</ref>), and by Clytaemnestra to Cassandra (<ref n="Aesch. Ag. 1440">Aesch. Ag. 1440</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χωρὶς_608"> “apart”: i.e. solely on the strength of your own guess <foreign xml:lang="grc">(γνώμη ἄδηλος),</foreign> without any evidence that I falsified the oracle or plotted with the seer. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_βίοτον_612"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign>: the life is <foreign xml:lang="lat">hospes comesque corporis,</foreign> dearest guest and closest companion: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 479b">Plat. Gorg. 479b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ ὑγιεῖ ψυχῇ συνοικεῖν</quote> </cit>: and the address of Archilochus to his own <foreign xml:lang="grc">θυμός</foreign> as his trusty ally (Bergk fr. 66), <foreign xml:lang="grc">—θυμέ, θύμ’ ἀμηχάνοισι κήδεσιν κυκώμενε, | ἐνάδευ, δυσμενῶν δ’ ἀλέξευ προσβαλὼν ἐναντίον | στέρνον.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φιλεῖ_612"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τις,</foreign> supplied from </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὑτῷ_612"> :<cit> <bibl n="Hes. WD 12">Hes. WD 12</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν μέν κεν ἐπαινήσειε νοήσας | ἡ δ’ ἐπιμωμητή.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τὴν μέν κεν ἐπαινήσειε νοήσας | ἡ δ’
									ἐπιμωμητή.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρόνος_614"> cp. Pind. fr. 132 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρῶν δικαίων χρόνος σωτὴρ ἄριστος</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Pind. O. 2">Pind. O. 2.53</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅ τ’ ἐξελέγχων μόνος | ἀλάθειαν ἐτήτυμον | χρόνος.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὅ τ’ ἐξελέγχων μόνος | ἀλάθειαν ἐτήτυμον |
							χρόνος.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακὸν_δὲ_614"> the sterling worth of the upright man is not fully appreciated until it has been long tried: but a knave is likely (by some slip) to afford an early glimpse of his real character. The Greek love of antithesis has prompted this addition, which is relevant to Creon's point only as implying, “if I <emph>had</emph> been a traitor, you would probably have seen some symptom of it ere now.” Cp. <ref n="Pind. P. 2">Pind. P. 2.90</ref> (speaking of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">φθονεροἴ· στάθμας δέ τινος ἑλκόμενοι | περισσᾶς ἐνέπαξαν ἕλκος ὀδυναρὸν ἑᾷ πρόσθε καρδίᾳ, | πρὶν ὅσα φροντίδι μητίονται τυχεῖν.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 493">Soph. Ant. 493</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φιλεῖ δ’ ὁ θυμὸς πρόσθεν ᾑρῆσθαι κλοπεὺς | τῶν μηδὲν ὀρθῶς ἐν σκότῳ τεχνωμένων.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
φιλεῖ δ’ ὁ θυμὸς πρόσθεν ᾑρῆσθαι κλοπεὺς | τῶν
							μηδὲν ὀρθῶς ἐν σκότῳ τεχνωμένων.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Φρονεῖν_617"> is like an accus. of respect (e.g. <foreign xml:lang="grc">βουλήν</foreign>) construed with both adjectives: “in counsel, the quick are not sure.” Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.70">Thuc. 1.70</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπινοῆσαι ὀξεῖς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταχύς_χωρῇ_618"> advances in quick fashion; nearly = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταχέως πως.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1266">Soph. Aj. 1266</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φεῦ, τοῦ θανόντος ὡς ταχεῖά τις βροτοῖς | χάρις διαρρεῖ,</quote> </cit> <emph>in what quick sort</emph> does it vanish. </gloss>

data.quote:
φεῦ, τοῦ θανόντος ὡς ταχεῖά τις βροτοῖς |
							χάρις
									διαρρεῖ,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_ἐμόν_622">. (1) Verse 624, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅταν προδείξῃς κ.τ.λ.,</foreign> which the MSS. give to Creon, belongs to Oedipus: and for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅταν</foreign> we should (I think) read </gloss>
lemma: τί δῆτα χρῄζεις; … τὸ γοῦν ἐμόν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἂν_622">. The argument that the stichomuthia should not be broken shows inattention to the practice of Soph. He not seldom breaks a stichomuthia, when a weighty utterance (as here, the king's threat) claims the emphasis of two verses. See (e.g.) 356-369, broken by 366 f. (the seer's denunciation): <ref n="Soph. Ant. 40-48">Soph. Ant. 40-48</ref>, broken by 45 f. (Antigone's resolve): <ref n="Soph. OC 579-606">Soph. OC 579-606</ref>, broken by 583 f. (where Theseus marks the singularity in the proposal of Oed.). (2) Verse 625 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς οὐχ ὑπείξων κ.τ.λ.,</foreign> which the MSS. give to Oedipus, belongs to Creon. (3) Between 625 and 626 a verse spoken by Oedipus has dropped out, to such effect as <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ γάρ με πείθεις οὕνεκ’ οὐκ ἄπιστος εἶ.</foreign> The fact of the next verse, our 626, also beginning with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_γὰρ_622"> may have led to the loss by causing the copyist's eye to wander. The echoed </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_γὰρ_622_2"> would suit angry dialogue: cp. 547, 548 KP. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦτ’ αὐτὸ νῦν μου πρῶτ’ ἄκουσον ὡς ἐρῶ. ΟΙ. τοῦτ’ αὐτὸ μή μοι φράζ’.</foreign> (See also on <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1252">Soph. Phil. 1252</ref>.) The traditional interpretations fail to justify (1) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἷόν ἐστι τὸ φθονεῖν,</foreign> as said by Creon: (2) <foreign xml:lang="grc">πιστεύσων,</foreign> as said by Oed. See Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρκτέον_628"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">δεῖ ἄρχειν,</foreign> one must rule: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 677">Soph. Ant. 677</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμυντέ’ ἐστὶ τοῖς κοσμουμένοις.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 14.10">Isoc. 14.10</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ τῶν ἄλλων αὐτοῖς ἀρκτέον</quote> </cit> (they ought not to rule over others) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλλὰ πολὺ μᾶλλον Ὀρχομενίοις φόρον οἰστέον.</foreign> In <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Tim. 48b">Plat. Tim. 48b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρκτέον</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">δεῖ ἄρχεσθαι,</foreign> one must begin; in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 853">Soph. Aj. 853</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀρκτέον τὸ πρᾶγμα</quote> </cit> = must be begun. Some understand— “<emph>one must be ruled</emph>,” and <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔτοι κακῶς γ’ ἄρχοντος,</foreign>“ No, not <emph>by one</emph> who rules ill”: but (a) though <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρκτέα πόλις</foreign> might mean, “the city is to be ruled,” an absolute passive use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρκτέον</foreign> is certainly not warranted by such an isolated example as <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ καταπληκτέον ἐστίν</foreign> (“we must not be unnerved”) in <ref n="Din. 1.108">Din. 1.108</ref>: (b) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄρχομαί τινος,</foreign> “I am ruled by one” (instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκ</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπό</foreign>), could only plead the analogy of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀκούω τινός,</foreign> and lacks evidence. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρχοντος_629"> when one rules. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρκτέον</foreign> being abstract, “it is right to rule,” there is no harshness in the gen. absol. with <foreign xml:lang="grc">τινός</foreign> understood (cp. 612), which is equivalent to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐάν τις ἄρχῃ·</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 6.20">Dem. 6.20</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λέγοντος ἄν τινος πιστεῦσαι οἴεσθε;</quote> </cit> “think you that, if any one had said it, they would have believed?” = <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἴεσθε, εἴ τις ἔλεγε, πιστεῦσαι ἂν (αὐτούς);</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧ_πόλις_629"> here, an appeal: in Attic comedy, an exclamation like <foreign xml:lang="lat">o tempora, o mores</foreign>: Blaydes cp. Eupolis ap. <cit> <bibl>Athen. 424b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾦ πόλις, πόλις | ὡς εὐτυχὴς εἶ μᾶλλον ἢ καλῶς φρονεῖς</quote> </cit>: and so <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 27">Aristoph. Ach. 27</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote:
ᾦ πόλις, πόλις | ὡς εὐτυχὴς εἶ μᾶλλον ἢ καλῶς
							φρονεῖς

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πόλεως_630"> Most of the MSS. have <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέτεστι τῆσδ’ οὐχί.</foreign> Had they <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέτεστι τῆσδ’ οὐ</foreign> (which appears only in a few inferior MSS.) we should hardly be warranted in ejecting <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῆσδ’</foreign>: but, having the choice, we may safely prefer </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέτεστιν_οὐχὶ_630"> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέτεστι τῆσδ’ οὐ.</foreign> “I have some right in Thebes, as well as you.” Creon speaks not as a brother of Iocasta, but as a Theban citizen who denies that “the city belongs to one man” (<ref n="Soph. Ant. 737">Soph. Ant. 737</ref>).<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 768b">Plat. Laws 768b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεῖ δὲ δὴ καὶ τῶν ἰδίων δικῶν κοινωνεῖν κατὰ δύναμιν ἅπαντασ’ ὁ γὰρ ἀκοινώνητος ὢν ἐξουσίας τοῦ συνδικάζειν ἡγεῖται τὸ παράπαν τῆς πόλεως οὐ μέτοχος εἶναι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
δεῖ δὲ δὴ καὶ τῶν ἰδίων δικῶν κοινωνεῖν κατὰ
							δύναμιν ἅπαντασ’ ὁ γὰρ ἀκοινώνητος ὢν ἐξουσίας τοῦ συνδικάζειν
									ἡγεῖται τὸ παράπαν τῆς πόλεως οὐ μέτοχος εἶναι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴκους_637"> (the king's palace), acc. after </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἶ_637"> (cp. 533); </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατὰ_637"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στέγας_637"> only, referring to the house of Creon, who is not supposed to be an inmate of the palace: see 515, 533. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_ἄλγος_638"> the generic use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή</foreign> (“a grief <emph>such as</emph> to be naught,” —quod nihili <emph>sit</emph>), here giving a causal force (“seeing that it is naught”): cp. 397, 1019; <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1166">Soph. El. 1166</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δέξαι … | τὴν μηδὲν ἐς τὸ μηδέν</quote> </cit> :</gloss>

data.quote: δέξαι … | τὴν μηδὲν ἐς τὸ μηδέν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_φέρειν_638">, make into a great matter: cp. (<ref n="Soph. Phil. 259">Soph. Phil. 259</ref>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">νόσος | ἀεὶ τέθηλε κἀπὶ μεῖζον ἔρχεται.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυοῖν_κακοῖν_640"> The traditional reading, <foreign xml:lang="grc">δρᾶσαι … δυοῖν,</foreign> is the only extant example of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυοῖν_640"> scanned as one syllable, though in the tragic poets alone the word occurs more than 50 times. Synizesis of <foreign xml:lang="grc">υ</foreign> is rare in extant Greek poetry: <cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 4">Pind. P. 4.225</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γενύ¯ων</quote> </cit> :<title>Anthol.</title> 11.413 (epigram by Ammianus, 1st century A.D.) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὤκιμον, ἡδύ¯οσμον, πήγανον, ἀσπάραγος.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IT 970">Eur. IT 970</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅσαι δ’ Ἐρινύ¯ων οὐκ ἐπείσθησαν νόμῳ,</quote> </cit> and <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IT 1456">Eur. IT 1456</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴστροις Ἐρινύ¯ων,</quote> </cit> where most editors write <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἐρινῦν,</foreign> as <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IT 299">Eur. IT 299</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἐρινῦς</quote> </cit> (acc. plur.). <cit> <bibl n="Hes. Sh. 3">Hes. Sh. 3</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἠλεκτρύ¯ωνος.</quote> </cit> It might be rash to say that Soph. could not have used </gloss>

data.quote: ὅσαι δ’ Ἐρινύ¯ων οὐκ ἐπείσθησαν νόμῳ,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυοῖν_640_2"> as a monosyllable; for he has used the ordinary synizesis in a peculiarly bold way, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1129">Soph. Aj. 1129</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή νυν ἀτίμα θεοὺς θεοῖς σεσωμένος</quote> </cit>: but at least it moves the strongest suspicion. </gloss>

data.quote: μή νυν ἀτίμα θεοὺς θεοῖς σεσωμένος

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποκρίνας_640">, on the other hand, seems genuine. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀποκρίνειν</foreign> is properly <foreign xml:lang="lat">secernere</foreign> to <emph>set apart</emph>: e.g. <foreign xml:lang="grc">γῆν</foreign> (<ref n="Plat. Rep. 303d">Plat. Rep. 303d</ref>): or <emph>to select</emph>:<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 946a">Plat. Laws 946a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλήθει τῶν ψήφων ἀποκρίναντας,</quote> </cit> having selected (the men) according to the number of votes for each. Here, “<emph>having set apart</emph> (for me) one of two ills” is a phrase suitable to the arbitrary rigour of doom which left a choice only between death and exile. For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυοῖν_640_3"> Elms. proposed <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῖνδ’</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῖνδέ γ’</foreign>: Herm., <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῖνδ’ ἕν</foreign>: A. Spengel, <foreign xml:lang="grc">δείν’.</foreign> I should rather believe that </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δρᾶν_640"> was altered into <foreign xml:lang="grc">δρᾶσαι</foreign> by a grammarian who looked to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπῶσαι_κτεῖναι_640">, and perh. also sought a simpler order. But for pres. infin. combined with aor. infin. cp. 623 <foreign xml:lang="grc">θνῄσκειν … φυγεῖν</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 204">Soph. Ant. 204</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μήτε κτερίζειν μήτε κωκῦσαι.</quote> </cit> See also <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 732">Soph. OC 732</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἥκω γὰρ οὐχ ὡς δρᾶν τι βουληθείς,</quote> </cit> where in prose we should have expected <foreign xml:lang="grc">δρᾶσαι.</foreign> The quantity of </gloss>

data.quote: ἥκω γὰρ οὐχ ὡς δρᾶν τι βουληθείς,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποκρίνας_640_2"> is supported by <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 24">Aesch. PB 24</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπο‐κρύψει· ἀπο‐τροπή</quote> </cit> and its cognates in Aesch. and Eur.: <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπι‐κρύπτειν</quote> <bibl n="Eur. Supp. 296">Eur. Supp. 296</bibl> </cit> :<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπι‐κράνων</quote> <bibl n="Eur. IT 51">Eur. IT 51</bibl> </cit>. Blaydes conj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">δοὺς δυοῖν κρῖναι κακοῖν</foreign> (i.e. “giving me my choice of two ills”; cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 640">Soph. OC 640</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τούτων … δίδωμί σοι | κρίναντι χρῆσθαι</quote> </cit>): Dindorf, <foreign xml:lang="grc">θάτερον δυοῖν κακοῖν</foreign> (where I should at least prefer <foreign xml:lang="grc">κακόν</foreign>): “but since, with either of these supposed readings, the construction would have been perfectly clear, it is hard to see how </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποκρίνας_640_3">— a far-sought word—could have crept in as an explanatory gloss. That, however, is Whitelaw's view, who suggests that the original may have been something like <foreign xml:lang="grc">φαῦλον αἵρεσίν γ’ ἐμοί.</foreign> Wolff would compress vv. 640 f. into one, thus: <foreign xml:lang="grc">δρᾶσαι δικαιοῖ, δείν’, ἀποκτεῖναι λαβών.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δρῶντα_σῶμα_642"> would properly describe bodily outrage: here it is a heated way of saying that Creon's supposed plot touched the <emph>person</emph> of the king (who was to be dethroned), and not merely the <foreign xml:lang="grc">νόμοι πόλεως.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀραῖος_644"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὥσπερ αὐτὸς ἐπαρῶμαι.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅρκον_θεῶν_647"> (object. gen.), an oath by the gods (since one said <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀμνύναι θεούς</foreign>):<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 2.377">Hom. Od. 2.377</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θεῶν μέγαν ὅρκον ἀπώμνυ</quote> </cit>: 10. 299 <foreign xml:lang="grc">μακάρων μέγαν ὅρκον ὀμόσσαι</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 657">Eur. Hipp. 657</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅρκοις θεῶν.</quote> </cit> But in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1767">Soph. OC 1767</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Διὸς Ὅρκος</quote> </cit> is personified. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θελήσας_649"> having consented (<foreign xml:lang="grc">πιστεύειν</foreign>).<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 757">Soph. OC 757</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρύψον</quote> </cit> (hide thy woes), <foreign xml:lang="grc">θελήσας ἄστυ καὶ δόμους μολεῖν.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Isaeus 8.11">Isaeus 8.11</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα ποιῆσαι μὴ θελήσας.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plut. Septem 149f">Plut. Mor. 149f</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">συνδειπνεῖν μὴ θελήσαντος.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρονήσας_649"> having come to a sound mind. <cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 8.141">Isoc. 8.141</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καλόν ἐστιν ἐν ταῖς τῶν ἄλλων ἀδικίαις καὶ μανίαις πρώτους εὖ φρονήσαντας προστῆναι τῆς τῶν Ἑλλήνων ἐλευθερίας.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
καλόν ἐστιν ἐν ταῖς τῶν ἄλλων ἀδικίαις καὶ
							μανίαις
									πρώτους εὖ φρονήσαντας προστῆναι τῆς τῶν Ἑλλήνων ἐλευθερίας.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰκάθω_651"> the aor. subj. is certainly most suitable here: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 761">Soph. Phil. 761</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βούλει λάβωμαι;</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 80">Soph. El. 80</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θέλεις | μείνωμεν;</quote> </cit> In such phrases the <emph>pres.</emph> subj. (implying a continued or repeated act) is naturally much rarer: <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">βούλει ἐπισκοπῶμεν</quote> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 3.5.1">Xen. Mem. 3.5.1</bibl> </cit>. As regards the form of <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰκάθω,</foreign> Curtius (<title>Verb</title> 11. 345, Eng. tr. 505), discussing presents in <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐θω</foreign> and past tenses in <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐θον</foreign> from vowel stems, warns us against “looking for anything particularly aoristic in the <foreign xml:lang="grc">θ</foreign>” of these verbs. In Greek usage, he holds, “a decidedly aoristic force” for such forms as <foreign xml:lang="grc"> σχεθεῖν</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰκαθεῖν</foreign>“ never established itself”: and he justly cites <ref n="Soph. El. 1014">Soph. El. 1014</ref> as a place where <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰκαθεῖν</foreign> is in no way aoristic. He would therefore keep the traditional accent, and write <foreign xml:lang="grc">σχέθειν, εἰκάθειν,</foreign> with Buttmann. Now, while believing with Curtius that these forms were prob. in origin presents, I also think that in the usage of the classical age they were <emph> often</emph> aorists: as e.g. <foreign xml:lang="grc">σχεθεῖν</foreign> in <ref n="Aesch. Seven 429">Aesch. Seven 429</ref> distinctly is. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔτε_τε_652"> cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1397">Soph. OC 1397 ff.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέγαν_652"> “great,” i.e. strong, worthy of reverence, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_ὅρκῳ_652">, by means of, in virtue of, his oath: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Tro. 669">Eur. Tro. 669</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξυνέσει γένει πλούτῳ τε κἀνδρείᾳ μέγαν</quote> </cit>: for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν,</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 185">Soph. Phil. 185</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔν τ’ ὀδύναις ὁμοῦ | λιμῷ τ’ οἰκτρός.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ξυνέσει γένει πλούτῳ τε κἀνδρείᾳ μέγαν
ἔν τ’ ὀδύναις ὁμοῦ | λιμῷ τ’ οἰκτρός.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_βαλεῖν_656">), so as to dishonour him (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄτιμον_656">), with the help of an unproved story (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὺν_λόγῳ_656">), the friend who is liable to a curse (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐναγἦ_656">: i.e. who has just said (644) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀραῖος ὀλοίμαν κ.τ.λ.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Aeschin. 3.110">Aeschin. 3.110</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γέγραπται γὰρ οὕτως ἐν τῇ ἀρᾷ· εἵ τις τάδε, φησί, παραβαίνοι, … ἐναγής, φησιν, ἔστω τοῦ Ἀπόλλωνος,</quote> </cit> “let him rest under the ban of Apollo”: as Creon would rest under the ban of the gods by whom he had sworn. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 6.56">Hdt. 6.56</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τῷ ἄγεϊ ἐνέχεσθαι,</quote> </cit> to be liable to the curse. </gloss>

data.quote:
γέγραπται γὰρ οὕτως ἐν τῇ ἀρᾷ· εἵ τις τάδε,
							φησί,
									παραβαίνοι, … ἐναγής, φησιν, ἔστω τοῦ Ἀπόλλωνος,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_βαλεῖν_656_2"> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. L. 7.341a">Plat. Letter 7.341a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς μηδέποτε βαλεῖν ἐν αἰτίᾳ τὸν δεικνύντα ἀλλ’ αὐτὸν αὑτόν,</quote> </cit> “so that he may never blame his teacher, but only himself,” equiv. to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμβαλεῖν αἰτίᾳ</foreign>: cp. the prose phrases <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμβάλλειν εἰς συμφοράς, γραφάς, ἔχθραν, κ.τ.λ.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Tro. 305">Eur. Tro. 305</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰς ἔμ’ αἰτίαν βάλῃ.</quote> </cit> Seidler's <foreign xml:lang="grc">σύ γ’ ἀφανεῖ λόγων,</foreign> which Wolff adopts, is specious. </gloss>

data.quote:
ὡς μηδέποτε βαλεῖν ἐν αἰτίᾳ τὸν δεικνύντα ἀλλ’
							αὐτὸν αὑτόν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_τὸν_660"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ μὰ τὸν,</foreign> as not seldom; usu. followed by a second negative (as if here we had <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἔχω τάνδε φρόνησιν</foreign>): 1088, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 758">Soph. Ant. 758</ref>, etc. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρόμον_660"> standing foremost in the heavenly ranks, most conspicuous to the eyes of men: the god “who sees all things and hears all things” (<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 3.277">Hom. Il. 3.277</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὃς πάντ’ ἐφορᾷς καὶ πάντ’ ἐπακούεις</quote> </cit>): invoked <ref n="Soph. Trach. 102">Soph. Trach. 102</ref> as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὦ κρατιστεύων κατ’ ὄμμα.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: ὃς πάντ’ ἐφορᾷς καὶ πάντ’ ἐπακούεις

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅ_πύματόν_663"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἐστἰ, (τοῦτὀ</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀλοίμαν_663">: schol. <foreign xml:lang="grc">φθαρείην ὅπερ ἔσχατον, ἤγουν ἀπώλειαν ἥτις ἐσχάτη.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_δσφῷν_666"> and, on the other hand, if the ills arising from you two are to be added to the former ills. Prof. Kennedy gives </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_δ_666">, rightly, I think: for </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γᾶ_φθίνουσα_666"> refers to the blight and plague (25): </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάδ_666"> would obscure the contrast between <emph>those</emph> troubles and the new trouble of the quarrel. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσάψει_666"> intrans., as perh. only here and in fr. 348 <foreign xml:lang="grc">καί μοι τρίτον ῥίπτοντι … | ἀγχοῦ προσῆψεν,</foreign> “he came near to me.” <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 188">Eur. Hipp. 188</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ μέν ἐστιν ἁπλοῦν· τῷ δὲ συνάπτει | λύπη τε φρενῶν χερσίν τε πόνος,</quote> </cit> “is joined.” It is possible, but harsh, to make <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσαψει</foreign> act. with <foreign xml:lang="grc"> γῆ</foreign> as subject. Since in 695 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλύουσαν κατ’ ὀρθὸν οὐρίσας</foreign> is clearly sound, Herm. rightly struck out <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ</foreign> before </gloss>

data.quote:
τὸ μέν ἐστιν ἁπλοῦν· τῷ δὲ συνάπτει | λύπη τε
							φρενῶν χερσίν τε πόνος,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_δ_666_2"> here. See on 696. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_οὖν_669"> then <emph>let</emph> him go: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 114">Soph. Aj. 114</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ δ’ οὖν … | χρῶ χειρί.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλεινόν_672"> tertiary predicate: “I compassionate thy words, piteous as they are.” Where a possessive pron. with art. has preceded the subst., Soph. sometimes thus subjoins and adj., which really has the predicative force to which its position entitles it, though for us it would be more natural to translate it as a mere attributive: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 881">Soph. Ant. 881</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν δ’ ἐμὸν πότμον ἀδάκρυτον | οὐδεὶς … στενάζει</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1456">Soph. Phil. 1456</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὐμὸν ἐτέγχθη | κρᾶτ’ ἐνδόμυχον</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1143">Soph. El. 1143</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς ἐμῆς πάλαι τροφῆς | ἀνωφελήτου.</quote> </cit> In 1199 (where see note) <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰν γαμψ. παρθ. χρησμῳδόν</foreign> is not a similar case. Prof. Kennedy, placing a comma after <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐποίκτείρω,</foreign> but none after <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦδ’,</foreign> construes: <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ σὸν στόμα ἐλεινόν (ἐστἰ, οὐκ ἐποικτείρω τὸ τοῦδε.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
τὸν δ’ ἐμὸν πότμον ἀδάκρυτον | οὐδεὶς …
							στενάζει

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στυγήσεται_672"> pass. Other examples in Soph. are 1500 <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὀνειδιεῖσθε</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 581">Soph. OC 581</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δηλώσεται,</quote> </cit> 1186 <foreign xml:lang="grc">λέξεται</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 210">Soph. Ant. 210</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τιμήσεται,</quote> </cit> 637 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀξιώσεται</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 971">Soph. El. 971</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καλεῖ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 48">Soph. Phil. 48</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φυλάξεται</quote> </cit>: among many found in prose as well as in verse are <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀδικήσομαι, ἁλώσομαι, ἐάσομαι, ζημιώσομαι, τιμήσομαι, ὠφελήσομαι.</foreign> The middle forms of the aorist were alone peculiar to that voice; the so-called “future middle,” like the rest, was either middle or passive. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στυγνὸς_περάσῃς_673"> “thou art seen to be sullen when thou yieldest, but fierce when thou hast gone far in wrath”: i.e., <emph>as</emph> thou art fierce in passion, <emph>so</emph> art thou sullen in yielding. Greek idiom co-ordinates the clauses, though the emphasis is on <foreign xml:lang="grc">στυγνὸς μὲν εἴκων,</foreign> which the other merely enforces by contrast: see on 419. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βαρὺς_673"> <emph>bearing heavily</emph> on the object of anger, and so, “vehement,” “fierce”: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1017">Soph. Aj. 1017</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δύσοργος, ἐν γήρᾳ βαρύς,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 656">Soph. Aj. 656</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μῆνιν βαρεῖαν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1045">Soph. Phil. 1045</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βαρύς τε καὶ βαρεῖαν ὁ ξένος φάτιν τήνδ’ εἶπε</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 767">Soph. Ant. 767</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νοῦς δ’ ἐστὶ τηλικοῦτος ἀλγήσας βαρύς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
βαρύς τε καὶ βαρεῖαν ὁ ξένος φάτιν τήνδ’
									εἶπε
νοῦς δ’ ἐστὶ τηλικοῦτος ἀλγήσας βαρύς.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περάσῃς_673"> absol., = <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρόσω ἔλθῃς</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 154">Soph. OC 154</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">περᾷας,</quote> </cit> (you go too far), <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 885">Soph. OC 885</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πέραν | περῶσ’ οἵδε δή.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θυμοῦ_673">, partitive gen.: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 2.785">Hom. Il. 2.785</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">διέπρησσον πεδίοιο</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 3.105">Hdt. 3.105</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προλαμβάνειν … τῆς ὁδοῦ</quote> </cit>: sometimes helped by a prep. or adverbial phrase, as <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Apol. 30">Xen. Apol. 30</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προβήσεσθαι πόρρω μοχθηρίας</quote> </cit> :<title>2 Epist. Tim.</title> 2.16 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ πλεῖον γὰρ προκόψουσιν ἀσεβείας.</foreign> —Others render: “resentful [;or “remorseful”]; even when thou hast <emph>passed out of</emph> wrath”: but (a) <foreign xml:lang="grc">περάσῃς</foreign> with a simple gen. could not bear this sense: (b) the antithesis pointed by </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὲν_673"> and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δὲ_673"> is thus destroyed. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγνῶτος_677"> active, as in 681, 1133: but passive, “unknown,” <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1008">Soph. Phil. 1008</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 1001">Soph. Ant. 1001</ref>. Ellendt is not quite accurate in saying that Soph. was the first who used <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγνώς</foreign> in an active sense, for it is clearly active in <ref n="Pind. P. 9">Pind. P. 9.58</ref> (478 B.C.) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔτε παγκάρπων φυτῶν νήποινον οὔτ’ ἀγνῶτα θηρῶν (χθονὸς αἶσαν),</foreign> “a portion of land not failing in tribute of plants bearing all manner of fruit, nor <emph>a stranger</emph> to beasts of chase.” The passive use was, however, probably older than the active: compare <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 5.79">Hom. Od. 5.79</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγνῶτες … ἀλλήλοισι</quote> </cit> (pass.) with <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.53">Thuc. 3.53</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγνῶτες ἀλληλων</quote> </cit> (act.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_ἐν_677"> of the tribunal or company by whom one is judged: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 459">Soph. Ant. 459</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν θεοῖσι τὴν δίκην | δώσειν·</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 988">Eur. Hipp. 988</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ γὰρ ἐν σοφοῖς | φαῦλοι παρ’ ὄχλῳ μουσικώτεροι λέγειν</quote> </cit>: and so, more boldly, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1213">Soph. OC 1213</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σκαιοσύναν φυλάσσων ἐν ἐμοὶ</quote> </cit> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">me iudice</foreign>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">κατάδηλος ἔσται.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
οἱ γὰρ ἐν σοφοῖς | φαῦλοι παρ’ ὄχλῳ
							μουσικώτεροι
									λέγειν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴσος_677"> <foreign xml:lang="lat">aequus</foreign>, just: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 975c">Plat. Laws 975c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν μέλλοντα δικαστὴν ἴσον ἔσεσθαι.</quote> </cit> <ref n="Dem. 7.35">Dem. 7.35</ref> (by a contemporary of Dem.) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἴσῳ καὶ κοινῷ δικαστηρίῳ.</foreign> So <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 685">Soph. Phil. 685</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴσος ὢν ἴσοις ἀνήρ.</quote> </cit> The Scholiast explains, <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρὰ δὲ τούτοις τῆς ὁμοίας δόξης ἣν καὶ πρώην εἶχον περὶ ἐμέ,</foreign> i.e. “<emph>of the same repute as before.”</emph> To me such a version of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἵσος</foreign> appears most strange. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαθοῦσά_γ_680"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">κομιῶ</foreign>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 335">Soph. Trach. 335</ref> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δόκησις_λόγων_681"> a <emph>suspicion</emph> resting on mere <emph>assertions</emph> (those made by Oedipus), and not supported by facts <foreign xml:lang="grc"> (ἔργἀ</foreign>: hence </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγνὼς_681"> ,<emph>unknowing</emph>, guided by no real knowledge. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.4">Thuc. 1.4</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ λόγων … κόμπος τάδε μᾶλλον ἢ ἔργων ἐστὶν ἀλήθεια</quote> </cit>: 3. 43 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῆς οὐ βεβαίου δοκήσεως.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐ λόγων … κόμπος τάδε μᾶλλον ἢ ἔργων ἐστὶν
							ἀλήθεια

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δάπτει_δὲ_681">: Oedipus was incensed against Creon, without proof; on the other hand (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δὲ_681">) Creon also (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_681">) was incensed by the unjust accusation. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δάπτει_681"> might be historic pres., but need not be so taken: Creon is still pained. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 437">Aesch. PB 437</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">συννοίᾳ δὲ δάπτομαι κέαρ.</quote> </cit> The version, “and <emph>even</emph> injustice wounds,” would make the words a reflection;—“An accusation galls, <emph>even</emph> when unfounded”: but this is unsuitable. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφοῖν_αὐτοῖν_683"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦλθε τὸ νεῖκος;</foreign> Thus far, Iocasta only knew that Oedipus charged Creon with treason. The words of the Chorus now hint that Oedipus himself was partly to blame. “So then,” Iocasta asks, “provocation had been given on <emph>both sides</emph>?” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λόγος_683"> the story (of the alleged treason): for the words of Oed. (642 <foreign xml:lang="grc">δρῶντα κακῶς, τέχνη κακή</foreign>) had been vague. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προπονουμένας_685"> “<emph>already</emph> troubled,” not, “troubled exceedingly.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">προπονεῖν</foreign> always = to suffer <emph>before</emph>, or <emph>for</emph>:<cit> <bibl>Luc. Iupp. Trag. 40</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀθηνᾶ Ἄρην καταγωνίζεται, ἄτε καὶ προπεπονηκότα οἶμαι ἐκ τοῦ τραύματος,</quote> </cit> <emph> already</emph> disabled. </gloss>

data.quote:
Ἀθηνᾶ Ἄρην καταγωνίζεται, ἄτε καὶ
							προπεπονηκότα
									οἶμαι ἐκ τοῦ τραύματος,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁρᾷς_ἥκεις_687"> conveys indignant reproach: a grave charge has been laid against your king; instead of meeting it with denial, you are led, by your sympathy with Creon, to imply that it cannot be directly met, and must be hushed up. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 735">Soph. Ant. 735</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρᾷς τάδ’ ὡς εἴρηκας ὡς ἄγαν νέος</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 628">Soph. El. 628</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρᾷς; πρὸς ὁργὴν ἐκφέρει</quote> </cit> . </gloss>

data.quote: ὁρᾷς τάδ’ ὡς εἴρηκας ὡς ἄγαν νέος

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παριεὶς_688"> with </gloss>
