content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅτε_918"> seeing that, = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπειδή</foreign>:<ref n="Soph. Ant. 170">Soph. Ant. 170</ref>:<ref n="Soph. El. 38">Soph. El. 38</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Dem. 1.1">Dem. 1.1</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτε τοίνυν οὕτως ἔχει</quote> </cit>: so <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁπότε</quote> <bibl n="Thuc. 2.60">Thuc. 2.60</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Λύκεῑ_Ἄπολλον_919"> see on <foreign xml:lang="grc">Λύκειε</foreign> 203. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατεύγμασιν_920"> the prayers symbolised by the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱκετηρία</foreign> and offerings of incense. The word could not mean “votive offerings.” Wunder's conject. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατάργμασιν_920">, though ingenious, is neither needful nor really apposite. That word is used of (a) offerings of <emph>first-fruits</emph>, presented along with the <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰρεσιώνη</foreign> or harvestwreath, <ref n="Plut. Thes. 22">Plut. Thes. 22</ref>: (b) the <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐλοχύται</foreign> or barley sprinkled on the altar and victim at the <emph>beginning</emph> of a sacrifice: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IT 244">Eur. IT 244</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χέρνιβάς τε καὶ κατάργματα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λύσιν_εὐαγῆ_921"> <emph>a solution without defilement</emph>: i.e. some end to our anxieties, other than such an end as would be put to them by the fulfilment of the oracles dooming Oedipus to incur a fearful <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄγος.</foreign> For <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὐαγὴς λύσις</foreign> as = one which will leave us <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὐαγεῖς,</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Pind. O. 1">Pind. O. 1.26</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καθαροῦ λέβητος,</quote> </cit> the vessel of cleansing. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_νεώς_923"> not <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς (ὄντα) κυβερν. ν.,</foreign> <emph>because</emph> he is our pilot, but <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς (ὀκνοῖμεν ἂν) βλέποντες κυβερν. ν. ἐκπεπληγμένον</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 2">Aesch. Seven 2</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅστις φυλάσσει πρᾶγος ἐν πρύμνῃ πόλεως | οἴακα νωμῶν, βλέφαρα μὴ κοιμῶν ὕπνῳ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὅστις φυλάσσει πρᾶγος ἐν πρύμνῃ πόλεως | οἴακα
							νωμῶν, βλέφαρα μὴ κοιμῶν ὕπνῳ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μάλιστα_926"> denotes what stands <emph>first</emph> among one's wishes: cp. 1466: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 799">Soph. Trach. 799</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μάλιστα μέν με θὲς | ἐνταῦθ’ ὅπου με μή τις ὄψεται βροτῶν· | εἰδ’ οἶκτον ἴσχεις, κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 617">Soph. Phil. 617</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴοιτο μὲν μάλισθ’ ἑκούσιον λαβών, | εἰ μὴ θέλοι δ’, ἄκοντα</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 327">Soph. Ant. 327</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ εὑρεθείη μὲν μάλιστ’· ἐὰν δέ τοι | ληφθῇ τε καὶ μὴ κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
μάλιστα μέν με θὲς | ἐνταῦθ’ ὅπου με μή τις
							ὄψεται
									βροτῶν· | εἰδ’ οἶκτον ἴσχεις, κ.τ.λ.

οἴοιτο μὲν μάλισθ’ ἑκούσιον λαβών, | εἰ μὴ
							θέλοι
									δ’, ἄκοντα

ἀλλ’ εὑρεθείη μὲν μάλιστ’· ἐὰν δέ τοι | ληφθῇ
							τε
									καὶ μὴ κ.τ.λ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γυνὴ_δέ_928"> Here, and in 930, 950, the language is so chosen as to emphasise the conjugal relation of Iocasta with Oedipus. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παντελής_930"> because the wife's estate is crowned and perfected by the birth of children (928). The choice of the word has been influenced by the associations of <foreign xml:lang="grc">τέλος, τέλειος</foreign> with marriage. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 835">Aesch. Eum. 835</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θύη πρὸ παίδων καὶ γαμηλίου τέλους</quote> </cit> (the marriage rite): <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 214">Aesch. Eum. 214</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἥρας τελείας καὶ Διὸς πιστώματα</quote> </cit>: schol. on <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Thes. 973">Aristoph. Thes. 973</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐτιμῶντο ἐν τοῖς γάμοις ὡς πρυτάνεις ὄντες τῶν γάμων· τέλος δὲ ὁ γάμος</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Pind. N. 10">Pind. N. 10.18</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τελεία μήτηρ</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἥρα,</foreign> who (<ref n="Aristoph. Thes. 976">Aristoph. Thes. 976</ref>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">κλῇδας γάμου φυλάττει.</foreign> In <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 972">Aesch. Ag. 972</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνὴρ τέλειος</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">οἰκοδεσπότης</foreign>: as <foreign xml:lang="grc">δόμος ἡμιτελὴς</foreign> (<ref n="Hom. Il. 2.700">Hom. Il. 2.700</ref>) refers to a house left without its lord: cp. <cit> <bibl>Luc. Dial. Mort. 19</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡμιτελῆ μὲν τὸν δόμον καταλιπών, χήραν δὲ τὴν νεόγαμον γυναῖκα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: θύη πρὸ παίδων καὶ γαμηλίου τέλους

ἐτιμῶντο ἐν τοῖς γάμοις ὡς πρυτάνεις ὄντες τῶν
							γάμων· τέλος δὲ ὁ γάμος

ἡμιτελῆ μὲν τὸν δόμον καταλιπών, χήραν δὲ τὴν
							νεόγαμον γυναῖκα.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὔτως_931"> (<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 1040">Soph. Trach. 1040</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὧδ’ αὔτως ὥς μ’ ὤλεσε</quote> </cit>) can be nothing but adverb from <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτός</foreign> (with Aeolic accent), = ”in that very way “: hence, according to the context, (a) simply “likewise,” or (b) in a depreciatory sense, “only thus,” —i.e. “inefficiently,” “vainly.” The custom of the grammarians, to write <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὕτως</foreign> except when the sense is “vainly,” seems to have come from associating the word with <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὗτος,</foreign> or possibly even with <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὑτός.</foreign> For Soph., as for Aesch. and Eur., our MSS. on the whole favour <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὕτως</foreign>: but their authority cannot be presumed to represent a tradition older than, or independent of, the grammarians. It is, indeed, possible that <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὕτως</foreign> was an instance of old aspiration on false analogy, —as the Attic <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡμεῖς</foreign> (Aeolic <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄμμες</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀσμές)</foreign> was wrongly aspirated on the analogy of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑμεῖς</foreign> (see Peile, <title>Greek and Latin Etymology</title> p. 302, who agrees on this with Curtius). In the absence of evidence, however, that <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὔτως</foreign> was a like instance, it appears most reasonable to write <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὔτως.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐεπείας_932"> gracious words, = <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὐφημίας,</foreign> in this sense only here: elsewhere = elegance of diction: Isocrates <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν εὐέπειαν ἐκ παντὸς διώκει καὶ τοῦ γλαφυρῶς λέγειν στοχάζεται μᾶλλον ἢ τοῦ ἀφελῶς</foreign> (<ref>Dion. Hal. Isoc. 538</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρὰ_τίνος_935"> The change of <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρά</foreign> into <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρός</foreign> by an early hand in L is remarkable. I formerly received <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρός,</foreign> supporting the phrase by <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 8.28">Hom. Od. 8.28</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξεῖνος ὅδ’, οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅστις, ἀλώμενος ἵκετ’ ἐμὸν δῶ | ἠὲ πρὸς ἠοίων ἢ ἐσπερίων ἀνθρώπων.</quote> </cit> There, however, <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρός</foreign> is more natural, as virtually denoting the geographical regions (cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 21.347">Hom. Od. 21.347</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς Ἤλιδος,</quote> </cit> ”on the side of Elis “). And <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς θεῶν ὡρμημένος</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. El. 70">Soph. El. 70</ref>) would be parallel only if here we had <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐσταλμένος.</foreign> Questioning, then, whether <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀφικνεῖσθαι πρός τινος</foreign> is defensible, I now read <foreign xml:lang="grc">παρά,</foreign> with most edd. </gloss>

data.quote:
ξεῖνος ὅδ’, οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅστις, ἀλώμενος ἵκετ’
							ἐμὸν δῶ
									| ἠὲ πρὸς ἠοίων ἢ ἐσπερίων ἀνθρώπων.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_ἔπος_936"> “at the word,” accus. of the object which the feeling concerns: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. El. 831">Eur. El. 831</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί χρῆμ’ ἀθυμεῖς;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀσχάλλοις_937"> from root <foreign xml:lang="grc">σεχ,</foreign> prop. “not to hold oneself,” “to be impatient,” the opposite of the notion expressed by <foreign xml:lang="grc">σχο‐λή</foreign> (<ref>Curt. Etym. 170</ref>): the word occurs in Her., Xen., Dem.; and in <ref n="Hom. Od. 2.193">Hom. Od. 2.193</ref> replaces the epic <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀσχαλάαν.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 1049">Aesch. Ag. 1049</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πείθοῑ ἄν, εἰ πείθοῑ, ἀπειθοίης δ’ ἴσως.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: πείθοῑ ἄν, εἰ πείθοῑ, ἀπειθοίης δ’ ἴσως.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγκρατὴς_941"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν κράτει</foreign>: cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔναρχος</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν ἀρχῇ,</foreign> in office, <ref>Appian Civ. War 1.14</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πῶς_πόλυβος_943"> has been patched up in our best MSS. by a clumsy expansion of the next verse (see crit. note). The </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γέρων_943"> supplied by Triclinius (whence some late MSS. have </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γέρον_943">)was plainly a mere guess. Nauck's conj. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_πατήρ_943"> is recommended (1) by the high probability of a gloss </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Πόλυβος_943"> on those words: (2) by the greater force which this form gives to the repetition of the question asked in 941: (3) by the dramatic effect for the spectators. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦ_μαντεύματα_946"> Iocasta's scorn is pointed, not at the gods themselves, but at the <foreign xml:lang="grc">μάντεις</foreign> who profess to speak in their name. The gods are wise, but they grant no <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρόνοια</foreign> to men (978). Cp. 712. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵν_ἵνα_947"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅτι ἐνταῦθα,</foreign> ”to think that ye have come to this! “: cp. 1311. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτον_ἔφευγε_947"> he feared and avoided this man, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_κτάνοι_947"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(αὐτόν).</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_τύχης_949"> i.e. in the course of nature, and not by the special death which the oracle had foretold. Cp. 977. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξεπέμψω_951"> the midd. as in <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκκαλεῖσθαι</foreign> (see on 597), <foreign xml:lang="grc">μεταπέμπεσθαι,</foreign> etc., the act. being properly used of the summoner or escort: see on <foreign xml:lang="grc">στελοῦντα</foreign> (860). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_λέγει_954"> ”what does he tell (of interest) for me? “ (not ”what does he say to me? “: nor ”what, pray, does he say? “). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_956"> see on 848. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σημάντωρ_957"> is, I think, unquestionably right. A is among the MSS. which have it, and in several it is explained by the gloss <foreign xml:lang="grc"> μηνυτής.</foreign> That the word was not unfamiliar to poetical language in the sense (“indicator,” “informant”) which it has here, may be inferred from <ref>Anthol. 6.62</ref> (Jacobs 1.205) <foreign xml:lang="grc">κυκλοτερῆ μόλιβον, σελίδων σημάντορα πλευρῆς,</foreign> the pencil which makes notes in the margin of pages: Nonnus 37.551 <foreign xml:lang="grc">σημάντορι φωνῇ.</foreign> On the other hand, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σημήνας_γενοῦ_957"> could mean nothing but “place yourself in the position of having told me,” and could only be explained as a way of saying, “tell me at once.” But such a use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">γενέσθαι</foreign> with aor. partic. would be unexampled. The only proper use of it is made clear by such passages as these: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 588">Soph. Aj. 588</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ προδοὺς ἡμᾶς γένῃ,</quote> </cit> do not make yourself guilty of having betrayed us: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 772">Soph. Phil. 772</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ σαυτόν θ’ ἅμα | κἀμὲ … κτείνας γένῃ,</quote> </cit> do not make yourself guilty of having slain both yourself and me. </gloss>

data.quote:
μὴ σαυτόν θ’ ἅμα | κἀμὲ … κτείνας
									γένῃ,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὖ_ἴσθ_959"> <ref>Dion. Hal. 1.41</ref> thus quotes a verse from the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Προμηθεὺς Λυόμενος</foreign> of Aesch. (Nauck fr. 193. 2) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔνθ’ οὐ μάχης εὖ οἶδα καὶ θοῦρός περ ὤν,</foreign> where Strabo p. 183 gives <foreign xml:lang="grc">σάφ’ οἶδα</foreign>: and so Pors. here would write <foreign xml:lang="grc">σάφ’ ἴσθι.</foreign> But the immediately preceding </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σαφῶς_959"> is decisive against this. Soph. had epic precedent, <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 1.385">Hom. Il. 1.385</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὖ εἰδὼς ἀγόρευε,</quote> </cit> etc. Cp. 1071, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰοὺ ἰού.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θανάσιμον_βεβηκότα_959"> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 516">Soph. Aj. 516</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μοῖρα … | καθεῖλεν Ἅιδου θανασίμους οἰκήτορας</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 424">Soph. Phil. 424</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θανὼν … φροῦδος.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυναλλαγῇ_960">: see on 34. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σμικρὰ_ῥοπή_961"> <foreign xml:lang="lat">leve momentum</foreign>: the life is conceived as resting in one scale of a nicely poised balance: diminish the weight in the other scale ever so little, and the inclination <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ῥοπἤ,</foreign> though due to a slight cause <foreign xml:lang="grc">(σμικρἄ,</foreign> brings the life to the ground (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐνάζει_961"> ).<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 556e">Plat. Rep. 556e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥσπερ σῶμα νοσῶδες μικρᾶς ῥοπῆς ἔξωθεν δεῖται προσλαβέσθαι πρὸς τὸ κάμνειν, … οὕτω δὴ καὶ ἡ κατὰ ταὐτὰ ἐκείνῳ διακειμένη πόλις ἀπὸ σμικρᾶς προφάσεως … νοσεῖ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὥσπερ σῶμα νοσῶδες μικρᾶς ῥοπῆς ἔξωθεν δεῖται
							προσλαβέσθαι πρὸς τὸ κάμνειν, … οὕτω δὴ καὶ ἡ κατὰ ταὐτὰ ἐκείνῳ
							διακειμένη πόλις ἀπὸ σμικρᾶς προφάσεως … νοσεῖ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συμμετρούμενος_963">, sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτοῖς,</foreign> lit. ”commensurably with them “): the part. being nearly equiv. to <foreign xml:lang="grc"> συμμέτρως,</foreign> and expressing that, if his years are reckoned, his death cannot appear premature. Cp. 1113, and <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 387">Soph. Ant. 387</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποίᾳ ξύμμετρος προὔβην τύχῃ;</quote> </cit> “<emph>seasonably</emph> for what hap?” </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκοποῖτο_964"> midd. as <ref n="Soph. Trach. 296">Soph. Trach. 296</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὴν_ἑστίαν_964"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν Πυθοῖ μαντικὴν ἑστίαν,</foreign> as Apollo himself is <foreign xml:lang="grc">Πυθόμαντις,</foreign> i.e. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ Πυθοῖ μάντις,</quote> <bibl n="Aesch. Lib. 1030">Aesch. Lib. 1030</bibl> </cit>: cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">Πυθόκραντος, Πυθόχρηστος, Πυθόνικος.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑστίαν_964">, as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 413">Soph. OC 413</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Δελφικῆς ἀφ’ ἑστίας</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ion 461">Eur. Ion 461</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Φοιβήιος … γᾶς | μεσόμφαλος ἑστία.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλάζοντας_966"> the word used by Teiresias of the birds when their voice <foreign xml:lang="grc">(φθόγγος)</foreign> had <emph>ceased</emph> to be clear to him, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1001">Soph. Ant. 1001</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κακῷ | κλάζοντας οἴστρῳ καὶ βεβαρβαρωμένῳ</quote> </cit> . </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧν_ὑφηγητῶν_966"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄντων,</foreign> quibus indicibus: 1260 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ὑφηγητοῦ τινος</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1588">Soph. OC 1588</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑφηγητῆρος οὐδενὸς φίλων.</quote> </cit> In these instances the absence of the part. is softened by the noun which suggests the verb; but not so in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 83">Soph. OC 83</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐμοῦ μόνης πέλας.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κτενεῖν_967"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κτανεῖν,</foreign> which the MSS. give, cannot be pronounced positively wrong; but it can hardly be doubted that Soph. here wrote <foreign xml:lang="grc">κτενεῖν.</foreign> If <foreign xml:lang="grc">κτανεῖν</foreign> is right, it is the only aor. infin. after <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέλλω</foreign> in Soph., who has the fut. infin. 9 times (<ref n="Soph. El. 359, 379, 538">Soph. El. 359, 379, 538</ref>:<ref n="Soph. Aj. 925, 1027, 1287">Soph. Aj. 925, 1027, 1287</ref>:<ref n="Soph. Ant. 458">Soph. Ant. 458</ref>:<ref n="Soph. Phil. 483, 1084">Soph. Phil. 483, 1084</ref>): and the pres. infin. 9 times (<ref n="Soph. El. 305, 1486">Soph. El. 305, 1486</ref>:<ref n="Soph. Aj. 443">Soph. Aj. 443</ref>:<ref n="Soph. OT 678, 1385">Soph. OT 678, 1385</ref>:<ref n="Soph. OC 1773">Soph. OC 1773</ref>:<ref n="Soph. Trach. 79, 756">Soph. Trach. 79, 756</ref>:<ref n="Soph. Phil. 409">Soph. Phil. 409</ref>). Aeschylus certainly has the aor. in <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 625">Aesch. PB 625</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μήτοι με κρύψῃς τοῦθ’ ὅπερ μέλλω παθεῖν.</quote> </cit> Excluding the Laconic <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰδῆν</foreign> in <ref n="Aristoph. Lys. 117">Aristoph. Lys. 117</ref>, there are but two instances in Comedy, <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Birds 366">Aristoph. Birds 366</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί μέλλετ’—ἀπολέσαι,</quote> </cit> and <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Ach. 1159">Aristoph. Ach. 1159</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μέλλοντος λαβεῖν.</quote> </cit> Cp. W. G. Rutherford, <title>New Phrynichus</title> pp. 420-425, and Goodwin, <title>Greek Moods and Tenses</title> sect. 23.2. The concurrence of tribrachs in the 4th and 5th places gives a semi-lyric character which suits the speaker's agitation. </gloss>

data.quote: μήτοι με κρύψῃς τοῦθ’ ὅπερ μέλλω παθεῖν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεύθει_968"> is hidden. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 635">Soph. Aj. 635</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἅιδᾳ κεύθων.</quote> </cit> In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 989">Soph. Trach. 989</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σιγῇ κεύθειν</quote> </cit> may be regarded as transitive with a suppressed acc., ”to shroud (thy thought) in silence. “ Elsewhere <foreign xml:lang="grc">κεύθω</foreign> is always trans., and only the perf. <foreign xml:lang="grc">κέκευθα</foreign> intransitive. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δὴ_968"> here nearly = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἤδη</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 170">Soph. Ant. 170</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅτ’ οὖν ὤλοντο … | ἐγὼ κράτη δὴ … ἔχω.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ὅτ’ οὖν ὤλοντο … | ἐγὼ κράτη δὴ …
									ἔχω.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄψαυστος_969"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ ψαύσας</foreign>: cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀφόβητος</foreign> 885 (n.): <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 8.124">Hdt. 8.124</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄκριτος,</quote> </cit> without deciding: id. 9. 98 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄπιστος,</foreign> mistrustful; <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1031">Soph. OC 1031</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πιστός,</quote> </cit> trusting (n.): <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 687">Soph. Phil. 687</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφίπληκτα ῥόθια,</quote> </cit> billows beating around: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 446">Soph. Trach. 446</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μεμπτός,</quote> </cit> blaming: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hec. 1117">Eur. Hec. 1117</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὕποπτος,</quote> </cit> suspecting. Cp. note on <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀτλητῶν</foreign> 515. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴ_μὴ_969"> an abrupt afterthought: -unless perchance: see on 124.<foreign xml:lang="grc">—τὠμῷ πόθῳ</foreign>: cp. 797: <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 11.202">Hom. Od. 11.202</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὸς … πόθος,</quote> </cit> longing for thee. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴη_ξ_970"> cp. 1075: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 467">Soph. Phil. 467</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλεῖν μὴ ξ ἀπόπτου. ἐξ,</quote> </cit> as dist. from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπό,</foreign> is strictly in place here, as denoting the ultimate, not the proximate, agency. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_παρόντα_971"> but the oracles as they stand, at any rate (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δ_οὖν_971">,669, 834), Polybus has carried off with him, proving them worthless (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄξῑ_οὐδενός_971">, tertiary predicate), and is hidden with Hades. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_παρόντα_971_2"> with emphasis: even supposing that they have been fulfilled in some indirect and figurative sense, they certainly have not been fulfilled to the letter. The oracle spoke of bloodshed <foreign xml:lang="grc"> (φονεύς,</foreign> 794), and is not satisfied by <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατέφθιτο ἐξ ἐμοῦ</foreign> in the sense just explained. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συλλαβὼν_971"> is a contemptuous phrase from the language of common life: its use is seen in <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Pl. 1079">Aristoph. Pl. 1079</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν δ’ ἄπιθι χαίρων συλλαβὼν τὴν μείρακα,</quote> </cit> now be off—with our blessing and the girl: <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Birds 1469">Aristoph. Birds 1469</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπίωμεν ἡμεῖς συλλαβόντες τὰ πτερά,</quote> </cit> let us pack up our feathers and be off: Soph. has it twice in utterances of angry scorn, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1383">Soph. OC 1383</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ δ’ ἔρρ’ ἀπόπτυστός τε κἀπάτωρ ἐμοῦ | κακῶν κάκιστε, τάσδε συλλαβὼν ἀράς,</quote> </cit> begone … and take these curses with thee: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 577">Soph. Phil. 577</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔκπλει σεαυτὸν συλλαβὼν ἐκ τῆσδε γῆς,</quote> </cit> ”hence in thy ship—pack from this land! “ </gloss>

data.quote: νῦν δ’ ἄπιθι χαίρων συλλαβὼν τὴν μείρακα,

σὺ δ’ ἔρρ’ ἀπόπτυστός τε κἀπάτωρ ἐμοῦ | κακῶν
							κάκιστε, τάσδε συλλαβὼν ἀράς,
ἔκπλει σεαυτὸν συλλαβὼν ἐκ τῆσδε γῆς,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ηὔδας_974"> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">προὔλεγες</foreign>: see on 54. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νυν_975"> enforcing the argument introduced by <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔκουν</foreign> (973), is clearly better than the weak <foreign xml:lang="grc">νῦν</foreign>.<foreign xml:lang="grc">—ἐς θυμὸν βάλῃς</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 7.51">Hdt. 7.51</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς θυμὸν βαλεῦ καὶ τὸ παλαιὸν ἔπος</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 8.68">Hdt. 8.68</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ τόδε ἐς θυμὸν βαλεῦ, ὡς κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.84">Hdt. 1.84</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰδὼν … τῶν τινα Λυδῶν καταβάντα … ἐφράσθη καὶ ἐς θυμὸν ἑβάλετο.</quote> </cit> The active in the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Βίος Ὁμήρου</foreign> sect. 30 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐς θυμὸν ἔβαλε τὸ ῥηθέν.</foreign> In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1347">Soph. El. 1347</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδέ γ’ ἐς θυμὸν φέρω</quote> </cit> is not really similar. </gloss>

data.quote: ἐς θυμὸν βαλεῦ καὶ τὸ παλαιὸν ἔπος
καὶ τόδε ἐς θυμὸν βαλεῦ, ὡς κ.τ.λ.

ἰδὼν … τῶν τινα Λυδῶν καταβάντα … ἐφράσθη
									καὶ ἐς θυμὸν ἑβάλετο.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾦ_977"> “for whom,” in relation to whom: not, “in whose opinion.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_τύχης_977"> is here somewhat more than a mere periphrasis for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ τύχη,</foreign> since the plur. suggests successive incidents. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τύχη_977"> does not here involve denial of a divine order in the government of the world, but only of man's power to comprehend or foresee its course. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 5.104">Thuc. 5.104</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πιστεύομεν τῇ μὲν τύχῃ ἐκ τοῦ θείου μὴ ἐλασσώσεσθαι.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Lys. 24.22">Lys. 24.22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὖ μόνου μεταλαβεῖν ἡ τύχη μοι ἕδωκεν ἐν τῇ πατρίδι,</quote> </cit> the only privilege which Fortune (i.e. my destiny) has permitted me to enjoy in my country. </gloss>

data.quote:
πιστεύομεν τῇ μὲν τύχῃ ἐκ τοῦ θείου μὴ
							ἐλασσώσεσθαι.

οὖ μόνου μεταλαβεῖν ἡ τύχη μοι ἕδωκεν ἐν τῇ
							πατρίδι,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρόνοια_978"> Bentley on Phalaris (xvii, Dyce ii. 115) quotes Favorinus in <ref>Diog. Laert. Plat. 24</ref> as saying that Plato <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρῶτος ἐν φιλοσοφίᾳ … ὠνόμασε … θεοῦ πρόνοιαν.</foreign> Bentley takes this to mean that Plato was the first to use <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρόνοια</foreign> of divine providence (not merely of human forethought), and cites it in proof that Phalaris <title>Ep.</title> 3 (= 40 Lennep) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἕως ἂν ἡ διοικοῦσα πρόνοια τὴν αὐτὴν ἁρμονίαν τοῦ‐κόσμου φυλάττῃ</foreign> is later than Plato. Lennep, in his edition of Phalaris (p. 158), puts the case more exactly. The Stoics, not Plato, first used <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρόνοια,</foreign> <emph>without further qualification</emph>, of a divine providence. When Plato says <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν τοῦ θεοῦ … πρόνοιαν</foreign> (<ref n="Plat. Tim. 30c">Plat. Tim. 30c</ref> ),<foreign xml:lang="grc">προνοίας θεῶν</foreign> (<ref n="Plat. Tim. 44c">Plat. Tim. 44c</ref>), the phrase is no more than Herodotus had used before him, <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 3.108">Hdt. 3.108</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ θείου ἡ προνοίη.</quote> </cit> The meaning of Favorinus was that Plato first established in <emph> philosophy</emph> the conception of a divine providence, though popular language had known such a phrase before. Note that in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1180">Soph. OC 1180</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόνοια τοῦ θεοῦ</quote> </cit> = ”reverence for the god “: in <ref n="Eur. Phoen. 637">Eur. Phoen. 637</ref> a man acts <foreign xml:lang="grc">θείᾳ προνοίᾳ</foreign> = ”with inspired foresight “: in <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 1.4.6">Xen. Mem. 1.4.6</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προνοητικῶς</quote> </cit> = not, “providentially,” but simply, ”with forethought. “ </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰκῆ_979"> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 503e">Plat. Gorg. 503e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ εἰκῆ ἐρεῖ, ἀλλ’ ἀποβλέπων πρός τι</quote> </cit> (with some definite object in view). </gloss>

data.quote: οὐκ εἰκῆ ἐρεῖ, ἀλλ’ ἀποβλέπων πρός τι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κράτιστον_δύναιτο_979"> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 666">Soph. Ant. 666</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὂν πόλις στήσειε τοῦδε χρὴ κλύειν</quote> </cit>: where <foreign xml:lang="grc">χρὴ κλύειν</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">δικαίως ἂν κλύοι.</foreign> So here, though <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐστί</foreign> (not <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦν)</foreign> must be supplied with <foreign xml:lang="grc">κράτιστον,</foreign> the whole phrase = <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰκῆ κράτιστον ἄν τις ζῴη.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.19">Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.19</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ … αὐτὸν λέγειν ἃ μὴ σαφῶς εἰδείη φείδεσθαι δεῖ</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀρθῶς ἂν φείδοιτο.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: ἀλλ’ ὂν πόλις στήσειε τοῦδε χρὴ κλύειν

τοῦ … αὐτὸν λέγειν ἃ μὴ σαφῶς εἰδείη φείδεσθαι
							δεῖ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φοβοῦ_980"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">φοβεῖσθαι εἴς τι</foreign> = to have fears regarding it: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 1211">Soph. Trach. 1211</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ φοβεῖ πρὸς τοῦτο</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1119">Soph. OC 1119</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ θαύμαζε πρὸς τὸ λιπαρές.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀν_ὀνείρασιν_981"> in dreams <emph>also</emph> (as well as in this oracle); and, as such dreams have proved vain, so may this oracle. Soph. was prob. thinking of the story in <ref n="Hdt. 6.107">Hdt. 6.107</ref> that Hippias had such a dream on the eve of the battle of Marathon, and interpreted it as an omen of his restoration to Athens. Cp. the story of a like dream coming to Julius Caesar on the night before he crossed the Rubicon (<ref>Plut. Caes. 32</ref>,<ref>Suet. 7</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρ_οὐδέν_983"> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 34">Soph. Ant. 34</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ πρᾶγμ’ ἄγειν | οὐχ ὡς παρ’ οὐδέν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: τὸ πρᾶγμ’ ἄγειν | οὐχ ὡς παρ’ οὐδέν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξείρητο_984"> the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξ–</foreign> glances at her blunt expression of disbelief, not her frank reference to a horrible subject. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀφθαλμὸς_987"> the idea is that of a <emph>bright, sudden comfort</emph>: so <ref n="Soph. Trach. 203">Soph. Trach. 203</ref> Deianeira calls on her household to rejoice, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἄελπτον ὄμμ’ ἐμοὶ | φήμης ἀνασχὸν τῆσδε νῦν καρπούμεθα</foreign> (the unexpected news that Heracles has returned). More often this image denotes the “darling” of a family (<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Lib. 934">Aesch. Lib. 934</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀφθαλμὸς οἴκων),</quote> </cit> or a dynasty that is “the light” of a land (<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">Σικελίας δ’ ἔσαν | ὀφθαλμός,</quote> <bibl n="Pind. O. 2">Pind. O. 2.9</bibl> </cit> :<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ Βάττου παλαιὸς ὄλβος … πύργος ἄστεος, ὄμμα τε φαεννότατον | ξένοισι,</foreign> <ref n="Pind. P. 5">Pind. P. 5.51</ref>). Not <emph>merely</emph> (though this notion comes in) “a great help to seeing” that oracles are idle <foreign xml:lang="grc">(δήλωσις ὡς τὰ μαντεύματα κακῶς ἔχει,</foreign> schol.). A certain hardness of feeling appears in the phrase: Iocasta was softened by fear for Oedipus and the State: she is now elated. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_989"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκφοβεῖσθε_989">; 772, 851. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκείνης_991"> what is there <emph>belonging to</emph> her, <emph>in</emph> her (attributive gen.): <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IA 28">Eur. IA 28</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἄγαμαι ταῦτ’ ἀνδρὸς ἀριστέως. —</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐς_φέρον_991">, tending to fear: cp. 519. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεήλατον_992"> <emph>sent upon us</emph> by the gods: cp. 255. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_θεμιτὸν_993">, the question is between </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐχὶ_θεμιτὸν_993"> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ θεμιστὸν.</foreign> The former is much more probable, since <foreign xml:lang="grc">θεμιτός</foreign> is the usual form, found in Attic prose, in Eur. (as <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 97">Eur. Orest. 97</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σοὶ δ’ οὐχὶ θεμιτόν),</quote> </cit> and in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1758">Soph. OC 1758</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ οὐ θεμιτὸν κεῖσε μολεῖν.</quote> </cit> On the other hand <foreign xml:lang="grc">θεμιστός</foreign> is a rare poet. form, found once in Pindar (who has also <foreign xml:lang="grc"> θεμιτός),</foreign> and twice in the lyrics of Aesch. Had we <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄλλῳ,</foreign> the subject of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεμιτὸν_993"> would be </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μάντευμα_993">: the accus. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλον_993"> shows </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεμιτὸν_993_2"> to be impersonal, as in <ref n="Eur. Orest. 97">Eur. Orest. 97</ref>,<cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 9">Pind. P. 9.42</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ θεμιτὸν ψεύδει θιγεῖν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_ἑλεῖν_996"> is strictly ”to achieve (the shedding of) my father's blood. “ Classical Greek had no such phrase as <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἶμα χεῖν</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκχεῖν</foreign> in the sense of “to slay.” <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἱρεῖν</foreign> is to <emph>make a prey of</emph>, meaning “to slay,” or “to take,” according to the context (<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 353">Soph. Trach. 353</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Εὔρυτόν θ’ ἕλοι | τὴν θ’ ὑψίπυργον Οἰχαλίαν).</quote> </cit> Cp. fr. 726 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνδρὸς αἶμα συγγενὲς | κτείνας,</foreign> which is even bolder than this, but similar, since here we might have had simply <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸν πατέρα ἑλεῖν,</foreign> ”to <emph>slay</emph> my father “: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 284">Eur. Orest. 284</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴργασται δ’ ἐμοὶ | μητρῷον αἶμα,</quote> </cit> I have wrought the murder of a mother. </gloss>

data.quote:
Εὔρυτόν θ’ ἕλοι | τὴν θ’ ὑψίπυργον
									Οἰχαλίαν).

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποικεῖν_997"> is a comparatively rare word. Eur. has it twice (<ref n="Eur. Her. 557">Eur. Her. 557</ref>:<ref n="Eur. IA 680">Eur. IA 680</ref>: in both with gen., <emph>‘to dwell far from ’</emph>): Thuc. once with <foreign xml:lang="grc">μακρὰν</foreign> (<ref n="Thuc. 3.55">Thuc. 3.55</ref>) and Xen. once (<ref n="Xen. Ec. 4.6">Xen. Oec. 4.6</ref>), —both absol., as = <emph>‘to dwell afar ’:</emph> as prob. <ref>Theocr. 15.7</ref> (reading <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὦ μέλ’ ἀποικεῖς</foreign> with Meineke): Plato once thus (<ref n="Plat. Laws 753a">Plat. Laws 753a</ref>), and twice as = to <emph> emigrate</emph> (<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ Γόρτυνος,</quote> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 708a">Plat. Laws 708a</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς Θουρίους,</quote> <bibl n="Plat. Euthyd. 271c">Plat. Euthyd. 271c</bibl> </cit>): in which sense Isocr. also has it twice (<ref n="Isoc. 4.122">Isoc. 4.122</ref>,<ref n="Isoc. 6.84">Isoc. 6.84</ref>): Pindar once (with accus. of motion to a place), <cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 4">Pind. P. 4.258</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Καλλίσταν ἀπῴκησαν,</quote> </cit> they went and settled at Callista. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐτυχῶς_998"> because of his high fortunes at Thebes. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῶν_τεκόντων_998"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τῶν γονέων</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 1081">Eur. Hipp. 1081</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς τεκόντας ὅσια δρᾶν,</quote> </cit> and oft.: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 975">Eur. Her. 975</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βοᾷ δὲ μήτηρ, ὦ τεκών [;</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὦ πάτερ];, τί δρᾷς</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπόπτολις_1000"> exile, as <ref n="Soph. OC 208">Soph. OC 208</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατρός_τε_1001"> So the MSS., rightly. It is the fear of Oed. regarding his <emph>mother</emph> by which the messenger's attention has been fixed. In explaining this, Oed. has indeed mentioned the other fear as to his father; but in v. 1000, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦ γὰρ τάδ’ ὀκνῶν,</foreign> the messenger means: “So this, then, was the fear about her which kept you away? ” —alluding to his own question in 991. As the speaker's tone seems to make light of the cause, Oed. answers, “<emph>and</emph> that further dread about my father which I mentioned. ” <foreign xml:lang="grc">πατρός</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_1001"> is unsuitable, since it would imply that this was his <emph>sole</emph> fear. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγὼ_οὐχὶ_1002"> synizesis: see on 332 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ οὔτ’.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξελυσάμην_1003"> the aor. implies, “why have I not done it already?” i.e. “why <emph>do</emph> I not do it at once?” <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 747">Aesch. PB 747</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί δῆτ’ ἐμοὶ ζῆν κέρδος, ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἐν τάχει | ἔρριψ’ ἐμαυτὴν τῆσδ’ ἀπὸ στύφλου πέτρας;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τί δῆτ’ ἐμοὶ ζῆν κέρδος, ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἐν τάχει |
							ἔρριψ’ ἐμαυτὴν τῆσδ’ ἀπὸ στύφλου πέτρας;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_μὴν_1004"> properly “however ”; here, like our “well indeed ” (if you <emph>would</emph> do so). The echoing </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_μὴν_1004_2"> of 1005 expresses eager assent. Cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 221">Soph. Ant. 221</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτ_ἀφικόμην_1005"> see on 788. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καλῶς_1008"> <foreign xml:lang="lat">pulchre, belle,</foreign> thoroughly, a colloquialism, perh. meant here to be a trait of homely speech: cp. Alciphron <title>Ep.</title> 1.36 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πεινήσω τὸ καλόν</foreign> ( “I shall be fine and hungry ”): Aelian <title>Ep.</title> 2 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπέκοψε τὸ σκέλος πάνυ χρηστῶς</foreign> ( “in good style ”). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταρβῶν_1011"> is right; not that </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταρβῶ_1011"> could not stand, but Greek idiom distinctly favours the participle. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 403">Soph. Ant. 403</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΚΡ. ἦ καὶ ξυνίης καὶ λέγεις ὀρθῶς ἃ φής; ΦΥ. ταύτην γ’ ἰδὼν θάπτουσαν.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 517">Soph. Ant. 517</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΑΝ. … ἀδελφὸς ὤλετο. ΚΡ. πορθῶν γε τήνδε γῆν.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Sym. 164e">Plat. Sym. 164e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἶπον οὖν ὅτι … ἥκοιμι. —καλῶς</quote> </cit> (v. l. <foreign xml:lang="grc">καλῶς γ’), ἔφη, ποιῶν.</foreign> Cp. 1130 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξυναλλάξας</foreign>.<foreign xml:lang="grc">—ἐξέλθῃ;</foreign> cp. 1182 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξήκοι σαφῆ,</foreign> come true. </gloss>

data.quote:
ΚΡ. ἦ καὶ ξυνίης καὶ λέγεις ὀρθῶς ἃ φής; ΦΥ.
							ταύτην γ’ ἰδὼν θάπτουσαν.

ΑΝ. … ἀδελφὸς ὤλετο. ΚΡ. πορθῶν γε τήνδε
									γῆν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_δίκης_1014"> as justice would prompt, “justly.” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_1014"> prop. = “from the quarter of,” then “on the side of ”: <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.59">Thuc. 3.59</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ πρὸς τῆς ὑμετέρας δόξης … τάδε,</quote> </cit> not in the interest of your reputation: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 459c">Plat. Gorg. 459c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐάν τι ἡμῖν πρὸς λόγου ᾖ,</quote> </cit> “if it is in the interest of our discussion.” <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 470c">Plat. Rep. 470c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν … ἀπὸ τρόπου λέγεις· ὅρα δὴ καὶ εἰ τόδε πρὸς τρόπου λέγω,</quote> </cit> “correctly.” <ref n="Thphr. Char. 30">Theophr. Char. 30</ref> (= 26 in my 1st ed. p. 156) <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς τρόπου πωλεῖν,</foreign> to sell on reasonable terms. </gloss>

data.quote: οὐ πρὸς τῆς ὑμετέρας δόξης … τάδε,
ἐάν τι ἡμῖν πρὸς λόγου ᾖ,

οὐδὲν … ἀπὸ τρόπου λέγεις· ὅρα δὴ καὶ εἰ τόδε
							πρὸς τρόπου λέγω,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_γένει_1016"> <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 47.70">Dem. 47.70</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἔστιν ἐν γένει σοι ἡ ἄνθρωπος,</quote> </cit> compared with sect. 72 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμοὶ δὲ οὔτε γένει προσῆκεν.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: οὐκ ἔστιν ἐν γένει σοι ἡ ἄνθρωπος,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῷ_μηδενί_1019"> dat. of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ μηδείς,</foreign> one who is <emph> such</emph> as to be of account (in respect of consanguinity with me), —the generic use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή</foreign> (cp. 397, 638). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπ_χειρὸς_1023"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">λαβών.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμπολήσας_τυχών_1025"> i.e. “Did you buy me, or did you light upon me in the neighbourhood of Corinth? ” Oed. is not prepared for the Corinthian's reply that he had found the babe on <emph>Cithaeron</emph>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμπολήσας_1025">: cp. the story of Eumaeus (<ref n="Hom. Od. 15.403">Hom. Od. 15.403-483</ref>) who, when a babe, was carried off by Phoenician merchants from the wealthy house of his father in the isle Syria, and sold to Laertes in Ithaca: the Phoenician nurse says to the merchants, <foreign xml:lang="grc">τόν κεν ἄγοιμ’ ἐπὶ νηός, ὁ δ’ ὑμῖν μυρίον ὦνον | ἄλφοι, ὅπῃ περάσητε κατ’ ἀλλοθρόους ἀνθρώπους</foreign>.</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τυχών_1025"> is answered by <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὑρών</foreign> (1026) as in 973 <foreign xml:lang="grc">προὔλεγον</foreign> by <foreign xml:lang="grc">ηὔδας.</foreign> Cp. 1039. The </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τεκών_1025"> of the MSS. is absurd after vv. 1016-1020. The man has just said, “Polybus was no more your father than I am ”; Oed. is anxiously listening to every word. He could not ask, a moment later, “Had you bought me, or <emph>were you my father?</emph>” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ναπαίαις_πτυχαῖς_1026"> becomes vivid to anyone who traverses Cithaeron by the road ascending from Eleusis and winding upwards to the pass of Dryoscephalae, whence it descends into the plain of Thebes. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπὶ_θητείᾳ_1029"> like <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ μισθῷ</quote> <bibl n="Hdt. 5.65">Hdt. 5.65</bibl> </cit> etc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">θητεία,</foreign> labour for wages, opp. to <foreign xml:lang="grc">δουλεία</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 14.48">Isoc. 14.48</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλοὺς μὲν … δουλεύοντας, ἄλλους δ’ ἐπὶ θητείαν ἰόντας.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
πολλοὺς μὲν … δουλεύοντας, ἄλλους δ’ ἐπὶ
							θητείαν ἰόντας.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλάνης_1029">, roving in search of any employment that he can find (not merely changing summer for winter pastures, 1137). The word falls lightly from him who is so soon to be <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ πλανήτης Οἰδίπους</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. OC 3">Soph. OC 3</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοῦ_δ_1030"> With the </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοῦ_γ_1030"> of most MSS.: “Yes, and thy <emph>preserver</emph>” (the first <foreign xml:lang="grc">γε</foreign> belonging to the sentence, the second to <foreign xml:lang="grc">σωτήρ</foreign>). Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.187">Hdt. 1.187</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ μέντοι γε μὴ σπανίσας γε ἄλλως ἀνοίξῃ</quote> </cit>: where the second <foreign xml:lang="grc">γε</foreign> belongs to <foreign xml:lang="grc">σπανίσας.</foreign> There is no certain example of a double <foreign xml:lang="grc">γε</foreign> in Soph. which is really similar. With </gloss>

data.quote: μὴ μέντοι γε μὴ σπανίσας γε ἄλλως ἀνοίξῃ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοῦ_δ_1030_2">: “<emph>But</emph> thy <emph>preserver</emph>”: the <foreign xml:lang="grc">γε</foreign> still belonging to <foreign xml:lang="grc">σωτήρ,</foreign> and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δὲ_1030"> opposing this thought to that of v. 1029. For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δέ_γε_1030"> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 938">Aesch. Ag. 938</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ΑΓ. φήμη γε μέντοι δημόθρους μέγα σθένει. ΚΛ. ὁ δ’ ἀφθόνητός γ’ οὐκ ἐπίζηλος πέλει.</quote> </cit> “True, but … ” The gentle reproof conveyed by </gloss>

data.quote:
ΑΓ. φήμη γε μέντοι δημόθρους μέγα σθένει. ΚΛ.
							ὁ δ’
									ἀφθόνητός γ’ οὐκ ἐπίζηλος πέλει.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δέ_γε_1030_2"> is not unfitting in the old man's mouth: and a double </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_1030">, though admissible, is awkward here. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_ἄλγος_1031"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> And in what sense wast thou my <foreign xml:lang="grc">σωτήρ?</foreign> The </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_κακοῖς_1031"> of the later MSS. is intolerably weak: “<emph>what pain</emph> was I suffering when you found me <emph>in trouble?</emph>” The </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_καιροῖς_1031"> of L (found also, with the addition of <foreign xml:lang="grc">με,</foreign> in one later MS., Pal.) seems most unlikely to have been a corruption of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν κακοῖς.</foreign> Among the conjectures, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγκάλαις με</foreign> (Kock), or, better, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγκάλαισι,</foreign> is perh. most probable; being slightly nearer the letters than Verrall's ingenious <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἴσχον τἀγκάλισμα.</foreign> (For the dat. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγκάλαις</foreign> without <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν,</foreign> cp. <ref n="Eur. IT 289">Eur. IT 289</ref>, etc.) Such conjectures as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν δέοντι</foreign> (Wecklein), <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν καλῷ</foreign> (Wunder), presuppose that <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν καιροῖς</foreign> was a gloss: but it is more probable that it was a corruption. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεινόν_γε_1035"> in comment, as <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1225">Soph. Phil. 1225</ref>,<ref n="Soph. El. 341">Soph. El. 341</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1127">Soph. Aj. 1127</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σπαργάνων_1035"> “<emph>from</emph> my swaddling clothes ”: i.e. “from the earliest days of infancy ” (cp. <ref>Ovid Heroid. 9.22</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat"> <emph>Et tener</emph> in cunis <emph>iam Iove dignus eras</emph> </foreign>). The babe was exposed a few days after birth (717). <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1139">Soph. El. 1139</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔτε … πυρὸς | ἀνειλόμην … ἄθλιον βάρος.</quote> </cit> Some understand, “I was furnished with cruelly dishonouring <emph>tokens of my birth</emph>,”<foreign xml:lang="grc">δεινῶς ἐπονείδιστα σπάργανα,</foreign> alluding to a custom of tying round the necks of children, when they were exposed, little tokens or ornaments, which might afterwards serve as means of recognition (<foreign xml:lang="lat">crepundia, monumenta</foreign>): see esp. <ref n="Pl. Rud. 4.4">Plaut. Rud. 4.4.111-126</ref>,<ref n="Pl. Epid. 5.1">Plaut. Epidic. 5.1.34</ref>: and Rich s. v. Crepundia, where a woodcut shows a statue of a child with a string of <foreign xml:lang="lat">crepundia</foreign> hung over the right shoulder. <ref n="Plut. Thes. 4">Plut. Thes. 4</ref> calls such tokens <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνωρίσματα.</foreign> In <ref n="Aristoph. Ach. 431">Aristoph. Ach. 431</ref> the <foreign xml:lang="grc">σπάργανα</foreign> of Telephus have been explained as the tokens by which (in the play of Eur.) he was recognised; in his case, these were <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥακώματα</foreign> (431). But here we must surely take </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σπαργάνων_1035_2"> with<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνειλόμην.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥστε_1036"> assents and continues: “(yes,) and so … ” </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὃς_εἶ_1036"> i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">Οἰδίπους</foreign>: see on 718. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_πατρός_1037"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄνειδος ἀνειλόμην</foreign> (1035): “was it at the hands of mother or father (rather than at those of strangers) that I received such a brand?” The agitated speaker follows the train of his own thoughts, scarcely heeding the interposed remark. He is not thinking so much of his parents' possible cruelty, as of a fresh clue to their identity. Not: “was I so named by mother or father?” The <emph> name</emph> —even if it could be conceived as given before the exposure—is not the sting; and on the other hand it would be forced to take “<emph>named</emph>” as meaning “<emph>doomed to bear</emph> the name. ” </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βοτήρ_1044"> cp. 837, 761. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰδεῖτ_1046"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰδείητε,</foreign> only here, it seems: but cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἶτε</foreign> =<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴητε</quote> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 21.195">Hom. Od. 21.195</bibl> </cit> (doubtful in <ref n="Soph. Ant. 215">Soph. Ant. 215</ref>).<foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰδεῖμεν</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἶμεν</foreign> occur in Plato (<ref n="Plat. Rep. 581e">Plat. Rep. 581e</ref>,<ref n="Plat. Theaet. 147a">Plat. Theaet. 147a</ref>) as well as in verse. In <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 14.27">Dem. 14.27</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καταθεῖτε</quote> </cit> is not certain (<foreign xml:lang="grc">κατάθοιτε</foreign> Baiter and Sauppe): in <ref n="Dem. 18.324">Dem. 18.324</ref> he has <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐνθείητε.</foreign> Speaking generally, we may say that the contracted termination <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐εῖεν</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐είησαν</foreign> is common to poetry and prose; while the corresponding contractions, <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ‐εῖμεν</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐είημεν</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐εῖτε</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐είητε,</foreign> are rare except in poetry. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὖν_1049"> with the first </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἴτε_1049">, as <ref n="Soph. El. 199">Soph. El. 199</ref>, 560: it stands with the second above, 90, 271, <ref n="Soph. Phil. 345">Soph. Phil. 345</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπ_ἀγρῶν_1049"> <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 22.47">Hom. Od. 22.47</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλὰ μὲν ἐν μεγάροισιν … πολλὰ δ’ ἐπ’ ἀγροῦ</quote> </cit>: (cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 184">Soph. OC 184</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ ξένης,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1136">Soph. El. 1136</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἀπὶ γῆς ἄλλης·)</quote> </cit> the usual Attic phrase was <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν ἀγρῷ</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατ’ ἀγρούς.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
πολλὰ μὲν ἐν μεγάροισιν … πολλὰ δ’ ἐπ’
									ἀγροῦ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_καιρὸς_1050"> for the art., cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Ax. 364b">Plat. Axioch. 364b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν ὁ καιρὸς ἐνδείξασθαι τὴν ἀεὶ θρυλουμένην πρὸς σοῦ σοφίαν. —</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
νῦν ὁ καιρὸς ἐνδείξασθαι τὴν ἀεὶ θρυλουμένην
							πρὸς
									σοῦ σοφίαν. —

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ηὑρῆσθαι_1050">: Bellermann (objecting to the tense) reads <foreign xml:lang="grc"> εὑρέσθαι,</foreign> citing <ref n="Soph. Aj. 1023">Soph. Aj. 1023</ref> (where, as usual, the aor. midd. = “to gain ”): but the perf. is right, and forcible, here; it means, “to be discovered once for all. ” For the form, cp. 546 n. <cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 15.295">Isoc. 15.295</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν δυναμένων λέγειν ἢ παιδεύειν ἡ πόλις ἡμῶν δοκεῖ γεγενῆσθαι διδάσκαλος,</quote> </cit> to be the <emph>established</emph> teacher. </gloss>

data.quote:
τῶν δυναμένων λέγειν ἢ παιδεύειν ἡ πόλις ἡμῶν
							δοκεῖ γεγενῆσθαι διδάσκαλος,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶμαι_1051">, though often parenthetic (as <ref n="Soph. Trach. 536">Soph. Trach. 536</ref>), is not less common with infin. (<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 474a">Plat. Gorg. 474a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶον ἐγὼ οἶμαι δεῖν εἶναι),</quote> </cit> and Soph. often so has it, as <ref n="Soph. El. 1446">Soph. El. 1446</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἂν_ἂν_1053"> see on 862. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νοεῖς_1054"> = “you wot of, ” the man- i.e. you understand to whom I refer. We need not, then, write <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ κεῖνον</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκεῖνον</foreign> with A. Spengel, or <foreign xml:lang="grc">νοεῖς; ἐκεῖνον</foreign> with Blaydes, who in 1055, reading <foreign xml:lang="grc">τόνδ’,</foreign> has a comma at <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐφιέμεσθα.</foreign> Cp. 859. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόνδ_1055"> is certainly right: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόν_θ_1055"> arose, when the right punctuation had been lost, from a desire to connect </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγει_1055"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐφιέμεσθα_1055">. Dindorf, however, would keep <foreign xml:lang="grc">τόν θ’</foreign>: “know ye him whom we summoned <emph>and</emph> him of whom this man speaks?” i.e. “Can you say whether the persons are identical or distinct?” But the language will not bear this. </gloss>

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τρίτης_μητρὸς_1062"> without <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκ,</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 341">Soph. El. 341</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὖσαν πατρός,</quote> </cit> 366 <foreign xml:lang="grc">καλοῦ | τῆς μητρός.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τρίτης_τρίδουλος_1062">, thrice a slave, sprung from the third (servile) mother: i.e. from a mother, herself a slave, whose mother and grandmother had also been slaves. No commentator, so far as I know, has quoted the passage which best illustrates this: Theopompus fr. 277 (ed. Muller 1. 325) <foreign xml:lang="grc">Πυθονίκην … ἣ Βακχίδος μὲν ἦν δούλη τῆς αὐλητρίδος, ἐκείνη δὲ Σινώπης τῆς Θρᾴττης, … ὥστε γίνεσθαι μὴ μόνον τρίδουλον ἀλλὰ καὶ τρίπορνον αὐτήν.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 58.17">Dem. 58.17</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ γὰρ ὀφείλοντος αὐτῷ τοῦ πάππου πάλαι … διὰ τοῦτ’ οἰήσεται δεῖν ἀποφεύγειν ὅτι πονηρὸς ἐκ τριγονίας ἐστίν … ,</quote> </cit> “if, his grandfather having formerly been a debtor, … he shall fancy himself entitled to acquittal because he is a <emph>rascal of the third generation</emph>.” Eustathius <ref n="Hom. Od. 15.42">Hom. Od. 15. 42-50</ref> quotes from Hippônax <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἀφέω τοῦτον τὸν ἑπτάδουλον</foreign> (Bergk fr. 75), i.e. “seven times a slave. ” For the force of <foreign xml:lang="grc">τρι‐,</foreign> cp. also <foreign xml:lang="grc">τριγίγας, τρίπρατος</foreign> (thricesold, —of a slave), <foreign xml:lang="grc">τριπέδων</foreign> (a slave who has been thrice in fetters). Note how the reference to the <emph>female</emph> line of servile descent is contrived to heighten the contrast with the real situation. </gloss>

data.quote:
εἰ γὰρ ὀφείλοντος αὐτῷ τοῦ πάππου πάλαι … διὰ
							τοῦτ’ οἰήσεται δεῖν ἀποφεύγειν ὅτι πονηρὸς ἐκ τριγονίας ἐστίν …
									,

Euthyph. 4e">Plat. Euthyph. 4e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ φοβεῖ δικαζόμενος τῷ πατρί, ὅπως μὴ αὖ σὺ ἀνόσιον πρᾶγμα τυγχάνῃς πράττων;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

Kn. 626">Aristoph. Kn. 626</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ δ’ ἄρ’ ἔνδον ἐλασίβροντ’ ἀναρρηγνὺς ἔπη</quote> </cit>: Pind. fr. 172 <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ πρὸς ἅπαντας ἀναρρῆξαι τὸν ἀχρεῖον λόγον</foreign>: (2) the image is that of a storm bursting forth from a great stillness, and requires that the mysterious </gloss>

data.quote: ὁ δ’ ἄρ’ ἔνδον ἐλασίβροντ’ ἀναρρηγνὺς ἔπη

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακά_1075_2"> should be the subject: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 775">Soph. Aj. 775</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκρήξει μάχη</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aristot. Meteo. 2.8">Aristot. Meteor. 2.8</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκρήξας … ἄνεμος.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βουλήσομαι_1076"> “I shall wish ”: i.e. my wish will remain unaltered until it has been satisfied. Cp. 1446 <foreign xml:lang="grc">προστρέψομαι</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 681">Soph. Aj. 681</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὠφελεῖν βουλήσομαι,</quote> </cit> it shall henceforth be my aim: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 259">Eur. Med. 259</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοσοῦτον οὖν σου τυγχάνειν βουλήσομαι,</quote> </cit> I shall wish (shall be content) to receive from you only thus much (cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 825">Soph. Aj. 825</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰτήσομαι δέ σ’ οὐ μακρὸν γέρας λαχεῖν).</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1289">Soph. OC 1289</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ταῦτ’ ἀφ’ ὐμῶν … βουλήσομαι | … κυρεῖν ἐμοί</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Pind. O. 7">Pind. O. 7.20</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐθελήσω … διορθῶσαι λόγον,</quote> </cit> I shall have good will to tell the tale aright. That these futures are normal, and do not arise from any confusion of present <emph>wish</emph> with future <emph>act,</emph> may be seen clearly from <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedo 91a">Plat. Phaedo 91a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ἐγω μοι δοκῶ ἐν τῷ παρόντι τοσοῦτον μόνον ἐκείνων διοίσειν· οὐ γὰρ ὅπως τοῖς παροῦσιν ἃ ἐγὼ λέγω δόξει ἀληθῆ προθυμηθήσομαι·</quote> </cit> and <ref n="Plat. Phaedo 191c">Plat. Phaedo 191c</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote: αἰτήσομαι δέ σ’ οὐ μακρὸν γέρας λαχεῖν).

καὶ ταῦτ’ ἀφ’ ὐμῶν … βουλήσομαι | … κυρεῖν
									ἐμοί

καὶ ἐγω μοι δοκῶ ἐν τῷ παρόντι τοσοῦτον μόνον
							ἐκείνων διοίσειν· οὐ γὰρ ὅπως τοῖς παροῦσιν ἃ ἐγὼ λέγω δόξει ἀληθῆ
							προθυμηθήσομαι·

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_γυνὴ_1078"> for a woman: though, as it is, her “proud spirit” only reaches the point of being sensitive as to a lowly origin. She is proud of her lineage; Oedipus, of what he is. Whitelaw well compares Tennyson: “Her pride is yet no mate for mine, Too proud to care from whence I came.” Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Heraclid. 978">Eur. Heraclid. 978</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ταῦτα τὴν θρασεῖαν ὅστις ἂν θέλῃ | καὶ τὴν φρονοῦσαν μεῖζον ἢ γυναῖκα χρὴ | λέξει</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 640">Eur. Hipp. 640</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ γὰρ ἔν γ’ ἐμοῖς δόμοις | εἴη φρονοῦσα πλεῖον ἢ γυναῖκα χρή.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

							τὴν
									φρονοῦσαν μεῖζον ἢ γυναῖκα χρὴ | λέξει

μὴ γὰρ ἔν γ’ ἐμοῖς δόμοις | εἴη φρονοῦσα
							πλεῖον ἢ
									γυναῖκα χρή.

Icilius) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς Ῥωμαῖος, εἰπεῖν οὐκ ἀδύνατος.</foreign> See on 763. </gloss>
