ἦν δὲ οὐδὲ ἀδύνατος, ὡς Λακεδαιμόνιος,
									εἰπεῖν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_διδούσης_1081"> the beneficent: here absol., usu. with dat., as <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">σφῷν δ’ εὖ διδοίη Ζεύς,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1435">Soph. OC 1435</bibl> </cit>. Not gen. abs., “while she prospers me, ” since the poet. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_1081"> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτῆς</foreign> could stand only at the beginning of a sentence or clause, as 1082. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συγγενεῖς_1082"> as being also sons of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Τύχη</foreign>: the word further expresses that their lapse is the measure of his life: cp. 963: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλκᾷ ξύμφυτος αἰών</foreign> (<ref n="Aesch. Ag. 107">Aesch. Ag. 107</ref>), years with which bodily strength keeps pace. <cit> <bibl n="Pind. N. 5">Pind. N. 5.40</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πότμος συγγενής,</quote> </cit> the destiny born with one. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διώρισαν_1083"> not: “<emph>have determined that I should be</emph> sometimes lowly, sometimes great”; to do this was the part of controlling <foreign xml:lang="grc">Τύχη.</foreign> Rather: “have <emph>distinguished me as</emph> lowly or great”: i.e., his life has had chapters of adversity alternating with chapters of prosperity; and the months have marked these off (cp. 723). The metaphor of the months as sympathetic brothers is partly merged in the view of them as divisions of time: see on 866, 1300. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκφὺς_1084">, whereas <foreign xml:lang="grc">φύς</foreign> would be merely ”having been born such “) I will never afterwards prove (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξέλθοιμι_1084"> ,<foreign xml:lang="lat">evadam</foreign>, cp. 1011) another man ” (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλος_1084">, i.e. false to my own nature). The text is sound. The license of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποτ_1084"> at the beginning of 1085 is to be explained on essentially the same principle as <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέλας δ’ |,</foreign> etc. (29, cp. 785, 791) at the end of a verse; viz. that, where the movement of the thought is rapid, one verse can be treated as virtually continuous with the next: hence, too, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 986">Soph. Aj. 986</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐχ ὅσον τάχος | δῆτ’ αὐτὸν ἄξεις δεῦρο</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 66">Soph. Phil. 66</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δ’ ἐργάσει | μὴ ταῦτα.</quote> </cit> So here Soph. has allowed himself to retain </gloss>

data.quote: οὐχ ὅσον τάχος | δῆτ’ αὐτὸν ἄξεις δεῦρο

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔτι_ποτέ_1084"> in their natural connexion instead of writing <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔτι | ἄλλος ποτ’.</foreign> The genuineness of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποτ’</foreign> is confirmed by the numerous instances in which Soph. has combined it with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔτι,</foreign> as above, 892, below, 1412: <ref n="Soph. Aj. 98">Soph. Aj. 98</ref>, 687: <ref n="Soph. Trach. 830">Soph. Trach. 830</ref>, 922. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μάντις_1086"> as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 472">Soph. El. 472</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ γὼ παράφρων μάντις ἔφυν καὶ γνώμας | λειπομένα σοφᾶς</quote> </cit>: cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1080">Soph. OC 1080</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 1160">Soph. Ant. 1160</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Aj. 1419">Soph. Aj. 1419</ref>: and <foreign xml:lang="grc">μαντεύομαι</foreign> = “to presage. ” </gloss>

data.quote:
εἰ μὴ γὼ παράφρων μάντις ἔφυν καὶ γνώμας |
							λειπομένα σοφᾶς

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατὰ_1087"> with an accus. of respect is somewhat rare (<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 102">Soph. Trach. 102</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρατιστεύων κατ’ ὄμμα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 379">Soph. Trach. 379</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ κάρτα λαμπρὰ καὶ κατ’ ὄμμα καὶ φύσιν),</quote> </cit> except in such phrases as <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατὰ πάντα, κατ’ οὐδέν, κατὰ τοῦτο.</foreign> Cp. Metrical Analysis. </gloss>

data.quote: ἦ κάρτα λαμπρὰ καὶ κατ’ ὄμμα καὶ φύσιν),

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_1088"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ μὰ</foreign>: see on 660. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπείρων_1088"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄπειρος</foreign>:<cit> <bibl>Hesych. 1.433</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀπείρονας· ἀπειράτους. Σοφοκλῆς Θυέστῃ.</quote> </cit> Ellendt thinks that <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπειράτους</foreign> here meant <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπεράντους</foreign> ( “limitless ”): but elsewhere <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπείρατος</foreign> always = “untried” or “inexperienced.” Conversely Soph. used <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄπειρος</foreign> in the commoner sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπείρων,</foreign> “vast, ” fr. 481 <foreign xml:lang="grc">χιτὼν ἄπειρος ἐνδυτήριος κακῶν. περά‐ω,</foreign> to go through, <foreign xml:lang="grc">πεῖρα (περίἀ,</foreign> a going-through (<foreign xml:lang="lat">peritus, periculum</foreign>), are closely akin to <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέρα,</foreign> beyond, <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέρας, πεῖραρ</foreign> a limit (<ref>Curt. Etym. 356-357</ref>): in poetical usage, then, their derivatives might easily pass into each other's meanings. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰν_πανσέληνον_1090"> “the full-moon of to-morrow, ” acc. of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ αὔριον πανσέληνος</foreign> (there is no adj. <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὔριος),</foreign> as <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 784">Eur. Alc. 784</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν αὔριον μέλλουσαν,</quote> </cit> acc. of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ αὔριον μέλλουσα,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 1117">Eur. Hipp. 1117</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν αὔριον χρόνον.</quote> </cit> At Athens the great Dionysia were immediately followed by the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Πάνδι—α,</foreign> a festival held at full-moon in the middle of the month Elaphebolion (at the beginning of April): cp. A. Mommsen <title>Heortol.</title> p. 389, and C. F. Hermann <title>Ant.</title> 2.59. Wolff remarks that, if this play was produced on the last day of the Dionysia, the poet would have known that arrangement long beforehand, and may have intended an allusion to the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Πάνδια</foreign> which his Athenian hearers would quickly seize. This would explain why precisely “to-morrow's fullmoon ” is named. —Nauck reads </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὖρι_1090">(as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταχέως,</foreign> “the coming ” full-moon): Wecklein, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦρι_1090">(dat. of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦῤ,</foreign> “the vernal full-moon ” —that, namely, in Elaphebolion. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πανσέληνον_1090"> (sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὥραν)</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 2.47">Hdt. 2.47</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τῇ αὐτῇ πανσελήνῳ.</quote> </cit> For the accus., cp. on 1138 <foreign xml:lang="grc">χειμῶνα.</foreign> The meaning is: “At the next full-moon we will hold a joyous <foreign xml:lang="grc">παννυχίς,</foreign> visiting the temples with <foreign xml:lang="grc">χοροί</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. Ant. 153">Soph. Ant. 153</ref>), in honour of the discovery that Oedipus is of Theban birth; and thou, Cithaeron, shalt be a theme of our song. ” Cp. <ref n="Eur. Ion 1078">Eur. Ion 1078</ref>, where, in sympathy with the nocturnal worship of the gods, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀστερωπὸς | ἀνεχόρευσεν αἰθήρ, | χορεύει δὲ Σελάνα.</foreign> The rites of the Theban Dionysus were <foreign xml:lang="grc">νύκτωρ τὰ πολλά</foreign> (<ref n="Eur. Ba. 486">Eur. Ba. 486</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατριώταν_1091"> since Cithaeron partly belongs to Boeotia; so Plutarch of Chaeroneia calls the Theban Dionysus his <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">πατριώτην θεόν,</quote> <bibl>Plut. Mor. 671c</bibl> </cit>. —I read </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Οἰδίπουν_1091"> instead of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Οἰδίπου_1091">. With the genitive, the subject to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὔξειν_1091"> must be either (1) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡμᾶς</foreign> understood, which is impossibly harsh; or (2) <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰν … πανσέληνον.</foreign> Such a phrase as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ πανσέληνος αὔξει σε,</foreign> i.e., “sees thee honoured,” is possible; cp. 438 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἥδ’ ἡμέρα φύσει σε καὶ διαφθερεῖ</foreign>: but it is somewhat forced; and the order of the words is against it. The addition of one letter, giving </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Οἰδίπουν_1091_2">, at once yields a clear construction and a pointed sense. “Thou shalt not fail to know that <emph>Oedipus</emph> honours thee both as native to him, and as his nurse and mother (i.e., not merely as belonging to his Theban fatherland, but as the very spot which sheltered his infancy); and that thou art celebrated in choral song by <emph>us</emph> (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_1091"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡμῶν),</foreign> seeing that thou art well-pleasing to <emph>him</emph>.”</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_οὐ_1091"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὔξειν_1091_2">, because <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἀπείρων ἔσει</foreign> = a verb of hindrance or denial with a negative. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αὔξειν_1091_3">, not merely by praises, but by the fact of his birth in the neighbourhood: as Pindar says of a victor in the games, <cit> <bibl n="Pind. O. 5">Pind. O. 5.4</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰν σὰν πόλιν αὔξων,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 8">Pind. P. 8.38</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὔξων πάτραν.</quote> </cit> The acc. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέροντα_1091">, instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">φέρων,</foreign> may be explained by supposing that <foreign xml:lang="grc">σέ γε</foreign> is carried on as subject to <foreign xml:lang="grc">χορεύεσθαι</foreign>: cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 706">Soph. Trach. 706</ref> n. Another defence of the acc. would be to take <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ χορ. πρὸς ἡμῶν</foreign> as a parenthesis (cp. <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1279">Soph. Ant. 1279</ref> n.): so Tyrrell in <title>Class. Rev.</title> 2.141. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τροφὸν_1092"> as having sheltered him when exposed: <foreign xml:lang="grc">τί μ’ ἐδέχου;</foreign> 1391. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ματέρ_1092">, as the place from which his life rose anew, though it had been destined to be his <foreign xml:lang="grc">τάφος,</foreign> 1452. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χορεύεσθαι_1094"> to be celebrated with choral song: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1153">Soph. Ant. 1153</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάννυχοι | χορεύουσι τὸν ταμίαν Ἴακχον.</quote> </cit> (Not “danced over, ” like <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀείδετο τέμενος,</quote> <bibl n="Pind. O. 11">Pind. O. 11.76</bibl> </cit> .) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπὶ_φέροντα_1095"> see Merry's note on <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 3.164">Hom. Od. 3.164</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὖτις ἐπ’ Ἀτρείδῃ Ἀγαμέμνονι ἦρα φέροντες</quote> </cit> .</gloss>

data.quote: αὖτις ἐπ’ Ἀτρείδῃ Ἀγαμέμνονι ἦρα φέροντες

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦρα_1095"> was probably acc. sing. from a nom. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦρ,</foreign> from root <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρ</foreign> (to fit), as = “pleasant service. ” After the phrase <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦρα φέρειν</foreign> had arisen, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ</foreign> was joined adverbially with <foreign xml:lang="grc">φέρειν, ἐπὶ ἦρα φέρειν</foreign> being equivalent to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦρα ἐπιφέρειν.</foreign> Aristarchus, who according to Herodian first wrote <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπίηρα</foreign>, must have supposed an impossible tmesis of a compound adj. in the passage of the <title>Od.</title> just quoted, also in <ref n="Hom. Od. 16.375">Hom. Od. 16.375</ref>,<ref n="Hom. Od. 18.56">Hom. Od. 18.56</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖς_τυρ_1095"> i.e. to Oedipus: for the plur., see on <foreign xml:lang="grc">θανάτων,</foreign> 497. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰήϊε_1096"> esp. as the Healer: see on 154. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σοὶ_δὲ_1097"> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 150">Soph. El. 150</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Νιόβα, σὲ δ’ ἔγωγε νέμω θεόν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: Νιόβα, σὲ δ’ ἔγωγε νέμω θεόν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρέστ_1097"> i.e. consistent with those oracles which still await a <foreign xml:lang="grc">λύσις εὐαγής</foreign> (921). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔτικτε_1098"> see on 870. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τᾶν_μακραιώνων_1099"> here not goddesses (<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 524">Aesch. Seven 524</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δαροβίοισι θεοῖσιν</quote> </cit>), but the Nymphs, who, though not immortal, live beyond the human span; <cit> <bibl n="HH 4.260">HH 4.260</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἵ ῥ’ οὔτε θνητοῖς οὔτ’ ἀθανάτοισιν ἕπονται· | δηρὸν μὲν ζώουσι καὶ ἄμβροτον εἶδαρ ἔδουσιν.</quote> </cit> They consort with Pan, <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅς τ’ ἀνὰ πίση | δενδρήεντ’ ἄμυδις φοιτᾷ χοροήθεσι Νύμφαις,</quote> <bibl n="HH 19">HH 19.2</bibl> </cit>. </gloss>

data.quote:
αἵ ῥ’ οὔτε θνητοῖς οὔτ’ ἀθανάτοισιν ἕπονται· |
							δηρὸν μὲν ζώουσι καὶ ἄμβροτον εἶδαρ ἔδουσιν.

ὅς τ’ ἀνὰ πίση | δενδρήεντ’ ἄμυδις φοιτᾷ
							χοροήθεσι
									Νύμφαις,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Πανὸς_προσπελασθεῖσ_1100">, the reading of the MSS., we note (1) the loss after <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀρεσσιβάτα</foreign> of one syllable, answering to the last of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπείρων</foreign> in 1087: (2) the somewhat weak compound <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσπελασθεῖσ’</foreign>: (3) the gen., where, for this sense, the dat. is more usual, as <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 896">Aesch. PB 896</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲ πλαθείην γαμετῇ.</quote> </cit> L has <foreign xml:lang="grc">κοίτῃ</foreign> written over <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀρεσσιβάτα.</foreign> I had thought of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέκτροις_πελασθεῖσ_1100">. But the gen. is quite admissible: and on other grounds Lachmann's </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατρὸς_πελασθεῖσ_1100"> is far better, since <foreign xml:lang="grc">πατρὸς</foreign>, written <foreign xml:lang="grc">προς</foreign> (with line superscribed), would explain the whole corruption. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_αὔριον_1101">, it is best to read here with Arndt. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_τις_1101">. On the view that in 1090 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰν ἐπιοῦσαν ἔσει</foreign> was a probable emendation (see Appendix on that verse), I proposed to read here, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἢ σέ γ’ ἔφυσε πατὴρ | Λοξίας;</foreign> If the <foreign xml:lang="grc">σε</foreign> of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔφυσε</foreign> had once been lost (through a confusion with the preceding <foreign xml:lang="grc">σἔ, ΓΕΦΥΠΑΤΗΡ</foreign> might easily have become <foreign xml:lang="grc">ΓΕΘΥΓΑΤΗΡ</foreign>: the <foreign xml:lang="grc">τις</foreign> (which is not in L) would have been inserted for metre's sake, and the change of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Λοξίας</foreign> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">Λοξίου</foreign> would have followed. (It cannot be objected that a mention of the mother is required here, since, as the context shows, the foremost thought is, “what god was thy sire? ”) It would be a very forced way of taking <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἢ σέ γέ τις θυγάτηρ</foreign> to make <foreign xml:lang="grc">θυγάτηρ</foreign> depend on <foreign xml:lang="grc"> μακραιώνων,</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">Λοξίου</foreign> on <foreign xml:lang="grc">πελασθεῖσ’</foreign> (i.e., “some daughter of the Nymphs wedded to Pan, or haply to Loxias ”). Nor does it seem easy to take <foreign xml:lang="grc">θυγάτηρ</foreign> with <foreign xml:lang="grc">τᾶν μακραιώνων</foreign> in both clauses ( “some daughter of the Nymphs, wedded to Pan, or perhaps to Loxias ”). On the whole, I now prefer Arndt's correction. -For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σέ_γε_1101"> in the second alternative, cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1116">Soph. Phil. 1116</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πότμος σε δαιμόνων τάδ’, | οὐδὲ σέ γε δόλος ἔσχεν.</quote> </cit> <ref n="Hdt. 7.10">Hdt. 7.10</ref> (ad fin.) <foreign xml:lang="grc">διαφορεύμενον ἤ κου ἐν γῇ τῇ Ἀθηναίων ἢ σέ γε ἐν τῇ Λακεδαιμονίων.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
πότμος σε δαιμόνων τάδ’, | οὐδὲ σέ γε δόλος
							ἔσχεν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλάκες_ἀγρόνομοι_1103"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">πλ. ἀγροῦ νεμομένου,</foreign> highlands affording open pasturage: so <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀγρον. αὐλαῖς,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 785">Soph. Ant. 785</bibl> </cit>. Apollo as a pastoral god had the title of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Νόμιος</foreign> (Theocr. 25. 21), which was esp. connected with the legend of his serving as shephered to Laomedon on Ida (<ref n="Hom. Il. 21.448">Hom. Il. 21.448</ref>) and to Admetus in Thessaly (<ref n="Hom. Il. 2.766">Hom. Il. 2.766</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 572">Eur. Alc. 572</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηλονόμας).</quote> </cit> Macrobius 1.17.43 (Apollinis) <foreign xml:lang="lat">aedes ut ovium pastoris sunt apud Camirenses</foreign> [in Rhodes] <foreign xml:lang="lat"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιμηλίου</foreign>, apud Naxios <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποιμνίου,</foreign> itemque deus <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρνοκόμης</foreign> colitur, et apud Lesbios <foreign xml:lang="grc">ναπαῖος</foreign> </foreign> [cp. above, 1026], <foreign xml:lang="lat">et multa sunt cognomina per diversas civitates ad dei pastoris officium tendentia.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Call. Ap. 47">Callim. Apoll. 47</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδέ κεν αἶγες | δεύοιντο βρεφέων ἐπιμηλίδες, ᾗσιν Ἀπόλλων | βοσκομένῃς ὀφθαλμὸν ἐπήγαγεν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐδέ κεν αἶγες | δεύοιντο βρεφέων ἐπιμηλίδες,
							ᾗσιν
									Ἀπόλλων | βοσκομένῃς ὀφθαλμὸν ἐπήγαγεν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_ἀνάσσων_1104"> Hermes: <cit> <bibl n="HH 3.1">HH 3.1</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἑρμῆν ὕμνει, Μοῦσα, Διὸς καὶ Μαιάδος υἱόν, | Κυλλήνης μεδέοντα καὶ Ἀρκαδίης πολυμήλου</quote> </cit> :<ref n="Verg. A. 8.138">Verg. Aen. 8.138</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">quem candida Maia | Cyllenes gelido conceptum vertice fudit.</foreign> The peak of Cyllene (now <emph>Ziria</emph>), about 7300 ft. high, in N. E. Arcadia, is visible from the Boeotian plain near Leuctra, where Cithaeron is on the south and Helicon to the west, with a glimpse of Parnassus behind it: see my <title>Modern Greece</title>, p. 77. </gloss>

data.quote:
Ἑρμῆν ὕμνει, Μοῦσα, Διὸς καὶ Μαιάδος υἱόν, |
							Κυλλήνης μεδέοντα καὶ Ἀρκαδίης πολυμήλου

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_θεὸς_1105"> not “the god <foreign xml:lang="grc">Βάκχος</foreign>” (though in <ref n="Soph. OC 1494">Soph. OC 1494</ref> the MSS. give <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ποσειδαωνίῳ θεῷ</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc"> Ποσειδῶνἰ,</foreign> but “the god of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Βάκχοι, ”</foreign> the god of Bacchic frenzy; <cit> <bibl n="HH 19">HH 19.46</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ Βάκχειος Διόνυσος</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 678">Soph. OC 678</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ Βακχιώτας … Διόνυσος.</quote> </cit> Some would always write <foreign xml:lang="grc">Βάκχειος</foreign> (like <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ὁμήρειος, Αἰάντειος,</foreign> etc.): on the other hand, <foreign xml:lang="grc">Βακχεῖος</foreign> is said to have been Attic (cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">Καδμεῖος)</foreign>: see Chandler, <title>Greek Accentuation</title>, §381, 2nd ed. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὕρημα_1107"> expresses the sudden delight of the god when he receives the babe from the mother, —as Hermes receives his new-born son Pan from the <foreign xml:lang="grc">Νύμφη ἐϋπλόκαμος,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="HH 19">HH 19.40</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν δ’ αἶψ’ Ἑρμείης ἐριούνιος ἐς χέρα θῆκεν | δεξάμενος· χαῖρεν δὲ νόῳ περιώσια δαίμων.</quote> </cit> The word commonly = a lucky “find, ” like <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἕρμαιον,</foreign> or a happy thought. In <ref n="Eur. Ion 1349">Eur. Ion 1349</ref> it is not “<emph>a foundling, </emph>” but the box containing <foreign xml:lang="grc">σπάργανα</foreign> found by Ion. </gloss>

data.quote:
τὸν δ’ αἶψ’ Ἑρμείης ἐριούνιος ἐς χέρα θῆκεν |
							δεξάμενος· χαῖρεν δὲ νόῳ περιώσια δαίμων.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συμπαίζει_1109"> Anacreon fr. 2 (Bergk p. 775) to Dionysus: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὦναξ, ᾧ δαμάλης</foreign> (subduing) <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἔρως | καὶ Νύμφαι κυανώπιδες | πορφυρέη τ’ Ἀφροδίτη | συμπαίζουσιν· ἐπιστρέφεαι δ’ | ὑψηλῶν κορυφὰς ὀρέων. Ἑλικωνίδων</foreign> is Porson's correction of <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἑλικωνιάδων</foreign> (MSS.), ad <ref n="Eur. Orest. 614">Eur. Orest. 614</ref>. Since </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἶς_1109"> answers to <foreign xml:lang="grc">δέ</foreign> in 1097, Nauck conjectured <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἑλικῶνος αἶσι.</foreign> But this is unnecessary, as the metrical place allows this syllable to be either short or long: so in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 486">Soph. El. 486</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰσχίσταις</quote> </cit> answers to 502 <foreign xml:lang="grc">νυκτὸς εὖ.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀμὲ_1110"> as well as you, who perhaps know better (1115). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_πω_1110"> though I have never come into intercourse with him, have never met him: see on 34, and cp. 1130. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_γήρᾳ_1112"> :<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν</foreign> describes the condition <emph>in</emph> which he is, as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 185">Soph. Phil. 185</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔν τ’ ὀδύναις ὁμοῦ | λιμῷ τ’ οἰκτρός</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1017">Soph. Aj. 1017</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν γήρᾳ βαρύς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἔν τ’ ὀδύναις ὁμοῦ | λιμῷ τ’ οἰκτρός

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξυνᾴδει_1113"> with<foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷδε τἀνδρὶ· σύμμετρος</foreign> merely strengthens and defines it: he agrees with this man in the tale of his years. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλως_τε_1114"> and moreover: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 8.142">Hdt. 8.142</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλλως τε τούτων ἁπάντων αἰτίους γενέσθαι δουλοσύνης τοῖσι Ἕλλησι Ἀθηναίους οὐδαμῶς ἀνασχετόν</quote> </cit> ( “and <emph>besides</emph>,” introducing an additional argument). Soph. has <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄλλως τε καί</foreign> = “especially,” <ref n="Soph. El. 1324">Soph. El. 1324</ref>. “I know them as servants” would be <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔγνωκα ὄντας οἰκέτας.</foreign> The </gloss>

data.quote:
ἄλλως τε τούτων ἁπάντων αἰτίους γενέσθαι
							δουλοσύνης τοῖσι Ἕλλησι Ἀθηναίους οὐδαμῶς ἀνασχετόν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥσπερ_1114"> can be explained only by an ellipse: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὥσπερ ἂν γνοίην οἰκέτας ἐμαυτοῦ</foreign> (cp. 923). Here it merely serves to mark <emph>his first impression</emph> as they come in sight: “I know those who bring him as (<emph>methinks</emph>) servants of mine own. ” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γάρ_1117"> in assent ( “you are right, <emph>for</emph>,” etc.), 731: <ref n="Soph. Phil. 756">Soph. Phil. 756</ref>:<ref n="Soph. Ant. 639">Soph. Ant. 639</ref>, etc. —</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Λαΐου_νομεὺς_1117">: a comma at </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦν_1117"> is admissible (cp. 1122), but would not strictly represent the construction here, in which the idea <foreign xml:lang="grc">—Λαΐου ἦν πιστὸς νομεύς, εἴπερ τις ἄλλος</foreign> —has been modified by the restrictive </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_1117"> before <foreign xml:lang="grc">νομεύς.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_1117_2"> only means that the sense in which a <foreign xml:lang="grc">νομεύς</foreign> can show <foreign xml:lang="grc">πίστις</foreign> is narrowly limited by the sphere of his work. See on 763: cp. 1078. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ξένον_1119"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σὲ_1119">, instead of a vocative, gives a peremptory tone: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 441">Soph. Ant. 441</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὲ δή, σὲ τὴν νεύουσαν εἰς πέδον κάρα, | φὴς ἢ καταρνεῖ κ.τ.λ.,</quote> </cit> where the equivalent of </gloss>

data.quote:
σὲ δή, σὲ τὴν νεύουσαν εἰς πέδον κάρα, | φὴς ἢ
							καταρνεῖ κ.τ.λ.,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐρωτῶ_1119"> here is understood. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 71">Soph. Aj. 71</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὗτος, σὲ τὸν τὰς κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> So in the nomin. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 4.5.22">Xen. Cyrop. 4.5.22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ δ’, ἔφη, ὁ τῶν Ὑρκανίων ἄρχων, ὑπόμεινον.</quote> </cit> Blaydes thinks that <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷ Κορινθίῳ ξένῳ</foreign> in <ref n="Aristoph. Thes. 404">Aristoph. Thes. 404</ref> comes hence. Surely rather from the <title>Sthenoboea</title> of Eur. ap. <cit> <bibl>Athen. 427e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πεσὸν δὲ νιν λέληθεν οὐδὲν ἐκ χερός, | ἀλλ’ εὐθὺς αὐδᾷ, τῷ Κορινθίῳ ξένῳ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
σὺ δ’, ἔφη, ὁ τῶν Ὑρκανίων ἄρχων,
									ὑπόμεινον.

πεσὸν δὲ νιν λέληθεν οὐδὲν ἐκ χερός, | ἀλλ’
							εὐθὺς
									αὐδᾷ, τῷ Κορινθίῳ ξένῳ.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_1123"> the old Attic form of the 1st pers., from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔα</foreign> (<ref n="Hom. Il. 4.321">Hom. Il. 4.321</ref>,<ref n="Hdt. 2.19">Hdt. 2.19</ref>): so the best MSS. in <ref n="Plat. Phaedo 61b">Plat. Phaedo 61b</ref>, etc. That Soph. used <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦ</foreign> here and in the <title>Niobe</title> (fr. 409) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦ γὰρ φίλη γὼ τῶνδε τοῦ προφερτέρου,</foreign> is stated by the schol. on <ref n="Hom. Il. 5.533">Hom. Il. 5.533</ref> and on <ref n="Hom. Od. 8.186">Hom. Od. 8.186</ref>. L has <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦν</foreign> here and always, except in <ref n="Soph. OC 973">Soph. OC 973</ref>, 1366, where it gives </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_1123_2">. In <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Tro. 474">Eur. Tro. 474</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ μὲν τύραννος κεἰς τύρανν’ ἐγημάμην</quote> </cit> is Elmsley's corr. of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦμεν τύραννοι κ.τ.λ.</foreign> On the other hand Eur., at least, has <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦν</foreign> in several places where <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἦ</foreign> is impossible: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 1012">Eur. Hipp. 1012</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μάταιος ἆρ’ ἦν, οὐδαμοῦ μὲν οὖν φρενῶν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 1416">Eur. Her. 1416</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐς τὸ λῆμα παντὸς ἦν ἥσσων ἀνήρ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 655">Eur. Alc. 655</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παῖς δ’ ἦν ἐγώ σοι τῶνδε διάδοχος δόμων</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ion 280">Eur. Ion 280</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βρέφος νεογνὸν μητρὸς ἦν ἐν ἀγκάλαις. —</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἦ μὲν τύραννος κεἰς τύρανν’ ἐγημάμην
μάταιος ἆρ’ ἦν, οὐδαμοῦ μὲν οὖν φρενῶν
ὡς ἐς τὸ λῆμα παντὸς ἦν ἥσσων ἀνήρ
παῖς δ’ ἦν ἐγώ σοι τῶνδε διάδοχος δόμων
βρέφος νεογνὸν μητρὸς ἦν ἐν ἀγκάλαις. —

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἴκοι_τραφείς_1123">, and so more in the confidence of the master: cp. schol. <ref n="Aristoph. Kn. 2">Aristoph. Kn. 2</ref> (on <foreign xml:lang="grc">Παφλάγονα τὸν νεώνητον), πεφύκαμεν γὰρ καὶ τῶν οἰκετῶν μᾶλλον πιστεύειν τοῖς οἴκοι γεννηθεῖσι καὶ τραφεῖσιν ἢ οις ἃν κτησώμεθα πριάμενοι.</foreign> Such <foreign xml:lang="lat">vernae</foreign> were called <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἰκογενεῖς</foreign> (<ref n="Plat. Meno 82b">Plat. Meno 82b</ref>:<cit> <bibl>Dio Chrys. 15.25</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς παρὰ σφίσι γεννηθέντας οὓς οἰκογενεῖς καλοῦσἰ, οἰκοτραφεῖς</quote> </cit> (<ref>Pollux 3.78</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐνδογενεῖς</foreign> (oft. in inscriptions, as <title>C. I. G.</title> 1.828), or <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰκότριβες</quote> <bibl n="Dem. 13.24">Dem. 13.24</bibl> </cit> ,<ref>Hesych. 2.766</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote:
τοὺς παρὰ σφίσι γεννηθέντας οὓς οἰκογενεῖς
							καλοῦσἰ, οἰκοτραφεῖς

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μεριμνῶν_1124"> In classical Greek <foreign xml:lang="grc">μεριμνᾶν</foreign> is usu. “to give one's thought to a question ” (as of philosophy, <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 4.7.6">Xen. Mem. 4.7.6</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ταῦτα μεριμνῶντἀ;</quote> </cit> here merely = “to be occupied with ”: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 8.7.12">Xen. Cyrop. 8.7.12</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ πολλὰ μεριμνᾶν</quote> </cit>: and so in the 1 Cor. 7.33 <foreign xml:lang="grc">μεριμνᾷ τὰ τοῦ κόσμου.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξύναυλος_1126"> prop. “dwelling with ” (<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">μανίᾳ ξύναυλος</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 611">Soph. Aj. 611</bibl> </cit>): here, after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_1126">, merely: “having thy haunts ”: an instance of that redundant government which Soph. often admits: below 1205 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν πόνοις | ξύνοικος</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 464">Soph. Aj. 464</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γυμνὸν … τῶν ἀριστείων ἄτερ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 31">Soph. Phil. 31</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κενὴν οἴκησιν ἀνθρώπων δίχα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 919">Soph. Ant. 919</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρημος πρὸς φίλων</quote> </cit>: 445 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔξω βαρείας αἰτίας ἐλεύθερον.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦν_μὲν_1127"> as if replying to <foreign xml:lang="grc">χῶροι τίνες ἦσαν πρὸς οἷς ξυν. ἦσθα;</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶσθα_1128"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μαθών_1128">, are you aware of having observed this man here? Cp. 1142 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶσθα … δούς;</foreign> We could not render, “do you <emph> know</emph> this man, through having observed him?” <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰδέναι,</foreign> implying intuitive apprehension, is said of knowing facts and propositions: in regard to persons, it is not used in the mere sense of “being acquainted with one” <foreign xml:lang="grc">(γνωρίζὠ,</foreign> but only in that of “knowing one's character, ” as <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 39">Eur. Med. 39</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγᾦδα τήνδε.</quote> </cit> So <foreign xml:lang="lat">scire</foreign>,<foreign xml:lang="deu">wissen</foreign> ,<foreign xml:lang="fra">savoir</foreign>, Ital. <foreign xml:lang="ita"> sapere</foreign>. On the other hand, <foreign xml:lang="grc">γιγνώσκω,</foreign> implying a process of examination, applies to all mediate knowledge, through the senses, of external objects: so <foreign xml:lang="lat">noscere</foreign>,<foreign xml:lang="deu">kennen</foreign>,<foreign xml:lang="fra">connaître</foreign>, Ital. <foreign xml:lang="ita">conoscere</foreign>. Cp. Cope in <title>Fourn. of Philology</title> 1.79. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_λέγεις_1129"> see on 772. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶσθα_ξυναλλάξας_1130"> Oed. takes no more notice of the herdsman's nervous interruption than is necessary for the purpose of sternly keeping him to the point. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ__1130"> “have you ever met him? ” mars the force of the passage. The testimony of L to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="συναλλάξας_1130"> has the more weight since this is the less obvious reading. Cp. verse 1037, which continues after an interruption the construction of verse 1035. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐχ_εἰπεῖν_1131"> cp. 361. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μνήμης_ὕπο_1131">, at the prompting of memory, <foreign xml:lang="grc">—ὑπό</foreign> having a like force as in compound verbs meaning to “suggest, ” etc.: <cit> <bibl n="Plut. Praecepta 813e">Plut. Mor. 813e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λογισμοὺς οὓς ὁ Περικλῆς αὑτὸν ὑπεμίμνησκεν,</quote> </cit> recalled to his mind: so <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑποβολεύς</foreign> (ib.), “a prompter. ” The phrase is more poetical and elegant than </gloss>

data.quote:
λογισμοὺς οὓς ὁ Περικλῆς αὑτὸν
									ὑπεμίμνησκεν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μνήμης_ἄπο_1131">, the conjecture of Reiske. Blaydes, reading <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄπο,</foreign> compares <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπὸ τῆς γλώσσης</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. OC 936">Soph. OC 936</ref>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοὐδέν_γε_1132"> cp. <ref n="Soph. Phil. 38">Soph. Phil. 38</ref> n. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγνῶτ_1132"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ γιγνώσκοντα,</foreign> not recognising me: 677 n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦμος_1134"> in two other places of dialogue, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 531">Soph. Trach. 531</ref> (answered by <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῆμος)</foreign> and 155; also once in lyrics <ref n="Soph. Aj. 935">Soph. Aj. 935</ref>; Eur. once in lyrics (<ref n="Eur. Hec. 915">Eur. Hec. 915</ref>); Aesch. and Comedy, never. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_τόπον_1134"> The sentence begins as if it were meant to proceed thus: <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸν Κ. τόπον ὁ μὲν διπλοῖς ποιμνίοις ἔνεμεν, ἐγὼ δ’ ἑνὶ (ἔνεμον), πλησιάζων αὐτῷ</foreign>: but, the verb <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔνεμε</foreign> having been postponed, the participle <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλησιάζων</foreign> is irregularly combined with the notion of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔνεμον</foreign> and turned into a finite verb, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπλησίαζον_1134">: thus leaving <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸν Κ. τόπον</foreign> without any proper government. (In the above explanation, the act. voice of <foreign xml:lang="grc">νέμω</foreign> has been used, since this was specially said of shepherds: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 3.2.20">Xen. Cyrop. 3.2.20</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεὶ ὄρη ἀγαθὰ ἔχετε, ἐθέλοιτ’ ἂν ἐᾶν νέμειν ταῦτα τοὺς Ἀρμενίους;</quote> </cit> The midd. would also be correct, as = “to range over. ”) For the irregular but very common change of participle into finite verb cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 190">Soph. El. 190</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἰκονομῶ … ὧδε μὲν ἀεικεῖ σὺν στολᾷ | κεναῖς δ’ ἀμφίσταμαι τραπέζαις</quote> </cit> (instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀμφισταμένἠ</foreign>: so <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 810">Soph. Ant. 810</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(ὔμνος ὔμνησεν</quote> </cit> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὕμνῳ ὑμνηθεῖσαν)</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 676">Soph. Trach. 676</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠφάνισται, διάβορον πρὸς οὐδενὸς | τῶν ἔνδον, ἀλλ’ ἐδεστὸν ἐξ αὑτοῦ φθίνει.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 4.100">Thuc. 4.100</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προσέβαλον τῷ τειχίσματι, ἄλλῳ τε τρόπῳ πειράσαντες καὶ μηχανὴν προσήγαγον.</quote> </cit> Though we can have <foreign xml:lang="grc">δῶμα πελάζει</foreign> (<ref n="Eur. Andr. 1167">Eur. Andr. 1167</ref>), “is carried towards the house,” the dat.<foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷδε τἀνδρὶ</foreign> after </gloss>

data.quote:
οἰκονομῶ … ὧδε μὲν ἀεικεῖ σὺν στολᾷ | κεναῖς
									δ’ ἀμφίσταμαι τραπέζαις

ἠφάνισται, διάβορον πρὸς οὐδενὸς | τῶν ἔνδον,
							ἀλλ’
									ἐδεστὸν ἐξ αὑτοῦ φθίνει.

προσέβαλον τῷ τειχίσματι, ἄλλῳ τε τρόπῳ
							πειράσαντες καὶ μηχανὴν προσήγαγον.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπλησίαζον_1134_2"> here is proof in itself that the verb does not govern </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τόπον_1134">: further the sense required is not “approached,” but “occupied.” Brunck, taking <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷδε τἀνδρὶ</foreign> as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμοί,</foreign> was for changing <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπλησίαζον</foreign> to <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἑπλησίαζε</foreign>: which only adds the new complication of an irregular <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέν</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">δέ.</foreign> The text is probably sound. Heimsoeth's conjecture, </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νέμων_1134"> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ μέν,</foreign> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπλησίαζε_1134">, is attractive, but the parenthetic <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ δ’ ἑνί</foreign> is then very awkward. Nauck proposes <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν Κιθαιρῶνος νάπαις |</foreign> (this with Blaydes) <foreign xml:lang="grc">νομεὺς διπλοῖσι ποιμνίοις ἐπιστατῶν | ἐπλησίαζε</foreign>: but this is to re-write, not to correct. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξ_ἀρκτοῦρον_1137"> <emph> from</emph> March to September. In March the herd of Polybus drove his flock up to Cithaeron from Corinth, and met the herd of Laius, who had brought up his flock from the plain of Thebes. For six months they used to consort in the upland glens of Cithaeron; then, in September, when Arcturus began to be visible a little before dawn, they parted, taking their flocks for the winter into homesteads near Corinth and Thebes. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρκτοῦρον_1137"> (the star </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="α_1137"> of the constellation Bootes,) first so called in <ref n="Hes. WD 566">Hes. WD 566</ref> where (610) his appearance as a morning star is the signal for the vintage. <ref>Hippoc. Epidem. 1.2.4</ref>, has <foreign xml:lang="grc">περὶ ἀρκτοῦρον</foreign> as = “a little before the autumnal equinox ”: and <ref n="Thuc. 2.78">Thuc. 2.78</ref> uses <foreign xml:lang="grc">περὶ ἀρκτούρου ἐπιτολάς</foreign> to denote the same season. See Appendix. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑκμήνους_1137">. Plato (<ref n="Plat. Laws 916b">Plat. Laws 916b</ref>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐντὸς ἑκμήνου,</foreign> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc"> χρόνου</foreign>: the statement in Lidd. and Scott's Lexicon (t\h ed.) that it is <emph>feminine</emph> was due to a misunderstanding of the words <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλὴν τῆς ἱερᾶς</foreign> (sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">νόσοὐ</foreign> just afterwards. Aristotle also has this form. Cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἕκπλεθρος</foreign> (Eur.), <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἕκπους, ἕκπλευρος.</foreign> The form <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἑξμέδιμνον</foreign> in <ref n="Aristoph. Peace 631">Aristoph. Peace 631</ref> is an Atticism: cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἕξπουν</foreign> Plat. Comicus fr. 36, where Meineke quotes Philemon (a grammarian who wrote on the Attic dialect): <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἀττικῶς μὲν ἕξπουν καὶ ἕξκλινον λέγεται, ὥσπερ καὶ παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ ἑξπηχυστί</foreign>: adding Steph. Byz. 345 <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἕξγυιος, πόλις Σικελίας, γραφὴν Ἀττικὴν ἔχουσα.</foreign> Besides <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔκμηνος,</foreign> Aristotle uses the form <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἑξάμηνος</foreign> (which occurs in a perhaps interpolated place of <ref n="Xen. Hell. 2.3.9">Xen. Hell. 2.3.9</ref>); as he has also <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἑξάπους.</foreign> The Attic dialect similarly preferred <foreign xml:lang="grc">πεντέπους</foreign> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">πεντάπους, ὀκτώπους</foreign> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀκτάπους,</foreign> but always said <foreign xml:lang="grc">πενταπλοῦς, ἑξαπλοῦς, ὀκταπλοῦς.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χειμῶνα_1138"> without notice of a variant, while some other MSS. notice it as a variant on their </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χειμῶνι_1138">, is in favour of the accus., the harder reading. It may be rendered “<emph> for</emph> the winter,” since it involves the notion of the time <emph> during</emph> which the flock was to remain in the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔπαυλα.</foreign> It is, however, one of those temporal accusatives which are almost adverbial, the idea of duration being merged in that of season, so that they can even be used concurrently with a temporal genitive: <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 3.117">Hdt. 3.117</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν μὲν γὰρ χειμῶνα ὕει σφι ὁ θεός … τοῦ δὲ θέρεος σπείροντες … χρηΐσκοντο τῷ ὕδατι.</quote> </cit> 2.95 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῆς μὲν ἡμέρης ἰχθῦς ἀγρεύει, τὴν δὲ νύκτα τάδε αὐτῷ χρᾶται.</foreign> 2.2 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν ὥρην ἐπαγινέειν σφι αἶγας,</foreign> “at the due season.” 7.151 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸν αὐτὸν τοῦτον χρόνον πέμψαντας … ἀγγέλους.</foreign> Cp. above, 1090 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰν αὔριον πανσέληνον.</foreign> The tendency to such a use of the accus. may have been an old trait of the popular language (cp. <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀωρίαν ἥκοντες</quote> <bibl n="Aristoph. Ach. 23">Aristoph. Ach. 23</bibl> </cit> ,<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">καιρὸν ἐφήκεις</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 34">Soph. Aj. 34</bibl> </cit>). Modern Greek regularly uses the accus. for the old temporal dat.: e. g. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν τρίτην ἡμέραν</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῇ τρίτῃ ἡμέρᾳ.</foreign> Classical prose would here use the genit.: <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.30">Thuc. 1.30</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χειμῶνος ἤδη ἀνεχώρησαν.</quote> </cit> The division of the year implied is into <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔαρ, θέρος</foreign> (including <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀπώρα,</foreign>) and <foreign xml:lang="grc">χειμών</foreign> (including <foreign xml:lang="grc">φθινόπωρον).</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
τὸν μὲν γὰρ χειμῶνα ὕει σφι ὁ θεός … τοῦ δὲ
							θέρεος σπείροντες … χρηΐσκοντο τῷ ὕδατι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πεπραγμένον_1140"> predicate: = re/rpaktai/ ti tou/twn a(\ le/gw; </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_1141"> properly “at the interval of ”; cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 1.10.11">Xen. Anab. 1.10.11</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκ πλέονος ἢ τὸ πρόσθεν ἔφευγον,</quote> </cit> at a greater distance: so <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκ τόξου ῥύματος,</foreign> at the interval of a bowshot, <ref n="Xen. Anab. 3.3.15">Xen. Anab. 3.3.15</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote: ἐκ πλέονος ἢ τὸ πρόσθεν ἔφευγον,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_ἔστι_1144"> = “what is the matter?” “what do you mean?” Cp. 319 (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_τί_1144"> cannot be connected as a relative clause with <foreign xml:lang="grc">τί δ’ ἔστι,</foreign> since <foreign xml:lang="grc">τίς</foreign> in classical Greek can replace <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅστις</foreign> only where there is an indirect question; e.g. <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰπὲ τί σοι φίλον.</foreign> Cp. <ref n="Soph. El. 316">Soph. El. 316</ref>:<ref n="Soph. Trach. 339">Soph. Trach. 339</ref>. Hellenistic Greek did not always observe this rule: Mark xiv. 36 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ τί ἐγὼ θέλω, ἀλλὰ τί σύ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦ_τᾶν_1145"> triumphantly, “my good friend. ” It is not meant to be a trait of <emph> rustic</emph> speech: in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1387">Soph. Phil. 1387</ref> Neoptolemus uses it to Philoctetes; in <ref n="Eur. Her. 321">Eur. Her. 321</ref> Iolaus to Demophon, and <ref n="Eur. Her. 688">Eur. Her. 688</ref> the <foreign xml:lang="grc"> θεράπων</foreign> to Iolaus; in <ref n="Eur. Ba. 802">Eur. Ba. 802</ref> Dionysus to Pentheus. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_ὄλεθρον_1146"> see on 430. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_ἔσει_1146"> = a fut. perfect,—<emph>at once</emph>, or <emph>once for all</emph>;<cit> <bibl n="Dem. 4.50">Dem. 4.50</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ δέοντα ἐσόμεθα ἐγνωκότες καὶ λόγων ματαίων ἀπηλλαγμένοι.</quote> </cit> So <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1067">Soph. Ant. 1067</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντιδοὺς ἔσει,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 816">Soph. OC 816</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λυπηθεὶς ἔσει.</quote> </cit> The situation shows that this is not an “aside. ” The <foreign xml:lang="grc">θεράπων,</foreign> while really terrified, could affect to resent the assertion that his master had been a foundling. </gloss>

data.quote:
τὰ δέοντα ἐσόμεθα ἐγνωκότες καὶ λόγων ματαίων
							ἀπηλλαγμένοι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κόλαζε_1147"> of <emph>words</emph>,<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1107">Soph. Aj. 1107</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ σέμν’ ἔπη | κόλαζ’ ἐκείνους.</quote> </cit> On the Harvard stage, the Theban at 1146 was about to <emph>strike</emph> the Corinthian (see sect. 9 of the first note in the Appendix). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦ_φέριστε_1149"> in tragedy only here and <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Seven 39">Aesch. Seven 39</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(Ἐτεόκλεες, φέριστε Καδμείων ἄναξ);</quote> </cit> ironical in <ref n="Plat. Phaedrus 238d">Plat. Phaedrus 238d</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_χάριν_1152"> so as to oblige: <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 8.1">Dem. 8.1</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μήτε πρὸς ἔχθραν ποιεῖσθαι λόγον μηδένα μήτε πρὸς χάριν</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 594">Soph. Phil. 594</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ἰσχύος κράτος,</quote> </cit> by main force. </gloss>

data.quote:
μήτε πρὸς ἔχθραν ποιεῖσθαι λόγον μηδένα μήτε
							πρὸς
									χάριν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κλαίων_1152"> see on 401. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύστηνος_1155"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγώ.</foreign> This agrees best with Soph.'s usage: see <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 377">Soph. Trach. 377</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ δύστηνας</quote> </cit> (n.): though the adj. could also refer to Oed. (cp. 1071). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_τόδ_1158"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰς τὸ ὀλέσθαι</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1365">Soph. Aj. 1365</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸς ἐνθάδ’ ἴξομαι,</quote> </cit> i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰς τὸ θάπτεσθαι.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐς_ἐλᾷ_1160"> will push (the matter) to delays (<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 577">Soph. Ant. 577</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ τριβὰς ἔτἰ,</quote> </cit> —is bent on protracting his delay: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐλαύνειν</foreign> as in <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 2.124">Hdt. 2.124</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐς πᾶσαν κακότητα ἐλάσαι,</quote> </cit> they said that he <emph>went all lengths</emph> in wickedness: <cit> <bibl>Tyrt. 11.10</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφοτέρων δ’ εἰς κόρον ἠλάσατε,</quote> </cit> ye had taken your fill of both. For the fut., expressing resolve, cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Birds 759">Aristoph. Birds 759</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἶρε πλῆκτρον, εἰ μαχεῖ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_ἔγωγε_1161"> as <ref n="Soph. Phil. 735, 1157">Soph. Phil. 735, 1157</ref>: so <foreign xml:lang="lat">dudum</foreign> can refer to a recent moment. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κείνου_γεγώς_1168"> some one belonging by birth to his race, the genit. depending on the notion of <foreign xml:lang="grc">γένος</foreign> in the adj., like <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">δωμάτων ὑπόστεγοι,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1386">Soph. El. 1386</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέγειν_1169"> being added to explain the particular sense in which <emph>he</emph> is<foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς τῷ δεινῷ,</foreign> as </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀκούειν_1169"> defines that in which Oedipus is so. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 542">Soph. El. 542</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἐμῶν … ἵμερον τέκνων … ἔσχε δαίσασθαι·</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Crito 52b">Plat. Crito 52b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ἐπιθυμία σε ἄλλης πόλεως οὐδ’ ἄλλων νόμων ἔλαβεν εἰδέναι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τῶν ἐμῶν … ἵμερον τέκνων … ἔσχε
									δαίσασθαι·

οὐδ’ ἐπιθυμία σε ἄλλης πόλεως οὐδ’ ἄλλων νόμων
							ἔλαβεν εἰδέναι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γέ_δή_1171"> is rarer: we find it in <ref n="Aristoph. Cl. 372">Aristoph. Cl. 372</ref>,<ref n="Plat. Phaedrus 264a">Plat. Phaedrus 264a</ref>,<ref n="Plat. Rep. 476e">Plat. Rep. 476e</ref>,<ref n="Plat. Rep. 504a">Plat. Rep. 504a</ref>,<ref n="Plat. Crito 44c">Plat. Crito 44c</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_1174"> = “in her intention ”: see on 848. <foreign xml:lang="grc">—πρὸς τί χρείας</foreign> nearly = <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ποίαν χρείαν,</foreign> with a view to what kind of need or desire, i.e. with what aim: cp. 1443: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 174">Soph. Phil. 174</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ παντί τῳ χρείας ἱσταμένῳ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1229">Soph. Ant. 1229</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐν τῷ (</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τίνἰ ξυμφορᾶς,</foreign> in what manner of plight. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὺς_τεκόντας_1176"> not, as usually, “his parents ” (999), but “his father ”: the plur. as <foreign xml:lang="grc">τυράννοις,</foreign> 1095. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_δοκῶν_1178">, “as thinking” etc.: i.e., as one might fitly give it up, who so thought. This virtually elliptic use of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_1178"> is distinct from that at 848, which would here be represented by <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἀποίσοντι.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλην_ἀποίσειν_1178"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(αὐτόν)</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1769">Soph. OC 1769</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θήβας δ’ ἡμᾶς | τὰς ὠγυγίους πέμψον.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: θήβας δ’ ἡμᾶς | τὰς ὠγυγίους πέμψον.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κάκ_1180"> a disyllabic subst. or adj. with short penult. is rarely elided unless, as here, it is (a) <emph>first</emph> in the verse, and also (b) <emph> emphatic</emph>: so <ref n="Soph. OC 48">Soph. OC 48</ref>, 796: see A. W. Verrall in <title>Fourn. Phil.</title> xii. 140. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἂν_ἐξήκοι_1182"> <emph>must have</emph> come true (cp. 1011), the opt. as <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 502d">Plat. Gorg. 502d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκοῦν ἡ ῥητορικὴ δημηγορία ἂν εἴη</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.2">Hdt. 1.2</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴησαν δ’ ἂν οὗτοι Κρῆτες</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 8.136">Hdt. 8.136</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τάχα δ’ ἂν καὶ τὰ χρηστήρια ταῦτά οἱ προλέγοι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: οὐκοῦν ἡ ῥητορικὴ δημηγορία ἂν εἴη

τάχα δ’ ἂν καὶ τὰ χρηστήρια ταῦτά οἱ
									προλέγοι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀφ_χρῆν_1184"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(φῦναἰ,</foreign> since he was foredoomed to the acts which the two following clauses express. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_1187"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐναριθμῶ_μηδὲν_1187"> adverbially with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζώσας_1187">: i.e. how absolutely do I count you as living a life which is no life. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζώσας_1187_2"> should not be taken as = “while you live,” or “though you live.” We find <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδέν εἰμι,</foreign> “I am no more,” and also, with the art., <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ μηδέν εἰμι,</foreign> “I am as if I were not”: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 1107">Soph. Trach. 1107</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κἂν τὸ μηδὲν ὦ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1275">Soph. Aj. 1275</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸ μηδὲν ὄντας.</quote> </cit> Here </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζώσας_1187_3"> is a more forcible substitute for <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔσας,</foreign> bringing out the contrast between the semblance of vigour and the real feebleness. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴσα_καὶ_1187"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἴσα</foreign> (or <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἴσον) ὥσπερ,</foreign> a phrase used by <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.14">Thuc. 3.14</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(ἴσα καὶ ἱκέται ἐσμέν),</quote> </cit> and <cit> <bibl n="Eur. El. 994">Eur. El. 994</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(σεβίζω σ’ ἴσα καὶ μάκαρας),</quote> </cit> which reappears in late Greek, as Aristid. 1. 269 (Dind.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐναριθμῶ_1187"> only here, and (midd.) in <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 623">Eur. Orest. 623</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ τοὐμὸν ἔχθος ἐναριθμεῖ κῆδός τ’ ἐμόν</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν ἀριθμῷ ποιεῖ,</foreign> if you make of account. </gloss>

data.quote: εἰ τοὐμὸν ἔχθος ἐναριθμεῖ κῆδός τ’ ἐμόν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέρει_1190"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">φέρεται,</foreign> cp. 590. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοκεῖν_1191"> “to seem,” sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὐδαιμονεῖν</foreign>: not absol., “to have reputation,” a sense which <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἱ δοκοῦντες, τὰ δοκοῦντα</foreign> can sometimes bear in <emph>direct antithesis</emph> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἱ ἀδοξοῦντες</foreign> or the like (<ref n="Eur. Hec. 291">Eur. Hec. 291</ref> etc.) Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 865">Eur. Her. 865</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν εὐτυχεῖν δοκοῦντα μὴ ζηλοῦν πρὶν ἂν | θανόντ’ ἴδῃ τις</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 125">Soph. Aj. 125</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁρῶ γὰρ ἡμᾶς οὐδὲν ὄντας ἅλλο πλὴν | εἴδωλ’ ὅσοιπερ ζῶμεν ἢ κούφην σκιάν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τὸν εὐτυχεῖν δοκοῦντα μὴ ζηλοῦν πρὶν ἂν |
							θανόντ’
									ἴδῃ τις

ὁρῶ γὰρ ἡμᾶς οὐδὲν ὄντας ἅλλο πλὴν | εἴδωλ’
							ὅσοιπερ ζῶμεν ἢ κούφην σκιάν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀποκλῖναι_1192"> a metaphor from the heavenly bodies; cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀποκλινομένης τῆς ἡμέρης</foreign> (<ref n="Hdt. 3.104">Hdt. 3.104</ref>): and so <foreign xml:lang="grc">κλίνει ἡ ἡμέρα, ὁ ἥλιος</foreign> in later Greek: <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 1.13">Dem. 1.13</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἐπὶ τὸ ῥᾳθυμεῖν ἀπέκλινεν.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 3.5.13">Xen. Mem. 3.5.13</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ πόλις … ἐπὶ τὸ χεῖρον ἔκλινεν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ἡ πόλις … ἐπὶ τὸ χεῖρον ἔκλινεν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_τον_1193"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> The apparently long syllable </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_1193"> (=<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἐξ</foreign> in 1202) is “irrational, ” having the time-value only of ˘: see Metrical Analysis. The </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_τοι_1193"> of the MSS. involves a most awkward construction:— “having thy example,—having thy fate, I say, (<emph>as</emph> an example) ”; for we could not well render “having thy case <foreign xml:lang="grc">(τὸ σόν)</foreign> as an example. ” Against </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_σόν_1193">, which is decidedly more forcible, nothing can be objected except the threefold repetition; but this is certainly no reason for rejecting it in a lyric utterance of passionate feeling. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδὲν_βροτῶν_1195"> nothing (i.e. no being) among men, a stronger phrase than <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδένα</foreign>: Nauck compares fr. 652 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἱ δὲ τῇ γλώσσῃ θρασεῖς | φεύγοντες ἄτας ἐκτός εἰσι τῶν κακῶν· | Ἄρης γὰρ οὐδὲν τῶν κακῶν λωτίζεται,</foreign> “no dastard life ”: <cit> <bibl n="HH 4.34">HH Herm. 34</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὔπερ τι πεφυγμένον ἔστ’ Ἀφροδίτην | οὔτε θεῶν μακάρων οὔτε θνητῶν ἀνθρώπων.</quote> </cit> Add <ref n="Soph. Phil. 446">Soph. Phil. 446</ref> (with reference to Thersites being still alive) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔμελλ’· ἐπεὶ οὐδέν πω κακόν γ’ ἀπώλετο, | ἀλλ’ εὖ περιστέλλουσιν αὐτὰ δαίμονες· | καί πως τὰ μὲν πανοῦργα καὶ παλιντριβῆ | χαίρουσ’ ἀναστρέφοντες ἐξ Ἅιδου, τὰ δὲ | δίκαια καὶ τὰ χρήστ’ ἀποστέλλουσ’ ἀεί.</foreign> The </gloss>

data.quote:
οὔπερ τι πεφυγμένον ἔστ’ Ἀφροδίτην | οὔτε θεῶν
							μακάρων οὔτε θνητῶν ἀνθρώπων.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδένα_1195"> of the MSS. involves the resolution of a long syllable (the second of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδὲν_1195">)which has an ictus; this is inadmissible, as the ear will show any one who considers the antistrophic verse, 1203, <foreign xml:lang="grc">Θήβαισιν ἀνάσσων.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καθ_τοξεύσας_1197"> having hit the answer to the riddle of the Sphinx, when Teiresias and all others had failed: cp. 398: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 628">Aesch. Ag. 628</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔκυρσας ὥστε τοξότης ἄκρος σκοποῦ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκράτησε_1197"> At 1193 the Chorus addressed Oedipus: at 1197 (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅστις_1197"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.)</foreign> they turn to invoke <emph>Zeus</emph> as the witness of his achievements; and so in 1200 L, which here has the corrupt <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκράτησας,</foreign> rightly gives </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνέστα_1197">. Then at 1201 (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξ_οὗ_1197"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.)</foreign> they resume the direct address to Oedipus, which is thenceforth maintained to the end of the ode. To read <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκράτησας</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἀνέστας</foreign> would be to efface a fine trait, marking the passion of grief which turns from earth to heaven, and then again to earth. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_εὐδαίμονος_1197"> for the adverbial </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάντα_1197"> see on 475; also 823, 1425. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φθίσας_1198"> because the Sphinx, when her riddle was solved, threw herself from a rock (<ref n="Apollod. 3.5">Apollod. 3.5</ref>): cp. 397 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔπαυσά νιν.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰν_γαμψώνυχα_1199"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> The place of the second adj. may be explained by viewing<foreign xml:lang="grc">παρθένον‐χρησμῳδόν</foreign> as a composite idea: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 393">Soph. Phil. 393</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν μέγαν Πάκτωλον‐εὔχρυσον</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1234">Soph. OC 1234</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τό τε κατάμεμπτον … | γῆρας‐ἄφιλον</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 133">Soph. El. 133</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἐμὸν … πατέρ’ ἄθλιον.</quote> </cit> So <ref n="Pind. P. 1">Pind. P. 1.95</ref>, 5. 99 etc. This is not like <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸ σὸν στόμα … ἐλεινόν</foreign> in 672 (n.). - </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παρθένον_1199">: see on <foreign xml:lang="grc">κόρα,</foreign> 508. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θανάτων_πύργος_1200"> see on 218. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀκούειν_1204"> to hear of, defining </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀθλιώτερος_1204"> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 1202">Eur. Hipp. 1202</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φρικώδη κλύειν.</quote> </cit> Whose woes are more impressive to others, or more cruel for himself? Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 306">Soph. OC 306</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολὺ … τὸ σὸν | ὄνομα διήκει πάντας.</quote> </cit> The constr. is </gloss>

data.quote: πολὺ … τὸ σὸν | ὄνομα διήκει πάντας.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίς_τίς_1204"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἀθλιώτερος)</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξύνοικος_ἄταις_1204"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.,</foreign> who is more wretched to hear of (whose story is more tragic), who is more wretched as dwelling amid woes (whose present miseries are sharper)? It is not possible to supply <foreign xml:lang="grc">μᾶλλον</foreign> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ξύνοικος_1204"> from<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀθλιώτερος.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίς_πόνοις_1205"> is far the most probable cure for the metre. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_1205"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄταις_1205"> as well as </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πόνοις_1205">: see on 734: for the redundant </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_ξύν_1205"> ,1126. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λιμὴν_1208"> schol. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅτι μήτηρ ἦν καὶ γυνὴ ἡ Ἰοκάστη, ἣν λέγει λιμένα.</foreign> Cp. 420 ff. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πεσεῖν_1210"> here = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμπεσεῖν</foreign> (which Hartung would read, but unnecessarily). <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Thes. 1122">Aristoph. Thes. 1122</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πεσεῖν ἐς εὐνὰς καὶ γαμήλιον λέχος.</quote> </cit> The bold use is assisted by<foreign xml:lang="grc">θαλαμηπόλῳ</foreign> (bridegroom) which goes closely with <foreign xml:lang="grc">πεσεῖν.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: πεσεῖν ἐς εὐνὰς καὶ γαμήλιον λέχος.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλοκες_1211"> cp. 1256, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 569">Soph. Ant. 569</ref>,<ref n="Aesch. Seven 753">Aesch. Seven 753</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σῖγ_1212"> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 37">Aesch. Ag. 37</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶκος δ’ αὐτός, εἰ φθογγὴν λάβοι, | σαφέστατ’ ἂν λέξειεν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
οἶκος δ’ αὐτός, εἰ φθογγὴν λάβοι, | σαφέστατ’
							ἂν
									λέξειεν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄκονθ_1213"> not as if he had been a criminal who sought to hide conscious guilt; but because he had not foreseen the disclosure which was to result from his inquiry into the murder of Laius. —</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρόνος_1213">, which <foreign xml:lang="grc">φύει ἄδηλα</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. Aj. 647">Soph. Aj. 647</ref>): fr. 280 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ταῦτα κρύπτε μηδέν, ὡς ὁ πάνθ’ ὁρῶν | καὶ πάντ’ ἀκούων</foreign> (cp. note on 660) <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάντ’ ἀναπτύσσει χρόνος</foreign>: see on 614. Time is here invested with the attributes of the divine omniscience and justice. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δικάζει_1214"> (see on 1205), prop. “tries, ” as a judge tries a cause <foreign xml:lang="grc">(δίκην δικάζεἰ</foreign>: here, “brings to justice,” punishes: a perhaps unique poetical use, for in <ref n="Pind. O. 2">Pind. O. 2.59</ref>, which Mitchell quotes, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλιτρὰ … δικάζει τις</foreign> = simply “tries.” Aesch. has another poet. use, <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 1412">Aesch. Ag. 1412</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δικαάζεις … φυγὴν ἐμοί</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">καταδικάζεις φυγὴν ἐμοῦ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γάμον_τεκνοῦμενον_1214"> one in which <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ τεκνούμενος</foreign> has long been identified with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁ τεκνῶν</foreign>: i.e. in which the son has become the husband. The expression is of the same order as <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">τά γ’ ἔργα μου | πεπονθότ’ ἐστὶ μᾶλλον ἢ δεδρακότα,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. OC 266">Soph. OC 266</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>

data.quote:
τά γ’ ἔργα μου | πεπονθότ’ ἐστὶ μᾶλλον ἢ
							δεδρακότα,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰὼ_τέκνον_1216"> Erfurdt's <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὦ</foreign> is the most probable way of supplying the required syllable, and Reisig's objection to its place is answered by <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 395">Soph. Aj. 395</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρεβος ὦ φαεννότατον.</quote> </cit> Hermann, however, preferred </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὤ_1216">, as a separate exclamation: “Alas, of Laius (oh horror!) the son. ” Bothe's <foreign xml:lang="grc">Λαϊήιον</foreign> could be supported by <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IA 757">Eur. IA 757</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Φοιβήιον δάπεδον</quote> </cit>: Eur. fr. 775. 64 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁσίαν βασιλήιον</foreign>: but seems less likely here. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύρομαι_περίαλλα_1218">[sic; in one MS. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_στομάτων_1218">. I conjecture </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύρομαι_ἐκστομάτων_1218">: “I lament as one who pours from his lips a dirge ”: i.e., Oedipus is to me as one who is dead. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Pind. I. 7">Pind. I. 7.58</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ θρῆνον … πολύφαμον ἔχεαν,</quote> </cit> “over the tomb they poured forth a resounding dirge. ” My emendation has been adopted by Prof. Kennedy (ed. 1885). Every attempt to explain the vulgate is unavailing. (1) </gloss>
lemma:
δύρομαι γὰρ ὥσπερ ἰάλεμον χέων | ἐκ
							στομάτων

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_περίαλλ_1218"> is supposed to be like <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐτητύμως, ὡς μάλιστα,</foreign> “in measure most abundant. ” Now </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περίαλλα_1218"> could mean only “<emph>preeminently</emph>,” “<emph>more than others</emph>”: Soph. fr. 225 <foreign xml:lang="grc">νόμων | οὓς Θαμύρας περίαλλα μουσοποιεῖ,</foreign> “strains which Thamyras weaves <emph>with art preeminent</emph>”:<cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Thes. 1070">Aristoph. Thes. 1070</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί ποτ’ Ἀνδρομέδα | περίαλλα κακῶν μέρος ἐξέλαχον;</quote> </cit> “why have I, Andromeda, been dowered with sorrows <emph>above all women</emph>?”<cit> <bibl n="Pind. P. 11">Pind. P. 11.5</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θησαυρὸν ὂν περίαλλ’ ἐτίμασε Λοξίας,</quote> </cit> honoured <emph>preeminently</emph>. Here, </gloss>

data.quote:
τί ποτ’ Ἀνδρομέδα | περίαλλα κακῶν μέρος
							ἐξέλαχον;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περίαλλα_1218_2"> is utterly unsuitable; and the added </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_1218"> makes the phrase stranger still. (2) The MSS. have </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰαχέων_1218">. Both <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰα^χεῖν</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰα—χεῖν</foreign> occur: but the latter should, with Dindorf, be written <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰακχέω.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 752">Eur. Her. 752</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἰακχήσατε</quote> </cit>: 783 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀλολύγματα … ἰακχεῖ</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 826">Eur. Orest. 826</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Τυνδαρὶς ἰάκχησε τάλαινα</quote> </cit>: 965 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰακχείτω δὲ γᾶ Κυκλωπία.</foreign> The participle, however, is unendurably weak after </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύρομαι_1218">, and leaves </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_στομάτων_1218"> weaker still. (3) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_στομάτων_1218_2"> can mean only “<emph>from my lips</emph>” (the plur. as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 938">Soph. Trach. 938</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφιπίπτων στόμασιν,</quote> </cit> kissing her lips: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 404">Eur. Alc. 404</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποτὶ σοῖσι πίτνων στόμασιν)</quote> </cit>: it could not mean “loudly. ” (4) Elmsley, doubtless feeling this, took </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰαχέων_1218_2"> as gen. of a supposed, but most questionable, <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἰαχέος,</foreign> “loud,” formed from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰαχή.</foreign> Erfurdt conjectured </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰακχίων_1218">, “from lips wild as a bacchant's.” But a Greek poet would not have brought Iacchos and Thanatos so close together; <foreign xml:lang="grc">χωρὶς ἡ τιμὴ θεῶν.</foreign> (5) </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰάλεμον_1218"> gives exactly the right force; for them, Oed. is as the dead. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἰάλεμος_1218"> is <emph>a wail for the dead</emph> in the four places of Eur. where it occurs (<ref n="Eur. Orest. 1391">Eur. Orest. 1391</ref>,<ref n="Eur. Phoen. 1033">Eur. Phoen. 1033</ref>,<ref n="Eur. Tro. 600">Eur. Tro. 600</ref>,<ref n="Eur. Tro. 1304">Eur. Tro. 1304</ref>), in <ref n="Eur. Rh. 895">Eur. Rh. 895</ref>, and in the one place of <ref n="Aesch. Supp. 115">Aesch. Supp. 115</ref>, which is just to our point: the Chorus of Danaides say, <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάθεα … θρεομένα … | ἰηλέμοισιν ἐμπρεπῆ ζῶσα γόοις με τιμῶ,</foreign> “lamenting sorrows meet for funeral wails (i.e. the sorrows of those who are as dead), while yet living, I chant mine own dirge.” </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_στομάτων_1218_3"> fits </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χέων_1218">, since <foreign xml:lang="grc">χεῖν</foreign> was not commonly used absolutely for “to utter” (as by Pindar, l. c. above). (6) The corruption may have thus arisen in a cursive MS.: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰάλεμον</foreign> being written <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰαλεμὸ,</foreign> the last five letters of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡσπεριαλεμοχ῎ων</foreign> would first generate <foreign xml:lang="grc">αχεων</foreign> (as in one MS.), or, with the second stroke of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">μ, ιαχεων</foreign>: the attempt to find an intelligible word in the immediately preceding group of letters would then quickly produce the familiar <foreign xml:lang="grc"> περίαλλα</foreign> (in one MS. <foreign xml:lang="grc">περίαλἀ.</foreign> The nonelision of the final <foreign xml:lang="grc">α</foreign> in the MSS. favours this view. As to metre, with <foreign xml:lang="grc">πατρὶ</foreign> in 1209, a tribrach <foreign xml:lang="grc">(‐τρὶ θαλαμ)</foreign> answers to a dactyl <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ὡς περι‐,</foreign> my <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὥσπερ ἰ‐),</foreign> whether we keep the traditional text, or adopt my conjecture, or that of Wecklein or of Burges; though Wecklein, by a strange oversight, has noticed this objection as if it were peculiar to my conjecture. Wunder's <foreign xml:lang="grc">πόσει</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">πατρὶ</foreign> in 1209 would restore exact correspondence, and may be right; but I rather prefer, with Heinrich Schmidt (<title>Compositionslehre</title> 64), to regard the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς</foreign> as an “irrational syllable ”: see Metrical Analysis. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_εἰπεῖν_1221"> like <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς εἰπεῖν ἔπος,</foreign> prefaces the bold figure of speech: I might truly say that by thy means (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκ_σέθεν_1221"> )I <emph>received a new life</emph> (when the Sphinx had brought us to the brink of ruin); and now have again <emph>closed my eyes</emph> in a sleep as of death, —since all our weal perishes with thine. The Thebans might now be indeed described as <foreign xml:lang="grc">στάντες τ’ ἐς ὀρθὸν καὶ πεσόντες ὔστερον</foreign> (50). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνέπνευσα_1221"> “revived, ” i.e. was delivered from anguish; cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 11.382">Hom. Il. 11.382</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀνέπνευσαν κακότητος,</quote> </cit> had a respite from distress: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 274">Soph. Aj. 274</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔληξε κἀνέπνευσε τῆς νόσου.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κατεκοίμησα_1222"> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 1293">Aesch. Ag. 1293</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἀσφάδαστος … ὄμμα συμβάλω τόδε</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 831">Soph. Aj. 831</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καλῶ θ’ ἅμα | πομπαῖον Ἑρμῆν χθόνιον εὖ με κοιμίσαι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
καλῶ θ’ ἅμα | πομπαῖον Ἑρμῆν χθόνιον εὖ με
							κοιμίσαι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅσον_δ_1224"> see on 29. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀρεῖσθε_1224"> take upon you, i.e. have laid upon you: like <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἴρεσθαι ἄχθος</foreign> (so <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 907">Soph. Ant. 907</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πόνον,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 491">Soph. Trach. 491</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νόσον)</quote> </cit>: while in <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 14.130">Hom. Il. 14.130</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μή πού τις ἐφ’ ἕλκεϊ ἕλκος ἄρηται</quote> </cit> is more like <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 12.435">Hom. Il. 12.435</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μισθὸν ἄρηται,</quote> </cit> “win. ” </gloss>

data.quote: μή πού τις ἐφ’ ἕλκεϊ ἕλκος ἄρηται

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγγενῶς_1224"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐγγενεῖς ὄντες,</foreign> like true men of the Cadmean stock to which the house of Labdacus belonged (261, 273). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἴστρον_1227"> the Thracian name for the lower course of the river which the Kelts called Danuvius (for this rather than Danubius is the correct form, Kiepert <title>Anc. Geo.</title> §196 n., Byzantine and modern <foreign xml:lang="grc">Δούναβις).</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Φᾶσιν_1227"> (<emph>Rion</emph>), dividing Colchis from Asia Minor and flowing into the Euxine. ( “Phasis ” in <ref n="Xen. Anab. 4.6.4">Xen. Anab. 4.6.4</ref> must mean the Araxes, which flows into the Caspian.) Soph. names these simply as great rivers, not with conscious choice as representatives of Europe and Asia. <ref n="Ov. Met. 2.248">Ovid Met. 2.248</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">arsit Orontes | Thermodonque citus Gangesque et Phasis et Ister.</foreign> Commentators compare <ref>Seneca Hipp. 715</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">Quis eluet me Tanais? aut quae barbaris Maeotis undis Pontico incumbens mari? Non ipse toto magnus Oceano pater Tantum piarit sceleris,</foreign> and <cit> <bibl n="Shak. MAC 2.2.60">Shaksp. <title>Macbeth</title> 2.2.60</bibl> <quote xml:lang="eng">“Will all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood Clean from my hand?”</quote> </cit>: where, however, the agony of personal remorse renders the hyperbole somewhat more natural than it is here in the mouth of a messenger. </gloss>

Etym. 439</ref>), cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 11.830">Hom. Il. 11.830</ref> etc. </gloss>

It was altered to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ᾔδεμεν</foreign> by Elms. on <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ba. 1345">Eur. Ba. 1345</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὄψ’ ἐμάθεθ’ ἡμᾶς, ὅτε δ’ ἐχρῆν, οὐκ ᾔδετε</quote> </cit>: where the <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἴδετε</foreign> of the MSS. is possible, but less probable. <ref n="Aeschin. 3.82">Aeschin. 3.82</ref> has <foreign xml:lang="grc">ᾔδειμεν</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Dem. 55.9">Dem. 55.9</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾔδειτε.</quote> </cit> See <ref>Curtius Verb 11.239</ref>, Eng. tr. 432, who points out that the case of the <emph>third</emph> pers. plur. is different: for this, the forms in <foreign xml:lang="grc">εσαν</foreign> (as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ᾔδεσαν)</foreign> <emph>alone</emph> have good authority. </gloss>

Phaedrus 234d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">συνεβάκχευσα μετὰ σοῦ τῆς θείας κεφαλῆς</quote> </cit> ( “your worship ”). </gloss>

Alc. 1 127e">Plat. Alc. 1 127e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἂν θεὸς ἐθέλῃ εἴ τι δεῖ καὶ τῇ ἐμῇ μαντείᾳ πιστεύειν, σύ τε κἀγὼ βέλτιον σχήσομεν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
