content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνἔνι_1239"> (=<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἔνεστἰ,</foreign> as <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐνεῖναι ἐν</quote> <bibl n="Aristoph. Kn. 1132">Aristoph. Kn. 1132</bibl> </cit> etc. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βοων_εἰσέπαισεν_1241">,1252). The messenger and others who were in the court watch him in terror as he raves for a sword and asks for Iocasta. Then the thought strikes him that she is in the <foreign xml:lang="grc">θάλαμος.</foreign> He bursts into it (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐνήλατο_1241">1261). They follow. There they find Iocasta dead, and see Oedipus blind himself. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐθὺ_1242"> “straight,” is obviously more forcible here than <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὐθύς,</foreign> “without delay”; a distinction to which <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 1197">Eur. Hipp. 1197</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν εὐθὺς Ἄργους κἀπιδαυρίας ὁδόν</quote> </cit> is an exception rare in classical Attic. Nauck, with tasteless caprice, writes <foreign xml:lang="grc">εὐθὺς ἐς.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀμφιδεξίοις_1243"> here = not simply “<emph>both,</emph>” but “<emph>belonging to both hands</emph>” (for </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀκμαῖς_1243"> <emph> alone</emph> would scarcely have been used for “hands ”): so in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1112">Soph. OC 1112</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐρείσατε πλευρὸν ἀμφιδέξιον</quote> </cit> can mean, “press your sides to mine <emph>on either hand</emph>.”<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀμφιδέξιος</foreign> usu. means “equally deft with either hand ” (<foreign xml:lang="lat">ambidexter</foreign>), opp. to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀμφαρίστερος,</foreign> “utterly gauche ” (Ar. fr. 432): hence “ambiguous ” (of an oracle, <ref n="Hdt. 5.92">Hdt. 5.92</ref>). The Sophoclean use has at least so much warrant from etymology that <foreign xml:lang="grc">δεξιά,</foreign> from <foreign xml:lang="grc">δεκ</foreign> with added <foreign xml:lang="grc">ς,</foreign> prop. meant merely “the catcher” or “receiver”: see <ref>Curt. Etym. 11.266</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπιρράξασ_1244"> from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιρράσσω,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Plut. De Iside 356c">Plut. Mor. 356c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοὺς δὲ συνόντας ἐπιδραμόντας ἐπιρράξαι τὸ πῶμα,</quote> </cit> hastily put the lid on the chest. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 24.452">Hom. Il. 24.452</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θύρην δ’ ἔχε μοῦνος ἐπίβλης | εἰλάτινος, τὸν τρεῖς μὲν ἐπιρρήσσεσκον Ἀχαιοί, | τρεῖς δ’ ἀναοίγεσκον κ.τ.λ.</quote> </cit> (from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιρρήσσὠ.</foreign> Hesych. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιρρήσσει. ἐπικλείει.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Prot. 314c">Plat. Prot. 314c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀμφοῖν τοῖν χεροῖν τὴν θύραν … ἐπήραξε</quote> </cit> (from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπαράσσὠ.</foreign> In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1503">Soph. OC 1503</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(χάλαζ’) ἐπιρράξασα</quote> </cit> is intrans. </gloss>

Od. 3.49">Hom. Od. 3.49</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νεώτερός ἐστιν, ὁμηλικίη δέ μοι αὐτῷ (</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὁμῆλιξ).</foreign> Not acc. in appos. with sentence, “an evil way of begetting children, ” because </gloss>

data.quote: νεώτερός ἐστιν, ὁμηλικίη δέ μοι αὐτῷ (

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λίποι_αὐτοῦ_1248">, “left <emph>to</emph> (or <emph>for</emph>) his own, ” would then be very weak. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γοᾶτο_1249"> Cp. <ref>Curt. Verb 1.138</ref>, Eng. tr. 92: “It seems to me best on all grounds to suppose that shortly before the rise of the Greek Epic the [syllabic] augment became occasionally exposed to the same tendency towards wearing away (<foreign xml:lang="deu">Verwitterung</foreign>) which the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀ</foreign> of <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἄρα</foreign> and the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐ</foreign> of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔνερθε</foreign> could not always withstand; that there were, in short, pairs of forms then in use, one with the augment and one without … The omission of the syllabic augment in Homer was purely a matter of choice … Post-Homeric poetry adopts the power of dispensing with the syllabic augment as an inheritance from its predecessor, and makes the greater use of it in proportion as it is removed from the language of ordinary life. Hence it is that, as is shown by the careful investigations made by Renner (<title>Stud.</title> 1.2.18 ff.), the omission of the syllabic augment is extremely rare in iambic, and far more common in elegiac and lyric verse. Hence, as is shown (<title>Stud.</title> 1.2.259) by Gerth, in the dialogue of tragedy the range of this license is very limited indeed, while the majority of instances of it occur in the slightly Epic style of the messengers” speeches, or still more commonly in lyric passages. “ The tragic <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥήσεις</foreign> here borrow from a practice more marked in epic <emph>narrative</emph> than in epic <emph> speeches</emph>. In Homer, where augmented and unaugmented forms are on the whole about equally numerous, the proportion of augmented to unaugmented is in the speeches about 10 to 3, in the narrative about 5 to 7: see Monro, <title>Hom. Grammar</title> sect. 69. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διπλοῦς_1249"> acc. plur., a twofold progeny, viz. (1) Oedipus by Laius <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἐξ ἀνδρὸς ἄνδρἀ,</foreign> and (2) her four children by Oedipus <foreign xml:lang="grc">(τέκνα ἐκ τέκνων,</foreign> where the poetical plur. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τέκνων</foreign> is for symmetry with <foreign xml:lang="grc">τέκνα,</foreign> as 1176 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοὺς τεκόντας</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸν πατέρἀ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπόλλυται_οἶδα_1251">)is a bold ”hyperbaton “: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1427">Soph. OC 1427</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς δὲ τολμήσει κλύων | τὲ τοῦδ’ ἕπεσθαι τἀνδρός … ;</quote> </cit> and <ref n="Soph. OC 135">Soph. OC 135 ff.</ref> Blaydes cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 205">Eur. Her. 205</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σοὶ δ’ ὡς ἀνάγκη τούσδε βούλομαι φράσαι | σῴζειν,</quote> </cit> where <foreign xml:lang="grc">σῴζειν</foreign> ought to come before <foreign xml:lang="grc">βούλομαι.</foreign> </gloss>

τίς δὲ τολμήσει κλύων | τὲ τοῦδ’ ἕπεσθαι
							τἀνδρός … ;

σοὶ δ’ ὡς ἀνάγκη τούσδε βούλομαι φράσαι |
							σῴζειν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φοιτᾷ_1255a"> moves wildly about. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 15.685">Hom. Il. 15.685</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὣς Αἴας ἐπὶ πολλὰ θοάων ἴκρια νηῶν | φοίτα μακρὰ βιβάς—</quote> </cit> where he has just been likened to a man <emph>jumping</emph> from one horse to another, <foreign xml:lang="grc">θρώσκων ἄλλοτ’ ἐπ’ ἄλλον.</foreign> So of the sharp, sudden visits of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">νόσος,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 808">Soph. Phil. 808</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀξεῖα φοιτᾷ καὶ ταχεῖ’ ἀπέρχεται.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 59">Soph. Aj. 59</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φοιτῶντ’ ἄνδρα μανιάσιν νόσοις,</quote> </cit> “raving.” Curtius (<ref>Curt. Etym. 417</ref>) would refer the word to <foreign xml:lang="grc">φυ, φοιτάω</foreign> coming from <foreign xml:lang="grc">φοv‐ι‐τα‐ω,</foreign> “to be often” (in a place). </gloss>

data.quote:
ὣς Αἴας ἐπὶ πολλὰ θοάων ἴκρια νηῶν | φοίτα
							μακρὰ

Hell. 7.4.39">Xen. Hell. 7.4.39</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠπόρει τε ὅ τι χρήσαιτο τῷ πράγματι</quote> </cit>: i.e. his thought was, <foreign xml:lang="grc">τί χρήσωμαι;</foreign> </gloss>

ἤτοι τις ἐξέκλεψεν ἢ ξᾘτήσατο | θεός τις, οὐκ
							ἄνθρωπος

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ὑφηγ_1260"> see on 966. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πύλαις_διπλαῖς_1261"> the folding doors of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">θάλαμος</foreign>.<ref n="Hom. Od. 2.344">Hom. Od. 2.344</ref> (the <foreign xml:lang="grc">θάλαμος</foreign> of Odysseus) <foreign xml:lang="grc">κληισταὶ δ’ ἔπεσαν σανίδες πυκινῶς ἀραρυῖαι | δικλίδες.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πυθμένων_1261"> prop. “bases”: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 1046">Aesch. PB 1046</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χθόνα δ’ ἐκ πυθμένων | αὐταῖς ῥίζαις πνεῦμα κραδαίνοι.</quote> </cit> Here the “bases” of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">κλῇθρα</foreign> (bolts) are the staples or sockets which held them. They were on the inner side of the doors, which Iocasta had closed behind her (1244). The pressure of Oedipus on the outer side forces the bolts, causing them to bend inwards (</gloss>

data.quote:
χθόνα δ’ ἐκ πυθμένων | αὐταῖς ῥίζαις πνεῦμα
							κραδαίνοι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κοῖλα_1261">).So Oedipus, within the house, gives the order <foreign xml:lang="grc">διοίγειν κλῇθρα,</foreign> 1287. Others understand: ”forced the doors from their hinges or posts “: but this gives an unnatural sense to <foreign xml:lang="grc">κλῇθρα. πυθμένες</foreign> would then mean the <foreign xml:lang="grc">στρόφιγγες</foreign> (<ref>Theophr. Hist. Pl. 5.5.4</ref>) or pivots (working in sockets called <foreign xml:lang="grc">στροφεῖς)</foreign> which served as hinges. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰώραισιν_1264"> expresses that the suspended body was still oscillating, and is thus more than <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρτάναις. αἰώρα</foreign> (akin to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀείρω, ἄορ, ἀορτήρ, ἄωρος</foreign> “uplifted,” <ref n="Hom. Od. 12.89">Hom. Od. 12.89</ref>,<ref>Curt. Etym. 518</ref>) meant a <emph>swing</emph> (as in Modern Greek), or <emph>swinging movement</emph>:<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedo 111e">Plat. Phaedo 111e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα δὲ πάντα κινεῖν ἄνω τε καὶ κάτω ὥσπερ αἰώραν τινὰ ἐνοῦσαν ἐν τῇ γῇ,</quote> </cit> there is a sort of swinging in the earth which moves all these things up and down; <foreign xml:lang="grc"> … αἰωρεῖται δὴ καὶ κυμαίνει ἄνω καὶ κάτω,</foreign> so they swing and surge: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 789d">Plat. Laws 789d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅσα τε ὑπὸ ἑαυτῶν (κινεῖταἰ ἢ καὶ ἐν αἰώραις</quote> </cit> (in swings) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἢ καὶ κατὰ θάλατταν ἢ καὶ ἐφ’ ἵππων ὀχουμένων.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl>Athen. 618e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦν δὲ καὶ ἐπὶ ταῖς ἐώραις τις, ἐπ’ Ἠριγόνῃ, ἢν καὶ ἀλῆτιν καλοῦσιν ᾠδήν,</quote> </cit> “at the Feast of Swings there was also a song in memory of Erigone, otherwise called the Song of the Wanderer.” The festival was named <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐῶραι</foreign> (small images, like the <foreign xml:lang="lat">oscilla</foreign> offered to Bacchus, <ref n="VERG. G. 2.389">Verg. Georg. 2.389</ref>, being hung from trees) because Erigone had <emph>hanged herself</emph> on the tree under which she had found the corpse of her father Icarius; the name <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλῆτις</foreign> alluding to her wanderings in search of him. Hesych. s. v. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλῆτις</foreign> has <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐώρα</foreign>: the gloss of Suidas <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἐώρα· ὕψωσις ἢ μέταρσις)</foreign> is from the schol. here. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐώρημα</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἰώρημα</foreign> (the stage <foreign xml:lang="grc">μηχανἤ</foreign> occurs in schol. <ref n="Aristoph. Peace 77">Aristoph. Peace 77</ref>.</gloss>

data.quote:
ταῦτα δὲ πάντα κινεῖν ἄνω τε καὶ κάτω ὥσπερ
							αἰώραν
									τινὰ ἐνοῦσαν ἐν τῇ γῇ,

ὅσα τε ὑπὸ ἑαυτῶν (κινεῖταἰ ἢ καὶ ἐν
									αἰώραις

ἦν δὲ καὶ ἐπὶ ταῖς ἐώραις τις, ἐπ’ Ἠριγόνῃ, ἢν
							καὶ
									ἀλῆτιν καλοῦσιν ᾠδήν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰωρα_1264">, however, is the only form for which there is good authority of the classical age. [Eustathius on <ref n="Hom. Il. 3.108">Hom. Il. 3.108</ref> says: <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἠερέθεσθαι δὲ κυρίως μὲν τὸ ἐν ἀέρι κρέμασθαι, ἐξ οὗ καὶ ἡ αἰώρα. ὅτι δὲ ἡ ῥηθεῖσα αἰώρα καὶ διὰ τοῦ ε ψιλοῦ ἔχει τὴν ἄρχουσαν, ὡς δηλοῖ οὐ μόνον τὸ πλεκταῖς ἐώραις ἐμπεπλεγμένην, ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ μετέωρος, ἕτεροι ἐπαγωνιζέσθωσαν.</foreign> Prof. Kennedy quotes this to prove ”the classical use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐώρα. “</foreign> But it rather indicates that this verse furnished the only classical example of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐώρα</foreign> known to Eustathius; and there is no proof that here he was following an older or better MS. than L.] </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμπεπληγμένεν_1264"> (see crit. n.) would mean ”having dashed herself into … “: but this can hardly be justified by the intrans. use of the active, <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 22.468">Hom. Od. 22.468 ff.</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅταν … πέλειαι | ἕρκει ἐνιπλήξωσι</quote> </cit>: nor is it appropriate here in reference to the hanging corpse. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γῇ_1266"> locative dat.: see on 20: cp. 1451 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ναίειν ὄρεσιν.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεινὰ_δ_1267"> For <foreign xml:lang="grc">δέ</foreign> introducing the apodosis after a temporal protasis (even when it is a short one), cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 7.46">Hom. Od. 7.46</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ὅτε δὴ βασιλῆος ἀγακλυτὰ δώμαθ’ ἵκοντο, | τοῖσι δὲ μύθων ἦρχε θεὰ γλαυκῶπις Ἀθήνη</quote> </cit>: and <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 7.184">Hom. Od. 7.184</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπεὶ σπεῖσάν τ’ ἔπιόν θ’ ὅσον ἤθελε θυμός, | τοῖσιν δ’ Ἀλκίνοος ἀγορήσατο.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀλλ’ ὅτε δὴ βασιλῆος ἀγακλυτὰ δώμαθ’ ἵκοντο, |
							τοῖσι δὲ μύθων ἦρχε θεὰ γλαυκῶπις Ἀθήνη

ἐπεὶ σπεῖσάν τ’ ἔπιόν θ’ ὅσον ἤθελε θυμός, |
							τοῖσιν δ’ Ἀλκίνοος ἀγορήσατο.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="περόνας_1269"> (called <foreign xml:lang="grc">πόρπαι</foreign> by <ref n="Eur. Phoen. 62">Eur. Phoen. 62</ref>), brooches with long pins which could serve as small daggers: one fastened Iocasta's <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱμάτιον</foreign> on her left shoulder, and another her Doric <foreign xml:lang="grc">χιτών</foreign> on the right shoulder, which the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱμάτιον</foreign> did not cover. The Doric <foreign xml:lang="grc">χιτών</foreign> was sleeveless, and usually made with a slit at each shoulder, requiring the use of brooches. (Cp. Guhl and Koner, <title>Life of the Greeks and Romans</title>, p. 162 Eng. tr.) In “The Harvard Greek Play” (1882), plate 11. p. 26 represents Iocasta with the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱμάτιον</foreign> thus worn. Cp. <ref n="Hdt. 5.87">Hdt. 5.87</ref>, where the Athenian women surround the sole survivor of the expedition to Aegina, <foreign xml:lang="grc">κεντεύσας τῇσι περόνῃσι τῶν ἱματίων,</foreign> and so slay him. Thus too in <ref n="Eur. Hec. 1170">Eur. Hec. 1170</ref> the women blind Polymestor; <foreign xml:lang="grc">πόρπας λαβοῦσαι τὰς ταλαιπώρους κόρας | κεντοῦσιν, αἱμάσσουσιν.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄρθρα_1270"> can only mean the sockets of the eye-balls (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κύκλων_1270">). “He struck his eye-balls in their sockets,” is a way of saying that he struck them full. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄρθρα</foreign> could not mean <foreign xml:lang="grc">κόρας</foreign> (pupils), as the schol. explains it. Eur. has another bold use of the word, <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Cycl. 624">Eur. Cycl. 624</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σιγᾶτε πρὸς θεῶν, θῆρες, ἡσυχάζετε, | συνθέντες ἄρθρα στόματος,</quote> </cit> i.e. shut your <emph>lips</emph> and be still. </gloss>

data.quote:
σιγᾶτε πρὸς θεῶν, θῆρες, ἡσυχάζετε, |
							συνθέντες
									ἄρθρα στόματος,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐκ_ὄψοιντο_1271"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> His words were: <foreign xml:lang="grc">—οὐκ ὄψεσθέ με οὔθ’ ὁποῖ’ ἔπασχον οὔθ’ ὁποῖ’ ἔδρων κακά, ἀλλ’ ἐν σκότῳ τὸ λοιπὸν οὓς μὲν οὐκ ἔδει ὄψεσθε, οὓς δ’ ἔχρῃζον οὐ γνώσεσθε</foreign>: Ye shall not see the evils which I was (unconsciously) suffering and doing [as defiled and defiling], but in darkness henceforth ye shall see those whom ye ought never to have seen [Iocasta and his children], and fail to know those whom I longed to know [his parents, Laius and Iocasta]. -<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔπασχεν … ἔδρα … ἔδει … ἔχρῃζεν</foreign> can represent nothing but imperfects of the direct discourse: had they represented presents, they must have been <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάσχει,</foreign> etc., or else <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάσχοι,</foreign> etc. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔπασχεν_ἔδρα_1271"> mean “was suffering,” “was doing” all this time, while ye failed to warn me; and express the reciprocal, though involuntary, wrong of the incestuous relation, with its consequences to the offspring. (Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 171">Soph. Ant. 171</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παίσαντές τε καὶ | πληγέντες αὐτόχειρι σὺν μιάσματι.)</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
παίσαντές τε καὶ | πληγέντες αὐτόχειρι σὺν
							μιάσματι.)

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀψοίατο_γνωσοίατο_1273">, Ionic, as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 44">Soph. OC 44</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεξαίατο,</quote> </cit> 921 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πυθοίατο,</foreign> 945 <foreign xml:lang="grc">δεξοίατο</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 211">Soph. El. 211</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀποναίατο</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Pers. 369">Aesch. Pers. 369</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φευξοίατο,</quote> </cit> 451 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκσωζοίατο</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Her. 547">Eur. Her. 547</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐκτισαίατο</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hel. 159">Eur. Hel. 159</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀντιδωρησαίατο.</quote> </cit> So <ref n="Thuc. 3.13">Thuc. 3.13</ref> can say <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐφθάραται Ἀθηναῖοι … αἱ δ’ ἐφ’ ἡμῖν τετάχαται</foreign> (and 4. 31, 5. 6, 7. 4). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐφυμνῶν_1275"> of imprecation, as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1305">Soph. Ant. 1305</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κακὰς | πράξεις ἐφυμνήσασα τῷ παιδοκτόνῳ</quote> </cit>: here the idea of <emph>repetition</emph> is also suggested: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 292">Soph. Aj. 292</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βαί’ ἀεὶ δ’ ὑμνούμενα</quote> </cit>: so Lat. <foreign xml:lang="lat">canere, decantare</foreign>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμοῦ__1276">= at each blow (hence imperf. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔτεγγον_1276">):but in 1278 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁμοῦ</foreign> = all at once, not drop by drop (<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀστακτί</foreign>, and not <foreign xml:lang="grc">στάγδην</foreign>). See on 517 (<foreign xml:lang="grc">φέρον</foreign>). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄμβρος_αἱματοῦς_1279"> and Porson's </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄμβρος_αἱματοῦσσ_1279">. The fact that all the MSS. have </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χαλάζης_1279"> and that most (including L, A) have </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἵματος_1279"> favours Heath's reading, which is also the stronger. Dindorf prefers Porson's on the ground that such forms as <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἰματοῦς, αἱματοῦν</foreign> are rarer than the feminine forms; but this seems an inadequate reason. Seneca's free paraphrase (<title>Oed.</title> 978 <foreign xml:lang="lat">rigat ora foedus imber, et lacerum caput Largum revulsis sanguinem venis vomit</foreign>) affords no clue as to his text of Sophocles. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέλας_χαλάζης_1279"> = a shower of dark blood-drops rushing down as fiercely as hail: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1502">Soph. OC 1502</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀμβρία | χάλαζ’ ἐπιρράξασα.</quote> </cit> Pindar has <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν πολυφθόρῳ … Διὸς ὄμβρῳ | ἀναρίθμων ἀνδρῶν χαλαζάεντι φόνῳ</foreign> (<ref n="Pind. I. 4.49">Pind. I. 4.49</ref>) of a slaughter in which deathblows are rained thick as hail; and so <foreign xml:lang="grc">χάλαζαν αἵματος</foreign> (<ref n="Pind. I. 6.27">Pind. I. 6.27</ref>): so that the resemblance is only verbal. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐχ_μόνου_1280">. though plausible, is in sense somewhat weak, and does not serve to connect 1280 with 1281. In the conjecture, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_κάτα_1280">, the force of the prep. is suitable to the image of a descending torrent which overwhelms: and for its place cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 969">Soph. Aj. 969</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί δῆτα τοῦδ’ ἐπεγγελῷεν ἂν κάτα;</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 302">Soph. Aj. 302</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λόγους … τοὺς μὲν Ἀτρειδῶν κάτα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: τί δῆτα τοῦδ’ ἐπεγγελῷεν ἂν κάτα;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_πρὶν_1282"> = which they had till lately: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παλαιὸς_1282">, because the house of the Labdacidae was <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἀρχαιόπλουτος;</foreign> tracing its line to Cadmus and Agenor, 268. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δικαίως_1283"> in a true sense: cp. 853. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅσ_ὀνόματα_1284"> ,<foreign xml:lang="grc">(τούτων)</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐδέν_ἀπόν_1284"> :<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄνομα κακοῦ</foreign> standing for <foreign xml:lang="grc">κακὸν ὀνομαζόμενον.</foreign> So <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 210">Aesch. PB 210</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Γαῖα, πολλῶν ὀνμάτων μορφὴ μία</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">μορφὴ μία θεᾶς πολλαχῶς ὀνομαζομένης.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔν_τινι_1286"> is right. Even if <foreign xml:lang="grc">τίς σχολὴ κακοῦ</foreign> could mean “<emph>what form of</emph> respite from misery?” <foreign xml:lang="grc">τίνι</foreign> would be less suitable. The Chorus mean: “and is he now calmer?” —to which the answer is that he is <emph> still</emph> vehemently excited. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μητέρ_1289"> (Schneidewin), suggested by <ref n="Aristoph. Wasps 1178">Aristoph. Wasps 1178</ref>, would debase this passage. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δόμοις_ἀραῖος_1291"> fraught with a curse for the house, making it accursed, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἠράσατο_1291">, in terms of his own curse (238 <foreign xml:lang="grc">μήτ’ εἰσδέχεσθαι μήτε προσφωνεῖν, κ.τ.λ.),</foreign> according to which anyone who was knowingly <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξυνέστιος</foreign> with the criminal incurred the like curse as he (270). Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 608">Eur. Med. 608</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ σοῖς ἀραία γ’ οὖσα τυγχάνω δόμοις,</quote> </cit> i.e. bring a curse on it. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IT 778">Eur. IT 778</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(κόμισαί μἐ … ἢ σοῖς ἀραία δώμασιν γενήσομαι.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 236">Aesch. Ag. 236</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φθόγγον ἀραῖον οἴκοις.</quote> </cit> Not </gloss>

data.quote: καὶ σοῖς ἀραία γ’ οὖσα τυγχάνω δόμοις,

(κόμισαί μἐ … ἢ σοῖς ἀραία δώμασιν
									γενήσομαι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μενῶν_δόμοις_1291">, as though the dat. were locative, like <foreign xml:lang="grc">γῇ,</foreign> 1266. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_φέρειν_1293"> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hec. 1107">Eur. Hec. 1107</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρείσσον’ ἢ φέρειν κακά</quote> </cit>: the fuller constr., <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 3.14">Hdt. 3.14</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μέζω κακὰ ἢ ὥστε ἀνακλαίειν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δείξει_1294"> is Oedipus. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 813">Soph. Aj. 813</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">χωρεῖν ἕτοιμος, κοὐ λόγῳ δείξω μόνον.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 146">Soph. OC 146</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δηλῶ δ’</quote> </cit>: “and I prove it” (viz. that I am wretched), like <foreign xml:lang="grc">τεκμήριον δέ.</foreign> In <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Eccl. 933">Aristoph. Eccl. 933</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δείξει γε καὶ σοί· τάχα γὰρ εἶσιν ὡς ἐμέ,</quote> </cit> a person just mentioned is the subject of both verbs, as just afterwards we have, <ref n="Aristoph. Eccl. 936">Aristoph. Eccl. 936</ref>,<foreign xml:lang="grc">δείξει τάχ’ αὐτός.</foreign> On the other hand the verb seems really impersonal in <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Frogs 1261">Aristoph. Frogs 1261</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πάνυ γε μέλη θαυμαστά· δείξει δὴ τάχα</quote> </cit> (for the subject cannot well be either <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέλη</foreign> or Aeschylus): and so in <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 2.134">Hdt. 2.134</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">διέδεξε,</quote> </cit> it was made clear: as <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 2.117">Hdt. 2.117</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δηλοῖ,</quote> </cit> it is manifest. In <ref n="Hdt. 3.82">Hdt. 3.82</ref>, however, the subject to <foreign xml:lang="grc">διέδεξε</foreign> may be <foreign xml:lang="grc">μουναρχίη.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Hipp. Maj. 288b">Plat. Hipp. Maj. 288b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δ’ ἐπιχειρήσας ἔσται καταγέλαστος, αὐτὸ δείξει</quote> </cit> (the event will show): cp. <ref n="Plat. Theaet. 200e">Plat. Theaet. 200e</ref>, and see on 341. The central door of the palace is now opened. Oedipus comes forth, leaning on attendants; the bloody stains are still upon his face. </gloss>

data.quote: χωρεῖν ἕτοιμος, κοὐ λόγῳ δείξω μόνον.
δείξει γε καὶ σοί· τάχα γὰρ εἶσιν ὡς ἐμέ,
πάνυ γε μέλη θαυμαστά· δείξει δὴ τάχα

εἰ δ’ ἐπιχειρήσας ἔσται καταγέλαστος, αὐτὸ
							δείξει

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἷον_ἐποικτίσαι_1296"> proper for one to pity, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_στυγοῦντα_1296">, even though he abhors it. The infin. with <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἷος,</foreign> as with other adjectives of ability or fitness <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἱκανός, ἐπιτήδειος,</foreign> etc.): so, too, with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅσος</foreign> as = sufficient ”: <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 4.1.5">Xen. Anab. 4.1.5</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλείπετο τῆς νυκτὸς ὅσον σκοταίους διελθεῖν τὸ πεδίον.</quote> </cit> Cp. <ref n="Soph. Trach. 672">Soph. Trach. 672</ref>: fr. 598. 8 <foreign xml:lang="grc">φεῦ· κἂν ἀνοικτίρμων τις οἰκτίρειέ νιν.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἐλείπετο τῆς νυκτὸς ὅσον σκοταίους διελθεῖν τὸ
							πεδίον.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅσα_προσέκυρσα_1298"> I know no other example of an accus. after <foreign xml:lang="grc"> προσκυρεῖν,</foreign> which usu. takes the dat.: but the compound can at least claim the privilege of the simple <foreign xml:lang="grc">κυρεῖν.</foreign> The neut. plur. accus. of <emph>pronouns</emph> and <emph>adjectives</emph> can stand after <foreign xml:lang="grc">τυγχάνειν</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">κυρεῖν,</foreign> not as an accus. directly governed by the verb, but rather as a species of cognate or adverbial accus.: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 509">Soph. Phil. 509</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἆθλ’ οἷα μηδεὶς τῶν ἐμῶν τύχοι φίλων</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1106">Soph. OC 1106</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αἰτεῖς ἃ τεύξει</quote> </cit> (which need not be explained by attraction): <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Lib. 711">Aesch. Lib. 711</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τυγχάνειν τὰ πρόσφορα,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Lib. 714">Aesch. Lib. 714</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κυρούντων … τὰ πρόσφορα</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 1666">Eur. Phoen. 1666</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ ἂν τύχοις τάδε</quote> </cit>: cp. Munro on <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 1228">Aesch. Ag. 1228 ff.</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶα … τεύξεται</quote> </cit> in <title>Journ. Phil.</title> 11.134. In <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 746">Eur. Hipp. 746</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τέρμονα κύρων</quote> </cit> is not similar, since <foreign xml:lang="grc">κύρων</foreign> = “reaching, ” and the accus. is like that after <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἀφικνεῖσθαι.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: ἆθλ’ οἷα μηδεὶς τῶν ἐμῶν τύχοι φίλων

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_μοίρᾳ_1300"> “who is the deity that hath sprung upon thy hapless life with a leap greater than the longest leap?” i.e. “has given thee sorrow which almost exceeds the imaginable limit of human suffering? ” For </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μείζονα_μακίστων_1300"> see on 465 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄρρητ’ ἀρρήτων.</foreign> The idea of a malignant god leaping <emph>from above</emph> on his victim is frequent in Greek tragedy: see on 263. But here </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μακίστων_1300">, as in 311 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἵνα,</foreign> combines the notion of swooping from above with that of leaping <emph>to a far point, </emph>— as with Pindar <foreign xml:lang="grc">μακρὰ … ἅλματα</foreign> (<ref n="Pind. N. 5.19">Pind. N. 5.19</ref>) denote <emph>surpassing</emph> poetical efforts. We should then conceive the <foreign xml:lang="grc">δυσδαίμων μοῖρα,</foreign> the ill-fated life, as an attacked region, <emph>far into</emph> which the malign god springs. Here we see a tendency which may sometimes be observed in the imagery (lyric especially) of Sophocles: the <emph>image</emph> is slightly crossed and blurred by the interposing notion of the <emph>thing</emph>: as here he was thinking, “what suffering <emph>could have gone further</emph>?” See on <foreign xml:lang="grc">δῑ αἰθέρα τεκνωθέντες,</foreign> 866. With Aeschylus, on the other hand, the obscurity of imagery seldom or never arises from indistinctness of outline, but more often from an opposite cause, —the vividly objective conception of abstract notions. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_1302"> with dat., after a verb of throwing or falling, is warranted by epic usage: <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 5.415">Hom. Od. 5.415</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μήπως μ’ ἐκβαίνοντα βάλῃ λίθακι ποτὶ πέτρῃ | κῦμα μέγ’ ἅρπαξαν</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 20.420">Hom. Il. 20.420</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">λιαζόμενον προτὶ γαίῃ,</quote> </cit> sinking to earth. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 95">Soph. Aj. 95</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς … στρατῷ,</quote> </cit> 97 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρὸς Ἀτρείδαισιν</foreign> are different, since no motion is strictly implied. Here the conjecture <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπὶ</foreign> is metrically admissible (<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 66">Aesch. Ag. 66</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κάμακος θήσων Δαναοῖσι,</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Pers. 48">Aesch. Pers. 48</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φοβερὰν ὄψιν προσιδέσθαἰ,</quote> </cit> but needless. </gloss>

data.quote:
μήπως μ’ ἐκβαίνοντα βάλῃ λίθακι ποτὶ πέτρῃ |
							κῦμα
									μέγ’ ἅρπαξαν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύστην_1303"> harmonises with <foreign xml:lang="grc">σῇ</foreign> (1302) and <foreign xml:lang="grc">φρίκην</foreign> (1306), while <foreign xml:lang="grc">δύσταν’</foreign> would hardly be confirmed by <foreign xml:lang="grc">μακίστων,</foreign> since Tragedy used the latter form, and not <foreign xml:lang="grc">μήκιστος,</foreign> in dialogue also (Aesch. fr. 275: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 289">Aesch. Ag. 289</ref>: so <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Pers. 698">Aesch. Pers. 698</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μακιστῆρἀ.</quote> </cit> The use of Attic forms by the Chorus helps to bring out the more passionate lyric tone which Doricisms lend to the words of Oedipus (1307 f.). Cp. n. on <ref n="Soph. Ant. 804">Soph. Ant. 804 ff.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνερέσθαι_πυθέσθαι_1304">: cp. the questions at 1299 ff., 1327): in its visible presentment it has a fascination (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀθρῆσαι_1304">)even for those whom it fills with horror. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διαπέταται_1310"> (MSS.) is unquestionably corrupt. The view that these are anapaests of the “freer kind ” ( “ex liberioribus, ” Herm.) does not explain a verse which is not anapaestic at all. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διαπωτᾶται_1310"> is far the most probable remedy. The epic <foreign xml:lang="grc"> πωτᾶσθαι,</foreign> which Pind. uses, is admissible in lyrics. When there is no caesura after the 2nd foot, there is usually one in the 3rd: cp. however <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 172">Aesch. PB 172</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καί μ’ οὔ τι μελιγλώσσοις πειθους</quote> </cit>: and <ref n="Aristoph. Birds 536">Aristoph. Birds 536</ref>,<ref n="Aristoph. Peace 1002">Aristoph. Peace 1002</ref>. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1771">Soph. OC 1771</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">διακωλύσω | μεν ἰόντα φόνον.</quote> </cit> The wilder and more rugged effect of such a rhythm makes it preferable here to <foreign xml:lang="grc">φθογγὰ φοράδην διαπωτᾶται,</foreign> though the hiatus before <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰὼ</foreign> (in 1311) would be justified by the pause. To the conjecture </gloss>

data.quote: καί μ’ οὔ τι μελιγλώσσοις πειθους

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέτεται_1310"> (or </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέταται_1310">)it may be objected that the notion of dispersed sounds supports the compound with <foreign xml:lang="grc">διά.</foreign> Hermann simply omitted <foreign xml:lang="grc">διαπέταται,</foreign> dividing thus: <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἰαῖ—| δύστανος—| τλάμων; πᾶ μοι φθογγὰ φοπάδην;</foreign> Bergk, <foreign xml:lang="grc">πᾶ μοι | φθογγά; διά μοι πέταται φοράδην.</foreign> Schneidewin (ed. Nauck) <foreign xml:lang="grc">πᾶ μοι φθογγά; | φοράδην, ὦ δαῖμον, ἐνήλω.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φοράδην_1310"> = “in the manner of that which is carried ”; here correlative to <foreign xml:lang="grc">φέρεσθαι</foreign> as said of things which are <emph>swept onward</emph> by a tide or current: thus, of persons deficient in self-restraint, <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Theaet. 144b">Plat. Theaet. 144b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾄττοντες φέρονται ὥσπερ τὰ ἀνερμάτιστα πλοῖα,</quote> </cit> they are hurried away on currents like boats without ballast: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Crat. 411c">Plat. Crat. 411c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥεῖν καὶ φέρεσθαι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 496d">Plat. Rep. 496d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πνεῦμα φερόμενον.</quote> </cit> He has newly lost the power of seeing those to whom he speaks. He feels as if his voice was <emph>borne from him on the air</emph> in a direction over which he has no control. With the use of the adverb here, cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">βάδην, δρομάδην, σύδην.</foreign> Elsewhere </gloss>

data.quote:
ᾄττοντες φέρονται ὥσπερ τὰ ἀνερμάτιστα
									πλοῖα,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φοράδην_1310_2"> is parallel with <foreign xml:lang="grc">φέρεσθαι</foreign> as = to be carried, instead of walking: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Andr. 1166">Eur. Andr. 1166</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">φοράδην … δῶμα πελάζει,</quote> </cit> i.e. borne in a litter: <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 54.20">Dem. 54.20</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὑγιὴς ἐξελθὼν φοράδην ἦλθον οἴκαδε.</quote> </cit> Such adverbs in <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐δην,</foreign> which were probably accusatives cognate to the notion of the verb, are always formed from the verbal stem, (a) directly, like <foreign xml:lang="grc"> βά‐δην,</foreign> or (b) with modified vowel and inserted <foreign xml:lang="grc">α,</foreign> like <foreign xml:lang="grc">φοράδην</foreign> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">* φερδην, σποράδην</foreign> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">* σπερδην.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξήλου_1311"> In a paroemiac, the foot before the catalectic syllable is usually an anapaest, seldom, as here <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἐξήλ—),</foreign> a spondee: but cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Pers. 33">Aesch. Pers. 33</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵππων τ’ ἐλατὴρ Σωσθανης</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Supp. 7">Aesch. Supp. 7</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ψήφῳ πόλεως γνωσθεῖσαι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Supp. 976">Aesch. Supp. 976</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βάξει λαῶν ἐν χώρῳ</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 366">Aesch. Ag. 366</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">βέλος ἠλίθιον σκήψειεν.</quote> </cit> L and A are of the MSS. which give </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξήλου_1311_2">: and good MS. authority supports <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐνήλου</foreign> in <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 516">Aesch. Pers. 516</ref>,<foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰσαλοίμην</foreign> in Soph. fr. 685, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἥλοντο</foreign> in <ref n="Xen. Hell. 4.4.11">Xen. Hell. 4.4.11</ref>. The evidence, so far as it goes, seems to indicate that, while <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡλάμην</foreign> (itself rare in prose) was preferred in the indicative, a form <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡλόμην</foreign> was also admitted: see Veitch, <title>Irreg. Verbs</title>, ed. of 1879. Blaydes gives </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξήλω_1311">: Elms. gave </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξάλω_1311">, “inaudite <foreign xml:lang="grc">δωρίζων, ”</foreign> in Ellendt's opinion: but Veitch quotes <cit> <bibl>Theocr. 17.100</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξάλατο.</quote> </cit> The imperf. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξήλλου_1311">, which Dindorf, Campbell and others read, was explained by Hermann as = <foreign xml:lang="lat">tendebas</foreign>, i.e. “whither wast thou <emph>purposing to</emph> leap? ” To this I feel two objections: (1) the unfitness of thus representing a swift act: (2) the use of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἵνα,</foreign> which means <emph>where</emph>. This could not be used with the <emph>imperfect of a verb of motion</emph> (as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἵνα ἔβαινε,</foreign> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἷ’,</foreign> but only with the <emph>perfect</emph>, as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἵνα βέβηκε</foreign> (i.e. where <emph>is</emph> he now) or the aorist when equivalent to the perfect: as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 273">Soph. OC 273</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἱκόμην</quote> </cit> (I <emph>have</emph> come) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἵν’ ἱκόμην.</foreign> So, here, the aor. alone seems admissible: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵν_ἐξήλου_1311">, where <emph>hast</emph> thou leaped to, i.e. where <emph>art</emph> thou? cp. 1515 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἵν’ ἐξήκεις,</foreign> and see on 947. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπότροπον_1314"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅ τις ἂν ἀποτρέποιτο</foreign> (Hesych.): and so <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 608">Soph. Aj. 608</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἀπότροπον ἀΐδηλον Ἅιδαν,</quote> </cit> such as all would turn away from, abhorred. Not, “turning away from others,” “solitary,” as <cit> <bibl>Bion Idyll. 2.2</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν ἀπότροπον … Ἔρωτα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπιπλόμενον_1314"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιπελόμενον,</foreign> pres. part., as <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 7.261">Hom. Od. 7.261</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐπιπλόμενον ἔτος ἦλθε.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυσούριστον_1315"> is defective by one syllable as compared with 1323 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τυφλὸν κηδεύων.</foreign> Now the second syllable of <foreign xml:lang="grc">κηδεύων</foreign> is “irrational, ” i.e. it is a long syllable doing metrical duty for a short one (the third of an antibacchius, \h\\h\\v\). Hence in this verse also the penultimate syllable can be either long or short. Hermann's </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυσούριστον_ὄν_1315"> is therefore metrically admissible. It is, however, somewhat weak, and the sound is most unpleasing. I should rather propose </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυσούριστ_ἰόν_1315">: for the adverbial neut. plur., cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑπέροπτα … πορεύεται</foreign> (883, where see note); for the part., <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 873e">Plat. Laws 873e</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παρὰ θεοῦ … βέλος ἰόν.</quote> </cit> Nauck conjectured </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυσοιώνιστον_1315">. Blaydes gives </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δυσεξούριστον_1315">(not found), in the dubious sense of “hard to escape from. ” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κέντρων_1318"> not literally the pins of the brooches, (which we can scarcely suppose that he still carried in his hands,) but the stabs which they had dealt: as piercing pangs are <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">κέντρα,</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 840">Soph. Trach. 840</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_πήμασιν_1319"> when thy woes are so many: cp. 893 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν τοῖσδ’.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πενθεῖν_φέρειν_1320"> The form of the sentence, in dependence on <foreign xml:lang="grc">θαῦμα οὐδέν,</foreign> seems to exclude the version: “It is not strange that, <emph> as</emph> you bear, <emph>so</emph> you should mourn, a double pain ” (parataxis for hypotaxis). Rather the sense is: “that you should <emph> mourn</emph> (aloud) and (inwardly) <emph>suffer</emph> a double pain ” — i.e., the physical pain of the wounds, and the mental pain of retrospect. I do not agree with Schneidewin in referring </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="διπλᾶ_πενθεῖν_1320"> to the double <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἴμοι</foreign> (1316 f.) as = “make a twofold lament.” The </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φέρειν_1320"> of A must be right. <foreign xml:lang="grc">φορεῖν</foreign> can stand for <foreign xml:lang="grc">φέρειν</foreign> “to carry” when habitual carrying is implied (<ref n="Hdt. 3.34">Hdt. 3.34</ref>, and of bearers in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 965">Soph. Trach. 965</ref>): or fig., of mental habit (<cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦθος φορεῖν</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 705">Soph. Ant. 705</bibl> </cit>): but <foreign xml:lang="grc">φορεῖν κακά</foreign> could only mean “to carry ills about with thee ”; which is not appropriate here. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μόνιμος_1322"> steadfast: <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 8.5.11">Xen. Cyrop. 8.5.11</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ μονιμώτατοι πρόσθεν ὄντες</quote> </cit> (said of hoplites). Cp. <ref n="Soph. Aj. 348">Soph. Aj. 348 ff.</ref> where Ajax addresses the Chorus as <foreign xml:lang="grc">μόνοι ἐμῶν φίλων, | μόνοι ἐμμένοντες ἔτ’ ὀρθῷ νόμῳ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σκοτεινός_1326"> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 85">Soph. Aj. 85</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐγὼ σκοτώσω βλέφαρα καὶ δεδορκότα.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="Ἀπόλλων_1329"> The memory of Oedipus (cp. 1318) is connecting the oracle given to him at Delphi (789) with the mandate which afterwards came thence (106). Apollo was the author of the doom (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τελῶν_1329">),but the instrument of execution (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔπαισε_1329">)was the hand of Oedipus. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁ_κακὰ_1330"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> The dochmiac metre is sound (see Metrical Analysis): it is <foreign xml:lang="grc">νομάδος</foreign> in the antistrophe (1350) which is corrupt. Prof. Campbell, however, retaining the latter, here changes the second </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακὰ_1330"> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">κακῶς,</foreign> and the first </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐμὰ_1330"> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμοί.</foreign> The iteration of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάδε_ἐμὰ_1330"> is in a style which the lyrics of tragedy admitted where vehement agitation was expressed. Euripides carried it to excess. But here, at least, it is in place. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νιν_1331"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰς ὄψεις</foreign> (1328). <foreign xml:lang="grc">—οὔτις (ἄλλος),</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_1331">: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 8.311">Hom. Od. 8.311</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀτὰρ οὕ τί μοι αἴτιος ἄλλος | ἀλλὰ τοκῆε δύω.</quote> </cit> Schneid. cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 21.275">Hom. Il. 21.275</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄλλος δ’ οὔτις μοι τόσον αἴτιος οὐρανιώνων | ἀλλὰ</quote> </cit> [instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅσον] φίλη μήτηρ.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
ἀτὰρ οὕ τί μοι αἴτιος ἄλλος | ἀλλὰ τοκῆε
									δύω.

ἄλλος δ’ οὔτις μοι τόσον αἴτιος οὐρανιώνων |
							ἀλλὰ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσήγορον_1337">, passive in <ref n="Soph. Phil. 1353">Soph. Phil. 1353</ref>, is here active, as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 1185">Soph. Ant. 1185</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Παλλάδος θεᾶς | ὅπως ἱκοίμην εὐγμάτων προσήγορος</quote> </cit>.<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡδονᾷ,</foreign> modal dat. adverbially, as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀργῇ</foreign> 405. The form <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡδονάν,</foreign> intermediate between Attic <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡδονήν</foreign> and Doric <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἁδονάν,</foreign> is given by L in <ref n="Soph. El. 1277">Soph. El. 1277</ref>, where Herm. keeps it, but most edd. give <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἁδονάν.</foreign> If right, it was a compromise peculiar to tragedy. The Doricism of scenic lyrics was not thoroughgoing: here, for instance, we have <foreign xml:lang="grc"> τλάμων</foreign> (1333) yet <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσήγορον</foreign> (1338). </gloss>

data.quote:
Παλλάδος θεᾶς | ὅπως ἱκοίμην εὐγμάτων
							προσήγορος

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκτόπιον_1340"> cp. 1411 <foreign xml:lang="grc">θαλάσσιον,</foreign> and see Appendix on v. 478. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ὀλέθριον_1341"> is a certain correction of the MS. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὸν ὀλέθριον μέγαν</foreign> (or <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέγἀ,</foreign> a corruption due to the omission and subsequent marginal insertion of <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέγα.</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 1.158">Hom. Il. 1.158</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ μέγ’ ἀναιδές</quote> </cit>: 16. 46 <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέγα νήπιος</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 419">Soph. Phil. 419</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μέγα | θάλλοντες.</quote> </cit> The antistrophic words are <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτὸς ἔφυν τάλας</foreign> (1363). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀλέθριον_1341">, pass., “lost, ” as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 878">Soph. Trach. 878</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τάλαιν’ ὀλεθρία. τίνι τρόπῳ θανεῖν σφε φής;</quote> </cit> The objections to the conject. </gloss>

data.quote:
τάλαιν’ ὀλεθρία. τίνι τρόπῳ θανεῖν σφε
									φής;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄλεθρον_μέγαν_1341">(metrically admissible as a dochmiac, if the second of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄλεθρον</foreign> is made short) are: (1) the awkward necessity of supplying <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄντα</foreign> in order to defend the position of <foreign xml:lang="grc">μέγαν</foreign>: (2) the phrase <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὄλεθρον,</foreign> which belongs to the colloquial vocabulary of abuse; <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 18.127">Dem. 18.127</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">περίτριμμα ἀγορᾶς, ὄλεθρος γραμματεύς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἂν_1348"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἠθέλησα_γε_1348"> emphasises </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδέ_1348">. Oedipus had been the all-admired (8), the “saviour of the land ” (48). But now the Theban elders wish that they had never so much as heard his name or looked upon his face. That bitter cry is drawn from them by the very strength of their sympathy: for his ruin was the result of his coming to Thebes. The objections to the reading of the MSS., </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥς_ποτε_1348">, are these: (1) <ref n="Eur. Hel. 290">Eur. Hel. 290</ref> has the 1st aor. pass., <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνεγνώσθημεν ἄν,</foreign> “we should have been recognised ”: but <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀναγιγνώσκειν</foreign> occurs nowhere else in tragedy; and in Attic its regular sense was “to read,” or in the 1st aor. act., “to persuade.” I have not found a single example of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀναγιγνώσκω</foreign> as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀναγνωρίζω</foreign> ( “to recognise ”) in Thuc., Plato, Xen., or the Orators. (2) But the 2nd aor. has that sense in Homer, in <ref n="Pind. I. 2.23">Pind. I. 2.23</ref> and in <ref n="Hdt. 2.91">Hdt. 2.91</ref>: may not an Attic poet have followed them? Granted. The sense required here, however, after </gloss>
lemma: ὥς σ’ ἠθέλησα μηδ’ ἀναγνῶναί ποτε

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδέ_1348_2">, is to <emph>know</emph>, not to <emph>recognise</emph>: the latter would be pointless. (3) The ellipse of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄν</foreign> with the aor. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἠθέλησα</foreign> would be strangely harsh. Such an ellipse with the <emph>imperf</emph>. sometimes occurs: as <cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 5.1">Antiph. 5.1</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐβουλόμην</quote> </cit> (and so <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 866">Aristoph. Frogs 866</ref>),<cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 5.86">Antiph. 5.86</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἠξίουν.</quote> </cit> But if, as seems clear, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄν</foreign> is <emph> required</emph> here, then the probability is strengthened that </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀναγνῶναι_1348"> arose from </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἂν_γνῶναι_1348">. Between Dindorf's </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_γνῶναι_1348"> and Hermann's </gloss>
lemma: ὡς ἠθέλησα μηδέ σ’ ἂν γνῶναι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥς_γνῶναι_1348"> the question is: Which is more likely to have passed into the reading of the MSS.? Now they have </gloss>
lemma: ὥς σ’ ἠθέλησα μηδέ γ’ ἂν γνῶναι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὥς_σ_1348">, and the loss of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γ_1348"> through a confusion with the same letter in </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γνῶναι_1348"> is slightly more probable than the double error of omitting </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σ_1348"> before </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἂν_1348_2"> and inserting it after<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νομάδος_1350"> of the MSS. is corrupt. It would require an improbable alteration in the strophe (see on 1330); and it yields no good sense. The Scholiasts hesitated between rendering it (1) “feeding on my flesh ”! or (2) “in the pastures.” Reading </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νομάδ_1350">, we have a dochmiac dimeter, agreeing with 1330: see Metrical Analysis. But the use of the word is extraordinary. It must mean <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν νομαῖς,</foreign> “in the pastures”—said of the babe whom the shepherd had been ordered to expose on Cithaeron. Now elsewhere <foreign xml:lang="grc">νομάς</foreign> always means “<emph> roaming,</emph>” said (e.g.) of pastoral tribes, or of animals: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 271">Soph. Trach. 271</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἵππους νομάδας ἐξιχνοσκοπῶν,</quote> </cit> tracking horse <emph>that had strayed</emph>: fr. 87 <foreign xml:lang="grc">νομὰς δέ τις κεροῦσσ’ ἀπ’ ὀρθίων πάγων | καθεῖρπεν ἔλαφος</foreign>: of waters <emph>wandering</emph> over the land which they irrigate, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 686">Soph. OC 686</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κρῆναι … | Κηφισοῦ νομάδες ῥεέθρων.</quote> </cit> The idea of wandering movement is inseparable from the word. To apply it to a babe whose feet were pinned together would have been indeed a bold use. Prof. Campbell, retaining <foreign xml:lang="grc">νομάδος,</foreign> takes <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέδας</foreign> as acc. plur.: “that loosed the cruel clog upon my feet, <emph>when I was sent astray</emph>.” But could <foreign xml:lang="grc">νομάς</foreign>, ‘roaming, ’ be said of the maimed child merely in the sense of ‘<emph>turned adrift</emph>’ by its parents? The nomin. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νομὰς_1350">, referring to the roving shepherd (<foreign xml:lang="grc">πλάνης</foreign> 1029) would be intelligible; but the quadruple <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ‐ας</foreign> is against it. Now cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Pers. 734">Aesch. Pers. 734</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μονάδα δὲ Ξέρξην ἔρημον,</quote> </cit> “Xerxes alone and forlorn. ” Simply transposing <foreign xml:lang="grc">ν</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">μ</foreign> I conjecture </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μονάδ_1350">, a word appropriate to the complaint that the babe, sent to the lonely mountain, had not been left to perish in its solitude. The fact that the Corinthian shepherd received the child from the Theban is no objection: the child was <foreign xml:lang="grc">φίλων μεμονωμένος,</foreign> desolate and forlorn. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔλυσ_1350">, which suits the dochmiac as well as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔλαβέ μ’,</foreign> is more forcible here. There is a further argument for it. The MSS. give <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπ’ ἀγρίας</foreign> in 1349, but the strophe (1329) shows that <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπ’</foreign> must be omitted, since <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἀπόλλων, φίλοι</foreign> =</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὃς_πέδας_1350">, the first syllable of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγρίας_1350"> being short, as in 1205, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 344">Soph. Ant. 344</ref>, 1124. Now </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέδας_1350"> (i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέδης)</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔλαβε_1350"> ,<emph>took from</emph> the fetter, would be too harsh: we could only do as Schneidewin did, and refer </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπό_1350"> back to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέδας_1350_2">: but though <foreign xml:lang="grc">Δελφῶν κἀπὸ Δαυλίας</foreign> (734) admits of such treatment, the case is dissimilar here. On the other hand </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πέδας_ἔλυσ_1350"> ,<emph>loosed from</emph> the fetter, is correct. Thus the metrical impossibility of </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπ_1350"> confirms </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔλυσ_1350_2">. The epithet <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀγρία,</foreign> “cruel, ” is applied to <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέδη</foreign> as it is to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀδύνη</foreign> in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 975">Soph. Trach. 975</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔρρυτο_1351"> a strong aorist of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥύω,</foreign> formed as if there were a present <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥύμι</foreign>: in <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 18.515">Hom. Il. 18.515</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ῥύατο</quote> </cit> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ῥύντο</foreign> is its 3rd plur. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 5.23">Hom. Il. 5.23</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρυτο σάωσε δέ,</quote> </cit> where the aor. has a like relation to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐρύω</foreign> (the temporal augment being absent). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_χάριν_1351"> see on 1152. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θέλοντι_1356"> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1505">Soph. OC 1505</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποθοῦντι προὐφάνης</quote> </cit> :<ref n="Soph. Trach. 18">Soph. Trach. 18</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 2.3">Thuc. 2.3</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ γὰρ πλήθει … οὐ βουλομένῳ ἦν … ἀφίστασθαι</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Tac. Ag. 18">Tac. Agric. 18</bibl> <quote xml:lang="lat">quibus bellum volentibus erat</quote> </cit> . </gloss>

data.quote:
τῷ γὰρ πλήθει … οὐ βουλομένῳ ἦν …
									ἀφίστασθαι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φονεὺς_ἦλθον_1357"> have come to be the slayer, a compressed phrase for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐς τοσοῦτον ἦλθον ὥστε φονεὺς εἶναι</foreign>: cp. 1519 and <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 752">Soph. Ant. 752</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἦ κἀπαπειλῶν ὦδ’ ἐπεξέρχει θρασύς;</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 1157">Soph. Trach. 1157</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐξήκεις δ’ ἵνα | φανεῖ.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 18.180">Hom. Il. 18.180</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἴ κέν τι νέκυς ᾐσχυμμένος ἔλθῃ,</quote> </cit> <emph>come to be</emph> dishonoured (where some explain, “<emph>reach thee</emph> dishonoured ”): in <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 3.2.3">Xen. Anab. 3.2.3</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅμως δὲ δεῖ ἐκ τῶν παρόντων ἄνδρας ἀγαθοὺς ἐλθεῖν</quote> </cit> (so the MSS.: <foreign xml:lang="grc">τελέθειν</foreign> G. Sauppe) <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ μὴ ὑφίεσθαι,</foreign> the clause <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐκ τῶν παρόντων</foreign> helps <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐλθεῖν</foreign> as = <foreign xml:lang="lat">evadere</foreign>. In 1433 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐλθών</foreign> is not similar. No classical use of <foreign xml:lang="lat">venire</foreign> seems really parallel: thus in <ref>Iuv. 7.29</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">ut dignus venias hederis, venias</foreign> = “may come forward ” (Mayor ad loc.). </gloss>

data.quote: εἴ κέν τι νέκυς ᾐσχυμμένος ἔλθῃ,

ὅμως δὲ δεῖ ἐκ τῶν παρόντων ἄνδρας ἀγαθοὺς
							ἐλθεῖν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀφ_ὧν_1359">, i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταύτης ἀφ’ ἧς</foreign>: plur., as 1095, 1176, 1250. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄθεος_1360"> is a necessary correction of the MS. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄθλιος_1360">, the verse being a dochmiac dimeter, = 1340 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπάγετ’ ἐκτόπιον ὅτι τάχιστά με.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νῦν_1360"> answers to the <emph>short</emph> first syllable of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπάγετ_1360">, since the anacrusis can be either long or short: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Seven 181">Aesch. Seven 181</ref>, where <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἰθερία κόνις</foreign> is metrically parallel to <foreign xml:lang="grc">νῦν δ’ ἄθεος μέν εἰμ’</foreign> here. He is </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνοσίων_1360"> (i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνοσίας) παῖς</foreign> since through him Iocasta became such. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμογενὴς_ἔφυν_1362"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">κοινὸν γένος ἔχων (τούτοις) ἀφ’ ὦν αὐτὸς ἔφυν</foreign>: i.e. having a common brood (one born of the same wife) with those (Laius) from whom he sprang. For the plur., cp. 366: for <foreign xml:lang="grc">(τούτοις) ὧν,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 957">Soph. Phil. 957</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">παρέξω δαῖθ’ ὑφ’ ὦν ἐφερβόμην.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμογενὴς_1362"> is usu. taken as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁμοῦ γεννῶν,</foreign> i.e. “engendering ” <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁμοῦ τῇ τεκούσῃ.</foreign> But <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁμογενής</foreign> is a compound from <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁμο‐</foreign> and the stem of <foreign xml:lang="grc">γένος,</foreign> and could no more mean <foreign xml:lang="grc">γεννῶν ὁμοῦ</foreign> than <foreign xml:lang="grc">συγγενής</foreign> could mean <foreign xml:lang="grc">γεννῶν σὺν,</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐγγενής, γεννῶν ἐν.</foreign> In 460 <foreign xml:lang="grc">πατρὸς ὁμόσπορος</foreign> as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">σπείρων τὴν αὐτὴν ἣν ὁ πατήρ</foreign> is different, since the second part of the compound adj. represents a transitive verb. Meineke's <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁμολεχὴς</foreign> would be better than Musgrave's <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁμόγαμος</foreign>: but neither is needed. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρεσβύτερον_1365"> “older,” then, “ranking before”; here, “more serious ”: <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 5.63">Hdt. 5.63</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὰ γὰρ τοῦ θεοῦ πρεσβύτερα ἐποιεῦντο ἢ τὰ τῶν ἀνδρῶν</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 4.61">Thuc. 4.61</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦτο … πρεσβύτατον … κρίνας, τὸ κοινῶς φοβερὸν ἅπαντας εἶ θέσθαι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τὰ γὰρ τοῦ θεοῦ πρεσβύτερα ἐποιεῦντο ἢ τὰ τῶν
							ἀνδρῶν

τοῦτο … πρεσβύτατον … κρίνας, τὸ κοινῶς
									φοβερὸν ἅπαντας εἶ θέσθαι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρείσσων_ὤν_1368"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">κρεῖσσον ἦν σε μηκέτ’ εἶναι</foreign>: see on 1061. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄν</foreign> is omitted, as after <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔδει, εἰκὸς ἧν,</foreign> etc., <foreign xml:lang="grc">κρείσσων ἦσθα μὴ ὤν</foreign> implying the thought, <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν ἦσθα, εἰ τὰ βέλτιστα ἔπασχες</foreign>: see on 256. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄριστ_1369"> is adverbial, the construction being </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐχ_ὦδε_1369"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(εἰργασμένἀ</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐστὶν_εἰργασμένα_1369">: that, thus done, they are not done best. So <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἄριστα</foreign> is adverb 407, 1046, <ref n="Soph. Aj. 160">Soph. Aj. 160</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βλέπων_1371"> =</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰ_1371"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔβλεπον,</foreign> which is more forcible than to take it with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ποίοις_ὄμμασιν_1371">. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 110">Soph. Phil. 110</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς οὖν βλέπων τις ταῦτα τολμήσει λαλεῖν;</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.37">Hdt. 1.37</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν τε τέοισί με χρὴ ὄμμασι ἔς τε ἀγορὴν καὶ ἐξ ἀγορῆς φοιτέοντα φαίνεσθαι;</quote> </cit> <ref n="Dem. 25.98">Dem. 25.98</ref> (the work of a later rhetorician) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποίοις προσώποις ἢ τίσιν ὀφθαλμοῖς πρὸς ἕκαστον τούτων ἀντιβλέψετε;</foreign> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 462">Soph. Aj. 462</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ ποῖον ὄμμα πατρὶ δηλώσω φανεὶς | Τελαμῶνι;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: πῶς οὖν βλέπων τις ταῦτα τολμήσει λαλεῖν;

καὶ ποῖον ὄμμα πατρὶ δηλώσω φανεὶς |
									Τελαμῶνι;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_Ἅιδου_1372"> Blind on earth, Oed. will be blind in the nether world. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 12.266">Hom. Od. 12.266</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καί μοι ἔπος ἔμπεσε θυμῷ | μάντηος ἀλαοῦ Θηβαίου Τειρεσίαο,</quote> </cit> where Odysseus is thinking of the blind Teiresias as he had found him in Hades. Cp. <ref n="Hom. Od. 11.91">Hom. Od. 11.91</ref>, where <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔγνω</foreign> need not imply that the poet of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">νέκυια</foreign> conceived Teiresias as having sight. So Achilles in Hades is still <emph>swift-footed</emph> (<ref n="Hom. Od. 11.546">Hom. Od. 11.546</ref>). </gloss>

data.quote:
καί μοι ἔπος ἔμπεσε θυμῷ | μάντηος ἀλαοῦ
							Θηβαίου
									Τειρεσίαο,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶν_δυοῖν_1373"> a dative of the persons affected, as, instead of the usual <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποιῶ ταῦτά σε,</foreign> we sometimes find <foreign xml:lang="grc">ποιῶ ταῦτά σοι</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 808">Soph. Trach. 808</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(δρῶσ’)</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 14.289">Hom. Od. 14.289</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τρώκτης, ὃς δὴ πολλὰ κάκ’ ἀνθρώποισιν ἐώργει.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Apol. 30a">Plat. Apol. 30a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα καὶ νεωτέρῳ καὶ πρεσευτέρῳ … ποιήσω, καὶ ξένῳ καὶ ἀστῷ, μᾶλλον δὲ τοῖς ἀστοῖς.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Charm. 157c">Plat. Charm. 157c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν ἔχοιμεν ὅ τι ποιοῖμέν σοι.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Hiero 7.2">Xen. Hiero 7.2</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοιαῦτα γὰρ δὴ ποιοῦσι τοῖς τυράννοις οἱ ἀρχόμενοι καὶ ἄλλον ὅντιν’ ἃν ἀεὶ τιμῶντες τυγχάνωσι.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Wasps 1350">Aristoph. Wasps 1350</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πολλοῖς γὰρ ἤδη χἁτέροις αὔτ’ εἰργάσω.</quote> </cit> In <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 5.8.24">Xen. Anab. 5.8.24</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τούτῳ τάναντία ποιήσετε ἢ τοὺς κύνας ποιοῦσι,</quote> </cit> there is warrant for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦτον</foreign>: and in <cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 16.49">Isoc. 16.49</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲν ἀγαθὸν ποιήσας τῇ πόλει,</quote> </cit> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν πόλιν.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
τρώκτης, ὃς δὴ πολλὰ κάκ’ ἀνθρώποισιν
									ἐώργει.

ταῦτα καὶ νεωτέρῳ καὶ πρεσευτέρῳ … ποιήσω, καὶ
							ξένῳ καὶ ἀστῷ, μᾶλλον δὲ τοῖς ἀστοῖς.
οὐκ ἂν ἔχοιμεν ὅ τι ποιοῖμέν σοι.

τοιαῦτα γὰρ δὴ ποιοῦσι τοῖς τυράννοις οἱ
							ἀρχόμενοι
									καὶ ἄλλον ὅντιν’ ἃν ἀεὶ τιμῶντες τυγχάνωσι.
πολλοῖς γὰρ ἤδη χἁτέροις αὔτ’ εἰργάσω.

τούτῳ τάναντία ποιήσετε ἢ τοὺς κύνας
									ποιοῦσι,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κρείσσον_ἀγχόνης_1374"> not “<emph>worse than</emph> hanging ” (such that, rather than do them, he would have hanged himself): but “<emph>too bad for</emph> hanging ” (such that suicide by hanging would not adequately punish their author). <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hipp. 1217">Eur. Hipp. 1217</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰσορῶσι δὲ | θέαμα κρεῖσσον δεργμάτων ἐφαίνετο,</quote> </cit> <emph>too dreadful</emph> to be looked on: <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 1376">Aesch. Ag. 1376</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὔψος κρεῖσσον ἐκπηδήματος,</quote> </cit> <emph>too high</emph> to be leaped over. </gloss>

data.quote:
εἰσορῶσι δὲ | θέαμα κρεῖσσον δεργμάτων
							ἐφαίνετο,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγχόνης_1374">: cp. <ref n="Eur. Alc. 229">Eur. Alc. 229</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Ach. 125">Aristoph. Ach. 125</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα δῆτ’ οὐκ ἀγχόνη;</quote> </cit> “is not this enough to make one hang oneself? ” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_1375"> introduces (or answers) a supposed objection (the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὑποφορά</foreign> of technical Rhetoric): <cit> <bibl n="Andoc. 1.148">Andoc. 1.148</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίνα γὰρ καὶ ἀναβιβάσομαι δεησόμενον ὑπὲρ ἐμαυτοῦ; τὸν πατέρα; ἀλλὰ τέθνηκεν. ἀλλὰ τοὺς ἀδελφούς; ἀλλ’ οὐκ εἰσίν. ἀλλὰ τοὺς παῖδας; ἀλλ’ οὔπω γεγένηνται.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τίνα γὰρ καὶ ἀναβιβάσομαι δεησόμενον ὑπὲρ
							ἐμαυτοῦ;
									τὸν πατέρα; ἀλλὰ τέθνηκεν. ἀλλὰ τοὺς ἀδελφούς; ἀλλ’ οὐκ εἰσίν.
							ἀλλὰ
									τοὺς παῖδας; ἀλλ’ οὔπω γεγένηνται.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τέκνων_βλαστοῦσα_1375"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁρώμενα τέκνα βλαστόντα</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 967">Eur. Alc. 967</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Θρῄσσαις ἐν σανίσιν τὰς | Ὀρφεία κατέγραψεν γῆρυς,</quote> </cit> which the melodious Orpheus wrote down. </gloss>

data.quote:
Θρῄσσαις ἐν σανίσιν τὰς | Ὀρφεία κατέγραψεν
							γῆρυς,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπως_ἔβλαστε_1375"> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 1011">Eur. Med. 1011</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤγγειλας οἷ’ ἤγγειλας.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πύργος_1378"> the city-wall with its towers and its seven gates (already famous in the <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 11.263">Hom. Od. 11.263</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Θήβης ἕδος ἑπταπύλοιὀ.</quote> </cit> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ba. 170">Eur. Ba. 170</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Κάδμον … ὃς πόλιν Σιδωνίαν | λιπὼν ἐπύργωσ’ ἄστυ Θηβαῖον τόδε.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Hec. 1209">Eur. Hec. 1209</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πέριξ δὲ πύργος εἶχ’ ἔτι πτόλιν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
Κάδμον … ὃς πόλιν Σιδωνίαν | λιπὼν ἐπύργωσ’
							ἄστυ Θηβαῖον τόδε.
πέριξ δὲ πύργος εἶχ’ ἔτι πτόλιν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀγάλμαθ_ἱερά_1379"> the images of the gods in their temples: cp. 20. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῶν_1379"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὧν,</foreign> as <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1086">Soph. Ant. 1086</ref>: cp. 1427. Soph. has this use in many other places of dialogue: see <ref n="Soph. OC 747">Soph. OC 747</ref> n. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κάλλιστ_εἷς_1380"> in connection with a superlative, is strictly correct only where <emph> one</emph> is compared with <emph>several</emph>: as <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 8.40">Thuc. 8.40</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ γὰρ οἰκέται τοῖς Χίοις πολλοὶ ὄντες καὶ μιᾷ γε πόλει πλὴν Λακεδαιμονίων πλεῖστοι γενόμενοι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Heraclid. 8">Eur. Heraclid. 8</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλείστων μετέσχον εἶς ἀνὴρ Ἡρακλέει.</quote> </cit> So <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 460">Soph. Trach. 460</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλείστας ἀνὴρ εἷς … ἔγημε.</quote> </cit> But here, where the question is of degree in nobility, it merely strengthens </gloss>

data.quote:
οἱ γὰρ οἰκέται τοῖς Χίοις πολλοὶ ὄντες καὶ μιᾷ
							γε
									πόλει πλὴν Λακεδαιμονίων πλεῖστοι γενόμενοι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κάλλιστ_1380">: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 8.68">Thuc. 8.68</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πλεῖστα εἶς ἀνήρ, ὅστις ξυμβουλεύσαιτό τι, δυνάμενος ὠφελεῖν</quote> </cit>: which, notwithstanding <foreign xml:lang="grc">πλεῖστα,</foreign> is really like our passage, since we cannot suppose a contrast with the collective wisdom of several advisers. </gloss>

data.quote:
πλεῖστα εἶς ἀνήρ, ὅστις ξυμβουλεύσαιτό τι,
							δυνάμενος ὠφελεῖν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔν_θήβαις_1380"> the </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γε_1380">, by adding a second limitation, helps, like <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἶς ἀνήρ,</foreign> to emphasise the superlative. If the glories of Thebes can rejoice the sight, no <emph>Theban</emph> at least had a better right to that joy: (and who could have a better right than Thebans?) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπεστέρησ_ἐμαυτόν_1381"> a regular phrase in reference to separation from civic life: <cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 5.78">Antiph. 5.78</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δ’ ἐν Αἴνῳ χωροφιλεῖ, τοῦτο οὐκ ἀποστερῶν γε τῶν εἰς τὴν πόλιν ἑαυτὸν οὐδενὸς</quote> </cit> (not forfeiting any of his relations with Athens) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδ’ ἑτέρας πόλεως πολίτης γεγενημένος</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Dem. 13.22">Dem. 13.22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδενὸς ἔργων τῶν τότε ἀπεστέρησαν ἑαυτούς,</quote> </cit> the Athenians of those days did not renounce their share in any of the great deeds of the Persian Wars. </gloss>

data.quote:
εἰ δ’ ἐν Αἴνῳ χωροφιλεῖ, τοῦτο οὐκ ἀποστερῶν
							γε
									τῶν εἰς τὴν πόλιν ἑαυτὸν οὐδενὸς

οὐδενὸς ἔργων τῶν τότε ἀπεστέρησαν
									ἑαυτούς,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_ἀσεβῆ_1382"> naturally depends on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὠθεῖν_1382">. But, if so, it would be very awkward to take </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_φανέντα_1382"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀπεστέρησ’ ἐμαυτόν.</foreign> Rather </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸν_φανέντα_1382_2"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> also depends on </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὠθεῖν_1382_2">. “Bidding all to expel the impious one, —that man who has <emph>[since]</emph> been shown by the gods to be unholy—and of the race of Laius. ” His thought passes from the <emph>unknown</emph> person of the edict to <emph> himself</emph>, precisely as in 1440 f. The words </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_Λαΐου_1382"> are a climax, since the guilt of bloodshed, which the oracle had first denounced, was thus aggravated by a double horror. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κηλῖδα_1384"> see on 833: </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηνύσας_1384"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμήν,</foreign> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὖσαν.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀρθοῖς_1385"> see on 528. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_πηγῆς_1386"> the <emph>source</emph> (viz. the orifice of the ear) from which sounds flow in upon the sense: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedrus 245c">Plat. Phaedrus 245c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ψυχή … πηγὴ καὶ ἀρχὴ κινήσεως.</quote> </cit> (Not the <emph>stream</emph> of sound itself.) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δῑ_ὤτων_1386"> supplements <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῆς ἀκουούσης πηγῆς</foreign> by suggesting the channel through which the sounds pass from the fount. Cp. fr. 773 <foreign xml:lang="grc">βραδεῖα μὲν γὰρ ἐν λόγοισι προσβολὴ | μόλις δῑ ὠτὸς ἔρχεται τρυπωμένου. ἡ ἀκούουσα πηγή,</foreign> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ πηγὴ τῆς ἀκούσεως,</foreign> is said with a consciousness that <foreign xml:lang="grc">πηγή</foreign> means the organ of hearing, just as we might have <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ ἀκούοντα ὦτα.</foreign> Seneca paraphrases: <foreign xml:lang="lat">utinam quidem rescindere has quirem vias, Manibusque adactis omne qua voces meant Aditusque verbis tramite angusto patet, Eruere possem, gnata: … aures ingerunt, quicquid mihi Donastis, oculi</foreign> (<ref>Sen. Oed. 226 ff.</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐσχόμην_1387"> usu. in this sense with gen., as <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 4.422">Hom. Od. 4.422</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σχέσθαι … βίης.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_μή_1388"> cp. 1232. The simple <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή,</foreign> where (as here) <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ οὐ</foreign> is admissible, occurs also in prose, as <cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 4.2.4">Antiph. 4.2.4</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδεὶς ἡμῖν λόγος ὑπελείπετο μὴ φονεῦσιν εἶναι.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐδεὶς ἡμῖν λόγος ὑπελείπετο μὴ φονεῦσιν
									εἶναι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵν_ἦ_1389"> For </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἦ_1389"> (as 1393) see on 1123. The negative </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδέν_1389"> here shows how in this construction </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵνα_1389"> is essentially final, “so that I might have been ”; not = “in which case I should have been ”—for which the negative must have been <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδέν.</foreign> So <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἔδειξα μήποτε</foreign> (1392), that I might never have shown. Eur. fr. 442 <foreign xml:lang="grc">φεῦ φεῦ τὸ μὴ τὰ πράγματ’ ἀνθρώποις ἔχειν | φωνήν, ἵν’ ἦσαν μηδὲν οἱ δεινοὶ λόγοι.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔξω_κακῶν_1390"> i.e. undisturbed by those sights and sounds from the outer world which serve to recall past miseries. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐδέχου_1391"> helps the personification: “wast ready to shelter me. ” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_ἔδειξα_1392"> see on 1389, and cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 776">Aesch. PB 776</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί … οὐκ ἐν τάχει | ἔρριψ’ ἐμαυτήν … ὅπως πέδῳ σκήψασα τῶν πάντων πόνων | ἀπηλλάγην;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τί … οὐκ ἐν τάχει | ἔρριψ’ ἐμαυτήν … ὅπως
									πέδῳ σκήψασα τῶν πάντων πόνων | ἀπηλλάγην;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_λόγῳ_1394"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ λόγῳ πάτρια,</foreign> an order the less harsh since <foreign xml:lang="grc">πάτρια</foreign> (= of my <emph> fathers</emph>, not <foreign xml:lang="grc">πατρῷα,</foreign> of my <emph> father</emph>) is supplemented by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="παλαιά_1394">. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 635">Soph. Aj. 635</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ νοσῶν μάταν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 792">Soph. El. 792</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῦ θανόντος ἀρτίως</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 1013">Aesch. PB 1013</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ φρονοῦντι μὴ καλῶς</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Med. 874">Eur. Med. 874</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τοῖσι βουλεύουσιν εὖ.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κάλλος_ὕπουλον_1396"> a fair surface, with secret ills festering beneath it (gen. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κακῶν_1396"> as after words of fulness, = <foreign xml:lang="grc">κρυπτῶν κακῶν γέμον)</foreign>: because he had seemed most prosperous (775), while the doom decreed from his birth was secretly maturing itself with his growth. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κάλλος_1396"> concrete, a fair object, <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 5.2.7">Xen. Cyrop. 5.2.7</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὴν θυγατέρα, δεινόν τι καλλος καὶ μέγεθος, πενθικῶς δ’ ἔχουσαν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
τὴν θυγατέρα, δεινόν τι καλλος καὶ μέγεθος,
							πενθικῶς δ’ ἔχουσαν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὕπουλον_1396"> of a sore festering beneath an <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐλή</foreign> or scar which looks as if the wound had healed: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Gorg. 480b">Plat.
