Gorg. 480b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως μὴ ἐγχρονισθὲν τὸ νόσημα τῆς ἀδικίας ὕπουλον τὴν ψυχὴν ποιήσει καὶ ἀνίατον,</quote> </cit> “lest the disease of injustice become chronic, and render his soul <emph> gangrenous</emph> and past cure ” (Thompson). <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 8.64">Thuc. 8.64</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὕπουλον αὐτονομίαν,</quote> </cit> <emph> unsound</emph> independence opp. to <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν ἄντικρυς ἐλευθερίαν.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 18.307">Dem. 18.307</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡσυχίαν ἄγειν ἄδικον καὶ ὕπουλον,</quote> </cit> unjust and <emph>insecure</emph> peace. <cit> <bibl>Eustath. Od. 1496.35</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Σοφοκλῆς … λέγεται … ὕπουλον εἰπεῖν τὸν δούρειον ἵππον,</quote> </cit> the wooden horse at Troy, as concealing foes. </gloss>

data.quote:
ὅπως μὴ ἐγχρονισθὲν τὸ νόσημα τῆς ἀδικίας
							ὕπουλον
									τὴν ψυχὴν ποιήσει καὶ ἀνίατον,

Σοφοκλῆς … λέγεται … ὕπουλον εἰπεῖν τὸν
							δούρειον ἵππον,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κἀκ_κακῶν_1397"> like <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνοσίων παῖς</foreign> (1360), with reference to the stain incurred by Iocasta. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τρεῖς_νάπη_1398">):then, descending, he comes to a coppice (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δρυμός_1398">)at a point where his own road narrows (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="στενωπός_1398">)just before its junction with the two others (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐν_ὁδοῖς_1398">).See on 733. The genuineness of v. 1399 has been groundlessly questioned, on the score of supposed tautology. The language may be compared with that of the verses from the <title>Oedipus</title> of Aeschylus (fr. 167), quoted in the Introduction. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοὐμὸν_αἷμα_1400"> thus divided from </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατρός_1400">, is more than <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἷμα τοὐμοῦ πατρός</foreign>: “the same blood which flows in my own veins—the blood of my father. ” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τι_1401">, which has a tone of bitterness here, see on 124, 969. The <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅτι</foreign> of the MSS. must be explained in one of two ways: —(1) as if the construction was irregularly changed by </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶα_ὁποῖα_1401">: but the immediate succession of <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶα</foreign> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅτι</foreign> makes this intolerably harsh: or (2) as if </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶα_ὁποῖα_1401_2"> were exclamatory substitutes for <foreign xml:lang="grc">δεινά</foreign> or the like: which seems inadmissible. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀνεῖτε_σπέρμα_1405a"> By the change of one letter, we restore sense to the passage. The </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταὐτὸν_1405a"> of the MSS. is unintelligible. Oedipus was the </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σπέρμα_1405a"> of Laius and Iocasta. When Iocasta weds Oedipus, the marriage cannot be said <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνιέναι ταὐτὸν σπέρμα</foreign>: for it is absurd to suppose that <emph>the seed sown by Oedipus</emph> could be identified with <emph>Oedipus himself</emph>. But the marriage can be rightly said <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνιέναι ταὐτοῦ σπέρμα,</foreign> to yield seed <emph>from the same man</emph> (Oedipus) whom that womb had borne. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπεδείξατε_1405">)Oedipus at once <emph>father and brother</emph> (of his children), while he was also <emph>son</emph> (of his wife), … the closest relation in <emph> blood</emph> (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἶμ_ἐμφύλιον_1405">)becoming also the <emph>husband</emph>. The marriage made Iocasta the <emph>bride</emph> (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="νύμφας_1405">) … aye, and the child-bearing <emph>wife</emph> (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γυναῖκας_1405">),—of him to whom she was also <emph>mother</emph> (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μητέρας_1405">).Thus, through the birth of children from such a marriage, complex horrors of relationship arose (</gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁπόσα_αἶμἐμφύλιον_1405"> is in apposition with </gloss>
lemma:
ὁπόσα αἴσχιστα ἔργα γίγνεταἰ. αἶμ’
									ἐμφύλιον

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατέρας_παῖδας_1405">,— “a blood-kinship” standing for “a blood-kinsman.” It expresses that the monstrous union confounded the closest tie of <emph>consanguinity</emph> with the closest tie of <emph>affinity</emph>. The phrase <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμφύλιον αἷμα,</foreign> like <foreign xml:lang="grc">συγγενὲς αἶμα,</foreign> would in Tragedy more often mean “murder of a kinsman.” But it can, of course, mean also “kindred blood” in another sense; and here the context leaves no ambiguity. Cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1671">Soph. OC 1671</ref> (n.) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔμφυτον αἷμα,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 246">Eur. Phoen. 246</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κοινὸν αἷμα, κοινὰ τέκεα | τῆς κερασφόρου πέφυκεν Ἰοῦς.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
κοινὸν αἷμα, κοινὰ τέκεα | τῆς κερασφόρου
							πέφυκεν
									Ἰοῦς.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔξω_καλύψατ_1410"> the blind man asks that they will lead him away from Thebes, and <emph> hide</emph> him from the sight of men in some lonely spot—as amid the wilds of Cithaeron (1451). We must not transpose </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καλύψατ_1410"> and </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐκρίψατ_1410">, as is done in Schneidewin's ed. (as revised by Nauck), after Burges. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θαλάσσιον_1411"> cp. Appendix, note on v. 478. Cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 119">Soph. OC 119</ref> n. - </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔνθα_μή_1411"> with fut. indic., as <ref n="Soph. Aj. 659">Soph. Aj. 659</ref>,<ref n="Soph. El. 380">Soph. El. 380</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Trach. 800">Soph. Trach. 800</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧν_δέον_1416"> = seasonably in respect of those things which (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὧν_1416"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">τούτων ἅ)</foreign> you ask. For the gen. of relation cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Hell. 6.2.9">Xen. Hell. 6.2.9</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κεῖσθαι τὴν Κέρκυραν ἐν καλῷ μὲν τοῦ Κορινθιακοῦ κόλπου καὶ τῶν πόλεων αἳ ἐπὶ τοῦτον καθήκουσιν</quote> </cit> ( “conveniently in respect to ”), <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν καλῷ δὲ τοῦ τὴν Λακωνικὴν χώραν βλάπτειν</foreign>. </gloss>

data.quote:
κεῖσθαι τὴν Κέρκυραν ἐν καλῷ μὲν τοῦ
							Κορινθιακοῦ
									κόλπου καὶ τῶν πόλεων αἳ ἐπὶ τοῦτον καθήκουσιν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_βουλεύειν_1416"> are strictly accusatives of respect, “as to the doing and the planning, ” i.e. with a view to doing and planning. So <ref n="Soph. Ant. 79">Soph. Ant. 79</ref>,<ref n="Soph. El. 1030">Soph. El. 1030</ref>,<ref n="Soph. OC 442">Soph. OC 442</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Phil. 1253">Soph. Phil. 1253</ref>, etc. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μοῦνος_1418"> see on 304. Kuhlstadt (<title>De Dial. Trag.</title> 104) thinks that Soph. never uses <foreign xml:lang="grc">μοῦνος</foreign> for <foreign xml:lang="grc">μόνος</foreign> unless with some special emphasis: but, as Ellendt remarks, such instances as <ref n="Soph. OC 875, 991">Soph. OC 875, 991</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 705">Soph. Ant. 705</ref>, fr. 434 refute that view. Rather it was a simple question of metrical convenience. The same is true of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξεῖνος</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξένος,</foreign> with this exception, that, even where metre admitted <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξέν’, ξεῖν’</foreign> occurs as the <emph>first</emph> word of an address: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IT 798">Eur. IT 798</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ξεῖν’, οὐ δικαίως.</quote> </cit> In <ref n="Soph. OC 928">Soph. OC 928</ref> also, L and A give <foreign xml:lang="grc">ξεῖνον παρ’ ἀστοῖς.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίς_ἔνδικος_1420"> “<emph>what reasonable claim to confidence</emph> can be produced on my part?” Oedipus had brought a charge against Creon which was false, and had repudiated a charge against himself which was true. He means: — “How can I expect Creon to believe me now, when I represent myself as the blind victim of fate, —when I crave his sympathy and pity? ” <foreign xml:lang="grc">πίστις</foreign> has two main senses, each of which has several shades, —(1) <emph>faith</emph>, and (2) <emph>a warrant for faith</emph>. Here it is (2) essentially as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1632">Soph. OC 1632</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δός μοι χερὸς σῆς πίστιν.</quote> </cit> Not “a persuasive argument” in the technical sense of Rhetoric, for which <foreign xml:lang="grc">πίστεις</foreign> were “instruments of persuasion,” whether <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔντεχνοι,</foreign> provided by the Art itself <foreign xml:lang="grc">(λογική, παθητική, ἠθικἤ,</foreign> or <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄτεχνοι,</foreign> external to the art, as depositions, documents, etc. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πάντ_1421"> see on 475. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιόνδ_ἄγος_1424"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> as inconsistent with the profession which Creon has just made. Rather may we consider them as showing a kinsman's anxious and delicate concern for the honour of Oedipus and of the house (1430). Creon, deeply moved, deprecates the prolonged indulgence of a painful curiosity (cp. 1304). It is again Creon who says <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἴθι στέγης ἔσω</foreign> (1515) when Oedipus would fain linger. Clearly, then, these verses are rightly placed in the MSS. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βόσκουσαν_1425"> boldly for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τρέφουσαν</foreign>: cp. <ref n="Aesch. Ag. 633">Aesch. Ag. 633</ref>, where the sun is <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦ τρέφοντος … χθονὸς φύσιν.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δεικνύναι_1427"> depends on </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἰδεῖσθε_1427">, for the constr. of which with (1) acc. of persons revered, and (2) infin. of act which such reverence forbids, cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 2.3.22">Xen. Anab. 2.3.22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾐσχύνθημεν καὶ θεοὺς καὶ ἀνθρώπους προδοῦναι αὐτόν,</quote> </cit> “respect for gods and for men forbade us to betray him. ” </gloss>

data.quote:
ᾐσχύνθημεν καὶ θεοὺς καὶ ἀνθρώπους προδοῦναι
							αὐτόν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὸ_1427"> (=<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὅ,</foreign> see on 1379) </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μήτε_1427">, not <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔτε,</foreign> since <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοιόνδ’ ἄγος</foreign> indicates a <emph>class</emph> of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄγη</foreign>: not merely “<emph>which</emph>, ” but “<emph>such as</emph>, ” “earth will not welcome ” (<foreign xml:lang="lat"> <emph>quod Terra non</emph> admissura sit</foreign>): cp. 817, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 654">Soph. El. 654</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅσων ἐμοὶ | δύσνοια μὴ πρόσεστιν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γῆὄμβροςφῶς_1427">. The pollution <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἄγος)</foreign> of Oedipus is such that the pure elemental powers—represented by <emph>earth</emph>, the <emph>rain</emph> from heaven, the <emph>light</emph>— cannot suffer it to remain in their presence (</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσδέξεται_1427">):it must be hidden from them. Cp. <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 904">Aesch. Eum. 904 ff.</ref>, where the Erinyes, as Chthonian powers, invoke blessings on Attica, <foreign xml:lang="grc">γῆθεν—ἔκ τε ποντίας δρόσου—ἐξ οὐρανοῦ τε.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄμβρος_1427"> here is not a <emph>synonym</emph> but a <emph>symbol</emph> of water generally, as with Empedocles 282 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὣς τότ’ ἔπειτ’ ἐδίηνε Κύπρις χθόνα δηρὸν ἐν ὄμβρῳ | εἴδεα καὶ ποιοῦσα θοῷ πυρὶ δῶκε κρατῦναι</foreign>: cp. <ref>Lucr. 1.714 f.</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">quattuor ex rebus posse omnia rentur Ex igni terra atque anima procrescere et imbri.</foreign> In <ref n="Soph. Ant. 1073">Soph. Ant. 1073</ref> the exposure of the unburied corpse is spoken of as a <emph> violence</emph> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἱ ἄνω θεοί (βιάζονταἰ.</foreign> It was a common form of oath to pray that, if a man swore falsely, neither earth, nor sea, nor air, might tolerate the presence of his corpse (<ref n="Eur. Orest. 1085">Eur. Orest. 1085</ref>,<ref n="Eur. Hipp. 1030">Eur. Hipp. 1030</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἱερός_1428">, “strong ” (<ref>Curt. Etym. 614</ref>), suits a few phrases, such as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱερὸς ἰχθύς</foreign> (<ref n="Hom. Il. 16.407">Hom. Il. 16.407</ref>). But in such as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱερὸν ἦμαρ, κνέφας, ὄμβρος, ποταμοί</foreign> etc. it is more likely that the poet had no consciousness of any other sense than “sacred. ” </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μάλιστα_1430"> with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖς_γένει_1430"> is not that it follows these words (see on 1394), but that </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τἀγγενῆ_1430"> intervenes. Rather join it with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐσεβῶς_ἔχει_1430"> .<foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁρᾶν μόνοις τ’ ἀκούειν</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">μόνοις ὁρᾶν ἀκούειν τε.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐλπίδος_ἀπέσπασας_1432"> suddenly plucked me away from (made me to abandon) my uneasy foreboding: cp. Lat. <foreign xml:lang="lat">revellere</foreign> (<foreign xml:lang="lat">falsorum persuasionem</foreign>,<ref>Sen. Letter 95</ref>), and our phrase, “a revulsion of feeling ”: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1382">Soph. Aj. 1382</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὥς μ’ ἔψευσας ἐλπίδος πολύ.</quote> </cit> Conversely (<ref n="Soph. El. 809">Soph. El. 809</ref>)<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀποσπάσας … φρενὸς | αἵ μοι μόναι παρῆσαν ἐλπίδων.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄριστος_ἐμέ_1433"> having come to me in so noble a spirit; cp. 1422 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐλήλυθα.</foreign> This is more natural than to render, “having proved thyself most noble towards me ” (see on 1357). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πρὸς_σοῦ_1434"> in thy interest: <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Alc. 58">Eur. Alc. 58</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς τῶν ἐχόντων, Φοῖβε, τὸν νόμον τίθης</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 479">Soph. Trach. 479</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δεῖ γὰρ καὶ τὸ πρὸς κείνου λέγειν,</quote> </cit> the argument on his side. </gloss>

data.quote: πρὸς τῶν ἐχόντων, Φοῖβε, τὸν νόμον τίθης
δεῖ γὰρ καὶ τὸ πρὸς κείνου λέγειν,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χρείας_1435"> request: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1754">Soph. OC 1754</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προσπίτνομέν σοι. ΘΗ. τίνος, ὦ παῖδες, χρείας ἀνύσαι;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
προσπίτνομέν σοι. ΘΗ. τίνος, ὦ παῖδες, χρείας
							ἀνύσαι;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδενὸς_προσήγορος_1437"> accosted by no one: for the gen., cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1214">Soph. El. 1214</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὕτως ἄτιμός εἰμι τοῦ τεθνηκότος;</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 344">Soph. El. 344</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κείνης διδακτά.</quote> </cit> With dat. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 1353">Soph. Phil. 1353</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ προσήγορος;</quote> </cit> see on 1337: for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅπου μή</foreign> with fut. indic., on 1412. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄν_1438">, cp. 139. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτ_1438"> depends on <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἴσθι,</foreign> not <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔδρασα.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φάτις_1440"> (151), the message brought by Creon from Delphi (86); </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πᾶσ_1440">, “in full, ” explicitly: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 275">Soph. Aj. 275</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κεῖνος … λύπῃ πᾶς ἐλήλαται.</quote> </cit> The indefinite person of the <foreign xml:lang="grc">φάτις</foreign> is identified with Oedipus just as in 1382 f. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπολλύναι_1441"> could refer either to misery in exile (1436), or to death: cp. 100. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 252">Soph. Phil. 252</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">διωλλύμην.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἵνα_χρείας_1442"> see 367. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὕτως_1444"> with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀθλίου_1444"> :<cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 104">Soph. Phil. 104</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὕτως ἔχει τι δεινὸν ἰσχύος θράσος;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: οὕτως ἔχει τι δεινὸν ἰσχύος θράσος;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_1445"> belongs to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σύ_1445">: “even thou ” who didst not believe Teiresias. This is not spoken in mockery, but with grave sorrow. The phrase </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πίστιν_φέροις_1445"> as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">πιστεύοις</foreign> (<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 735">Soph. El. 735</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῷ τέλει πίστιν φέρων)</quote> </cit> prob. = “<emph>render</emph> belief” (as a tribute due), cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">φόρον, δασμόν, χρήματα φέρειν,</foreign> and the like figure in <cit> <bibl n="Pind. O. 11.17">Pind. O. 11.17</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νικῶν | Ἴλᾳ φερέτω χάριν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καὶ_γ_1446"> yes [I <emph>am</emph> prepared to abide by Apollo's word], and on <emph> thee</emph> too I lay an injunction, and I will now make a prayer to thee; i.e. as I turn to the god for what he alone can give (cp. 1519 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦ θεοῦ μ’ αἰτεῖς δόσιν),</foreign> so I turn to <emph> thee</emph> for that which lies in thine own power. The midd. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προστρέψομαι_1446"> as in fr. 759 <foreign xml:lang="grc">Ἐργάνην</foreign> (Athene) <foreign xml:lang="grc"> … προστρέπεσθε</foreign>: the active has the same sense in <ref n="Soph. Aj. 831">Soph. Aj. 831</ref>,<ref n="Soph. OC 50">Soph. OC 50</ref>. On the future, see 1077. There is no cause to desire <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπισκήψω</foreign>: each tense has its due force: I now enjoin, and am going on to ask. Just so in <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 2.44">Thuc. 2.44</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ὀλοφύρομαι μᾶλλον ἢ παραμυθήσομαι,</quote> </cit> where the conjecture <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀλοφυροῦμαι</foreign> is needless: “I <emph>do not</emph> bewail them, but rather <emph>intend to</emph> comfort them. ” The reading </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προτρέψομαι_1446"> must be judged by the context. With it, the sense is: —yes <emph>[I</emph> am sensible of my duty to Apollo], and I enjoin on <emph>thee</emph>, and will <emph>exhort</emph> thee, to do thine. (Cp. 358 <foreign xml:lang="grc">προὐτρέψω;</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 711b">Plat. Laws 711b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρὸς ἀρετῆς ἐπιτηδεύματα προτρέπεσθαι τοὺς πολίτας.)</quote> </cit> But this strain of lofty admonition seems little in accord with the tone of the broken man who has just acknowledged Creon's unexpected goodness (1432), and is now a suppliant (cp. 1468). In <ref n="Soph. Aj. 831">Soph. Aj. 831</ref> and <ref n="Soph. OC 50">Soph. OC 50</ref>, where <foreign xml:lang="grc">προστρέπω</foreign> is undoubtedly right, <foreign xml:lang="grc">προτρέπω</foreign> occurs as a variant. </gloss>

data.quote:
πρὸς ἀρετῆς ἐπιτηδεύματα προτρέπεσθαι τοὺς
							πολίτας.)

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆς_οἴκους_1447"> the <emph>name</emph> of Iocasta has not been uttered since 1235. Contrast 950. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τελεῖς_1448"> absol., like <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔρδειν,</foreign> perform rites, i.e. the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐντάφια</foreign> (<ref n="Isaeus 8.38">Isaeus 8.38</ref>). The special term for offerings to the dead was <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐναγίζειν</foreign> (<ref n="Isaeus 3.46">Isaeus 3.46</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀξιωθήτω_1449"> <emph>be condemned</emph>:<cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 3.145">Hdt. 3.145</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐμὲ μέν, ὦ κάκιστε ἀνδρῶν, … ἀδικήσαντα οὐδὲν ἄξιον δεσμοῦ γοργύρης ἠξίωσας,</quote> </cit> <emph> doomed</emph> me to a dungeon though I had done no wrong <emph>worthy</emph> of bonds. </gloss>

data.quote:
ἐμὲ μέν, ὦ κάκιστε ἀνδρῶν, … ἀδικήσαντα οὐδὲν
							ἄξιον δεσμοῦ γοργύρης ἠξίωσας,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔα_1451"> a monosyllable by synizesis, and in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 95">Soph. Ant. 95</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἀλλ’ ἔα με.</quote> </cit> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 9.283">Hom. Od. 9.283</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νέα μέν μοι κατέαξε Ποσειδάων ἐνοσίχθων.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: νέα μέν μοι κατέαξε Ποσειδάων ἐνοσίχθων.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὄρεσιν_1451"> locative dative, cp. <foreign xml:lang="grc">γῇ,</foreign> 1266.<foreign xml:lang="grc">—ἔνθα κλῄζεται κ.τ.λ.,</foreign> lit., “where my Cithaeron yonder is famed,” = “where yonder is Cithaeron, famed as mine,” —i.e. made famous by the recent discovery that it is <foreign xml:lang="grc">Οἰδίπου τροφὸς καὶ μήτηρ</foreign> (1092). There is an intense bitterness in the words; the name of Cithaeron is for ever to be linked with his dark story. Statius (quoted by Schneidewin) was doubtless thinking of this place: <foreign xml:lang="lat">habeant te lustra tuusque Cithaeron</foreign> (<ref>Stat. Theb. 11.752</ref>).<foreign xml:lang="grc">κλῄζεται</foreign> is stronger than <foreign xml:lang="grc">καλεῖται,</foreign> as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 659">Soph. Trach. 659</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔνθα κλῄζεται θυτήρ</quote> </cit> means, “where <emph>fame</emph> (that brought the tidings of his great victory) tells of him as sacrificing. ” For the idiom cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 11.757">Hom. Il. 11.757</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">Ἀλεισίου ἔνθα κολώνη | κέκληται.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξ_ἐκείνων_1453"> form the decisive argument for the </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζῶντε_1453"> of the MSS. against Toup's specious emendation, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζῶντι_1453">. His parents in <emph>their life-time</emph> appointed Cithaeron to be his grave. Now they are dead; but, though he can no longer die by their <emph> agency</emph>, he wishes to die <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξ ἐκείνων,</foreign> <emph>by their doom</emph>; i.e. by selfexposure in the same wilds to which they had consigned him (cp. 719 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔρριψεν ἄλλων χερσὶν εἰς ἄβατον ὄρος).</foreign> The thought of the <emph>dead</emph> bringing death upon the living is one which Sophocles has also in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1026">Soph. Aj. 1026</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἶδες ὡς χρόνῳ | ἔμελλέ σ’ Ἕκτωρ καὶ θανὼν ἀποφθιεῖν;</quote> </cit> <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1163">Soph. Trach. 1163</ref> (Heracles speaking of Nessus) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ζῶντά μ’ ἔκτεινεν θανών</foreign>:<ref n="Soph. Ant. 871">Soph. Ant. 871</ref>. The reading </gloss>

data.quote:
εἶδες ὡς χρόνῳ | ἔμελλέ σ’ Ἕκτωρ καὶ θανὼν
							ἀποφθιεῖν;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζῶντι_1453_2">, on the other hand, yields nothing but a weak verbal antithesis with </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τάφον_1453">. Had his parents meant him to <emph>live</emph> in lonely misery on Cithaeron, there would be some point in calling it his “living grave. ” But they meant him to die there forthwith (cp. 1174); <foreign xml:lang="grc">ζῶντι,</foreign> then, would mean nothing more than that the grave was chosen before the babe was dead. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κύριον_1453"> appointed by their authoritative decision: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Eum. 541">Aesch. Eum. 541</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ποινὰ γὰρ ἐπέσται· | κύριον μένει τέλος.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: ποινὰ γὰρ ἐπέσται· | κύριον μένει τέλος.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀπωλλύτην_1454"> for the imperf. of intention, cp. <cit> <bibl n="Andoc. 1.41">Andoc. 1.41</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τὸν πατέρα μου ἀπώλλυε</quote> </cit> ( “<emph>sought</emph> to ruin ”), <foreign xml:lang="grc">συνειδότα ἀποφαίνων.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶδα_πέρσαι_1455"> = “I am confident that nothing can destroy me ” <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή</foreign> is admissible since <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶδα</foreign> here = <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέποιθα,</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">μὴ ἂν πέρσαι</foreign> represents a negative conception of the mind. So with partic. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 656">Soph. OC 656</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶδ’ ἐγώ σε μή τινα | ἐνθένδ’ ἀπάξοντ’. οἶδα οὐκ ἂν πέρσαι</quote> </cit> would be more usual; the difference being that this would be the oblique form of <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶδα ὅτι οὐκ ἂν πέρσειε.</foreign> The ordinary usage is (1) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ</foreign> with infin. (=<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὅτι</foreign> with indic.) after verbs of saying or thinking, <foreign xml:lang="grc">λέγω, φημί, οἴομαι,</foreign> etc; (2) <foreign xml:lang="grc">μή</foreign> with infin. after verbs of feeling confident, promising, etc., as <foreign xml:lang="grc">πιστεύω, πέποιθα, ὑπισχνοῦμαι, ὄμνυμι.</foreign> But a few exceptions occur both ways, when a verb of either class is virtually equivalent to a verb of the other: e.g. (1) <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 29.48">Dem. 29.48</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἴεσθε οὐκ ἂν αὐτὴν λαβεῖν (</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὅτι οὐκ ἂν ἔλαβεν αὐτήν),</foreign> but <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Mem. 1.2.41">Xen. Mem. 1.2.41</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἶμαι</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
οἶδ’ ἐγώ σε μή τινα | ἐνθένδ’ ἀπάξοντ’. οἶδα
							οὐκ
									ἂν πέρσαι

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_1455"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἂν δικαίως τυχεῖν τούτου τοῦ ἐπαίνου τὸν μὴ εἰδότα</foreign>: (2) <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Prot. 336b">Plat. Prot. 336b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁμολογεῖ</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μὴ_1455_2"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">μετεῖναί οἱ μακρολογίας,</foreign> but <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Apol. 17a">Plat. Apol. 17a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁμολογοίην ἂν ἔγωγε</quote> </cit> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὐ_1455"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατὰ τούτους εἶναι ῥήτωρ.</foreign> Cp. Whitelaw in <title>Trans. Cam. Phil. Soc.</title> (1886) p. 34, and Gildersleeve in <title>Amer. Fourn. Philol.</title> 1.49. —Whitelaw here takes <foreign xml:lang="grc">πέρσαι ἄν</foreign> as = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔπερσεν ἄν,</foreign> and reads <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῷ</foreign> (not <foreign xml:lang="grc">τᾠ δεινῷ κακῷ</foreign>: “my parents wished to kill me; but nothing could have killed me; I was reserved for <emph>this</emph> dread evil. ” Surely, however, it is better to connect the verses with the wish for death which he has just uttered. The poet of Colonus gives Oedipus a presentiment that his end is not to be as that of other men. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μή_1457"> understand </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="σωθείς_1457">, =<foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ ἐσώθην ἐπὶ κακῷ τῳ</foreign>: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 950">Soph. Aj. 950</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἂν τάδ’ ἔστη τῇδε μὴ θεῶν μέτα,</quote> </cit> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">στάντα</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ ἔστη.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: οὐκ ἂν τάδ’ ἔστη τῇδε μὴ θεῶν μέτα,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προσθῇ_μέριμναν_1460"> <emph> take</emph> care <emph>upon thee</emph>: so often of assuming a <emph> needless</emph> burden: <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.78">Thuc. 1.78</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μὴ … οἰκεῖον πόνον προσθῆσθε</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 1.144">Thuc. 1.144</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κινδύνους αὐθαιρέτους μὴ προστίθεσθαι</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Prot. 346d">Plat. Prot. 346d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχθρας ἑκουσίας … προστίθεσθαι.</quote> </cit> Elmsley's plausible<foreign xml:lang="grc">προθῇ</foreign> (<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1334">Soph. El. 1334</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εὐλάβειαν προὐθέμην)</quote> </cit> would be weaker. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνδρες_1460">, males (though not <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐξηνδρωμένοἰ;</foreign> cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 1062">Soph. Trach. 1062</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θῆλυς οὗσα κοὐκ ἀνδρὸς φύσιν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖν_ἀθλίαιν_1462"> Instead of supplying <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρόσθου μέριμναν,</foreign> it is better to regard </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἷν_1462"> in 1466 as an anacolouthon for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τούτοιν,</foreign> arising from the length of the preceding clause. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Antiph. 5.11-12">Antiph. 5.11-12</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δέον σε διομόσασθαι … ἃ σὺ παρελθών,</quote> </cit> where, after a long parenthetic clause, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἅ</foreign> has been irregularly substituted for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταῦτα.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: δέον σε διομόσασθαι … ἃ σὺ παρελθών,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἷν_1463"> <emph>for whom</emph> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡ_τράπεζα_1463"> <emph>the table at which I ate</emph> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔποτε_ἐστάθη_1463"> <emph>was never placed apart</emph>,</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνευ_ἀνδρός_1463">(so that they should be) <emph>without me</emph>. Instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄνευ αὐταῖν,</foreign> we have <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄνευ τοῦδ’ ἀνδρός,</foreign> because <foreign xml:lang="grc">(οἶν</foreign> being dat. of persons affected) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οἶν οὔποτε ἡ ἐμὴ τράπεζα χωρὶς ἐστάθη ἄνευ τοῦδ’ ἀνδρός</foreign> is equivalent to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὣ οὔποτε τὴν ἐμὴν τράπεζαν χωρὶς σταθεῖσαν εἰδέτην, (ὥστε εἶναἰ ἄνευ τοῦδ’ ἀνδρός.</foreign> This is simpler than to construe: “for whom the dinner-table, which was (always) mine, was never placed apart, or without me ”: when <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡμή</foreign> would be a compressed substitute for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ ἐμὴ ἀεὶ οὖσα</foreign> in the sense of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀλλὰ ἡ ἐμὴ ἀεὶ ἦν.</foreign> We cannot take <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡμὴ βορᾶς τράπεζα</foreign> as merely = “the table which I <emph>provided</emph>”: the emphasis on <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἡμή</foreign> would alone exclude this. Prof. Kennedy understands: “apart from whom <foreign xml:lang="grc">(οἷν χωρίς)</foreign> my dinner-table ne'er was set <emph>without my bidding</emph>,” i.e. never except on special occasions, when I had so directed. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνευ_1463"> could certainly mean this (<ref n="Soph. OC 926">Soph. OC 926</ref> etc.). But can we understand Oedipus as saying, in effect, — “who always dined with me—except, indeed, when I had directed that they should <emph> not</emph>”? —I am much inclined to receive Arndt's </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄλλη_1463"> for </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἡμή_1463"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ΛΛ</foreign> for M), as Wecklein has done. —The attributive gen. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βορᾶς_1463"> is equivalent to an adj. of quality like <foreign xml:lang="grc"> τρόφιμος,</foreign> as <cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 1491">Eur. Phoen. 1491</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">στολὶς τρυφᾶς</quote> </cit> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">στολὶς τρυφερά</foreign>: not like <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἅμαξαι σίτου</foreign> (<ref n="Xen. Cyrop. 2.4.18">Xen. Cyrop. 2.4.18</ref>) “waggon-<emph>loads</emph> of grain. ” </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐστάθη_1463"> because a light table is brought in for the meal, and removed after it (cp. <ref n="Hom. Il. 24.476">Hom. Il. 24.476</ref>,<ref n="Hom. Od. 10.354">Hom. Od. 10.354</ref> etc). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνευ_ἀνδρός_1463_2"> explaining </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="χωρίς_1463">, as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 31">Soph. Phil. 31</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κενὴν οἴκησιν</quote> </cit> is explained by <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀνθρώπων δίχα,</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 464">Soph. Aj. 464</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">γυμνὸν φανέντα</quote> </cit> by <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῶν ἀριστείων ἄτερ.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἄνευ_1463_2"> as in <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 336">Soph. Trach. 336</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μάθῃς ἄνευ τῶνδ’,</quote> </cit> hear <emph>apart from</emph> these. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μέλεσθαι_1466"> infin. for imper.: cp. 462. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μάλιστα_μέν_1466">: see on 926. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἴθ_ὦναξ_1468"> A moment of agitated suspense is marked by the bacchius interrupting the trimeters, as <ref n="Soph. Phil. 749">Soph. Phil. 749 ff.</ref> (in an anxious entreaty, as here) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἴθ’, ὦ παῖ.</foreign> So <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1271">Soph. OC 1271</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί σιγᾷς;</quote> </cit> 318 <foreign xml:lang="grc">τάλαινα.</foreign> The speech of the agonised Heracles is similarly broken by short dactylic or choriambic phrases, <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1081">Soph. Trach. 1081</ref>,<foreign xml:lang="grc">αἶ, αἶ, ὦ τάλας</foreign>: 1085 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὦναξ Ἀΐδη δέξαι μ’, | ὦ Διὸς ἀκτίς, παῖσον.</foreign> But Soph. has used the license most sparingly, and always, it may be said, with fine effect. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γονῇ_γενναῖε_1469"> noble in the grain, —one whose <foreign xml:lang="grc">γενναιότης</foreign> is <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνησία,</foreign> inbred, true, —referring to the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀρετή</foreign> just shown by Creon (1433).<foreign xml:lang="grc">γονῇ</foreign> here is not merely intensive of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γενναῖε_1469">, making it = <foreign xml:lang="grc">γενναιότατε,</foreign> (as the sarcastic <foreign xml:lang="grc">γένει</foreign> seems to be in <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Soph. 231b">Plat. Soph. 231b</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡ γένει γενναία σοφιστική,</quote> </cit> “the most noble. ”) Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 1094">Soph. Aj. 1094</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μηδὲν ὢν γοναῖσιν.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δοκοῖμ_1470"> for this form, cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 895">Soph. Phil. 895</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δρῷμ’</quote> </cit> (n.). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἔχειν_σφας_1470"> .<foreign xml:lang="grc">σφέας</foreign> has the accent in Homer when it is emphatic, as when joined with <foreign xml:lang="grc">αὐτούς,</foreign> being then a disyllable: <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 12.43">Hom. Il. 12.43</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σφέας αὐτούς.</quote> </cit> When non-emphatic and enclitic, it is a monosyllable: <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 4.77">Hom. Od. 4.77</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καί σφεας φωνήσας.</quote> </cit> The perispomenon <foreign xml:lang="grc">σφᾶς</foreign> corresponds to <foreign xml:lang="grc">σφέας,</foreign> as in <foreign xml:lang="grc">σφᾶς αὐτούς</foreign>: the enclitic <foreign xml:lang="grc">σφας</foreign> to <foreign xml:lang="grc">σφεας.</foreign> Thus in <ref n="Soph. OC 486">Soph. OC 486</ref> we must write <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὥς σφας καλοῦμεν</foreign> with Herm.; where Elmsley gave <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς σφᾶς,</foreign> holding (against the grammarians) that this form was never enclitic. Here, as in 1508, the pronoun is non-emphatic. According to the rule now generally received, a <emph> monosyllabic</emph> enclitic stands unaccented after a paroxytone word, the latter remaining unaffected: we therefore write <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔχειν σφας.</foreign> But, according to Arcadius and Herodian, a paroxytone word followed by an enclitic <emph>beginning with</emph> <foreign xml:lang="grc">ς φ</foreign> took the acute on its last syllable, as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔχείν σφας</foreign>: see Chandler, §§965, 966, 2nd ed. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τί_φημί_1471"> the cry of one startled by a sound or sight, as <ref n="Soph. Trach. 865">Soph. Trach. 865</ref>:<cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 315">Soph. OC 315</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί φῶ;</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. PB 561">Aesch. PB 561</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς γῆ; τί γένος; τίνα φῶ λεύσσειν;</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: τίς γῆ; τί γένος; τίνα φῶ λεύσσειν;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῖν_δακρυρροούντοιν_1472"> Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 381">Soph. Ant. 381</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐ δή που ..;</quote> </cit> In participles belonging to the 3rd declens. the masc. form of the dual is often used as fem.; indeed the specially fem. forms, such as <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐχούσα,</foreign> are very rare. See <ref n="Soph. OC">Soph. OC</ref> append. on 1676, p. 293. Similarly <foreign xml:lang="grc">τώ, τοῖν, τούτοιν, οἶν</foreign> were the usual fem. forms: cp. 1462 f., 1504, and <ref n="Soph. Ant. 769">Soph. Ant. 769</ref> n. Thus <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Cyrop. 1.2.11">Xen. Cyrop. 1.2.11</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">μίαν ἄμφω τούτω τὼ ἡμέρα λογίζονται.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Phaedrus 237d">Plat. Phaedrus 237d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἡμῶν ἐν ἐκάστῳ δύο τινέ ἐστον ἰδέα ἄρχοντε καὶ ἄγοντε, οἶν ἑπόμεθα.</quote> </cit> So <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὼ θεώ, τοῖν θεοῖν</foreign> (Demeter and Persephone). </gloss>

data.quote: μίαν ἄμφω τούτω τὼ ἡμέρα λογίζονται.

ἡμῶν ἐν ἐκάστῳ δύο τινέ ἐστον ἰδέα ἄρχοντε καὶ
							ἄγοντε, οἶν ἑπόμεθα.

El. 682">Soph. El. 682</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πρόσχημ’ ἀγῶνος,</quote> </cit> a glory (consisting in) a contest. </gloss>

Crat. 404a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κινδυνεύεις τι λέγειν,</quote> </cit> compared with <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Sym. 205d">Plat. Sym. 205d</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">κινδυνεύεις ἀληθῆ λέγειν.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Kn. 333">Aristoph. Kn. 333</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν δεῖξον ὡς οὐδὲν λέγει τὸ σωφρόνως τραφῆναι,</quote> </cit> “what nonsense it is. ” </gloss>

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γνοὺς_πάλαι_1477"> aware of the delight which you now feel, —as you ever felt it: i.e. taught by the past to foresee that you would thus rejoice. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῆσδε_ὁδοῦ_1478">, causal gen.: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 626">Soph. El. 626</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">θράσους | τοῦδ’ οὐκ ἀλύξεις</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Orest. 1407">Eur. Orest. 1407</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔρροι τᾶς ἁσύχου προνοίας.</quote> </cit> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἢ_μὲ_1479"> is required here, since with <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἤ με</foreign> the stress would fall wholly on </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="φρουρήσας_1479">. On the other hand in 1478 </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καί_σε_1479"> is right, because, after </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εὐτυχοίης_1479">, the <emph>person</emph> does not need to be at once emphasised again. This is not, however, like <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 23.724">Hom. Il. 23.724</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἤ μ’ ἀνάειρ’ ἢ ἐγὼ σέ,</quote> </cit> where <foreign xml:lang="grc">με</foreign> suffices because the sense is, “<emph>slay</emph> or <emph>be slain</emph>.” In <ref n="Soph. El. 383">Soph. El. 383</ref>,<cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 1213">Soph. El. 1213</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">με</quote> </cit> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">σοι</foreign> are justified by the stress on <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὕστερον</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">προσήκει</foreign> respectively. </gloss>

data.quote: ἤ μ’ ἀνάειρ’ ἢ ἐγὼ σέ,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_χέρας_1481"> As the sense is so plainly equivalent to <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς ἐμέ,</foreign> we are scarcely justified in changing </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὡς_1481"> to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰς_1481">(with Elmsley), or </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐς_1481">(with Blaydes). <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 366">Soph. Trach. 366</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δόμους | ὡς τούσδε</quote> </cit> is a slightly stronger case for such a change, yet not a conclusive one. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐς</foreign> is now read for <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὡς</foreign> in <cit> <bibl n="Aristoph. Ach. 242">Aristoph. Ach. 242</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(ὡς τὸ πρόσθεν)</quote> </cit> and in <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 8.36">Thuc. 8.36</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">(ὡς τὴν Μίλητον),</quote> </cit> 103 <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ὡς τὴν Ἄβυδον).</foreign> Soph. has <cit> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς ὑμᾶς</quote> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 366">Soph. Trach. 366</bibl> </cit> . </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αἳ_ὑμὶν_1482"> who <emph>have effected</emph> for you </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τὰ_ὄμματαὧδεὁρᾶν_1482"> that the once bright eyes of your sire should see thus, i.e. should be sightless: cp. his own phrase quoted in 1273 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν σκότῳ τὸ λοιπὸν … ὀψοίατο.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Phil. 862">Soph. Phil. 862</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὡς Ἀΐδᾳ παρακείμενος ὁρᾷ,</quote> </cit> he sees as the dead, i.e. not at all. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Apol. 7">Xen. Apol. 7</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὁ θεὸς δῑ εὐμένειαν προξενεῖ μοι οὐ μόνον τὸ ἐν καιρῷ τῆς ἡλικίας καταλῦσαι τὸν βίον, ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ ᾗ ῥᾷστα,</quote> </cit> the god's kindly offices grant to me that I should close my life etc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">προξενεῖν</foreign> = (1) to be a <foreign xml:lang="grc">πρόξενος</foreign>: then (2) fig., to lend one's good offices: either (a) absol., as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 465">Soph. OC 465</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">προξένει,</quote> </cit> stand my friend: or (b) with dat. and acc., or acc. and infin., to <emph> effect</emph> a thing, or result, for one: <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 6.5.14">Xen. Anab. 6.5.14</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἴστε … με … οὐδένα πω κίνδυνον προξενήσαντα ὑμῖν</quote> </cit>:<cit> <bibl>Plut. Alex. 22</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">αὐτῷ … τοιαῦτα ὀνείδη προξενῶν</quote> </cit> (said of one who panders to vices): <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 726">Soph. Trach. 726</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλπὶς ἥτις καὶ θράσος τι προξενεῖ.</quote> </cit> In particular, <foreign xml:lang="grc">προξενεῖν τινά τινι</foreign> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">συνιστάναι,</foreign> to <emph>introduce</emph> one person to another. So Prof. Kennedy understands here: “which introduced to you your father's once brilliant eyes, that you should thus behold them ” —i.e. presented them to you in this state. But </gloss>

data.quote:
ὁ θεὸς δῑ εὐμένειαν προξενεῖ μοι οὐ μόνον τὸ
							ἐν
									καιρῷ τῆς ἡλικίας καταλῦσαι τὸν βίον, ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ ᾗ ῥᾷστα,

ἴστε … με … οὐδένα πω κίνδυνον
									προξενήσαντα ὑμῖν
ἐλπὶς ἥτις καὶ θράσος τι προξενεῖ.

lemma:
τὰ πρόσθε λαμπρὰ τοῦ φυτ. πατρὸς ὄμματα
							ὧδε
									ὁρᾶν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὦδ_ὁρᾶν_1482"> seems thus to lose its force: and the ordinary usage of <foreign xml:lang="grc">προξενεῖν</foreign> confirms the version given above. The conjecture </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="προυσέλησαν_1482">( “maltreated ”) has found some unmerited favour. Besides <foreign xml:lang="grc">προυσελούμενον</foreign> in <ref n="Aesch. PB 438">Aesch. PB 438</ref>, we find only <foreign xml:lang="grc">προυσελοῦμεν</foreign> in <ref n="Aristoph. Frogs 730">Aristoph. Frogs 730</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὔθ_ἱστορῶν_1484"> i.e. neither <emph>recognising</emph> his mother when he saw her, nor <emph>possessing any information</emph> which could lead him to suspect that she was such. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἱστορεῖν</foreign> is (1) to be, or (2) to become, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἵστωρ,</foreign> a knower: i.e. (1) to have information, or (2) to seek it. Sense (2) is more frequent: but Aesch. has (1) in <ref n="Aesch. Eum. 455">Aesch. Eum. 455</ref> and <ref n="Aesch. Pers. 454">Aesch. Pers. 454</ref>. [In <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 382">Soph. Trach. 382</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲν ἱστορῶν</quote> </cit> prob. = <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅτι οὐδὲν ἱστόρει</foreign> (imperf.), “did not ask. ”] Here (1) is best, because it would be almost absurd to say that he had wedded Iocasta “without asking any questions ”—as if he could have been expected to do so. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 273">Soph. OC 273</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νῦν δ’ οὐδὲν εἰδὼς ἱκόμην ἵν’ ἱκόμην.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote: νῦν δ’ οὐδὲν εἰδὼς ἱκόμην ἵν’ ἱκόμην.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἠρόθην_1485"> cp. 1257, 1210. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμιλίας_ἑορτάς_1489"> The poet is thinking of his own Athens, though the language is general. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὁμιλίας_1489"> comprises all occasions on which Attic women could appear in public, —as at the delivery of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιτάφιοι</foreign> (<ref n="Thuc. 2.45">Thuc. 2.45</ref>):</gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἑορτάς_1489"> suggests such festivals as the Thesmophoria, the Panathenaea, or the Dionysia (when women were present in the theatre, at least at tragedy). To feel the force of this passage, we must remember how closely the Greek festivals were bound up with the life of the <emph>family</emph>. Kinsfolk took part in them together: and at such moments a domestic disgrace, such as that which the sisters inherited, would be most keenly felt. In Athenian law-courts the fact of association at festivals could be cited in evidence of family intimacy: <cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 19.10">Isoc. 19.10</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἕως μὲν γὰρ παῖδες ἦμεν, περὶ πλέονος ἡμᾶς αὐτοὺς ἡγούμεθα ἢ τοὺς ἀδελφούς, καὶ οὔτε θυσίαν οὔτε θεωρίαν</quote> </cit> (public spectacle) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔτ’ ἄλλην ἑορτὴν οὐδεμίαν χωρὶς ἀλλήλων ἤγομεν.</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Isaeus 8.15">Isaeus 8.15</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">καὶ εἰς Διονύσια εἰς ἀγρὸν ἦγεν ἀεὶ ἡμᾶς, καὶ μετ’ ἐκείνου τε ἐθεωροῦμεν</quote> </cit> (in the theatre) <foreign xml:lang="grc">καθήμενοι παρ’ αὐτόν, καὶ τὰς ἑορτὰς ἤγομεν παρ’ ἐκεῖνον πάσας.</foreign> It was the Attic custom for a bridegroom <foreign xml:lang="grc">Θεσμοφόρια ἑστιᾶν τὰς γυναῖκας,</foreign> to provide a banquet at the next Thesmophoria for the women of his deme (<ref n="Isaeus 3.80">Isaeus 3.80</ref>), and also <foreign xml:lang="grc">φράτορσι γαμηλίαν εἰσφέρειν,</foreign> to provide a banquet for his clansmen when his bride was introduced into his <foreign xml:lang="grc">φρατρία</foreign> (<ref n="Isaeus 8.18">Isaeus 8.18</ref>). </gloss>

data.quote:
ἕως μὲν γὰρ παῖδες ἦμεν, περὶ πλέονος ἡμᾶς
							αὐτοὺς
									ἡγούμεθα ἢ τοὺς ἀδελφούς, καὶ οὔτε θυσίαν οὔτε θεωρίαν

καὶ εἰς Διονύσια εἰς ἀγρὸν ἦγεν ἀεὶ ἡμᾶς, καὶ
							μετ’
									ἐκείνου τε ἐθεωροῦμεν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="κεκλαυμέναι_1490"> only poet.: later poets and Plut. have <foreign xml:lang="grc">κέκλαυσμαι</foreign>: the poet. <foreign xml:lang="grc">δεδακρυμένος</foreign> also occurs in later prose, Plut., Lucian, etc. The festivals were religious celebrations, which would be polluted by the presence of persons resting under an inherited <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄγος</foreign> (cp. note on 240). Some word or act reminds the daughters of Oedipus that they are thus regarded, and they go home in tears. Greek sensitiveness to public notice on such occasions might be illustrated by the story in Herodotus of the affront offered to the deposed king Demaratus by his successor Leotychides at the Spartan festival of the <foreign xml:lang="grc"> γυμνοπαιδίαι</foreign> (<ref n="Hdt. 6.67">Hdt. 6.67</ref>). Demaratus drew his robe over his head, and left the theatre: <foreign xml:lang="grc">κατακαλυψάμενος ἤϊε ἐκ τοῦ θεήτρου ἐς τὰ ἑωυτοῦ οἰκία.</foreign> Contrast the effusive public greeting which Electra imagines herself and Chrysothemis as receiving <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔν θ’ ἑορταῖς ἔν τε πανδήμῳ πόλει</foreign> (<ref n="Soph. El. 982">Soph. El. 982</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀντὶ_θεωρίας_1491"> in place of the <emph>sight-seeing</emph> (for which they had looked). <foreign xml:lang="grc">θεωρία</foreign> is (1) subjectively, <emph>a sight-seeing</emph>: (2) objectively, <emph>a spectacle</emph>. In sense (1) the article is added here because a definite occasion is meant; usually, the art. is absent: <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 6.24">Thuc. 6.24</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πόθῳ ὄψεως καὶ θεωρίας</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 556c">Plat. Rep. 556c</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἢ κατὰ θεωρίας ἢ κατὰ στρατείας</quote> </cit> (on <emph>travels</emph> or <emph>campaigns</emph>):<cit> <bibl n="Isoc. 17.4">Isoc. 17.4</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἅμα κατ’ ἐμπορίαν καὶ κατὰ θεωρίαν.</quote> </cit> In <cit> <bibl n="Hdt. 1.30">Hdt. 1.30</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τῆς θεωρίης ἐκδημήσας … εἵνεκεν,</quote> </cit> the art. is added as in <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἡ εἰρήνη</foreign> ( “peace ”) etc., because “seeing the world ” is spoken of generically. </gloss>

data.quote: ἢ κατὰ θεωρίας ἢ κατὰ στρατείας
ἅμα κατ’ ἐμπορίαν καὶ κατὰ θεωρίαν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίς_τίς_1493"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.,</foreign> is more animated for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τίς οὖτος ἔσται, ὅστις.</foreign> <cit> <bibl>Theocr. 16.13</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τίς τῶν νῦν τοιόσδε; τίς εὖ εἰπόντα φιλασεῖ;</quote> </cit> is compared by Jacobs there, and by Schneidewin here, but is not really similar, since <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοιόσδε</foreign> there refers back to v. 5 f., <foreign xml:lang="grc">τίς γάρ … ὑποδέξεται (κ.τ.λ.);</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote:
τίς τῶν νῦν τοιόσδε; τίς εὖ εἰπόντα
									φιλασεῖ;

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λαμβάνων_1494"> instead of the infin. with <foreign xml:lang="grc">παραρρίψει,</foreign> as <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Laws 699a">Plat. Laws 699a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οὐδεὶς τότε ἐβοήθησεν οὐδ’ ἐκινδύνευσε ξυμμαχόμενος.</quote> </cit> </gloss>

data.quote:
οὐδεὶς τότε ἐβοήθησεν οὐδ’ ἐκινδύνευσε
							ξυμμαχόμενος.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γοναῖσιν_1495"> The disgraces of the polluted house will be ruinous not only to the children of Oedipus, but to his children's children (<foreign xml:lang="grc">σφῷν,</foreign> genit., sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc"> γοναῖς</foreign>). I formerly read <foreign xml:lang="grc">γόνοισιν</foreign>: but Kennedy justly objects that the plur. of <foreign xml:lang="grc"> γόνος</foreign> is not used; and his conjecture, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ταῖς ἐμαῖς γοναῖσιν,</foreign> gives more point here. For <foreign xml:lang="grc">γοναί,</foreign> “offspring, ” cp. <ref n="Soph. OC 1192">Soph. OC 1192</ref>,<ref n="Soph. Ant. 641">Soph. Ant. 641</ref>. The </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γονεῦσιν_1495"> of the MSS. yields no tolerable sense, whether it is referred to Laius and Iocasta or to Iocasta alone. <foreign xml:lang="grc">—δήλημα</foreign> is a hurt, bane, mischief, in a physical or material sense: <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Od. 12.286">Hom. Od. 12.286</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἄνεμοι χαλεποί, δηλήματα νηῶν</quote> </cit> :<ref n="HH 3.364">HH Apoll. 364</ref> (of the dead monster) <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐδὲ σύ γε ζώουσα κακὸν δήλημα βροτοῖσιν</foreign>: Aesch. fr. 119 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὁδοιπόρων δήλημα χωρίτης δράκων</foreign> (the serpent in the fields, a bane of wayfarers). The disgraces are </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δηλήματα_1495"> to the sons and daughters as involving their ruin in life: but could not be called <foreign xml:lang="grc">δηλήματα</foreign> to the <emph>dead</emph> in the remote figurative sense of <emph>disgracing their memories</emph>. Nor would there be any fitness in the conjuction of harm <emph>of another kind</emph> to the living. Oedipus here thinks of the living, and of the future, alone. The conject. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="γαμβροῖσιν_1495">, besides being far from the MSS., presumes the event which he regards as impossible. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πατέρα_1496"> for the tribrach see on 719. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τῶν_ἴσων_1498"> is poetically equivalent to <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῶν αὐτῶν,</foreign> i.e. <foreign xml:lang="grc">τῆς αὐτῆς</foreign>: it is like saying, “from a source which was <emph>even as that</emph> whence he sprang,” instead of, “from the <emph>same</emph> source whence he sprang.” Cp. 845 <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ γὰρ γένοιτ’ ἂν εἶς γε τοῖς πολλοῖς ἴσος,</foreign> and note. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀνειδιεῖσθε_1500"> see on 672. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δηλαδή_1501"> prosaic, but also in <ref n="Eur. Orest. 789">Eur. Orest. 789</ref>,<ref n="Eur. IA 1366">Eur. IA 1366</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλ_1503"> after the vocative, like <foreign xml:lang="grc">σὺ δέ,</foreign> but stronger, as introducing an appeal: as <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1405">Soph. OC 1405</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὦ τοῦδ’ ὅμαιμοι παῖδες, ἀλλ’ ὑμεῖς … μή μ’ ἀτιμάσητέ γε</quote> </cit>: and <ref n="Soph. OC 237">Soph. OC 237</ref>. </gloss>

data.quote:
ὦ τοῦδ’ ὅμαιμοι παῖδες, ἀλλ’ ὑμεῖς … μή μ’
							ἀτιμάσητέ γε

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="δύ_ὄντε_1505"> both of us: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Trach. 539">Soph. Trach. 539</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δύ’ οὖσαι μίμνομεν</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Ion 518">Eur. Ion 518</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">σὺ δ’ εὖ φρόνει γε καὶ δύ’ ὄντ’ εὖ πράξομεν</quote> </cit>.<foreign xml:lang="grc">—περιίδῃς</foreign>: on Porson's objection, see Appendix. </gloss>

data.quote:
σὺ δ’ εὖ φρόνει γε καὶ δύ’ ὄντ’ εὖ
									πράξομεν

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐγγενεῖς_1506"> your kinswomen as they are (where in prose we should have <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὔσας</foreign> added). The word was full of meaning for an Attic audience, who would think of Creon as placed by Oedipus in the position of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπίτροπος</foreign> (guardian) and <foreign xml:lang="grc">κύριος</foreign> (representative before the law) of the unmarried girls who are here viewed as orphans (1505); their brothers not being of age. Cp. <ref n="Isaeus 5.10">Isaeus 5.10</ref>;<ref n="Dem. 46.18">Dem. 46.18</ref>. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξισώσῃς_τάσδε_1507"> do not put them on the level of my miseries: cp. 425: for <foreign xml:lang="grc">τάσδε</foreign> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὰ τῶνδε κακά,</foreign> cp. note on 467. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τηλικάσδ_1508"> at their age, i.e. so young: <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Ant. 726">Soph. Ant. 726</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἱ τηλικοίδε</quote> </cit> (so old) <foreign xml:lang="grc">καὶ διδαξόμεσθα δὴ | φρονεῖν πρὸς ἀνδρὸς τηλικοῦδε</foreign> (so young) <foreign xml:lang="grc">τὴν φύσιν;</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="πλὴν_μέρος_1509"> except in so far as, on thy part, <foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐκ ἔρημοι εἰσί.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰχέτην_1511"> 2nd pers. dual, with the form proper to the 3rd <foreign xml:lang="grc">(μετειχέτην,</foreign> 1465). Before the Attic period, the Greek language had attained to this regular distinction of active dual forms: —(1) primary tenses, 2nd pers. <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐τον,</foreign> 3rd pers. <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ‐τον;</foreign> (2) secondary tenses, 2nd pers. <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ‐τον,</foreign> answering to Skt. <emph>tam</emph>: 3rd pers. <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐την,</foreign> Skt. <emph>tām</emph>. As regards (2), two classes of exceptions occur: (a) Homeric 3rd pers. in <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐τον</foreign> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ‐την;</foreign> three instances, <foreign xml:lang="grc">διώκετον</foreign> (<ref n="Hom. Il. 10.364">Hom. Il. 10.364</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἐτεύχετον</foreign> (<ref n="Hom. Il. 13.346">Hom. Il. 13.346</ref>),<foreign xml:lang="grc">λαφύσσετον</foreign> (<ref n="Hom. Il. 18.583">Hom. Il. 18.583</ref>). These Curtius refers to “the want of proper linguistic instinct on the part of some late rhapsodist. ” (b) Attic 2nd pers. in <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐την</foreign> instead of <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐τον.</foreign> Our </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εἰχέτην_1511_2"> here is the only instance proved by metre: but 8 others are established. Against these fall to be set at least 13 Attic instances of the normal <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐τον.</foreign> Curtius regards the 2nd pers. in <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐την</foreign> as due to a false analogy. In the <emph> third</emph> person dual <foreign xml:lang="grc">‐την</foreign> was distinctive of the secondary tenses. Attic speech sometimes extended this distinction to the <emph>second</emph> person also. (<ref>Curt. Verb 1.80</ref>, Eng. tr. 53.) Cp n. on <ref n="Soph. OC 1378">Soph. OC 1378 ff.</ref> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦτ_μοι_1512">, “make this prayer, as I bid you ” (not, “pray on my account, ” in which sense Wunder reads <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐμοἴ</foreign>: the ethic dat. <foreign xml:lang="grc">μοι</foreign> in request, as <ref n="Soph. OC 1475">Soph. OC 1475</ref>. In these words Oedipus is thinking solely of his children: he has now passed away from the thought of self (1458). </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὑμᾶς_1512"> in 1514 is no argument for understanding <foreign xml:lang="grc">με</foreign> as subject to </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ζην_1512">: rather it is added to mark the contrast with<foreign xml:lang="grc"> πατρός.</foreign> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὗ_βίου_1513"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> on these grounds. 1. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοῦ_1513"> before </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="βίου_1513">, though not required, is commended, by Greek idiom; it also gives a decidedly better rhythm; and it is not likely to have crept into the text, since the occurrence of <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀεί</foreign> with the <foreign xml:lang="grc">α</foreign> long was not so uncommon that it should have suggested the need of supplementing the metre by <foreign xml:lang="grc">τοῦ</foreign>: but, apart from metrical motive, there was no other for <emph>intruding</emph> the article. 2. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὗ_καιρός_1513">, without any verb, though a possible phrase, is a harsh one. 3. From </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="εαι_1513"> to </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="αει_1513"> would be an easy transition. And<foreign xml:lang="grc">καιρὸς ἐᾷ</foreign> is quite a natural expression: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Eur. IA 858">Eur. IA 858</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">δοῦλος· οὐχ ἁβρύνομαι τῷδ’· ἡ τύχη γὰρ οὐκ ἐᾷ.</quote> </cit> The foreboding of Oedipus is that his daughters must become homeless exiles (1506) unless Creon shelters them at Thebes. “To live <emph>where occasion allows</emph>” means in his inner thought, “to live at Thebes, if that may be—if not, in the least unhappy exile that the gods may grant you. ” The monosyllabic <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔα</foreign> (1451, <ref n="Soph. Ant. 95">Soph. Ant. 95</ref>) and <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἐᾷ</foreign> (<cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 5.256">Hom. Il. 5.256</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τρεῖν μ’ οὐκ ἐᾷ Παλλὰς Ἀθήνἠ</quote> </cit> go far to remove the metrical objection. Meineke's conjecture, <foreign xml:lang="grc">ᾖ</foreign>, gives a more prosaic phrase, and is too far from the <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀεί</foreign> of the MSS. </gloss>

data.quote:
δοῦλος· οὐχ ἁβρύνομαι τῷδ’· ἡ τύχη γὰρ οὐκ
									ἐᾷ.
τρεῖν μ’ οὐκ ἐᾷ Παλλὰς Ἀθήνἠ

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐξήκεις_1515"> see on 1357. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καιρῷ_1516"> =<foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν καιρῷ.</foreign> In <ref n="Thuc. 4.59">Thuc. 4.59</ref> most MSS. give <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἰ μὴ καιρῷ τύχοιεν ἑκάτεροι πράσσοντες</foreign>: Classen reads <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐν καιρῷ</foreign> on the ground that Thuc. so has it in <ref n="Thuc. 1.121">Thuc. 1.121</ref>,<ref n="Thuc. 5.61">Thuc. 5.61</ref>,<ref n="Thuc. 6.9">Thuc. 6.9</ref>. </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οἶσθ_οὖν_1517"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">εἶμι;</foreign> were said with some return of his former agitation: </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="λέξεις_1517"> <foreign xml:lang="grc">κ.τ.λ.</foreign> is said by Creon with calm, grave courtesy; they have nothing in them of such irony as, “I shall know when you are pleased to tell me.” So <ref n="Aesch. Seven 260">Aesch. Seven 260</ref> ET. <foreign xml:lang="grc">αἰτουμένῳ μοι κοῦφον εἰ δοίης τέλος</foreign>: “would that thou couldst grant me a light boon.” XO. <foreign xml:lang="grc">λέγοις ἂν ὡς τάχιστα, καὶ τάχ’ εἴσομαι</foreign> (i.e. and then I shall know if I can serve thee). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὅπως_πέμψεις_1518"> sc. <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅρα</foreign>:<cit> <bibl n="Xen. Anab. 1.7.3">Xen. Anab. 1.7.3</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως οὖν ἔσεσθε ἄνδρες,</quote> </cit> “see that ye be”: <cit> <bibl n="Plat. Rep. 337a">Plat. Rep. 337a</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὅπως μοι, ὦ ἄνθρωπε, μὴ ἐρεῖς.</quote> </cit> Not <foreign xml:lang="grc">(εἶμι ἐπὶ τούτοις), ὅπως κ.τ.λ.</foreign> </gloss>

data.quote: ὅπως μοι, ὦ ἄνθρωπε, μὴ ἐρεῖς.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἀλλὰ_γ_1519"> i.e. “Nay, the <emph>gods</emph>, who hate me, will not be displeased that I should be thrust forth.” For the synizesis in </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="θεοῖς_1519"> cp. 215. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἤκω_1519"> cp. 1357, <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1177">Soph. OC 1177</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἔχθιστον ἥκει,</quote> </cit> has come to be most hateful. Creon's reply, </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τοιγαροῦν_τάχα_1519">, means: “if the gods <emph>do</emph> desire thy banishment, thou wilt soon have thy wish”—when the oracle at Delphi is consulted (1443). According to the story which Soph. follows, Oedipus was at first detained at Thebes against his own wish. But when some time had elapsed, and that wish had given place to a calmer mood, the Thebans, in their turn, demanded his expulsion; and Creon then yielded (<ref n="Soph. OC 433">Soph. OC 433 ff.</ref>). </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἃ_φρονῶ_1520"> In <ref n="Soph. OC 765">Soph. OC 765 ff.</ref>) Creon is represented as opposing a distinct refusal to this prayer of Oedipus. His words here could mean: “No, I do not promise, for I am not wont to speak vain words when I lack knowledge” <foreign xml:lang="grc">(φρονῶ</foreign> as in 569): i.e., “I cannot tell how Apollo may decide.” But I now think that, on the whole, it suits the context better to take them as expressing consent <foreign xml:lang="grc">(ἃ μὴ φρονῶ</foreign> = what I do not mean to do). As this consent can be only provisional—depending on the approval of Apollo—it is not necessarily inconsistent with <ref n="Soph. OC 765">Soph. OC 765 ff.</ref> </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἕλῃ_μου_1522">: cp. 1022 <foreign xml:lang="grc">χειρῶν λαβών.</foreign> </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ᾔδει_αἰνίγματα_1525"> (plur. with reference to the hexameter <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔπη</foreign> in which it was chanted) = knew <emph>instinctively</emph>, by the intuition of genius: in <ref n="Eur. Phoen. 1759">Eur. Phoen. 1759</ref> the adapter of this verse has altered <foreign xml:lang="grc">ᾔδει</foreign> (perhaps by a slip of memory) to the more natural but less forcible <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔγνω,</foreign> “read aright,” solved. </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="οὖ_ἐπέβλ_1526"> “on whose fortunes what citizen did not look with emulous admiration?” (Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Xen. Hiero 1.10">Xen. Hiero 1.10</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">πῶς δὲ πάντες ἐζήλουν ἂν τοὺς τυράννους;</quote> </cit>) To me it appears certain that we should here read the interrogative </gloss>

data.quote: πῶς δὲ πάντες ἐζήλουν ἂν τοὺς τυράννους;

lemma: οὖ τίς οὐ ζήλῳ … ταῖς τύχαις ἐπέβλ.,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="τίς_1526">, with </gloss>
<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπέβλεπεν_1526"> instead of </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπιβλέπων_1526">. Cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. OC 1133">Soph. OC 1133</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ᾦ τίς οὐκ ἔνι | κηλὶς κακῶν ξύνοικος;</quote> </cit> 871 <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὅπου τίς ὄρνις οὐχὶ κλαγγάνει;</foreign> <cit> <bibl n="Soph. El. 169">Soph. El. 169 ff.</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τί … οὐκ … | … ἀγγελίας</quote> </cit> :<cit> <bibl n="Eur. Phoen. 878">Eur. Phoen. 878</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἁγὼ τί δρκων οὐ, ποῖα δ’ οὐ λέγων ἔπη, | εἰς ἔχθος ἦλθον.</quote> </cit> <cit> <bibl n="Dem. 18.48">Dem. 18.48</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ἐλαυνομένων καὶ ὑβριζομένων καὶ τί κακὸν οὐχὶ πασχόντων πᾶσα ἡ οἰκουμένη μεστὴ γέγονεν.</quote> </cit> Then the </gloss>

data.quote: ᾦ τίς οὐκ ἔνι | κηλὶς κακῶν ξύνοικος;

ἁγὼ τί δρκων οὐ, ποῖα δ’ οὐ λέγων ἔπη, | εἰς
							ἔχθος
									ἦλθον.

ἐλαυνομένων καὶ ὑβριζομένων καὶ τί κακὸν οὐχὶ
							πασχόντων πᾶσα ἡ οἰκουμένη μεστὴ γέγονεν.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="καί_1526"> of the MSS. should probably be </gloss>

<gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ταῖς_1526">: though it is possible (as Whitelaw proposes) to take <foreign xml:lang="grc">ζήλῳ καὶ τύχαις</foreign> as “his glory and his fortunes”: cp. <cit> <bibl n="Soph. Aj. 503">Soph. Aj. 503</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">οἵας λατρείας ἀνθ’ ὅσου ζήλου τρέφει.</quote> </cit> I doubt, however, whether <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπέβλεπεν,</foreign> without <foreign xml:lang="grc">ζήλῳ,</foreign> could mean “admired.” On the usage of the verb <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπιβλέπω,</foreign> see Appendix. </gloss>

data.quote: οἵας λατρείας ἀνθ’ ὅσου ζήλου τρέφει.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ἐπισκοποῦντα_1529"> is peculiar. I take the exact sense to be: —“<emph>fixing one's eye on</emph> the final day (as on a point towards which one is moving), <emph>that one should see it</emph>,” i.e. “until one shall have had experience of it.” Thus <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἐπισκοπεῖν</foreign> is used in a sense closely akin to its common sense of “attentively considering” a thing: and the whole phrase is virtually equivalent to, “<emph>waiting meditatively to see</emph> the final day.” For the added infin., cp. <cit> <bibl n="Thuc. 3.2">Thuc. 3.2</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">νεῶν ποίησιν ἐπέμενον τελεσθῆναι, καὶ ὅσα ἐκ τοῦ Πόντου ἔδει ἀφικέσθαι.</quote> </cit> Cp. <ref>Plin. NH 7.132</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat"> <emph>alius de alio iudicat dies</emph>, et tamen supremus de omnibus, <emph>ideoque nullis credendum est</emph>. </foreign> Hartung proposed to replace <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰδεῖν</foreign> by <foreign xml:lang="grc">γε δεῖ</foreign> (where <foreign xml:lang="grc">γε</foreign> would be intolerable); Stanley by <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἔδει</foreign>, Seyffert by <foreign xml:lang="grc">δέον</foreign>, and Nauck by <foreign xml:lang="grc">χρεών</foreign>. Kennedy, keeping <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἰδεῖν,</foreign> changes <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἐκείνην</foreign> into <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἄμεινον.</foreign> But the infin. </gloss>

data.quote:
νεῶν ποίησιν ἐπέμενον τελεσθῆναι, καὶ ὅσα ἐκ
							τοῦ
									Πόντου ἔδει ἀφικέσθαι.

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="ὀλβίζειν_1529"> as a “sententious” imperative (see on 462) is appropriate in this <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνώμη.</foreign> The accus. <foreign xml:lang="grc">(θνητὸν ὄντ’, ἐπισκοποῦντἀ</foreign> stands with the infin. when, as here, the infin. represents an imperat. of the <emph> third</emph> person; cp. <cit> <bibl n="Hom. Il. 3.284">Hom. Il. 3.284</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">εἰ δέ κ’ Ἀλέξανδρον κτείνῃ ξανθὸς Μενέλαος, | Τρῶας ἔπειθ’ Ἑλένην καὶ κτήματα πάντ’ ἀποδοῦναι,</quote> </cit> with Leaf's note: and Madvig <title>Gr.</title> sect. 546. When the infin. = an imperat. of the <emph>second</emph> pers., the case is regularly the nom. (<ref n="Hom. Od. 11.441">Hom. Od. 11.441</ref>), rarely the acc. (<ref n="Hes. WD 389">Hes. WD 389</ref>). The view that <foreign xml:lang="grc">ὀλβίζειν</foreign> depends on <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὥστε</foreign> requires a shorter pause at <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ἐλήλυθεν,</foreign> and thus weakens the effect of v. 1527. </gloss>

data.quote:
εἰ δέ κ’ Ἀλέξανδρον κτείνῃ ξανθὸς Μενέλαος, |
							Τρῶας ἔπειθ’ Ἑλένην καὶ κτήματα πάντ’ ἀποδοῦναι,

content: <gloss xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="μηδέν_ὀλβίζειν_1529"> .<ref n="Eur. Andr. 100">Eur. Andr. 100 ff.</ref> partly reproduces the language of this passage: <foreign xml:lang="grc">χρὴ δ’ οὔποτ’ εἰπεῖν οὐδέν’ ὄλβιον βροτῶν, | πρὶν ἂν θανόντος τὴν τελευταίαν ἴδῃς | ὅπως περάσας ἡμέραν ἥξει κάτω.</foreign> He has the thought also in <ref n="Eur. Tro. 510">Eur. Tro. 510</ref>,<ref n="Eur. Her. 866">Eur. Her. 866</ref>,<ref n="Eur. IA 161">Eur. IA 161</ref>, as Soph. in <ref n="Soph. Trach. 1">Soph. Tr. 1</ref> and fr. 588. The maxim, “Call no man happy before death,” first appears in Greek literature as a set <foreign xml:lang="grc">γνώμη</foreign> in <cit> <bibl n="Aesch. Ag. 928">Aesch. Ag. 928</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">ὀλβίσαι δὲ χρὴ | βίον τελευτήσαντ’ ἐν εὐεστοῖ φίλῃ</quote> </cit>: but Aristotle recognises the popular tradition which ascribed it to Solon. In <ref n="Hdt. 1.32">Hdt. 1.32</ref> Solon says that a man may be called <foreign xml:lang="grc"> εὐτυχής</foreign> <emph>in</emph> life, but <foreign xml:lang="grc"> ὄλβιος</foreign> only <emph>after</emph> a life exempt from reverse. Cp. <ref>Iuv. 10.274 ff.</ref> <foreign xml:lang="lat">Et Croesum, quem vox iusti facunda Solonis Respicere ad longae iussit spatia ultima vitae,</foreign> where Mayor refers to the proverbs <foreign xml:lang="grc">Λυδὸς</foreign> (Croesus) <foreign xml:lang="grc">ἀποθνήσκει σοφὸς ἀνήρ,</foreign> and <foreign xml:lang="grc">τέλος ὅρα βίου</foreign> (Parmoemiogr. 11. 187, I. 315 n.), and to notices of the saying in Cic. (<title>De Fin.</title> 2.87, 3.76), Diog. Laert. (<cit> <bibl>Diog. Laert. 1.50</bibl> <quote xml:lang="grc">τά θρυλούμενα</quote> </cit>), Ovid (<ref n="Ov. Met. 3.135">Ovid Met. 3.135</ref>), Seneca (<title>De Tranq. An.</title> 11.12), Josephus (<title>Bell. Iud.</title> 1.5.11=29.3), Arrian (7 sect. 16.7), Lucian (<title> Charon</title> 10): cp. Ecclus. 11. 28. Does Solon mean, Aristotle asks, (1) that a man <emph>is</emph> happy when he is dead? Or (2) that, after death, he <emph>may be said to have been</emph> happy? If (1), Arist. declines to allow that the dead are positively happy; and popular opinion, he says, denies that they are always negatively so, i.e. free from unhapppiness. If (2), then is it not absurd that at the time when he <emph>is</emph>happy we are not to call him so? The fallacy, he concludes, consists in treating “happiness” as dependant on bright <emph> fortunes</emph>:<foreign xml:lang="grc">οὐ γάρ ἐν ταύταις τὸ εὖ ἢ κακῶς ἀλλὰ προσδεῖται τούτων ὁ ἀνθρωπος βίος, καθάπερ εἴπαμεν, κύριαι δ’ εἰσὶν αἱ κατ’ ἀρετὴν ἐνέργειαι τῆς εὐδαιμονιας, αἱ δ’ ἐναντίαι τοῦ ἐναντίου.</foreign> (<ref n="Aristot. Nic. Eth. 1101a">Aristot. Nic. Eth. 1.11</ref>) </gloss>

data.quote:
ὀλβίσαι δὲ χρὴ | βίον τελευτήσαντ’ ἐν εὐεστοῖ
							φίλῃ
